OLSEN--Jean Rohrbach, 83, of 17 Cobble Road died Monday afternoon April 27, 2009 at Noble Horizons in Salisbury. Jean was born December 16, 1925 in Orange, NJ, daughter of the late John and Elsie (Alpaugh) Rohrbach. She was the wife of the late A. William Olsen, Headmaster of Hotchkiss from 1960-1980. Passionate about politics, books, and women's and children's rights, Jean leaves behind a legacy of caring for others. Her passion about women's rights led her to be a vocal advocate for co-education in the 1970s, and she played a large role in Hotchkiss School's successful leap to co-education in 1976. While at Hotchkiss she served as the faculty advisor to the social committee, was instrumental in getting dance as a course into the curriculum and taught women's literature. She was a vocal and committed advocate for the girls and women on the campus. In keeping with her commitment to serving others, she was a member of the boards of the Connecticut Child Welfare Association, Inc, Child and Family Services, Inc, Planned Parenthood, the Housatonic Mental Health Center, EXTRAS, and the Scoville Memorial Library. She was a member of the New York City Cosmopolitan Club where she served as chair of the Membership Committee and on the Club's Board of Governors. Jean was appointed by Governor Ella Grasso to serve on the State Board of Higher Education from 1977 to 1983. She gave of her time and passion to each of these organizations. A graduate of Emma Willard School, Troy, NY in 1943 where she was the recipient of the EW Award, The highest award the school conferred for distinguished citizenship through positive contribution in character, personality, and leadership. She was a trustee of the school. Voted by her peers at Emma Willard for her Best Laugh, Easiest to talk to, Best Orator, and Most Likely to succeed. She maintained these qualities throughout her adult life. Jean was also a graduate of Smith College, 1947. Jean is survived by her daughter, Elizabeth Olsen Waters of Andover, MA, her devoted brother, John Rohrbach of Bloomfield, CT, and her three beloved grandchildren, William, James, and Jessica all of Andover, MA. A Memorial Service will be Saturday May 9, 2009 at 11am in the Salisbury Congregational Church Main St. Salisbury, CT. Jean's life centered around caring for others whether it was working hard for the rights of others or just carrying on conversation with people to make them feel special. Donations in memory of Jean Olsen may be sent to Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation, 271 Main St., Great Barrington, MA 01230 or Noble Horizons, 17 Cobble Road, Salisbury, CT 06068

TAMLYN--Thomas T.,M.D., cardiologist and professional choir singer, died on April 26, 2009, at age 85. He graduated from Columbia College and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, served in the U.S. Public Health Service in Europe, and later was an attending physician at Roosevelt and St. Luke's hospitals. In 1969 he served on the teaching hospital ship S.S. Hope in Tunisia. For seventy-five years he was a singer and soloist in numerous choirs and choral groups, including the Columbia Chapel Choir, Calvary Church, the Canterbury Choral Society, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, and Central Presbyterian Church. Glen David Andrews was at center stage, tall and highly reflective in shades, white pants and a T-shirt almost completely encrusted in sequins. He was singing with a huge, swooping voice and whipping up crowd participation. To his left were two tambourine-equipped backup singers, also in white. To his right was half a brass band — trombone, sousaphone, two trumpets — and a gospel band, with piano and organ, all oom-pahing a second-line beat behind the songs Andrews was belting with preacherly passion.

Esperanza Spalding, who can play virtuosic jazz bass and improvise vocals, in unison or counterpoint, at the same time, unveiled the best audience-participation shtick I expect to see in some time. As her band played a modal vamp, she sweetly requested, “Will you sing with me? Please?” Then she divided the audience into three groups and proceeded to unveil prospective parts: quick scat syllables in arpeggiated lines that went on, and on, and on. “You got it, right?” she said. Much later, after breezing through a complex composition with a Latin lilt and a lot more blithe scat-singing, she called for that singalong, getting the expected silence and laughter. But instead of leaving the audience feeling inadequate, she offered a part that was brief enough to remember — but which might have sounded too tricky earlier. The singalong was instant and spirited — and so was the standing ovation that followed her set.

NEW ORLEANS — O.K., Saturday’s Jazzfest lineup was not exactly my all-time favorite, not with Bon Jovi — which is from a place somewhere outside New Orleans called New Jersey — as the top headliner. It’s a long way from Jazzfest’s origins as an event devoted entirely to music from Louisiana. At the first one, in 1970, the only band from outside Louisiana was the Duke Ellington Orchestra, which the festival commissioned to write his “New Orleans Suite.”

Re "Telling the Brutal Truth" (April 26): As a former Army interrogator (1986-97) and the author of "The Statement on Interrogation Practices" submitted to the members of the Committees on the Armed Forces in July 2006, I am quite interested in this topic.As a former interrogator and SERE trainer, I fully support the switch from "harsh" to "brutal" in describing the so-called enhanced interrogation techniques. I also supported the migration from "simulated drowning" to "near drowning" when describing waterboarding.But I would like to suggest that even "near drowning" doesn't really describe the reason why waterboarding is torture. I offer for your consideration the following short description of why waterboarding is undeniably torture:It's not the physical discomfort of being strapped down and having water pour on you that makes waterboarding torture. It's not the "simulation" of drowning that makes waterboarding torture. It's the threat of imminent death - that's what makes waterboarding torture.Can you put a noose around someone's neck and threaten to kick the chair out from under him if he doesn't answer your questions? No, that's torture.Can you attach electrodes to a person and threaten to electrocute him if he doesn't answer your questions? No, that's torture.Can you hold a gun to someone's head and threaten to blow his brains out if he doesn't answer your questions? No, that's torture.Can you strap someone to a board and threaten to drown him if he doesn't answer your questions? No, that's torture.Can you explain why our elected and appointed officials cannot understand this?Peter BauerSouth Bend, Ind., April 26, 2009

Early in last night's opening game of the Red Wings-Ducks conference semifinal series, Anaheim's Mike Brown became the most recent perpetrator and Detroit's Jiri Hudler the most recent victim in the N.H.L.'s current plague of hits to the head. The league's response to this will be interesting, especially in light of the Caps' Donald Brashear's injuring head shot on Rangers Blair Betts, for which he received a five-game ban. Here's the evidence:

Sid Gustafson, D.V.M., is a novelist and equine veterinarian specializing in thoroughbred sportsmedicine and equine behavior. He currently practices regulatory veterinary medicine, representing the safety and welfare of thoroughbred racehorses.

When Dexter Fowler of the Colorado Rockies stole five bases in a single game last Monday against the Padres, he joined an elite group of players to accomplish the feat, which had been done 22 times. The record for a single game, seven, is shared by George Gore and Billy Hamilton, both of whom did it before 1900.

Because of an editing error, a Spare Times entry on Friday about the Translation Slam poetry reading on Friday night at the Bowery Poetry Club in the East Village, part of the PEN World Voices Festival, misidentified the man shown in the photograph on the left. He is Nick Laird, a writer who was scheduled to read — not Michael F. Moore, the moderator of the event and chairman of the PEN translation committee.

A theater review on Friday about “Waiting for Godot,” at Studio 54 in Manhattan, misstated the Broadway history of John Goodman, who plays Pozzo. He appeared on Broadway in “Big River” in the 1980s; he is not making his Broadway debut in “Waiting for Godot.”.

The Mystery Writers of America gave “Blue Heaven” (St. Martin’s Minotaur) by C. J. Box its Edgar Award for best novel, the writers’ organization said on its Web site, theEdgars.com. Other winners included “The Foreigner” (Picador) by Francie Lin for best first novel by an American author; “China Lake” (New American Library — Obsidian Mysteries) by Meg Gardiner for best paperback original; “American Lightning: Terror, Mystery, the Birth of Hollywood, and the Crime of the Century” (Crown Publishers) by Howard Blum for best nonfiction crime book; and “In Bruges,” by Martin McDonagh, for best screenplay.

On the heels of the tenor Rolando Villazón’s announcement that he would withdraw from performing until at least the end of the year to undergo surgery on his vocal cords, the Los Angeles Opera said it had cast Giuseppe Filianoti, right, to replace Mr. Villazón in its season-opening production of Donizetti’s “Elisir d’Amore.” In a news release the opera said Mr. Filianoti would sing the role of Nemorino in the production, which is scheduled to run from Sept. 12 through Sept. 30. On Wednesday Mr. Villazón’s managers said he needed surgery as soon as possible to remove a cyst from his vocal cords. A coming run of “Les Contes d’Hoffmann” by Offenbach, scheduled to start at the Metropolitan Opera in December, was among the productions affected; the Met has not yet named a replacement for Mr. Villazón.

An act of violence committed years ago by Gregory Burke, the author of the Iraq war play “Black Watch,” right, has compelled him to refuse an honor he was to be presented by his former university, BBC News reported. Mr. Burke was scheduled to receive an honorary degree this November from the University of Stirling in Scotland, where he studied politics. But he has declined the degree after protests from the family of Mark Campbell, a fellow student whom Mr. Burke assaulted at the university about 20 years ago. After the assault, Mr. Burke was banned from the campus, and he eventually dropped out of the university. In a letter to Mr. Campbell, Christine Hallett, the university’s principal, wrote: “Mr. Burke has advised the university that he wishes to decline the offer of award of honorary degree. He explains that he does not wish to embarrass anyone at the university or to make any member of the alumni feel uncomfortable,” according to the BBC.

The Dallas Symphony Orchestra said it was postponing a tour of Europe planned for early next year, citing the downturn in the economy. The orchestra said it would put off until 2012 a nine-city European tour that was scheduled to run from Feb. 27, 2010, through March 11, 2010. It said that ticket sales for its 2008-9 season had been strong, but that its endowment and donations had suffered as the economy had declined. “The responsible thing to do is to postpone the tour,” Douglas Adams, the orchestra’s president, said in a statement. The orchestra said it still planned to perform at Carnegie Hall in May 2011, for its first performances there under its musical director, Jaap van Zweden.

Audiences on the West Coast will soon be able to have their senses overstimulated by the Wooster Group’s trippy production of “La Didone.” This New York troupe will begin a partnership with Redcat, the Roy and Edna Disney/CalArts Theater in Los Angeles, the Wooster Group said on Friday. Cynthia Hedstrom, the troupe’s producer, said in an interview that the collaboration would bring several Wooster Group productions to Redcat for residencies of one to two weeks over the next three to five years. The partnership was reported on the Web site of The Los Angeles Times, latimes.com. Ms. Hedstrom said that “La Didone,” the Wooster Group’s cross-pollination of a 1641 opera and a 1965 horror film, “Planet of the Vampires,” would play at Redcat from June 11 through 21, and that a production of Tennessee Williams’s “Vieux Carré” is scheduled there for February.

Masked gunmen stole two paintings from a Dutch museum on Friday, including a work by Salvador Dalí, officials said, The Associated Press reported. The police said several robbers had threatened a guard at the Scheringa Museum for Realism in Spanbroek with a gun before making off with two paintings. No one was injured, they said. The robbers took “Adolescence,” a 1941 gouache by Dalí, and “La Muscienne,” an oil painting from 1929 by the Polish-born Art Deco painter Tamara de Lempicka, the museum said in a statement. The paintings’ value was not released, but museum officials said they were among the top works in its collection. The Dalí painting is 18 by 12 inches, and the de Lempicka work is 46 by 29 inches. “We deeply regret the theft and hope the works are traced soon,” said a statement from the museum, which is 30 miles north of Amsterdam. The Dalí painting shows a landscape in which a woman’s face can be seen: her lips and nose are formed by the back of a seated woman, and her eyes are part of two hills in the background. The de Lempicka shows a woman in a vivid blue dress playing a mandolinlike instrument.

CBS and ABC can each claim a victory in Thursday night’s ratings. Nielsen’s estimates indicate that CBS earned the most viewers during every hour of prime time, with “Survivor” at 8 (11.7 million), “CSI” at 9 (15.3 million) and “Harper’s Island” at 10 (10.3 million). ABC averaged the night’s highest ratings in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, largely because of “Grey’s Anatomy” (13.9 million) and the season finale of “Private Practice” (9.8 million). Fox ranked third for the night with “Bones” (8.8 million) and “Hell’s Kitchen” (7 million). NBC was fourth over all, including its new shows “Parks and Recreation” (5.3 million) and “Southland” (6.7 million).

First swine flu took its toll on the film industry, delaying premieres in Mexico. Now outbreaks of the disease have forced the cancellation of several concerts in the United States and Mexico. The rapper Young Jeezy, right, canceled a performance at the University of Delaware on Thursday night because of reports of flu at that campus, The News Journal of Wilmington reported. Also Billboard reported that the band Los Lobos was one of several groups forced to cancel shows in Mexico City when the Mexican government banned public events there, adding that Metallica was still scheduled to perform there, and that the Jonas Brothers were still scheduled to perform in Monterrey, Mexico. On his MySpace page, the Japanese rapper Cornelius said his coming tour of North America had been canceled because of travel restrictions amid concerns about the flu.

GORDON--A. H.,101, passed away peacefully surrounded by his family at his home in New York City. Born on July 21, 1901, beloved husband of the late Polly Rousmaniere. Mr. Gordon is survived by his five children, 12 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Friends may call on Tuesday, May 5th at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. from 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm. The private interment for the immediate family will be held at Fishers Island. A memorial service to commemorate Mr. Albert Gordon's extraordinary life and exemplary character will take place on Thursday, May 28th at 10:30am at St. Ignatius Loyola Church located at 980 Park Avenue, New York to be followed by a reception at the New York Racquet Club at 370 Park Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to his memory may be made to the New York Road Runners Club.

YERMAN--Elliott, 92, on April 30. Devoted husband of the late Sybil Berg, loving father of Leslie, Douglas and Marcia. Role model and beloved grandfather of Philip Samuel Dubow. Major in WWII, recipient of the Bronze Star. President of Perfect Finishing Co., he embodied the values of the Greatest Generation. Service Sunday, May 3, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions Elliott Yerman Social Justice Scholarship (www.bhu.edu).

Health authorities and drug companies say that supplies are generally ample for the two drugs that would be vital to treating a pandemic caused by swine flu, but that they are acting to prevent hoarding. Some pharmacies in the United States and some other countries have run out of the drugs, in part because of strong demand from consumers who are not sick but want to have them -- just in case.

Audiences on the West Coast will soon be able to have their senses overstimulated by the Wooster Group's trippy production of ''La Didone.'' This New York troupe will begin a partnership with Redcat, the Roy and Edna Disney/CalArts Theater in Los Angeles, the Wooster Group said on Friday. Cynthia Hedstrom, the troupe's producer, said in an interview that the collaboration would bring several Wooster Group productions to Redcat for residencies of one to two weeks over the next three to five years. The partnership was reported on the Web site of The Los Angeles Times, latimes.com. Ms. Hedstrom said that ''La Didone,'' the Wooster Group's cross-pollination of a 1641 opera and a 1965 horror film, ''Planet of the Vampires,'' would play at Redcat from June 11 through 21, and that a production of Tennessee Williams's ''Vieux Carré'' is scheduled there for February.

HAMBRO--Richard A. The members of The Brook are saddened by the death of our long serving Governor and Chairman of the United Kingdom Committee and extend our deepest condolences to his wife Mary and their family. The Board of Governors of The Brook
A worker sorted through onions at a fruit and vegetable market in Karachi, a southern Pakistani city, on Friday. The city recently faced raging ethnic gang warfare.

Citigroup said on Friday that it would sell its Japanese brokerage and investment banking units for $5.56 billion, securing much-needed capital before results expected next week from a government ''stress test'' of its financial health. Citigroup, the recipient of about $45 billion in bailout money, will sell its Japanese securities arm and parts of its investment banking business to Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group.

Dr. Scott Dowell was sorting through e-mail messages on April 20 at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta when he decided to cruise through that day's outbreak reports from the agency's Global Disease Detection center. The agency receives scores of such reports every day, and a team of analysts sorts through them looking for patterns. But Dr. Dowell, the director of the C.D.C.'s division of global disease detection and emergency response, said he liked to puzzle over them himself on occasion. And that day, reports from Mexico caught his attention.

The writer Carol Ann Duffy was appointed Britain's poet laureate on Friday, becoming the first woman to take a 341-year-old job that has been held by, among others, Dryden, Tennyson, Wordsworth, Cecil Day-Lewis and Ted Hughes. Ms. Duffy, 53, is known for using a deceptively simple style to produce accessible, often mischievous poems dealing with the darkest turmoil and the lightest minutiae of everyday life. In her most popular collection, ''The World's Wife'' (1999), overlooked women in history and mythology get the chance to tell their side of the story, so that one poem imagines, for instance, the relief that Mrs. Rip Van Winkle must have felt when her husband fell asleep, finally giving her some time for herself.

As American confidence in the Pakistani government wanes, the Obama administration is reaching out more directly than before to Nawaz Sharif, the chief rival of Asif Ali Zardari, the Pakistani president, administration officials said Friday. American officials have long held Mr. Sharif at arm's length because of his close ties to Islamists in Pakistan, but some Obama administration officials now say those ties could be useful in helping Mr. Zardari's government to confront the stiffening challenge by Taliban insurgents.

Representative John P. Murtha, chairman of the House military spending subcommittee and a decorated former Marine, has long acted as a protective Uncle Jack to the Marine Corps. Now the corps has named one of his nephews, Col. Brian Murtha, to the office charged with advocating for its interests on Capitol Hill, where Representative Murtha, Democrat of Pennsylvania, helps write the military budget. In relocating to be near the Pentagon, Colonel Murtha has even moved into a unit in the same condominium building where his influential uncle lives in Arlington, Va.
KLINGSBERG--Alice. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alice Klingsberg, associated with The New York Times from February 2, 1945 until retiring on April 1, 1981.

When President Ronald Reagan decided to appoint a woman to the Supreme Court in 1981, he had to turn to Sandra Day O'Connor, an obscure state judge. When President Bill Clinton decided to add a second woman to the court, he confronted a world in which women were just beginning to climb the ranks of big law firms and ranking female judges, like Ruth Bader Ginsburg, were still scarce.

Identity theft is not just an unauthorized charge on a credit card anymore. Identity theft, according to the Federal Trade Commission, ''occurs when someone uses your personally identifying information, like your name, Social Security number or credit card number, without your permission, to commit fraud or other crimes.''
MELNICK--Gisele. In Memoriam 10/27/1935 - 05/02/2006. The world is diminished without her.

Manchester United defender Rio Ferdinand may play in the second leg of next week's Champions League semifinal at Arsenal after tests showed he had not cracked a rib. Ferdinand left clutching his side in the closing minutes of United's 1-0 home first-leg win over Arsenal on Wednesday.

The nation's capital geared up Friday for a battle over a Supreme Court vacancy that appeared likely to test President Obama's success at skirting divisive social issues, with conservative groups saying they viewed the opening created by the retirement of Justice David H. Souter as an opportunity to regroup after a series of political setbacks. Even as Mr. Souter delivered a letter to the White House formally disclosing his intention to step down at the end of this term, liberal and conservative leaders prepared for another of the intense battles over Supreme Court appointments that have marked the past 20 years in Washington. Mr. Souter -- though appointed by a Republican, the first President George Bush -- has been a part of the liberal bloc of the court, so Mr. Obama's appointment is unlikely to shift the ideological makeup of the court.

Labor unions usually dread bankruptcy, and for good reason. Their pay, benefits and pensions typically suffer significant cuts, as airline and steel workers can attest. But for the United Automobile Workers union, Chrysler's Chapter 11 case, which began in New York on Friday, could turn out to be -- if the company survives and thrives -- the Cadillac of bankruptcies.

CBS and ABC can each claim a victory in Thursday night's ratings. Nielsen's estimates indicate that CBS earned the most viewers during every hour of prime time, with ''Survivor'' at 8 (11.7 million), ''CSI'' at 9 (15.3 million) and ''Harper's Island'' at 10 (10.3 million). ABC averaged the night's highest ratings in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, largely because of ''Grey's Anatomy'' (13.9 million) and the season finale of ''Private Practice'' (9.8 million). Fox ranked third for the night with ''Bones'' (8.8 million) and ''Hell's Kitchen'' (7 million). NBC was fourth over all, including its new shows ''Parks and Recreation'' (5.3 million) and ''Southland'' (6.7 million).

Masked gunmen stole two paintings from a Dutch museum on Friday, including a work by Salvador Dalí, officials said, The Associated Press reported. The police said several robbers had threatened a guard at the Scheringa Museum for Realism in Spanbroek with a gun before making off with two paintings. No one was injured, they said. The robbers took ''Adolescence,'' a 1941 gouache by Dalí, and ''La Muscienne,'' an oil painting from 1929 by the Polish-born Art Deco painter Tamara de Lempicka, the museum said in a statement. The paintings' value was not released, but museum officials said they were among the top works in its collection. The Dalí painting is 18 by 12 inches, and the de Lempicka work is 46 by 29 inches. ''We deeply regret the theft and hope the works are traced soon,'' said a statement from the museum, which is 30 miles north of Amsterdam. The Dalí painting shows a landscape in which a woman's face can be seen: her lips and nose are formed by the back of a seated woman, and her eyes are part of two hills in the background. The de Lempicka shows a woman in a vivid blue dress playing a mandolinlike instrument.

An act of violence committed years ago by Gregory Burke, the author of the Iraq war play ''Black Watch,'' right, has compelled him to refuse an honor he was to be presented by his former university, BBC News reported. Mr. Burke was scheduled to receive an honorary degree this November from the University of Stirling in Scotland, where he studied politics. But he has declined the degree after protests from the family of Mark Campbell, a fellow student whom Mr. Burke assaulted at the university about 20 years ago. After the assault, Mr. Burke was banned from the campus, and he eventually dropped out of the university. In a letter to Mr. Campbell, Christine Hallett, the university's principal, wrote: ''Mr. Burke has advised the university that he wishes to decline the offer of award of honorary degree. He explains that he does not wish to embarrass anyone at the university or to make any member of the alumni feel uncomfortable,'' according to the BBC.

First swine flu took its toll on the film industry, delaying premieres in Mexico. Now outbreaks of the disease have forced the cancellation of several concerts in the United States and Mexico. The rapper Young Jeezy, right, canceled a performance at the University of Delaware on Thursday night because of reports of flu at that campus, The News Journal of Wilmington reported. Also Billboard reported that the band Los Lobos was one of several groups forced to cancel shows in Mexico City when the Mexican government banned public events there, adding that Metallica was still scheduled to perform there, and that the Jonas Brothers were still scheduled to perform in Monterrey, Mexico. On his MySpace page, the Japanese rapper Cornelius said his coming tour of North America had been canceled because of travel restrictions amid concerns about the flu.

Loving mother of Charles and Sheila, David and Judi, Linda Shulman and the late Stephen, and Louis and Marcy. Cherished grandmother of Alyse and Matt, Michael and Jaymee, Rachel and Craig, Craig and Wendi, Scott and Lisa, Daniel, and Julia. Adored great-grandmother of Ari, Zachary, Mia, Max, Jacob, Zoe, Joshua, and Spencer. Also survived by our very special family friend, Judy Kaleko. Services at 1:00 pm on Sunday, May 3, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

The Obama administration is moving toward reviving the military commission system for prosecuting Guantánamo detainees, which was a target of critics during the Bush administration, including Mr. Obama himself. Officials said the first public moves could come as soon as next week, perhaps in filings to military judges at the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, outlining an administration plan to amend the Bush administration's system to provide more legal protections for terrorism suspects.
If I were Bill de Blasio, I wouldn't publicize that too much. COUNCILMAN JOHN C. LIU OF QUEENS, on the Red Sox sympathies of Mr. de Blasio, a candidate for New York public advocate. [A18]

CORNELL--Owen Neal. Born July 9, 1923 in Eagle Rock, California. Died April 21, 2009 at home, peacefully, unexpectedly, in Pasadena, at age 85. Still golfing, making plans, always in motion, a spirit and force of nature. With humor, generosity, goodwill and energy, Neal had a mighty impact on all. Son of Marie and Earl, predeceased by brother Earl Jr., and an invaluable son to mother-in-law Donna. Devoted and loving husband to Barbara (Pell) for 61 years, most amazing father to Laura and Jennifer, extraordinary grampy to Tanner, Lilly and Paige, and mayor of the neighborhood. As a graduate of Occidental College in 1948, where he met his beloved Barbara, and of USC, he was a dedicated and revered elementary school teacher and principal in the Los Angeles school system for 38 years. Neal served in WWII, landing at Omaha Beach on D-Day plus 8 Hours, master sergeant of the 1st Infantry Division Big Red One, in combat at Herken Forest and Battle of the Bulge, to the beginning of the Nuremberg Trials. In 1951 he was sent to the front lines of the Korean War. Serving his family, country and community, Neal was humbly most exemplary of the Greatest Generation. Many stories told, many left to tell. How proud we are.

Through the first three weeks of the season, the number of broken bats has dropped slightly compared with last season, baseball officials said Friday. About 0.8 bats per game have broken this season compared with about one bat per game last season, said Pat Courtney, a spokesman for Major League Baseball. Under baseball's count, a broken bat is considered one that has broken into two or more pieces.

Music VOX 2009 BY NEW YORK CITY OPERA, an annual free opera series, with a roundtable discussion; Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, 566 La Guardia Place, at Washington Square South, Greenwich Village; panel starts at 5; performances begin at 7. Free.

Danny Gans, whose seemingly bottomless repertory of impressions, some of them spoken but most of them sung, made him one of the top headliners on the Las Vegas Strip, died on Friday at his home in Henderson, Nev. He was 52. The death was confirmed by Jennifer Dunne, a spokeswoman for Wynn Resorts, which hired Mr. Gans early this year to perform at its new Encore resort.

There is at least one owner who will not be attending the Kentucky Derby on Saturday. Rashard Lewis may have something else to do that day. To racing fans, Lewis is one of five co-owners of the Derby long shot Join in the Dance, but he is better known as a forward for the Orlando Magic, which advanced to the second round of the N.B.A. playoffs by ousting the Philadelphia 76ers on Thursday.

Honoring Eight Belles A ceremony for the filly Eight Belles, who finished second in last year's Kentucky Derby but shattered her front ankles and was euthanized, will take place Saturday before the Eight Belles Stakes.

There may be worse Jewish museums in the world than the Jüdisches Museum Berlin, which opened in 2001. But it is difficult to imagine that any could be as uninspiring and banal, particularly given its pedigree and promise. Has any other Jewish museum been more celebrated or its new building (designed by Daniel Libeskind) so widely hailed? Is any other Jewish museum of more symbolic importance? This is the largest such institution in Europe, a national museum devoted to exploring the history of a people this country was once intent on eradicating. Is there any museum of any kind more laden with the baggage of guilt and suffering, of restitution and tribute?

On the heels of the tenor Rolando Villazón's announcement that he would withdraw from performing until at least the end of the year to undergo surgery on his vocal cords, the Los Angeles Opera said it had cast Giuseppe Filianoti, right, to replace Mr. Villazón in its season-opening production of Donizetti's ''Elisir d'Amore.'' In a news release the opera said Mr. Filianoti would sing the role of Nemorino in the production, which is scheduled to run from Sept. 12 through Sept. 30. On Wednesday Mr. Villazón's managers said he needed surgery as soon as possible to remove a cyst from his vocal cords. A coming run of ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' by Offenbach, scheduled to start at the Metropolitan Opera in December, was among the productions affected; the Met has not yet named a replacement for Mr. Villazón.

The current Supreme Court, made up entirely of former federal appeals court judges, is in some ways the most insulated and homogenous in American history. None of the justices have held elective office. All but one attended law school at Harvard or Yale. And the only three justices in American history who never worked in private practice are on the current court.

Served in Special Commando Forces (LOC) during civil war in Greece 1948-50. Graduate cum laude University of Athens Medical School. Survived by his wife Anna and family. HOOK--Rosalie Fletcher, entered eternal peace April 25, 2009 at The American Hospital in Paris, France, after complications from cancer. Born November 4, 1924 and raised in New York City she lived in Greenwich, CT, New York and Palm Beach, FL where she started the Palm Beach Cooking School before moving to France 30 years ago with her late husband George Hook. She was preceded in death by her eldest daughter Diane C. Bush and will be remembered with love by her children Lynn and Steve Colhoun and Lisa Bolt Jeffery and her husband Jeremy Jeffery, as well as her grandchildren Wynn, Rosie and Daisy Jeffery and by Jean Christophe Lips and many other family members and friends. She will be fondly remembered for her joie de vivre, for being a self styled "foodie" and for her many acts of generosity and love.

Chrysler's sales fell 48 percent in April, underscoring the challenge it faces in trying to attract buyers while it reorganizes in bankruptcy. The decline, reported Friday, was the biggest drop among major automakers, and considerably worse than the industry average of 34 percent compared to a year ago.

LAWRENCE--Mitchell. The Corcoran Group mourns the passing of our beloved colleague and dear friend, Mitchell Lawrence. Throughout his 21 years at Corcoran, Mitchell blessed us with his infectious laugh, warm heart and unique zest for life. He was truly a special member of our family and his loss is hard to put into words, but his spirit will live on in us forever. Our thoughts go out to his longtime partner, Joseph Dwyer, his sister Stacey Lippman, brother-in-law John Lippman and his precious niece Danielle Lippman. A service will be held on Monday, May 4th, at 11:00am at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue at 30 West 68th Street.

MIDGLEY--Joan E.,on April 27, of complications from bone and liver cancer. A real-life Mary Poppins, Joan was born 75 years ago in Lincoln, England, where her father Wilfred worked as senior stonemason on the cathedral. She astonished friends and family by forsaking a promising secretarial career to become a professional nanny. Cared for the children of Lord Denning, Master of the Rolls, before venturing across the Atlantic, first to Chicago and then to New York, where she was the beloved nanny for Christian Plumb for 11 years, then eventually took care of Nathaniel, Raphael and Sarah Wertheimer for more than 20 years. She loved her charges as if they were her own and they, in turn, adored her. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 2 at Frank E. Campbell funeral chapel in Manhattan. Donations in her name may be made to the ASPCA.

Two articles in The Times on Sunday are worth a look for parents and students engaged in the college admissions process.Gretchen Morgenson has written a column offering advice about student loans, particularly the need to carefully study the various kinds of loans that are available.

Threadhead sounded like an odd name for a record company when I mentioned Glen David Andrews’s gospel album, “Walking Through Heaven’s Gate.” And there’s a story behind it. Threadheads are members of an online social community born out of message threads on the forum at nojazzfest.com; after Hurricane Katrina they started donating money and time to charitable projects. Naturally, musicians played at fund-raising parties, and when two of them, the guitarist Paul Sanchez (formerly with the New Orleans band Cowboy Mouth) and the singer John Boutté performed at one in 2007, they joked about having Mr. Sanchez produce Mr. Boutté’s next album. “I’d love to produce you,” Mr. Sanchez said during that set. “Does anyone have any money?”

In the opening sentence of the last chapter of his new book, "Reason, Faith and Revolution," the British critic Terry Eagleton asks, "Why are the most unlikely people, including myself, suddenly talking about God?" His answer, elaborated in prose that is alternately witty, scabrous and angry, is that the other candidates for guidance - science, reason, liberalism, capitalism - just don't deliver what is ultimately needed. "What other symbolic form," he queries, "has managed to forge such direct links between the most universal and absolute of truths and the everyday practices of countless millions of men and women?"

President Obama has said he will abolish the 16-year-old "don't ask, don't tell" policy, which allows gays and lesbians to serve in the military only if they do not disclose their sexual orientation. Nationwide, polls show that a majority of Americans support lifting the ban on openly gay members of the military. But support in the military's ranks and among retired officers is mixed. While several prominent retired generals and admirals have urged a repeal, others have said that allowing openly gay people to join the service would hurt recruiting and retention.

Floyd Mayweather Jr. announced his return to boxing less than a year after he said he was through with the sport. He will fight the lightweight champion Juan Manuel Marquez on July 18. Mayweather, an unbeaten five-time champion, last fought when he stopped Ricky Hatton in the 10th round in December 2007.

Russia scored three power-play goals to beat the United States, 4-1, in the second round of the world championship in Bern, Switzerland. The United States scored first but committed too many penalties as Russia rallied for a 3-1 lead at the end of the first period. Russia got another power-play goal early in the second, and the Americans never looked close to a comeback in the teams’ first meeting at the championship in five years.

Top-ranked Dinara Safina rallied to defeat Flavia Pennetta, 3-6, 7-5, 6-0, to set up a showdown with Svetlana Kuznetsova in the final of the Porsche Grand Prix in Stuttgart, Germany. Kuznetsova defeated second-seeded Elena Dementieva, 6-4, 6-2. Safina was down by 5-4 in the second set but held serve, then broke for a 6-5 lead and held serve. She cruised past a deflated Pennetta in the third. “I was a bit slow at the start,” Safina said. “And she was playing her best tennis.”.

The defending champion Novak Djokovic rallied after a rain delay Saturday to beat Roger Federer, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3, in the semifinals of the Rome Masters, extending Federer’s title drought to seven months.

In focusing entirely on Shai Agassi’s clever battery-exchange program as a way to mainstream electric cars, we might be exchanging one environmental problem for another by ignoring what’s inside batteries (Clive Thompson, April 19).

While the scientific and other speculation about why most of us aren’t very good at ecological thought and action is very interesting, the primary reason is likely more mundane (Jon Gertner, “Why Isn’t the Brain Green?” April 19). Humans are selfish creatures at base, and true “greenness” requires self-sacrifice — not having children, not driving or flying much, not eating much meat, not watering lawns or washing cars or building golf courses, not buying much of anything unnecessary. But as our previous vice president quipped, the American way of life is not negotiable. Too many of his fellow Americans still appear to agree with him. The primary “green” in our brains is cash, not conservation.

Eleanor, Eleanor! In perhaps the bravest casting of his career, Gus Van Sant directs Sean Penn in the role of Eleanor Roosevelt. The fantasy biopic explores what the first lady’s life would have been like if she had never married her distant cousin Franklin but had pursued a career as a social worker on the Lower East Side. Joaquin Phoenix returns to the screen after a three-year hiatus as her pickle-vending confidant. Dakota Fanning makes an appearance as a budding flapper who struggles with Asperger’s syndrome.
During Cannes, the local restaurants introduce a curious cuisine, nectar for the stars. At the Hôtel du Cap, the tables are set accordingly.
They came, we saw, they conquered. Seven originals who were never the same after Cannes.
Win or lose, the Spanish filmmaker always takes the prize for best dramatic flair.
Cannes is not only the cinematic start of 2009, it’s also a springlike rebirth for the ever more converging worlds of fashion, celebrity and culture.

An article on April 19 about Shai Agassi, an Israeli-American entrepreneur who is developing electric-car batteries, misspelled the model of a car his brother drove around Tel Aviv while being interviewed. It was the Renault Mégane, not Megone. The article also referred incorrectly to a report by a consulting firm about the cost of getting electric cars on the road. The figures of $49 million for developing cars and batteries and $21 billion for building charging networks referred to the creation of 17 million electric and low-carbon-dioxide-emitting cars for Europe, not 1.5 million electric cars for the United States, Europe and Japan. And the article misstated the percentage of total cars in the United States that President Obama’s stimulus plan would actually put on the road; 600,000 cars is about one-quarter of 1 percent of the 251 million cars in the United States, not 2 percent.

An article in The Green Issue on April 19 about the science of decision making and the difficulty of getting into a “green mind-set” misspelled, in one instance, the surname of an elder statesman of the field. He is Baruch Fischhoff, not Fischoff.
The Surfacing column on April 12, about Alfies Antique Market in Marylebone, London, misstated its phone number. It is 44-20-7723-6066.
Watch out for Tori Spelling, whose book “Mommywood” debuts at No. 4 on the nonfiction list.

He will be remembered for his masterful coordination of annual trips for fellow alumni of Amherst College's class of 1951. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Janet T. Maloney, his daughter, Bronwyn M. Quillen, his son, Gavin Y. Maloney, his son-in-law, Parker L. Quillen, and two grandsons, Declan and Loomis Quillen, all of New York City.

AMSTERDAM The Vindhek (www.vindhek.com) is conceptual art you can use -- especially if you drop your keys in the grass. Annemarieke Weber, the designer of the Vindhek -- a series of fences and kiosks on which passersby can look for items they lost in the city -- says the invention is based on universal values: honesty, respect, the art of looking after your fellow human.

DAVIDSON Philip David, of New York City, born March 31, 1931 in Wilkes-Barre, PA. Survived by daughters Jennifer and Leah, brother Martin, sisters Betty and Helen and loving ex-wife Sheila. A Wall Street icon, mentor and lifelong sports and horse racing enthusiast, Phil will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Contributions can go to the American Cancer Society.

DeVECCHI--Betsy Trippe. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are saddened by the loss of Betsy Trippe DeVecchi, a humanitarian leader and true friend of the world's most vulnerable people, especially refugee women and children. Betsy was a former member of the IRC board of directors and of the board of the IRC affiliate the Women's Refugee Commission. She was the founding president of Orbis International, the eye-care medical organization, and was a member of its board at the time of her death. We extend our deepest sympathies to her husband, Robert P. DeVecchi, IRC president emeritus, and their family and loved ones. Alan R. Batkin Jonathan L. Wiesner Co-Chairs of the Board Maureen White Chair, IRC Overseers George Rupp President
LIPPOLD--Richard. Your 94th birthday is spiritually celebrated today by your ever loving friend, Gianni.

NICHOLAS ANDERSEN and Julie Ho of Confetti System are art school graduates with a penchant for parties. And their piñatas -- dazzling jewel-shape sculptures, created by hand in their Brooklyn studio -- have made for some particularly exuberant ones, including Karen O's last birthday and United Bamboo's fall runway show. Now, in celebration of Cinco de Mayo, the pair has created a window installation for Opening Ceremony, on view all of May; and this week, their new line of multicolor piñatas and matching silk-and-leather blindfolds hits Bergdorf Goodman's seventh-floor chocolate shop.
DIAMOND--Juliet. Last of remarkable Perlman-Diamond quartet, beloved always. Sandy, Ken, Felice

STRAUS--Rebecca S.,86, on April 25, at home with her family in South Salem, NY. Beloved wife of Nathan III of 62 years, and mother to Andrea, Joseph and Martha. Mother-in-law of Sally Goldfarb, sister of Joseph W. Smith, and grandmother of six: Karen, Nadav, Michael, Adam, Elizabeth, Molly. Educator and historian, admired and respected by generations of devoted students and colleagues, Rebecca taught for many years at the Dalton School and was also head of the high school. She was Director of the Bank Street School and administrator andlater Adjunct Associate Professor of the NYU School of Continuing Education. For the past more than 10 years, she taught at The Adult Learning Center at the Hiram Halle Memorial Library, a program she founded and which held a special place in her heart. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her name to the Hiram Halle Library, 271 Westchester Ave., Pound Ridge, NY 10576. A memorial will be held Sunday, May 3, 2-5pm at The Willows in the Oakridge Commons Shopping Center, South Salem, NY, (914) 523-4110 for directions.

TWO OLD FRIENDS AT THE TEATRO GRECO, SYRACUSE, SICILYCher Lewis, 58, at right, a retired banker from New York now living in Pietrasanta, Tuscany, with Linda Stark, who splits her time between Australia and Italy, Sept. 10, 2008. ''I lived in the West Village for 32 years, on Bank Street for 21. Now I garden, I have chickens and I make olive oil. It's been seven years now -- or eight years, how time goes. Each year you feel more a part of the country you're in. When I go back, I find it harder and harder to understand what I saw in living in a big city where the values are so different. Here it's not all about money. It's more about family and friends. Linda was my twin daughters' piano teacher when they were 5 years old; she now lives in a town on the other side of the mountains six months a year. We've been talking about Sicily for at least four years. It was very rustic, old-fashioned Italy from the movies: you go through small, dusty town after dusty town, with people still farming. In this photo, I'm probably pointing at the capers. One thing I do when I travel is take little pieces of plants and then try to root them in my garden. I ended up taking a bit of caper but it didn't do too well; I think it's just not dry enough in Tuscany.'' As told to Seth Kugel

After the November auctions, top officials at Sotheby's and Christie's stopped offering sellers financing. But rules are made to be broken, and this spring Sotheby's has given Dakis Joannou, a Greek industrialist, a guarantee for works he is auctioning on May 12. Sotheby's is protected, however, by having what is called an irrevocable bid, meaning that a buyer has already agreed to purchase the art for an undisclosed sum. And if someone else wants to pay more? Then the original bidder gets a percentage of the profits. The highlight of the group, and the cover image of Sotheby's May 12 sale, is a 1988 self-portrait by the German artist Martin Kippenberger.

WHEN Terry J. Lundgren, the chief executive of Macy's, received Carnegie Hall's Medal of Excellence in April 2008, he beamed with pride. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg presented the award, which goes to a business leader who supports the arts. More than 1,000 guests, including Martha Stewart, Leonard Lauder and Tommy Hilfiger, cheered from their tables in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. Tony Bennett sang his heart out. And Carnegie Hall raised $4.2 million. But when it came time to select an honoree for this year's medal, Carnegie Hall's board and management were stumped. They canceled the benefit.
To the Editor: Your column about the photographer James T. Johnathan (The Island, ''A Long-Ago Bay Shore, and the Man Who Captured It,'' April 26) recalled an old friend and mentor.

MARKOWITZ--Leonard (Lenny), passed away after a short illness. He is survived by his loving brother, Irving Marks and his nephew, Daniel Marks, and nieces Anne Marks and Alexis Marks. He will be missed by his family, co-workers, and friends.

The sculptor Alexander Calder is proving to be the art world's comfort food. In depressed times, when prices for most artists drop, his work has consistently remained recession-proof. In a dreary sale at Sotheby's in November, for instance, four bidders wanted to take home ''Deux Dates,'' a painted metal and wire hanging mobile executed from 1964 to 1969. It ended up selling for $2.4 million, well above its high $1.8 million estimate. While his work never appealed to the Japanese who were responsible for the 1980s art boom or to the hedge fund billionaires or newly rich Russians who pushed prices in the last few years, it has, for the most part, been snapped up by low-key, seasoned collectors.

ERIKSON--Dr. George "Erik", 88, died on January 15, 2009 in Norton, MA. He was most admired by his many students first as assistant professor at Harvard Medical School from 1955 until 1965, and as full professor at Brown University Medical School from 1965 until 1990. He was senior anatomist at the Dept. of Surgery, Mass. General Hospital, Boston and on the faculty of the R.I. School of Design, Providence, RI. Listed in Marquis Who's Who in the World, Dr. Erikson received many awards: among them, a Guggenheim Fellowship for the study of primates in South America in 1949; the Alpha Omega Honor Medical Society from Harvard Medical in 1957; and the Wiley A.J. Ladman Exemplary Service Award from the American Association of Anatomists, 1999. In 1990, he founded the Erikson Biographical Institute in Providence. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Suzanne Henderson Erikson, and his four children: Ann Febiger of Gloucester, MA; David of Weare, NH; John of Vermillion SD; Tom of Oakland CA; and seven grandchildren. Donations may be sent in Dr. Erikson's name to: Doctors-Without-Borders, 333 Seventh Ave., 2nd floor, New York, NY, 10001-5004. A memorial service will held at 1pm on Saturday, May 30th in the Crystal Room, Alumnae Hall, Brown University, Meeting St., Providence, RI.
Film Mike Hale

LEVENSTEIN--Robert, age 94, accomplished pianist and chess player, New York State Chess Champion 1931, survived by his wife Helena, son Fredric, daughter-in-law Mary and grandchildren Katherine and Jacob.

SELIZKI--Dr. George Michael, died peacefully at his home in West Palm Beach, FL on April 21, 2009. Widely known as the "King of Long Hair Care", his techniques and system were adopted by salons throughout the world and featured in many leading magazines, trade journals and newspapers including the New York Times. He began his pioneering career in a small salon on Madison Avenue in 1957, quickly attracting lovers of long hair worldwide. His handpicked successor and stylist Maria Matarazzo took over in 1989, and has been sole owner of the world headquarters salon/ products division ever since. Now known as Madora George Michael of Madison Ave Salon, Maria invites clients, friends and affiliates to attend a memorial chapel service at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Monday, May 18th at 11am, followed by a remembrance of his life at the salon 422 Madison Ave.
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

NEFTCI--Salih. The New School is deeply saddened by the recent death of Salih Neftci, Professor of Economics at The New School for Social Research and Director of the Global Finance Program. Salih passed away on April 15, in Aubonne, Switzerland. He is recognized as one of the world's authorities in the fields of financial markets and financial engineering and is the author of many books and articles on these subjects. Salih was a brilliant teacher and a dedicated colleague, he will be profoundly missed. Bob Kerrey, President, The New School Julien J. Studley, Chair, Board of Trustees Michael Schober, Dean, The New School for Social Research

KOSTRON--Elsa Winkler. Marymount School of New York mourns the passing of Elsa Winkler Kostron, of Hopewell, New Jersey, beloved mother of Erika K. Aron, Trustee Emerita. Our entire School community extends its deepest sympathy to Erika and her family.

HIGH-END HOSTELS To the Editor: Regarding ''Hostels Grow Up'' (April 19): Some of us aren't as enthusiastic as Jennifer Conlin about the upscale hostels in Europe. A hostel room for $133.50? Are you kidding me? The whole point of a hostel is to make travel affordable for the young, the poor and the thrifty. I'm 45 and I still expect to be able to find a room for $40 anywhere in the world.

DORSETT--Burt N.,of Naples, Florida, died on April 26th at home with his wife and children at his side. He moved to Naples in 2004 after residing in New York City since 1970. He was 78 and lived an active and enjoyable life until the end. Mr. Dorsett, a native of Chicago, Illinois, attended the Masonic Children's Home, an orphanage in La Grange, Illinois, throughout his childhood and high school years, while attending Lions Township High School, where he was President of the Student Council. Upon high school graduation, Mr. Dorsett was a scholarship student at Dartmouth College, in Hanover, New Hampshire, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1953. Following college he was employed by E.I. duPont De Nemours in Seaford, Delaware, before moving his family to the Cambridge area to attend Harvard Business School, where he obtained a Masters in Business Administration in 1959. Mr. Dorsett was a consultant at Booz, Allen & Hamilton, in New York City from 1959 to 1962; then lived in Rochester, New York, from 1962 to 1970, where he was Vice President, Investments, at the University of Rochester. During that time he was a Director and Chairman of the Portfolio Committee at the Chemical Fund, a Director of Garlock Inc., a Director of the Eberstadt Fund, and a Trustee of Monroe County Savings Bank. He was also a Director of the Convalescent Hospital for Children, and of the Community Chest, Rochester; and a Trustee of Keuka College, in Keuka, New York. He moved to Darien in 1970 to become Executive Vice President and a Trustee of the College Retirement Equities Fund (TIAA/CREF) in New York City. In 1979, Mr. Dorsett joined the Westinghouse Corporation to become President of Westinghouse Pension Investments Corporation. In 1986 he formed Dorsett McCabe Capital Management, Inc., in New York City, which he operated as Principal until 2004. Mr. Dorsett was a longtime Director and member of the Investment Committee of the American Psychological Association, a Director of the Research Corporation from 1972 to 1990, followed by continued service as a Director of Research Corporation Technologies from 1987 to 2002. He also served as a Director of many Mutual Funds from 1972 to 2006. In 2001, together with a gift from the Research Corporation Technologies, he endowed the Dorsett Fellowship in Applied and Professional Ethics at the Ethics Institute of Dartmouth College. At the time of his death, Mr. Dorsett was a Consultant to Leeb Capital Management, Inc., in New York City. He is survived by his wife of 28 years, Trixie Elaine Dorsett; his former wife Judith Dorsett; his children Jeffrey Dorsett of Connecticut, Deborah Dorsett of Vermont, and Mark Dorsett and his wife Sharon, of Maine, and his sister Jean Glore of California, and eight wonderful grandchildren, Danielle, Clayton, Michael, Laura, Spencer, Carter, Chapin and Campbell. He was pre-deceased by his daughter Cynthia Dorsett in 1979. A private Reception in his memory will be held in New York City. Gifts may be made to the Dorsett Fellowship in Applied and Professional Ethics, at the Ethics Institute, Dartmouth College, 6031 Haldeman Center, Hanover, New Hampshire 03755.

MIDGLEY--Joan E.,on April 27, of complications from bone and liver cancer. A real-life Mary Poppins, Joan was born 75 years ago in Lincoln, England, where her father Wilfred worked as senior stonemason on the cathedral. She astonished friends and family by forsaking a promising secretarial career to become a professional nanny. Cared for the children of Lord Denning, Master of the Rolls, before venturing across the Atlantic, first to Chicago and then to New York, where she was the beloved nanny for Christian Plumb for 11 years, then eventually took care of Nathaniel, Raphael and Sarah Wertheimer for more than 20 years. She loved her charges as if they were her own and they, in turn, adored her. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 2 at Frank E. Campbell funeral chapel in Manhattan. Donations in her name may be made to the ASPCA.

A private memorial service for close friends and family to be announced. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Kathy's memory to the ASPCA, The Humane Society, or to your favorite charity. Rest in peace dear Kathy-you will be deeply missed and loved forever.

THE NEWS Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania announced that he was leaving the Republican Party to join the Democrats. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Specter, a five-term moderate who faced a likely primary defeat to a conservative challenger in 2010, found himself growing farther out of step with the rightward drift of his old party, especially after he broke ranks to vote for Mr. Obama's stimulus plan. He was wooed for months by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. His defection and the likely victory of Al Franken in Minnesota would give the Democrats 60 senators, enough to keep Republicans from blocking Mr. Obama's initiatives with filibusters.

Arthur is lovingly remembered as owner of Lanoff Fish, Kingsbridge Rd., Bronx. His legacy will be cherished by extended family and friends for generations.

GOOCH--Jane Bradford, (Mrs. Horace), 97, of Worcester, Massachusetts died on April 6. She leaves a daughter, Sally Gooch Paynter of New York City and Washington Connecticut; a son, Bradford Cushing Gooch, of Rome, Georgia; five grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Along with her lifelong leadership participation in Worcester's social service organizations, Jane Gooch was an enthusiastic golfer, fisherwoman, and traveler. Mrs. Gooch was also a writer, historian, and genealogist. She is remembered by her family as a mother and grandmother of grace and beauty and love and kindness and, as well, a woman who knew how to have fun.

Co-founded The Orpheus Chamber Singers and sang with The Robert Shaw Chorale, Sine Nomine Singers, Summit Chorale, and most recently with Masterwork Chorus performing Handel's Messiah in December 2008 at Carnegie Hall. Alexander Korda's 1941 film ''That Hamilton Woman,'' based on the scandalous real-life love affair between the British naval legend Adm. Horatio Nelson and Emma Hamilton -- played by the real-life husband-and-wife Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh -- uses a framing device that's lovely if somewhat painful: An impoverished and prematurely aged Emma is arrested for stealing a bottle of wine and locked in a jail cell. Her chatty cellmate cheerfully asks first for her name and then for her story: ''Tell us all about it -- doesn't matter if it's true or not.'' What follows, unfolding in the glowing terms of an older woman's reminiscence -- or maybe just the glowing terms of classical moviemaking -- is the story of how the youthful and extraordinarily beautiful Emma captured the heart of the stolid war hero and began an affair that would last until his heroic death at sea in 1805. Olivier, as great an actor as he was, gives the lesser performance here. It's Leigh (above) who captivates, playing a character just as flirty, though not as flinty, as the one who had made her famous a few years earlier, Scarlett O'Hara. Emma has more layers of melancholy, and of generosity, than Scarlett does, and Leigh brings those finer shadings to the fore. With her creamy bisque complexion and laughing feline eyes, Leigh as Emma is radiant to an almost unearthly degree. That's what gives the film's framing device its mournful sting: The movie's vision of the older, broken Emma Hamilton offers a glimpse into Leigh's own unhappy future. Though she did have a few more notable film roles (including that of Blanche DuBois in ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' in 1951), she suffered from bipolar disorder and worked infrequently until her death in 1967. But in ''That Hamilton Woman'' she's bracingly alive, as she and her husband embroider history in gilt thread. Doesn't matter if it's true or not. (Criterion Collection, Sept. 9, $39.95) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

JOHN CHEEVER was perhaps America's foremost chronicler of suburbia, and in his quirky short stories and novels, fictional suburbs like Shady Hill are often pictured as a place of deadening commuter routines, liquor-fueled get-togethers, loveless affairs and forays of conspicuous consumption. These writings suggest that he seemed to take a jaundiced view of so manicured and lovely a setting.

A summery, in-between-jobs listlessness floated me into a weekday matinee of ''The Matrix'' 10 years ago. I wasn't expecting much. The story is set in the year 2099 and involves Keanu Reeves as Neo, a computer hacker confronted by the irreversible knowledge that the world of appearances, the world in which people ''go to work, go to church, pay taxes,'' is an intricate simulation. With the aid of a red pill, Neo is jacked into his true habitat: a system of gooey, tube-fed pods in which he and millions of other naked, anesthetized humans are harvested for energy by a race of sentient machines.

Lang and Hazel Scott Lang and brother Frank Lang. Loving father to Phillip and Steven. TO most people, frugal travel means getting around by foot, bike, bus and low-cost airlines. But for Randy Sturrock and Marianne Edwards, a Canadian couple in their late 50s, the RV is their preferred mode of inexpensive transportation. In 2000, the couple set off on their first adventure, a year-long trek from their home in northern Ontario down through the Dakotas to Utah, Texas, California and Arizona. Along the way, they discovered that not only did they love the experience of the RV, but how much it saved them in travel costs. Since then, they've taken three, five-month RV trips, and now provide money-saving guidance to RV newbies via their Web site, frugal-rv-travel.com. Ms. Edwards spoke with me from Ontario about free campgrounds, great views and the joy of living without reservations. How is the experience of traveling by RV different from other ways of travel?

For collectors of sculpture by Alberto Giacometti, the dog is king, but some might say cats run a close second. This one happens to be one of the most expensive works in Sotheby's sale on Tuesday. Although Giacometti was best known for his depictions of the human figure, he produced bronzes of both animals and once even told a writer: ''The dog is myself. One day I saw it like that in the street. I was that dog.''

LeBron James may never be able to match Oscar Robertson's feat of averaging a triple-double for a season (1961-62), but in this year's playoffs he is as close as he has ever been. He averaged 32 points, 11.3 rebounds and 7.5 assists in Cleveland's four-game sweep of Detroit.

KROSNER--Evelyn Wolfenhaut, 101, Born August 4, 1907 in Williamsburg, NY. Died April 26, at Penninsula Hospital, Far Rockaway, NY. Widow of Harry. Survived by daughters Maryam Seley, East Hampton, NY, Barbara Kissin, Jupiter, FL, granddaughters Emily Hamilton, children Michelle and Jeremy of Santa Rosa, CA, Caroline Prewitt, children Will and Sally, Morganville, NJ, son-in-law Claud Kissin, Matawan, NJ, nieces, grandnieces and nephews, great- and great-great-grand nieces and nephews. KENNEDY--Yvonne Lawrence, 81, of Fairfield, CT died suddenly on April 27, surrounded by her children who adored her. A native New Yorker, she was "just visiting" Fairfield for sixty years. She was an elegant and extraordinary woman whose like will not pass this way again. Her deep and abiding faith sustained her and inspired not only her husband, eight children and twelve grandchildren, but so many she loved of every faith. She truly lived the principles of faith, hope and charity. She was the daughter of Joseph W. Lawrence and Alice M. Gallagher but largely raised after her father's death by a legendary grandmother, Mimi Gallagher, whom she emulated all her life. She arrived into adulthood with a rare mix of worldliness and humility. She looked the whole world in the eye, cared not about status or the bubble of reputation, and was generous to all, with her time, her spirit and her love. Loyal and funny, she was a larger-than-life personality that all were drawn to, yet was amazingly unaware of the deep and positive effect she had on others. Her brilliant and incisive mind encompassed many disciplines. She enjoyed challenging herself and broadening her intellectual horizons through reading and debating issues with many. She was known to read a book in a day and without fail, the New York Times and Wall Street Journal before starting her day. Her favorite hours were spent in the "booth" on the "ameche". She was the beating heart of the home she created and it was a large one, encompassing her children, an extended family and hosts of friends, who all loved to be around her. The door of her home on Sachem Road was always open. Unless, of course, she was out on the open road in the YLK-mobile, with a bucket of Kentucky Fried. A stalwart friend to many, and always ready to lend a hand, no friendship could compare with that she shared with Rosemary Barry. Together, they weathered lifes vicissitudes, its triumphs and tragedies, across six decades. A devoted wife of the late John M. Kennedy, she was an amazing mother to all her children: Anne K. Gargano (Joseph), John M. Kennedy, Jr. (Eileen), the late Martin J. Kennedy (Carol), Deane O. Kennedy (Kathleen), the late Lizzy Kennedy, Cornelia K. Suskind (Ron), Alice E. Kennedy (Dan), Marita K. Wein (Bryon). But it was her grandchildren that truly made those beautiful blue eyes sparkle the brightest: Jay and Meghan Gargano, John III and Sarah Kennedy, Brian and Grace Kennedy, Walter and Owen Suskind, Amanda Lange and Matthew, Laura and Julia Wein. She is also survived by her devoted and loving sister, Cornelia L. Smith ("Dickie") and siblings Joseph W. Lawrence, Michael P. Montesani, Diane M. Wenk, and Jeanette M. Curran. She was predeceased by her sister, Alice Murray Larson and brothers Joseph T. Montesani and Peter Montesani. A Memorial Mass in Celebration of her Life will take place on Saturday, May 16 at 1:30pm at St. Augustine's Cathedral, 359 Washington Ave., Bridgeport, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the foundation that has been set up in her memory: A Friend in Need Foundation, 6370 31st Pl. NW, Wash DC 20015.

''They were hoping that everybody else would make sacrifices, and they would have to make none.'' President Obama, on a group of Wall Street firms that refused to accept steep losses on their Chrysler investments.

OUTPOSTS President Obama is making it safe to be a liberal again -- and showing how meaningless such labels can be. His first lap reveals not so much about him as it does the country he governs: a nation willing to follow a man whose policies they may not fully believe in. Obama's broad support points to an old American character trait -- pragmatism. It can tilt conservative or liberal, as resilient as the times. We are said to be a center-right country. In truth, we lean to common sense. If that means tying up the banks in ropes of new regulation to keep them from running amok again, despite cries about restraining free enterprise, most people are for it. If that means firing hack public school teachers to the wails of the educational establishment, the public is there as well.

The early season is not always about young players trying to prove they belong. Sometimes, it is about veterans searching for lost magic. Lance Berkman, below, often has a bad month and still ends up with reliable numbers by the end of the season. So why should his .162 April, which ended with a 1-for-23 string, be cause for alarm? Well, perhaps because it came after he hit .171 last September. Berkman has five homers, so apparently he still has bat speed at 33. Maybe his mental health day on Wednesday or the turning of the calendar will straighten his course.

DUFAULT--Joan Pyle, Died on April 23rd at the age of 83 after a long illness. She was born in Bern, Switzerland on November 1, 1925 to Mita Waller and William Scott Pyle. Joan came to the U.S. where she attended Radcliffe College. Joan married Peter Kane Dufault in 1946 and raised a family. She was a photographer and received her MFA from the Pratt Institute of Art. She published a collection of photographs and interviews on the elderly entitled "Vintage". She was also an actress and won the Uta Hagen award. She was the loving mother of Tadea, Scott, Mark and Ethan. She is survived by her three sons, nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

Is Diane Lane the most believable presence in contemporary American movies? There's currently no one who better registers both the satisfactions of maturity and the regrets that only deepen with age. In ''Killshot,'' John Madden's adaptation of Elmore Leonard's fine novel, Ms. Lane plays Carmen Colson, a Midwestern real estate agent who knows that her marriage to her ironworker husband, Wayne (Thomas Jane, below with Ms. Lane), has come to an end. In one quietly devastating scene, Carmen and Wayne, out for a sociable evening at the local bar, recount how they met. Listening to Wayne tell a story she has heard countless times, Ms. Lane, a master at registering minute shifts of emotion, shows Carmen torn between familiar affection and pain for a life together that didn't work out.
Art Carol Vogel

REIS--Ruthanne (Abram), of Washington, DC and Augusta, GA, died in Augusta on April 19, 2009. Ruthanne was born in Fitzgerald, GA on June 9, 1920, the daughter of Sam and Irene Abram. Predeceased by her husband Harold Reis, noted Washington lawyer. Mother of Alan Reis (Dana) of New York City, Kate Grogan (Kevin) of Augusta, and Deborah Kennedy (Lee Bragg) of Manchester, ME. Predeceased by her siblings Dr. Lewis Abram, Morris Abram, and Jeanette Bernstein. A graduate of the University of Georgia, she was one of the first woman air traffic controllers, finishing that career at Washington National Airport (Reagan). The last sixty years of her life were devoted to the welfare and happiness of her family and friends, all of whom will miss her greatly.

BOSTON LEGAL: SEASON 5 James Spader and William Shatner star in the final 13-episode season of David E. Kelley's network drama. (Fox, $49.98, not rated) THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON From the director David Fincher (''Zodiac''), an epic contemplation of mortality centered on the metaphorical figure of a New Orleans foundling (a digitally enhanced Brad Pitt) who is born an old man and ages in reverse. In The New York Times in December, A. O. Scott said of the movie that ''the puzzles it invites us to contemplate -- in consistently interesting, if not always dramatically satisfying ways -- are deep and imposing, concerning the passage of time, the elusiveness of experience and the Janus-faced nature of love.'' With Cate Blanchett, Julia Ormond and Tilda Swinton. (Criterion Collection, Blu-ray $39.99, standard definition two-disc edition $34.98; Paramount, standard definition single-disc edition $29.98, PG-13)

I Want Revenge, the morning-line Kentucky Derby favorite, was scratched from the 135th running of the race Saturday after veterinarians detected lameness in his left front ankle. I Want Revenge, a son of Stephen Got Even, will probably miss the Preakness Stakes, too, his trainer, Jeff Mullins, said. It was a stunning development on par with the race-morning withdrawal in 1992 of another favorite, A. P. Indy, who is I Want Revenge's grand sire. Mullins and two veterinarians who examined I Want Revenge were not certain what was ailing him.

Miranda Richardson, Joan Plowright, Polly Walker and Josie Lawrence shine in Mike Newell's lovely version of Elizabeth von Armin's novel ''Enchanted April,'' due Tuesday. Also that day, Michelle Williams holds the screen in a nearly wordless performance in Kelly Reichardt's piercing ''Wendy and Lucy,'' and the great Chris Marker's epic documentary ''A Grin Without a Cat'' is released. On May 12 Criterion releases John Huston's fine film of Flannery O'Connor's novel ''Wise Blood,'' featuring a fierce performance by Brad Dourif. On May 19, with the DVD release of the 3D version of ''My Bloody Valentine'' (glasses included), those body parts can fly into your lap in the comfort of your own home. Isn't this modern age a wonder? The same day, the presiding muse of '60s horror films, Barbara Steele, turns up in ''Nightmare Castle,'' while, also from that era, one of Seijun Suzuki's usually delirious crime dramas, ''Detective Bureau 2-3: Go to Hell Bastards!'' even has a title to match.

HOCHHAUSER--Herbert, passed away April 30th at age 87. Loving husband to Aidalina Campillo, proud father of Michele (Ricardo) Bertran, Esq. and David (Janet) Hochhauser, M.D., beloved "Ipa" to grandchildren Nicole and Danielle Bertran, and Elizabeth, Rachel, Vanessa, Herbert Michael, Kimberly, Madeleine and Kevin Hochhauser. A World War II veteran, NYU and Columbia University School of Social Work graduate, he spent his career at Altro Health and Rehabilitation Services. He was a gentleman, ardent social justice supporter, avid NY Times reader and bridge player. Always interested in world affairs and the lives of others, most of all he deeply loved his family. "Uncle Herbie" is also survived by sister Connie Weinstock and many nieces and nephews. He was one of the most principled, kind and generous people anyone will ever know and will be forever missed.

LEWIS--Milton. "Now listen to this!" Milt's intro to Eyewitness News reports echoes forever. The feisty New York- born avatar of journalism died in San Francisco April 16. At 96 he was still reporting. Well done, Milt! Bob Lape and Joanna Pruess

Jeremy Renner has some memorable good guys on his résumé, most notably the young fireman suffering from depression in ''Twelve and Holding.'' But he is best known for creepy triumphs like Charlize Theron's vicious enemy in ''North Country'' and the chillingly affectless serial killer in ''Dahmer.'' That sort of gift can trap an actor, but if so, Kathryn Bigelow's suspenseful Iraq war movie, ''The Hurt Locker'' (June 26), should spring Mr. Renner once and for all. Not that his Staff Sgt. William James is just one of the boys. His specialty is disarming the improvised explosive devices -- I.E.D.'s -- that have become the chief killers of troops and civilians. The work is beyond dangerous, but as Mr. Renner plays him, Sergeant James is an enthusiast for this loaded version of Russian roulette. Decked out in his bulky protective gear and formidable helmet, he bounces toward his deadly target like an astronaut on the moon about to discover something wonderful. James's enthusiasm unnerves and infuriates another sergeant (Anthony Mackie), whose task it is to guide and protect him via remote control, and when a younger soldier accuses him of putting them all at risk for an adrenaline high, we see his point. As Mr. Renner plays him, James at first seems like your basic hot dog, flashy and fearless. Certainly he savors his skill at locating and teasing apart the lethal components of the I.E.D.'s; he's dicing with death. But as the story progresses, Mr. Renner gives James a fascinating complexity of macho intensity and guarded tenderness, as well as sly humor and -- surprising in someone who takes a certain pleasure in the discomfort of other men -- a hatred of human cruelty.

It's hard enough for bettors to focus on a 50-1 shot like Mine That Bird. ''Who's that horse?'' is a common refrain when a long shot enters the picture. But for a race caller who must keep track of 19 horses, the job is doubly difficult. Tom Durkin, who called the Kentucky Derby for NBC, appeared to lose sight of Mine That Bird's dramatic move around the far turn and in the homestretch of the Derby, when the winner slipped past Join in the Dance to seize control of the race.

The Belgian-born actress Yolande Moreau has enjoyed a 30-year career in French theater and film but remains virtually unknown in the United States. That may change for art house audiences with her extraordinary performance in the difficult title role of ''Séraphine'' (June 5), which dominated the 2009 Césars, France's version of the Oscars, with seven awards, including best actress for Ms. Moreau. The movie covers the later years in the life of Séraphine de Senlis, a deeply devout, middle-aged provincial cleaning woman who, at the behest of her guardian angel, became a recognized outsider artist before dying at 78 in a mental hospital in 1942. Playing a character who in an earlier era might have been seen as a saint and in ours as bipolar or schizophrenic presents a double challenge. Ms. Moreau meets it with a largely physical performance that is as subtle as it is vigorous.

In the world of stand-up, Zach Galifianakis is a meta comic who takes showbiz conventions and gives them an absurdist twist. Judging by the videos on his Web site (zachgalifianakis.com), his impersonations don't feature the famous, but rather characters like ''the lisping gay-basher'' and ''the timid pimp.'' And in ''Between Two Ferns,'' his sendup of local-access television talk shows, he's the worst host in the world, interviewing real guests who don't always seem in on the joke. With ''The Hangover'' (June 5), Mr. Galifianakis has his first major role in a high-profile comedy, and he's terrific, but there's nothing meta about it. On the contrary, he inhabits his ridiculous character with such sincerity that he nearly steals the movie. In ''The Hangover,'' three groomsmen take their about-to-be-married buddy to Las Vegas for a last bachelor spree and manage to lose him in the course of a particularly wild night. Two of the men are the groom's close friends; the third, played by Mr. Galifianakis, is the bride's eccentric brother, Alan. Round-bellied, socially inept and not the least bit shy about walking around without any pants on, he's the wackiest of the movie's characters; the others have their comic opportunities, but they're straight men by comparison. He also has many of the movie's broadest moments: being sucker-punched by Mike Tyson; stumbling blearily into the bathroom only to realize too late that there's a very annoyed tiger in there with him.
