Think of Boston and images of genteel, picturesque beauty come to mind: swan boats gliding across the pond at the Public Garden, a Paul Revere statue nobly silhouetted against the sky. There's none of that in Peter Yates's cold, damp and piercing modern noir from 1973, ''The Friends of Eddie Coyle.'' Its chief visual feature is the sad-eyed, beaten-down mug of the low-level hood Eddie, played by Robert Mitchum. But that's enough. Eddie, desperately trying to avoid a jail sentence, feeds some information on stolen guns to the feds, even as he is helping a crew of bank robbers -- people he counts among his ''friends'' -- obtain firearms for their next job. This is a world in which underworld gun dealers tote their merchandise in paper bags from Stop & Shop, and in which the sympathetic guy behind the bar (in this case played by Peter Boyle) really isn't your best friend.

DOYLE--Therese, on April 28, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Alvin. Loving mother of Howard, Alvin and Kevin. Mother-in-law of Patricia and Darla. A Memorial Mass will be held on Wednesday May 6, 10am at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th Street, New York City.

Manhattan. In July. The heat emanating from the sidewalk. The stench emanating from every nook and cranny of the sweltering town. How I yearned, during the summers I lived in New York, to just get out of that overheated, overanxious city every once in a while, to meander aimlessly along an esplanade in some quiet seaside spot, the gentle breeze ruffling the hair at the back of my neck. Woody Allen's ''Stardust Memories'' provides the quintessential backdrop for a New Yorker's escapist fantasies: a sleepy little film festival at the shore, where the besieged filmmaker Sandy Bates has been invited to attend a retrospective of his work. Although the soothing qualities of the place are not immediately accessible to our hero, once he does manage to give his swarming, rabid fans the slip, you can practically taste the salt in the air and hear the lapping of the waves in the middle distance.

While the odd painting by the Art Deco painter Tamara de Lempicka comes up at auction every year or so, the market is flooded with them this season. Six are for sale in two consecutive evenings at Sotheby's and Christie's this week (four at Sotheby's and two at Christie's), and six more will be up in day auctions. Ten of them belong to Wolfgang Joop, a German fashion designer, who is taking advantage of the fact that in these tough times he can get star billing for his paintings, whereas a year ago, when there was no end of quality works for sale, these paintings would have been relegated to the back of a catalog.

DON'T call them hypermilers. The Ford team that squeezed 1,445.7 miles out of a single tank of gas in a 2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid wants to avoid some of the negative connotations of that term, which is often applied to fuel-miser drivers. Overzealous hypermilers have been known to cruise right through stop signs and ''draft'' dangerously close behind other cars to reduce drag.

TAMLYN--Thomas T.,M.D., cardiologist and professional choir singer, died on April 26, 2009, at age 85. He graduated from Columbia College and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, served in the U.S. Public Health Service in Europe, and later was an attending physician at Roosevelt and St. Luke's hospitals. In 1969 he served on the teaching hospital ship S.S. Hope in Tunisia. For seventy-five years he was a singer and soloist in numerous choirs and choral groups, including the Columbia Chapel Choir, Calvary Church, the Canterbury Choral Society, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, and Central Presbyterian Church. During the 1960s he was lead tenor for the Village Light Opera Group. A lifelong enthusiast of history and literature, he was fluent in German, French, Spanish, and Dutch. We will miss him and his optimistic and energetic approach to life. Survived by his wife, Ann Donaldson Tamlyn, his sister, Elisabeth T. Harris, his daughter, Lucy Tamlyn, and two sons, Thomas T. Tamlyn, Jr. and Benjamin Warfield Tamlyn. A third son, Edward Bishop Tamlyn, died in 1978. Also survived by his grandchildren, Benjamin Tamlyn Serpa, Filipa Tamlyn Serpa, and Julia Catherine Tamlyn. Memorial service at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave. and 51st St., Saturday, May 16, at 4pm.

I was about 6 years old when I fell in love for the first time. The girl I sighed for was at least five years older, she had beautiful brown eyes, and she was completely out of reach. But I managed to get as many secret dates with her as I could, sitting in the warm darkness of a movie theater while she glowed on the screen, larger than life. Her name was Melody (Tracy Hyde) and she was in love -- oh, poor me! -- with Daniel (Mark Lester), whom I both admired and despised because I so much wanted to be him. Our dating continued years later, on television, our love intact. Then I lost her for many years. Set in London, ''Melody'' -- directed by Waris Hussein and written by Alan Parker -- is probably the film that I've seen most often. Though it was released in the United States in March, I think I saw it in Mexico in the summer, or maybe it's just that I associate London's raininess with Mexico City's wet summers. It was one of my first lessons about transgression: two kids in love take their own vows of marriage, beating all adult authority against them. Freedom, innocence, love: all signs of that era. Every time I fall in love, I look fruitlessly for Melody in the other person, just as every time I'm having fun with a friend I feel as if I'm Daniel fooling around with his friend Ornshaw in the streets while the Bee Gees sing ''Give Your Best.'' Yes, I know: corny. But true.

DeVECCHI--Betsy Trippe, died on Friday, April 24, at her home on Dunemere Lane in East Hampton, New York, after a long illness. She was in her 77th year. She is survived by her husband, Robert P. DeVecchi, her four children, William Trippe Duke, Terry Duke Marsh, John Hincks Duke and William Angus Douglass, eight grandchildren, Isobel Foxen Duke, Emily Trippe Duke, John Trippe Duke, Catherine Ellis Duke, Owen Beals Duke, John Stetinnius Marsh, Elizabeth Tickle Douglass, and William Trippe Douglass. Also surviving are her brothers Charles White Trippe and Edward Stetinnius Trippe and numerous nieces and nephews. A brother, John Trippe, predeceased her. Betsy was the eldest child and only daughter of Juan Terry Trippe, founder and long time president of Pan American Airways and Betty Stettinius Trippe, sister of Edward Stettinius, Secretary of State under Presidents Roosevelt and Truman and signer of the Charter of the United Nations for the United States. Born in New York City, Betsy was flown to East Hampton when she was three weeks old. Her father piloted her in an amphibian aircraft. Her first home in East Hampton was her grandparents house on Dunemere Lane where Betsy was to die 77 years later. During her lifetime, Betsy was extremely active in volunteer activities. She served on the Boards of Outward Bound, the Lighthouse, The Institute for the Visual Sciences, The Ackerman Institute, Homemaker Services, The Volunteer Consulting Group and the International Rescue Committee. In East Hampton she was an active member of the LVIS and the Garden Club. Betsy was a founding director and President of Orbis International which she helped create in 1973. Utilizing a converted DC-10 aircraft and volunteer opthomological personnel, Orbis is a flying eye hospital which travels the globe. It has restored sight to hundreds of thousands and provided training to thousands of young opthomologists. Funeral services will be held in New York City on Friday, May 15, at St. James Church (71st and Madison Avenue) at 11:00am. There will be a later celebration of Betsy's life in East Hampton at a time to be determined. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Betsy's honor to Orbis International, 520 8th Avenue, New York, NY, 10018, would be welcomed.

FAHEY--William C. January 12, 1939 - April 27, 2009. Died of complications after a stroke. Bill was the loving and devoted father of Julia; an outstanding lawyer and a beloved friend and colleague; a graduate of St. Peter's College in Jersey City, NJ and of Cornell University Law School. In his four years in the US Air Force as a Navigator he rose to the rank of captain. Bill's lifelong love of buses, planes and trains produced an encyclopedic knowledge of transportation which informed his work. He was past president and general counsel for the New York School Bus Contractors Association. His clients included Liberty Lines, New York Bus Company and Suffolk Transportation. A member and presenter for the American Public Transportation Association, Bill was the former chair of both the NYS Bar Association's Environmental Law Section and the NYC Bar Association's Transportation Law Comm. Private interment was May 1. Donations in his memory may be made to Cornell Univ. Law School.

CORNELL--Owen Neal. Born July 9, 1923 in Eagle Rock, California. Died April 21, 2009 at home, peacefully, unexpectedly, in Pasadena, at age 85. Still golfing, making plans, always in motion, a spirit and force of nature. With humor, generosity, goodwill and energy, Neal had a mighty impact on all. Son of Marie and Earl, predeceased by brother Earl Jr., and an invaluable son to mother-in-law Donna. Devoted and loving husband to Barbara (Pell) for 61 years, most amazing father to Laura and Jennifer, extraordinary grampy to Tanner, Lilly and Paige, and mayor of the neighborhood. As a graduate of Occidental College in 1948, where he met his beloved Barbara, and of USC, he was a dedicated and revered elementary school teacher and principal in the Los Angeles school system for 38 years. Neal served in WWII, landing at Omaha Beach on D-Day plus 8 Hours, master sergeant of the 1st Infantry Division Big Red One, in combat at Herken Forest and Battle of the Bulge, to the beginning of the Nuremberg Trials. In 1951 he was sent to the front lines of the Korean War. Serving his family, country and community, Neal was humbly most exemplary of the Greatest Generation. Many stories told, many left to tell. How proud we are.

Because the best Impressionist paintings are either hanging on museum walls or secreted away by collectors who are loath to part with them, anyone looking for one in today's economy will most likely have to rely on a timely death. Estate property has its benefits. For starters, estimates are nearly always low because the heirs are generally trying to raise cash to pay taxes. And because auction houses set the estimates for these works and this year want to make them as enticing as possible to lure buyers, there might be bargains in store. Collections from estates are also usually fresh to the market.

BRETON shirts, the traditional blue-and-white striped tops, introduced into the uniform of French seamen in 1858, have a way of showing up each spring, both on the runway and off. ''Every year, we put them out,'' said Seth Weisser, an owner of the SoHo vintage store What Comes Around Goes Around. ''And the people who get them, buy them, and those people tend to have great style.'' This season, however, it looks like Fleet Week in certain parts of town. Perhaps the appearance of a big-shouldered Breton top with sequins on Balmain's fall runway (left) is the reason. Or, possibly, it's Gwyneth. ''The classic French T-shirt always looks right in spring year after year,'' Ms. Paltrow recently wrote on Goop, her occasionally enlightening lifestyle Web site. She then recommended buying one from Saint James, a French company with a store on Madison Avenue. It's ''as authentic as it comes,'' she wrote. And only $65.

In the summer of 1985 I played a small part or, I should say, I was a small actor in a movie called ''Heartburn.'' Written by Nora Ephron, it stars the beautiful Meryl Streep and the irresistible Jack Nicholson as a couple whose great romance leads them to a marriage that doesn't last. Their best friends are played by Stockard Channing, Richard Masur, Milos Forman and ... me. We were gathered together in the deep summer heat of New York City by Mike Nichols, our very cool director. As a perspiring young actress from Toronto, my self-consciousness was, mercifully, overwhelmed by my gratitude for being in such good company. I expected Ms. Streep to be unapproachable on set. But, no. Never again could I suffer foolish actors who burden themselves and others with the weight of their craft after watching Ms. Streep's lighthearted but sure-footed dance between her tormented character and herself, the fun-loving actress. Oh, right, it's called acting, not feeling.

He is survived by his daughter Judith Dix, son-in-law Stuart Dix, granddaughter Farrel Starker, grandson-in-law Steven Starker, great-grandchildren Brian, Andrew and Stefanie Starker, brother Gene, and sisters Phyllis and Alice. We hope wherever he is, he's got them all laughing. May he rest in peace.

''Galaxy Quest'' was released in theaters in December 1999, along with the usual Christmas-season prestige pictures (among them ''The Talented Mr. Ripley'') and star vehicles (the Tom Hanks-driven ''Green Mile''). At the time, this seemingly dismissible comedy about actors from a long-canceled ''Star Trek''-like television show who are beamed into a for-real space adventure nearly became lost in the shuffle. But this clever and openhearted picture (directed by Dean Parisot) eventually found its audience on television and DVD. The flashy Christmas releases may have seemed important at the time, but 10 years later it's a movie like ''Galaxy Quest'' that you remember. Sigourney Weaver, Alan Rickman, Tim Allen and Tony Shalhoub (below) play washed-up actors forced to relive their glory days as the stars of a silly old sci-fi series. The only work they can get requires that they dress up in character and show up at sci-fi conferences and promotional events, where they're invariably greeted by wide-eyed fans dressed in elaborate get-ups. One day they're approached by an especially enthusiastic bunch, with hair that looks like patent leather and sleek one-piece uniforms to match. These exceedingly polite but socially awkward individuals turn out to be real-life aliens known as Thermians, and not only have they been watching the show faithfully for eons, they've also modeled their civilization on it. (They refer to the episodes as ''historical documents.'')

SPIRO--Gerald, age 93, of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Oradell, NJ. Predeceased by his beloved wife Janet Millenthal Spiro and later by his loving companion Dolores Poskanzer. Devoted father of Mark and his companion Marian. Barbara (Basil) Mavrovitis and Gary (Beth). Adored grandfather of Emma, Alana, Evan, Alex, Peter, Michaela, Jess and Rebecca. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Jerry was born in Hoboken, NJ in 1915 to Dr. Jesse Wilbur Spiro and Mildred Wacht Spiro. He was a survivor of the Flu Epidemic of 1918. Jerry graduated from Syracuse University, later serving in WWII (1941) and the North African and Italian Campaigns (1942-1945). He was a retiree from banking with J.P. Morgan Chase. Jerry enjoyed his hobbies of Geneology and collecting of books and memorabilia. He was a longtime Shriner. He was devoted to his family and loved them dearly. Services will be held at "Gutterman and Musicant" 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday at 10am.

WHATEVER the next step is for Chrysler, over the next few days the world will be inundated with retrospectives of the great products the company produced. You know, the original '55 Chrysler 300, the muscle-era Super Bees, Road Runners, Charger Daytonas and Hemi 'Cudas. But that was never what Chrysler was about. Chrysler has always been at its best when it made cars for buyers who appreciate a good plastic pocket protector. The Chrysler Corporation could never afford to match General Motors or Ford engineering dollar for engineering dollar. Chryslers, DeSotos, Dodges and Plymouths were, most of the time, the plain brown wrappers of the American auto industry, stripped-down transportation for the value conscious and fleet buyers. The heart of the market for Chrysler was always vehicles like the Plymouth Savoy, Dodge Dart and Chrysler Windsor. They were ordinary cars that few people bothered to collect, but which did yeoman duty as family haulers, taxicabs and police cars.

ANDY SPADE is one of few people who can look at a collection of grubby work gloves, run over by 18-wheelers, and find an offbeat charm. Anthony Sperduti is another. Together, they have opened Partners & Spade, a gallery-cum-concept shop filled with cool, clever -- and, as with the gloves, occasionally oddball -- art objects, curated installations and vintage curios. Among them: a Moroccan stop sign; French paper hats; paint-splattered artist palettes; Lehman Brothers swag (''They're the relics of our time,'' Mr. Spade noted); a motorcycle helmet customized by one of MoMA's master gilders; illustrations by Jean-Philippe Delhomme of fashion characters like Olivier Zahm and Terry Richardson; and coming this month, exclusive offerings from ThreeAsFour and Albertus Swanepoel. Need a gift for someone who has everything? Partners & Spade, 40 Great Jones Street (between Bowery and Lafayette Street); (646) 861-3835. Open weekends only.

SHEERIN--Edward V.,of Manhattan and Jupiter, FL, died at home on Saturday, May 2, 2009. Mr. Sheerin, 75, was born in Floral Park, NY. Mr. Sheerin was well known both in the United States and the Caribbean for his many roles associated with the hotel industry. He attended Hofstra University, and later his profession took him to Antigua, West Indies. From 1966 to 1987, he was the Managing Director of the Curtain Bluff Resort, where he was also a shareholder. While living in Antigua in 1967, he was a Founder of Antigua Sailing Week, a world-renowned international sailing regatta. Later for several years he was Chairman of the event, and throughout his life, a member of the Race Committee. He was also a member of the New York Yacht Club. From 1984 to 1986, he was the President of the Caribbean Hotel Association. From 1995 to 2000, he served as Vice-President and Treasurer of Quality Divisional Management, a group that owned the master franchise for Choice Hotels throughout the Caribbean. He was Chairman of the Board of Directors of Island Provision Limited, an Antiguan based food distribution company. Mr. Sheerin was known for his generous hospitality, both in his professional and personal life. He was beloved, not only by friends and family, but when he returned to the Curtain Bluff Resort, as he did often, the staff always greeted him affectionately by welcoming him home. He is survived by his wife, Virginia Wattiker Sheerin. Friends may pay respects at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, New York, NY. Monday, May 4, 2009, from 4pm until 8pm. A funeral Mass will be held on Tuesday, May 5, 2009, at 11am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY. Donations in memory of Edward V. Sheerin can be made to the Pain and Palliative Care Service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, New York, NY 10021.

I'm not trying to sugarcoat things. Things could still be better. But they're better than they were, that's my point. MILTON PATRICK, an auditor in Tampa. Fla., on race relations since the election of President Obama. [26]

There's a hypocritical disconnect between the (often justified) complaint that Americans are ignorant of events in other countries and the predictable charges of cultural appropriation that result whenever a Western filmmaker takes on the subject of political strife in a non-Western country. When John Boorman's ''Beyond Rangoon'' appeared in 1995, many reviews complained that at the center of this political melodrama about the brutal 1988 crackdown on the country's democracy movement was a Westerner, Patricia Arquette as an American tourist who runs afoul of the military junta in Burma. (In a small role, Frances McDormand plays her sister.)

PENDAGAST--Eileen Guerin. Retired educator, author and clinician died in Greenwich Hospital on Monday the 27th of April. A native of Fairfield, Mrs. Pendagast lived most of her adult life in Easton, CT with her late husband Edward L. Pendagast, M.D. and their two children. A widely known and highly regarded expert in family systems, she was the author of numerous book chapters and articles on family therapy. Editor of The Family, a journal jointly published by the Georgetown University Family Center and The Center for Family Learning in Rye Brook, NY, she also designed one of the original psycho-education programs in the country called Family Systems Training which continues to be used as a model for community programs throughout the country. Her children Eileen Weber and Ted Pendagast, her brother Philip J. Guerin, M.D., grandchildren, nieces, nephews and her friends and colleagues of The Center for Family Learning mourn her passing.

CAPLOW--Alvin. Lovely memories. M

From 1994 to 2008 Jeff Koons created five versions of the monumental sculpture ''Baroque Egg With Bow,'' each in a different color. Part of the artist's ''Celebration'' series, in which Mr. Koons fashioned oversized children's toys in shiny colors, the egg to be auctioned this week belongs to Daniel S. Loeb, a hedge fund manager who bought it from the Gagosian Gallery in 2004 . As part as Mr. Loeb's recent efforts to sell the egg, Mr. Gagosian featured it last fall in ''For What You Are About to Receive,'' an exhibition held at the Red October Chocolate Factory in Moscow where contemporary art experts said he was asking around $20 million for it.

MIRKIN--Edward L.,88, of Westbury, NY, on April 27, 2009. Beloved husband of Mitzi for 63 years. Dearest dad of Rick, Laurie, Robin and Randy. Adored and adoring grandfather of Brian, Chelsea, Ashley, Gabrielle, Zara, Edward Tracy and Chloe. Decorated Eighth Air Force Veteran, World War II; former men's fashion illustrator and New York Yankees fan forever. Rest peacefully, dear Poppie.

Audio Slide Show The provincial government in Babil, Iraq, has seized control of much of Babylon -- unlawfully, according to the State Board of Antiquities and Heritage -- and opened a park, hoping to draw visitors. Steven Lee Myers of The Times tours the ruins, which are open for the first time in six years. nytimes.com/world

CLIPPARD--James Henry, Jr.,of Memphis, TN, died suddenly on April 27, 2009. Born on September 17, 1937 in Asheville, NC, Jim was a graduate of NCSU and UNC Chapel Hill. Jim served in Korea in the US Army before heading up Investor Relations at IBM for 28 years and at Fedex for 10 years. He was a longtime member of the National Investor Relations Institute. An avid golfer, Jim was an incurable epicure and had interests as diverse as country and opera music, foie gras and barbecue, burgundy and beer. He was known for a broad smile and a bear hug. He is survived by his loving wife of 42 years, Margaret; children, Tere, Shelly, Kathryn and James III; and grandchildren, Harrison and Ava. A memorial was held on Thursday, April 30. He will be deeply missed.

O'LEARY--Thomas, H. of Saratoga, WY died peacefully on April 28, 2009 at the Eisenhower Medical Center, Palm Springs, CA. The son of Arthur J. and Eleanor Howard O'Leary of New York City, Tom was born on March 19, 1934. After graduating from Holy Cross College in 1954, Tom joined the Marine Corps where he served as an aviator and achieved the rank of Captain. In 1961, Tom received an MBA from the Wharton School of Finance. Tom joined the Missouri Pacific Corporation as Assisstant Treasurer in 1965. By 1974, Tom had become President of the company and served on its Board of Directors. He joined Burlington Northern, Inc. in Seattle in 1982 as Vice Chairman and was a Director of BNI from 1982 to 1992. Tom was elected President and CEO of Burlington Resources, Inc. in 1989 and Chairman of the Board in 1990. He retired from BRI in 1997. He was also a director of The Kroger Company and BF Goodrich. Tom is survived by his wife, Cheryl Westrum O'Leary, by five of his six children by his previous marriage: Timothy M., Thomas H., Denis A., Daniel G., and Mary Frances and by his sister, Susan. His eldest son, Mark E., died in March of this year. The funeral Mass will be said at 11 AM on Tuesday, May 5 at St. Ann's Church, Saratoga, WY, followed by burial at Saratoga Cemetery. Memorial Masses are scheduled at 11AM Thursday, May 7 at Sacred Heart Church, Palm Desert, CA and 10:00 AM on Friday, May 15 at Annunziata Catholic Church, St. Louis, MO. Instead of flowers, contributions may be made to the College of the Holy Cross, Worchester, MA, the Wyoming Stock Grower's Agricultural Land Trust, Cheyenne, WY and Rescue Me Dog, Saratoga, WY.

MADRID One of France's most radical 19th-century artists is riling up this city in an exhibition at the CaixaForum (Paseo del Prado, 36; 34-902-223-040), ''Maurice de Vlaminck: A Fauve Instinct, Paintings From 1900-1915,'' on view through June 6. With some 80 canvases, as well as a selection of ceramics, the exhibition offers the first retrospective held in Spain of the work of Vlaminck (1876-1958), the painter who once compared his career in painting to ''throwing a bomb.'' He continued: ''That way I have satisfied my desire to destroy, to disobey, and to recreate a sensitive, living, free world.'' Vlaminck was among the pioneering artists of his generation to see painting as something bold and visceral as opposed to refined and delicate. At the 1905 Salon d'Automne, Vlaminck and the artists with whom his work was shown -- Matisse, Derain, van Dongen, and Manguin -- were disparaged by the French critics as wild beasts, ''les fauves,'' for their daring use of color. As so often happens with criticism, that pejorative term stuck as the name of one of modern art's most beloved movements. -- Andrew Ferren

YERMAN--Elliott, 92, on April 30. Devoted husband of the late Sybil Berg, loving father of Leslie, Douglas and Marcia. Role model and beloved grandfather of Philip Samuel Dubow. Major in WWII, recipient of the Bronze Star. President of Perfect Finishing Co., he embodied the values of the Greatest Generation. Service Sunday, May 3, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions Elliott Yerman Social Justice Scholarship (www.bhu.edu).

During Cannes, the local restaurants introduce a curious cuisine, nectar for the stars. They must cater to every whim, to the impossible and absurd. But that's the way it is. At the Hôtel du Cap, which has been the area's most popular address every May for the last 63 years, the tables are set accordingly. Like plugs, they can adapt. Perched between Cannes and Nice, with 22 acres on the edge of the sea in Antibes, the Hôtel du Cap is one of the most beautiful palaces in the world. Countless aspirants have dreamed of landing one of the 124 rooms in order to rub shoulders with cinema royalty during festival week, undeterred by the 12-day minimum. The rest of the year, the Hôtel du Cap contents itself with merely being paradise, hidden behind Aleppo pines.

CHAVES--Mark Alan, on May 1st, 2009. Loving husband to Kim Chaves, devoted father of Evan and Allison, son of Herbert and Jane Chaves. Nephew of the late Carol Seid. Also survived by grandmother Florence Seid. Brother to Susan and Scott Zucker and uncle of Jeri and Brian Zucker. Are beloved husband, father, son, brother, uncle and friend to many passed away suddenly. The enormous void that will occupy our lives can only be filled with the joyous memories we hold of you in our hearts and cherished time we spent with you and your family. We will celebrate your life for the rest of ours and will love you forever and ever. Donations may be made to a charity of your choice. Love the Chaves family and the Zucker family

If one band had to encapsulate Jazzfest, it might well be the Voice of the Wetlands All-Stars, an improbable cooperative with a cause. Look at the front men: the swamp-rock bluesman Tab Benoit, the R&B keyboardist Dr. John, the Mardi Gras Indian chief Monk Boudreaux, the rock songwriter Anders Osborne, the Cajun fiddler Waylon Thibodeaux, the harmonica and accordion player Johnny Sansone and the percussionist Cyril Neville of the Neville Brothers. There are a few genres missing — gospel, hip-hop, jazz, country, bluegrass — but it’s still quite the portmanteau. And unlikely as the alliance might seem, the musicians genuinely cooperate, switching grooves as each songwriter steps forward and insisting by example that Louisiana music has no closed borders. Where but in this band would some Mardi Gras Indian funk, with Mr. Boudreaux singing in full green-and-yellow feathered suit, make room for a fiddle solo?

Never underestimate the loyalty a soul love man can command. Congo Square, Jazzfest’s stage devoted to hip-hop and R&B, drew ardent crowds for groups that had major hits in the 1970s and 1980s: the Whispers and the O’Jays on Saturday and Maze featuring Frankie Beverly (whose hits continued into the early 1990s) in a headlining spot on Sunday.

The Pulitzer Prize-winning play “Ruined” picked up another honor on Sunday night when it won the Lucille Lortel Award for outstanding play, The Off-Broadway League announced. The play, whose author, Lynn Nottage, won the Pulitzer Prize for drama last month, tells the story of a group of women living through a civil war in Congo; Saidah Arrika Ekulona was named outstanding lead actress for her performance in it. Other Lortel winners include John Douglas Thompson, who was named outstanding lead actor for his performance as the title character in Theater for a New Audience’s production of “Othello”; David Cromer, who was named outstanding director for “Our Town” at the Barrow Street Theater, which also won for outstanding revival; and “Fela! A New Musical” was named outstanding musical.
Big festivals like Coachella and Bonnaroo are held in out-of-the-way places with no strong musical identity of their own; bands arrive, play their music and move on to the next tour date.

No Sexy Nazis. More Realism. Don’t Kill Mom. A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis offered some constructive criticism for Tinseltown in their “Memos to Hollywood” featured this weekend in our Summer Movies special section. Do you have any suggestions of your own for the industry? Post them here.

The chief justice of Malawi’s Supreme Court adjourned a hearing on Monday in which a lawyer for Madonna continued to press the pop star’s efforts to adopt a second child from that African country, Agence France-Presse reported. Chief Justice Lovemore Munro said he would rule at a later date on Madonna’s appeal of a lower court’s decision to deny her adoption request. In April, Judge Esme Chombo of Malawi’s High Court rejected Madonna’s proposed adoption of a 3-year-old girl named Chifundo James because the singer had not resided in that country for at least 18 months, as required by law. Madonna did not appear at the hearing on Monday, at which the Supreme Court heard presentations from her lawyer, Alan Chinula, and a rights group opposing the adoption. Madonna has an adopted son, David Banda, 3, from Malawi, and two children, Lourdes, 12, and Rocco, 8, from previous relationships.

Veterans of the original Woodstock festival, including Levon Helm, Paul Kantner and Country Joe McDonald, have organized a scheduled flashback of sorts: they and several other musicians who performed at that 1969 concert will play a new show on Aug. 15 to mark the festival’s 40th anniversary, The Associated Press reported. The new concert, whose lineup also includes the Woodstock alumni Big Brother and the Holding Company, Ten Years After, Canned Heat and Mountain, will be held at the Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in upstate New York, where the first Woodstock festival took place over a rainy weekend from Aug. 15 through 17 in 1969. Mr. Helm, who played at Woodstock as a member of the Band, will be appearing with his Levon Helm Band, and Mr. Kantner, who performed at Woodstock with Jefferson Airplane, will appear at the anniversary concert with the upgraded Jefferson Starship.

Updated | 1:49 p.m. Though it’s hardly been a secret that the music of Trent Reznor and his band, Nine Inch Nails, isn’t appropriate for all age groups, a Nine Inch Nails-themed application for the iPhone was rejected by Apple because it contained potentially offensive content, the Web site Pitchfork.com reported. Over the weekend, Mr. Reznor published an e-mail message he received from Apple’s iPhone developer group at his official Web site, nin.com. In the message, Apple said that it would not carry the Nine Inch Nails iPhone application because it offered a streaming version of the band’s song “The Downward Spiral,” which Apple said was “objectionable content,” according to the e-mail message. On his Web site, Mr. Reznor wrote that though he loved Apple products, he urged the company to “think your policies through.” In a subsequent post, Mr. Reznor wrote that he had removed the song “The Downward Spiral” from his servers but had not heard from Apple if this was an acceptable solution. Apple did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

In the 1951 Billy Wilder film “Ace in the Hole,” reviewed in this week’s Critics’ Picks video by A. O. Scott, the lead character Charles Tatum (Kirk Douglas) has this to say about journalism: “Bad news sells best because good news is no news.”

A lawyer for Roman Polanski said that the director would not appear at a hearing this week at which a judge has offered to reconsider evidence against Mr. Polanski in a decades-old sex case, The Associated Press reported. Judge Peter Espinoza of Los Angeles County Superior Court set a deadline of Thursday for Mr. Polanski to return to the United States, before the judge would considered whether he was the victim of prosecutorial misconduct in a 1977 case in which Mr. Polanski was found guilty of having sex with a 13-year-old girl. In a court document filed Monday, Mr. Polanski’s lawyer said his client’s appearance was irrelevant to whether his constitutional rights had been violated at that trial.

Updated | 3:19 p.m. Anniversaries are bittersweet. They recognize survival, loyalty, stability and durability; they also mark the unstoppable passage of time. The New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival has long recognized both aspects, setting out to bolster the survival of local traditions by giving them new audiences, but also pointing out how precious the here and now is.

Students at Prospect Cooperative Nursery School in Maplewood were enthusiastic participants in their food drive. One little boy took to the idea of "Kids Feeding Kids" so much that he decided a hungry family HAD to have dessert in their grocery bag, so he volunteered his un-opened box of Girl Scout Cookies.

The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development just released its updated "Society at a Glance" report, which provides an overview of social and policy trends in its member countries. Among other things, the report looks at leisure time reported in time-use surveys around the globe, and the researchers found that there are significant differences in the amount of time men and women have for leisure.

The expansion of Smithfield Foods, an American agriculture business, into Eastern Europe's hog farming has transformed the pork industry in Romania and Poland.
No fans were allowed to watch Mark Sanchez's first practices with the Jets during rookie camp last weekend - he looked pretty sharp, by the way - but that doesn't mean they haven't embraced him.

When Mine That Bird romped in Saturday's Kentucky Derby, comparisons were made to Donerail, who won the Derby in 1913 at odds of 91-1, still the longest price ever for a Derby winner. But Mine That Bird's shocking win may have been more reminiscent of still another strange Derby outcome, one that happened in fairly recent times. Canonero II may have very well been the most illogical Kentucky Derby winner ever, or at least until Mine That Bird came around.

Rumors of a supersized Kindle, circulating for some time, were virtually confirmed by a Times story today, which reports that "Amazon will introduce a larger version of its Kindle wireless device tailored for displaying newspapers, magazines and perhaps textbooks."

The number of children qualifying for New York City's public school gifted kindergarten programs rose by 45 percent this year, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced Monday. The gains were fueled by a 19 percent - or 2,412-student - rise in the number of test-takers, to 14,822.

If you picked up last weekend's New York Times Magazine, you would have seen T's summer bonus with its focus on the storied Cannes Film Festival. (Had you seen it, you would not likely have forgotten Quentin Tarantino modeling a pair of women's high heels.) Web extras to accompany the issue include a Screen Test with the actress Diane Kruger, in which she sings "Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious" -- in German. It turns out that long before her starring turn in Hollywood and Cannes, Kruger fell in love with Mary Poppins. In other online exclusives, we interview the Russian-born director Géla Babluani, who will show an American remake of his cult film "13 Tezmati" at this year's festival; profile the rapper-turned movie macher Adam Yauch as he prepares for his first buying trip to Cannes; and spotlight the B-list beauty Edy Williams, who has been posing in eye-popping ensembles along the Croisette since the 60's. Who said glamour is dead?

ISTANBUL | When the waiter asks what you'll drink with dinner in Istanbul, the answer is likely to be beer, raki or maybe even tea. Turkish wines are not high on anyone's list: the affordable ones aren't very good, and the good ones aren't very affordable.

In the past week, followers of the swine flu story have seen schools close, travelers quarantined and transit riders don medical masks. Today, although the flu is widespread, global health officials are hopeful that this flu strain, known as H1N1, is less severe than originally feared.
With a Supreme Court seat to fill, President Obama has started his public outreach to search for a new member, reaching out on Monday to two members of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Because it is used in every e-mail address and many tweets, you might be forgiven for thinking that the remarkably common symbol @, which English-speakers know as the "at sign," but Italians call a "snail," and south Slavs know as a "monkey," is a fairly recent invention. In fact, as Wired magazine's Tony Long points out, a Florentine merchant named Francesco Lapi used the symbol @ in a letter written 473 years ago today, on May 4, 1536.

Our our sister blog, ArtsBeat, is reporting: A lawyer for Roman Polanski said that the director would not appear at a hearing this week at which a judge has offered to reconsider evidence against Mr. Polanski in a decades-old sex case, The Associated Press reported. Judge Peter Espinoza of Los Angeles County Superior Court set a deadline of Thursday for Mr. Polanski to return to the United States, before the judge would considered whether he was the victim of prosecutorial misconduct in a 1977 case in which Mr. Polanski was found guilty of having sex with a 13-year-old girl. In a court document filed Monday, Mr. Polanski's lawyer said his client's appearance was irrelevant to whether his constitutional rights had been violated at that trial.

ALBANY -- In what appeared to be an effort to lower expectations for any bailout of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Gov. David A. Paterson said on Monday that he did not expect a plan currently being formulated by the State Senate to include enough money to cover the authority's long-term capital needs. Instead, Mr. Paterson said, it would merely help avert service cuts and fare hikes scheduled to take effect at the end of May.

Millburn police officers and firefighters were working on Hobart Avenue by Highland Avenue this afternoon, addressing an oil spill that spread for several blocks. The Nutley Hazardous Materials team and Millburn Road Department were also on the scene, according to police spokesman Capt. James Miller. The source of the oil was probably a truck that was leaking while it was moving, Captain Miller said. Although the spill extended along Hobart Avenue for quite a distance, no roads were closed while workers were putting absorbent material on the spill.

The Rangers finally announced what has been rumored for days, that forward Markus Naslund is retiring, walking away from the final year of his contract and giving the Rangers much-needed salary cap space.
NBC offered a brief preview of "The Jay Leno Show," the network's forthcoming 10 p.m. comedy program, during a presentation to advertisers in New York on Monday.
Early Monday morning, a black Ferrari F430 crashed into the Sbarro restaurant on 47th Street in Times Square while filming a stunt for "The Sorcerer's Apprentice," a movie starring Nicolas Cage.

Supermodel Stephanie Seymour says she won't be attending tonight's gala for the "Model as Muse" show. "Azzedine has made my dress for every single ball," Seymour said this afternoon. "I had a fitting in Paris. But then he called me over the weekend and asked me not to wear the dress. I will still make my donation to the Met, but I won't be going."

The runaway success of English soccer teams on the fields of Europe - and on the financial balance sheets - has prompted top clubs in Italy to follow suit in an effort to secure their own sporting and financial futures.

For those from a certain place at a certain time, the enduring memory of Jack Kemp is that of Kemp the quarterback, wearing the blue shirt of the Buffalo Bills with the white No. 15 on his back, leading his team in a late-game rally before a roaring crowd at the long-vanished War Memorial Stadium.

The electricity in my neighborhood in south Baghdad has been very bad for the last five years. Until recently, we did not get electricity more than 40 minutes every five hours, and sometimes we did not get it at all, although recently it has improved and we now get five hours a day.

With the Global Financial Crisis prompting the closure of one of its three venues, Australian Fashion Week was only a two-ring circus this season. But that didn't stop a wave of new faces, and others who have tended to be conspicuous by their absence from making an appearance this time around. New York Fashion Week refugees Sass & Bide, Willow and Aurelio Costarella opted for low-key presentations instead of shows, with Willow designer Kit Podgornik presenting her embellished cocktail dresses suspended over Sydney Harbour from the swings on an old fig tree on the grounds of Carthona, a gothic mansion in Darling Point.

Richard M. Aborn, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan district attorney, has recently gained some momentum. He has received endorsements from a former police commissioner, William J. Bratton, and from several elected officials, and on Monday, he released his first detailed policy paper, a five-point plan for combating gun violence in Manhattan.

In 1609, the high-seas explorer Henry Hudson stumbled upon an island, where 400 years later public officials would devise a series of elaborate events and tie-ins to honor his discovery. One of the most noticeable is a plan to move the nation's largest Fourth of July fireworks from the East River to the river bearing his name.The news, quietly announced last week by Macy's and noted on the NewYorkology blog, has some city residents wondering whether all this celebration of Mr. Hudson has finally gone too far.

Skechers, the footwear company known for its inexpensive but fashionable shoes, has expensive taste when it comes to some things. In the proxy that the company filed last week, it disclosed spending $140,000 on a car.

WASHINGTON - After a brief but lively internal debate, the Obama administration has decided not to seek an immediate phase-out of hydrofluorocarbons (HFC's), a potent group of climate-warming gases, under a treaty aimed at protecting the ozone layer.

After President Obama announced that Fiat was taking a 20 percent stake in Chrysler on Thursday, Fiat's chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, acknowledged his company's desire to buy Opel, G.M.'s German subsidiary, publicly for the first time. News of a Fiat-Opel deal gained momentum, and by the end of the weekend Fiat's interest grew to include G.M.'s other European brand, Saab. In a nutshell, Fiat is attempting to transform itself from a regional European automaker to a major global player.

You've probably accumulated several different e-mail addresses over your years online. You might have an address for work, an address for your personal life, an address you got when you were in college-and perhaps a few more that you've forgotten about, too. It can be quite a chore to check each of these inboxes separately, which is why most e-mail gurus suggest using a universal inbox-a single address that collects messages from each of your various online profiles. This way, you get all your e-mail in one place.

Oh now I get it. To really love white asparagus, you peel it within an inch of its life, and cook it until it's limp, so that its essentially fibrous nature is diminished. Then you cover it with about a pound of a mixture of butter, eggs and herbs -- kind of a broken Hollandaise -- and serve it. Of course with that kind of sauce you would become fond of frozen asparagus grown in a greenhouse on the moon.

The Ducks-Red Wings game yesterday, settled early in the third overtime period on Todd Marchant's goal, won't go down in history as a Stanley Cup playoff classic. But it did raise a discussion on Montreal radio's Morning Show over the Team 990 about long OT's.

Our sister blog, ArtsBeat, has a posting up that flows out of the Summer Movies section in last Sunday's paper. In a cover piece, New York Times film critics A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis wrote a series of "memos" to Hollywood executives, telling them - in the notes form favored by the short-attention-span entertainment industry - exactly what they thought needed to be done to improve the quality of American movies. ArtsBeat is asking if anyone else out there was some thoughts on the subject - in memo form -that they'd to contribute to the worthy cause.

The Yale economist Robert Shiller wrote on Sunday about the ubiquity of depression scares. He noted that the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index has logged what looks like four "depression scares" since 1951 -- that is, occasions where a significant portion of survey respondents said a period of widespread unemployment or depression was coming soon.

Filene's Basement, the century-old retailer known for selling deeply discounted clothes and accessories by the likes of Gucci and Calvin Klein, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Delaware on Monday for the second time in 10 years. In court papers, Filene's said it would sell 17 of its 25 stores, including its flagship in Boston, to Crown Acquisitions for $22 million.

But there are efforts underway to bring new life to two of the city's central train stations, if not turn them into destinations in their own rights.

At a press conference in Rome on Sunday - just one day before an invitation-only screening there of "Angels & Demons" - director Ron Howard said that the Vatican had quietly worked behind the scenes to hobble his efforts to shoot the Tom Hanks thriller. A Vatican spokesman said the charges were just an attempt to drum up publicity for the expensive blockbuster. Based on the Dan Brown novel, it is the prequel to "The Da Vinci Code," to which the Vatican came out strongly against when it opened in theaters. Thus far, though, the Vatican has been keeping fairly quiet about "Angels & Demons" - despite widespread misgivings among some Catholic leaders who believe Mr. Brown's religious thrillers are thinly disguised attacks on the church. Reuters was at the press conference, too. "Angels & Demons" is due to open in U.S. theaters on May 15.

As much as you might want to shake your fist at New Jersey Transit -- this time for a disabled train in the tunnel on a rainy Monday morning -- you gotta love Clever Commute, the site of commuter-generated, e-mailed or text status reports about train delays. It's especially delightful when they call NJT out on their tendency to blame Amtrak for their troubles. At 8:54, after some chatter about delays, we hear from the 8:04 eastbound train: "Conductor claims it's an Amtrak train failure in tunnel! Can anyone confirm it's the 7:23 NJT train that broke down?" Three minutes later: "It's the 723...I'm on it - just hooked up the rescue engine." Busted! -- TINA KELLEY

Nascar: Kyle Busch is off to another strong start. Busch won his third Sprint Cup race of the year on Saturday at Richmond International Raceway in Virginia. It was also the 50th win of his career. He jumped into the lead after a late restart, passing Carl Edwards and Jeff Gordon on successive laps. Denny Hamlin, Busch's teammate, who grew up close to the track, led for the most laps. But according to The Washington Post, a mistake in the pits with 100 laps remaining cost him six positions. Tony Stewart finished second. Jeff Burton was third. Busch also won the Nationwide Series support race on Friday night.

Remember Madonna's Material Girl video? A begowned pre-Madge Madge channels Marilyn Monroe, is plied with diamonds by a dancing troupe of tuxedoed beefcakes, and ends up getting wooed by a man (played by Keith Carradine) proffering daisies and a lift in a dusty pick-up truck. Madonna, in her own way, could have been offering tips about how to date in a recession: Keep it simple. Don't break the bank to impress. And, whatever you do, don't give the girl diamonds -- at least not on the first date.

BAGHDAD -- Three construction workers, one from New Jersey, center, and two from India. The men are employed by KBR, Inc., the American engineering and construction company that was formerly a subsidiary of Halliburton and then called Kellogg Brown & Root. The Houston-based company is the largest American contractor in Iraq, providing food, housing and other services to American troops. The workers seen here are setting up Containerized Housing Units ("CHUs") that are surrounded by blast walls on Camp Union III in Baghdad. The containers will be inhabited by soldiers and civilian contractors.

When Marlene Dietrich left for Hollywood in the early 1930's, the Nazi officials who had been wooing her turned to Zarah Leander, a Swedish singer and actress, also known as "the singing horse" because of her ample frame. Though she refused to socialize with leading party members, and rumors persist that she was actually a Communist spy, Leander nevertheless became a tool of the German propaganda machine, entertaining troops and civilians alike while the country slipped ever further into self-created ruin. (Leander would later repeatedly claim to have been a "political idiot.") It's more than a little ironic then that in 1983, the campy anarchist Nina Hagen, who was "dishonorably discharged" from the Free German Youth group at age 12, recorded one of Leander's most famous songs, "Ich weiss es wird einmal ein Wunder geschehn" ("I Know One Day a Miracle Will Happen"), a song often believed to be a plea to persevere in time of war. Hagen's operatic pyrotechnics and theatrical get-ups in this video are divine and probably not the miracle that Leander had in mind.

Liverpool beat Newcastle, 3-0, to stay 3 points behind Manchester United in the English Premier League title race. Liverpool’s 22nd victory of the season gives it 77 points from 35 games.
Russia routed Latvia, 6-1, on Sunday, sealing a spot for the United States in the men’s world hockey quarterfinals. Sweden earned a spot with a 4-1 victory against Switzerland.
Among the Kentucky Derby entrants, only Gary Stute, the trainer of the fourth-place finisher, Papa Clem, said for certain he was heading for the Preakness Stakes, the second leg of the Triple Crown.
The government is digging itself deeper into debt, but the market for Treasuries is not infinite and interest payments are expected to balloon.
Chris Pizzotti, who finished No. 2 in Crimson history in completions, percentage and yards, hopes to be around come training camp to fight on the undercard for a roster spot.
Why the Federal Reserve must start to demonstrate the kind of courage and independence it has not recently shown.
Upset by an article in The Record, the Hackensack University Medical Center retaliated by removing ads and blocking newspaper sales before backing down.
The new government wants to reorient Israeli foreign policy away from a prospective Palestinian state and toward the rising threat from Iran.
The Pentagon has done little to collect at least $100 million in overcharges from the defense contractor KBR, two senators said.
Advertising is showing fewer “skilled” doctors and “caring“ nurses, and a more YouTube-influenced sketch of what hospital care is like for patients.
A teeing ground rules quiz.
Pakistan’s poorest families have turned to Islamic schools that feed and house children while pushing a militant brand of Islam.
As everyone knows, golf is going green, which, in a twist, actually means more brown grass. But now there is a green eco-friendly golf bag.
You’re in the trees. All you want to do is punch the ball out toward the fairway. You keep hitting other trees or duffing it short. What to do?
Bulletproofing has become a middle- and upper-middle-class obsession, especially in São Paulo, a city notorious for roadside assaults and kidnappings.
For family dealerships that have tied their names to Pontiac for generations, the closing of the brand hits hard.

New York City Ballet has bounced back into ebullient form.

“Waiting for Godot” will be extended another week, and “Hair” is planning a national tour.

The American Composers Orchestra offered a program of premieres by Lukas Ligeti and Derek Bermel and the New York premiere of the Guitar Concerto by Robert Beaser.

A look back at the good, the bad and the ugly from an entertaining and exhausting first round.
New releases from Ciara, Akron/Family and Crocodiles.

Senator Arlen Specter said he would not rubber-stamp White House policies and would vote against his new party, the Democrats, on “matters of conscience.”

HINTERBUCHNER--Ladislav P.,M.D., 86, died on May 1, 2009. Larry, to his friends, was professor emeritus of neurology at the State University of New York, Health Science Center, in Brooklyn. He was the founder and the Director of the Department of Neurology at The Brooklyn Hospital. He was a superb teacher and mentor to generations of students and residents. He was active in numerous medical societies including the Kings County Medical Society and the Academy of Medicine of Brooklyn, having served as the President of the Society and later as the Chairman of the Board of Trustees. He also was active in the Medical Society of the State of New York and was a Delegate from New York to the American Medical Association. He was a senior member of the Medical Club of Brooklyn and was honored this year becoming an Honorary Member, based on his many years of service and loyalty to the ideals and tenets of the Medical Club. In 2000, he was the recipient of the Ellis Island Medal of Honor. He practiced in Westchester for more than twenty years and was loved and trusted by his patients. Throughout his professional career he distinguished himself and brought honor to himself and to his colleagues. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends and community. Larry is survived by his beloved wife of fifty-four years, and by a loving extended family. Visiting Wednesday, May 6th, 3 6pm, Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY 10580. Phone: 914-967-0129. Funeral mass Thursday, May 7th, 11am at The Resurrection Church, 910 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY 10580. 914-967-0142.

AKRON/FAMILY ''Set 'Em Wild, Set 'Em Free'' (Dead Oceans) Akron/Family has moved quickly. It started out on record in 2005 as an experimental folk band, alternately zealous and floppy. A year later, on ''Meek Warrior,'' it connected with the jazz drummer Hamid Drake, singing chant lyrics and reaching bliss. On ''Love Is Simple'' in 2007, it gathered itself into a good, if precariously uncentered, rock band: conceptually overstuffed, goofy with enthusiasm for full-throated group singing, ritual rhythm and West African guitar music, running them all together in carefully staged freak-outs.

A memorial service for the jazz trumpeter Freddie Hubbard, who died on Dec. 29, will be held on Monday at 6:30 p.m. at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, in Manhattan. Scheduled speakers include the drummer Ray Appleton, the bassist Larry Ridley and the writer Stanley Crouch. The trumpeters Wynton Marsalis, Eddie Henderson, David Weiss and Roy Hargrove; the pianist George Cables; and the tenor saxophonist Billy Harper are among those expected to perform.

DUFAULT--Joan Pyle, Died on April 23rd at the age of 83 after a long illness. She was born in Bern, Switzerland on November 1, 1925 to Mita Waller and William Scott Pyle. Joan came to the U.S. where she attended Radcliffe College. Joan married Peter Kane Dufault in 1946 and raised a family. She was a photographer and received her MFA from the Pratt Institute of Art. She published a collection of photographs and interviews on the elderly entitled "Vintage". She was also an actress and won the Uta Hagen award. The government's economic stimulus package includes oodles of money -- more than $30 billion -- for high-technology projects like health information technology, smart electric grids and broadband networks for rural communities. But the money isn't flowing yet, and to start individual projects requires upfront investment for planning and design. I.B.M. announced on Thursday that its big finance unit would set aside $2 billion for bridge financing for high-tech infrastructure efforts likely to qualify for federal grants and incentive payments under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.

Do you treat your iPhone as a guilty pleasure? You're not alone. A new report from Compete surveying the behavior of 600 smartphone users found that 73 percent of iPhone owners used their mobile devices primarily for personal reasons, like entertainment. By comparison, 59 percent of owners with other types of smartphones -- from manufacturers like HTC, Research in Motion and Nokia -- primarily used their devices for business and work-related needs.

CIARA ''Fantasy Ride'' (LaFace/Zomba) There's nothing solid about Ciara, the sinewy Atlanta R&B singer whose whisper has floated above and dripped onto some of the most crooked soul music of the last five years. Invariably, though, those songs were more emphatic than Ciara is. Like liquid -- or better, gas -- she merely fit her singing to the container provided.

CROCODILES ''Summer of Hate'' (Fat Possum) Crocodiles, a San Diego duo, caused a stir in the indie blogosphere late last year, even before releasing an album or signing to a label. What started it all was a peer review: No Age, a big fish in the Los Angeles art-punk pond, listed the Crocodiles tune ''Neon Jesus'' as one of the year's best songs. Soon the band -- Brandon Welchez on vocals, Charles Rowell on guitar -- had plans to release its debut, ''Summer of Hate,'' on Fat Possum.

HAYES--Stephen Craig (Gideon), November 13, 1956- May 1, 2009. Triple-Threat Producer/Singer/Actor, Stephen Craig Hayes aka Steve Gideon of West Hollywood, California passed away on May 1, 2009, after an arduous battle with cancer that he fought with courage, humor and song. Stephen Hayes grew up in Virginia and North Carolina, where his love for theater began when he was just a boy. He went on to graduate from Harvard University and The Boston Conservatory of Music, before embarking on a career in musical theater. Steve gained national attention as one of the original cast members of the world-wide theatrical sensation Naked Boys Singing. In 1999, Hayes made theater history by securing permission to stage (and star in) the first same-sex production of Stephen Sondheim's Marry Me a Little which The Hollywood Reporter described as "a thoughtful, touching and charming show that attains all of the complexities of the essential early Sondheim", Hayes' other credits include Nite Club Confidential, for which he appeared in productions in New York, Boston, Long Beach and Los Angelos (where he appeared alongside Scott Bakula in a record-breaking run) and the musical revue All Night Strut. In the 1990's Steve released his first CD "Feels Like Home", with two original compositions, and was working on a new album, The Happening, based on music from his recent cabaret show of the same name. While Steve has appeared in countless cabaret shows, he also donated his talents to appear in shows such as Annie Get Your Chip and Beach Blanket Boozer, benefits for the West Hollywood Recovery Center. He is survived by his long time companion Bernard Vyzga of West Hollywood, CA, his father Luby Hayes (of Denver, NC), his sister Pam Poole (of Richmond, VA), his brother Ronald Hayes (of Gainesville, FL), as well as his beloved Dachshund LP, and many, many close friends and fans. Steve requested that donations be made in his memory to the West Hollywood Recovery Center, (www.thewhrc.org).

GOLDSMITH--Dolores. I Am Not There. Do not stand at my grave and weep, I am not there I do not sleep, I am a thousand winds that blow, I am the diamond glints on snow, I am the sunlight on ripened grain, I am the gentle autumn's rain, When you awaken in the morning's hush, I am the swift uplifting rush of quiet birds in circled flight, I am the soft stars that shine at night, Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there, I did not die.

HOCHHAUSER--Herbert, passed away April 30th at age 87. Loving husband to Aidalina Campillo, proud father of Michele (Ricardo) Bertran, Esq. and David (Janet) Hochhauser, M.D., beloved "Ipa" to grandchildren Nicole and Danielle Bertran, and Elizabeth, Rachel, Vanessa, Herbert Michael, Kimberly, Madeleine and Kevin Hochhauser. A World War II veteran, NYU and Columbia University School of Social Work graduate, he spent his career at Altro Health and Rehabilitation Services. He was a gentleman, ardent social justice supporter, avid NY Times reader and bridge player. Always interested in world affairs and the lives of others, most of all he deeply loved his family. "Uncle Herbie" is also survived by sister Connie Weinstock and many nieces and nephews. He was one of the most principled, kind and generous people anyone will ever know and will be forever missed.

9 P.M. (Sundance) THE HIP HOP PROJECT (2006) Chris Rolle, above, was born in the Bahamas but spent most of his teenage years alone and homeless in Brooklyn. In 1999 he founded the Hip Hop Project to offer adolescents like him the opportunity to write and record. This documentary, directed by Matt Ruskin, follows Mr. Rolle, known as Kazi, as he coaches a group of New York teenagers in the art of transforming their experiences into rhyme. Jeannette Catsoulis, writing in The New York Times, called the film ''vibrant and soulful.'' 9 A.M. In the universe of some 107 million blogs last week, the hot topics were mostly related to the potential of a swine flu pandemic. There was also room for the 100-day milestone of the Obama administration and the N.F.L. draft, which was also the most popular cable TV broadcast last week. Among the notable cultural events were the death on April 25 of the ''Golden Girls'' star Bea Arthur (above center, with Rue McClanahan, left, and Betty White) and free comic book day, a day of giveaways at neighborhood comic book stores on Saturday.

FRIEDBERG--Irving, was the kindest and most decent of men. He was a loving husband, married for 55 years to wife Rachel, and a loving father to three boys, Eric, Victor and Robert. His wife, sons, and six grandchildren survive him. Irving was a World War II veteran, a graduate of the City College of New York and Brooklyn Law School. He practiced maritime and then personal injury law for five decades.

OLSEN--Jean Rohrbach, 83, of Salisbury, CT died Monday afternoon April 27, 2009 at Noble Horizons. She was the wife of the late A. William Olsen, Headmaster of Hotchkiss School from 1960-1980. Passionate about politics, books, and women's and children's rights, Jean leaves behind a legacy of caring for others. She played a large role in Hotchkiss School's successful leap to co-education in 1974. She was a member of the New York City Cosmopolitan Club where she served as chair of the Membership Committee and was on the Club's Board of Governors. Jean was appointed by Governor Ella Grasso to serve on the Connecticut State Board of Higher Education from 1977 to 1983. A Memorial Service will be Saturday, May 9, 2009 at 11am in the Salisbury Congregational Church Main St. Salisbury, CT

SHEERIN--Edward V.,of Manhattan and Jupiter, FL, died at home on Saturday, May 2, 2009. Mr. Sheerin, 75, was born in Floral Park, NY. Mr. Sheerin was well known both in the United States and the Caribbean for his many roles associated with the hotel industry. He attended Hofstra University, and later his profession took him to Antigua, West Indies. From 1966 to 1987, he was the Managing Director of the Curtain Bluff Resort, where he was also a shareholder. While living in Antigua in 1967, he was a Founder of Antigua Sailing Week, a world-renowned international sailing regatta. Later for several years he was Chairman of the event, and throughout his life, a member of the Race Committee. He was also a member of the New York Yacht Club. From 1984 to 1986, he was the President of the Caribbean Hotel Association. From 1995 to 2000, he served as Vice-President and Treasurer of Quality Divisional Management, a group that owned the master franchise for Choice Hotels throughout the Caribbean. He was Chairman of the Board of Directors of Island Provision Limited, an Antiguan based food distribution company. Mr. Sheerin was known for his generous hospitality, both in his professional and personal life. He was beloved, not only by friends and family, but when he returned to the Curtain Bluff Resort, as he did often, the staff always greeted him affectionately by welcoming him home. He is survived by his wife, Virginia Wattiker Sheerin. Friends may pay respects at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, New York, NY. Monday, May 4, 2009, from 4pm until 8pm. A funeral Mass will be held on Tuesday, May 5, 2009, at 11am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY. Donations in memory of Edward V. Sheerin can be made to the Pain and Palliative Care Service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, New York, NY 10021.

''SWINE flu'' last week was the most searched term on Yahoo, displacing ''American Idol.'' The Wikipedia page Swine influenza had 1.3 million pages views on Wednesday and on Thursday. At the same time, Twitter was estimated to be transmitting 125,000 tweets a day mentioning swine flu -- 1 percent of all the chatter there -- overwhelmingly from users concerned about the outbreak's potential to do harm rather than, say, describing stomach pains.

BRAJER--Shirley Dorothy Feinstein Samuels, died April 20, 2009 at North Shore University Hospital-Manhasset, Palliative Care Unit. She was born in Passaic, New Jersey and lived in East Rutherford, NJ. After her graduation from East Rutherford High School, she went to work for the Prudential Insurance Company in Newark then transferred to its New York City, office. After the untimely death of her beloved husband, Arthur Samuels, she worked at The Bayside Kindergarten and Nursery School until her retirement at age 80. She was an active member of The Bayside Jewish Center for many years and was responsible for running the gift shop. Her interests included swimming and all needlework, especially knitting. She is survived by her daughter Susan M. Samuels, her sister Barbara A. Kraskin, four nephews, Dr. Stuart C. Feinstein of Santa Barbara, CA, William J. Feinstein, Berkeley, CA, Richard Kraskin of East Brunswick, New Jersey, and Charles Michael Adler of Calabasas CA, one niece Cheryl Adler of Nanuet, NY and her second husband Irving. Hers was a presence that will be sorely missed by those who truly loved her. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband Arthur Samuels. To honor her donations may be sent to UJA- Federation of New York Tribute Cards 1-212-836-1486.

Updated, 9:07 p.m. | State leaders have agreed on a breakthrough deal for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which would increase fares and tolls by 10 percent, officials in Albany said. Gov. David A. Paterson, Assemby Speaker Sheldon Silver, and Senator Malcolm A. Smith, the leader of the State Senate, announced the details on Tuesday night.The base subway and bus fare will rise to $2.25, from $2, under the deal. Major service cuts will be averted, as will a larger planned fare and toll increase of 20 to 30 percent. The cost of a monthly MetroCard would rise, possibly by about $8, from $81. Other fares and tolls, including tickets on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad, would go up about 10 percent.

There are only two weeks between the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, which presents a challenge to trainers. Click above to watch snippets of "Ice People," a documentary about scientists working in Antarctica, which makes its premiere on the Sundance Channel tonight at 10 p.m. (Eastern time). Shot over the course of four months by the filmmaker Anne Aghion, it follows a team of researchers from North Dakota State University as they scoured ancient lakebeds looking for signs of life, and as they turned up evidence of a formerly green Antarctica whose climate changed abruptly 14 million years ago. Giacomo took advantage of a collapsing pace to win the 2005 Kentucky Derby. My friend John Wilke died late last week. He was only 54, and had spent the great bulk of his career at The Wall Street Journal as an investigative reporter. As I was talking to mutual friends over the weekend, mourning, we all kept noting how his passing wasn't just a personal loss, as huge as that was. His death meant that an important but dwindling role in American journalism -- the investigative reporter -- had lost one of one its finest practitioners.

More than 200 parents crowded into the South Orange Maplewood Board of Education meeting last night to voice their support for Tom Gibbons, the principal of South Mountain Elementary School and Annex, in South Orange. The school board did not act on his contract last night; it will be resolved after a tenure hearing to be held before June 30.

In a speech in Toronto on Friday, Lord Nicholas Stern, the economics adviser to former British Prime Minister Tony Blair and the author of a massive 2006 study on the cost of climate change, outlined in broad strokes a potential international deal to confront global warming -- the objective of a global conference on climate change to be held in Copenhagen this December.
Warren E. Buffett says investing isn't about being a genius -- it's about keeping it simple.
The recently opened Ed Benedict skatepark in Portland, Ore., offers some unusual sights: Trees. And plants. And rocks. And dirt.

The Federal Trade Commission has begun an inquiry into whether the close ties between the boards of two of technology's most prominent companies, Apple and Google, amount to a violation of antitrust laws, The New York Times's Miguel Helft and Brad Stone reported, citing several people briefed on the inquiry.

Can tomatoes be taught to make antiviral drugs for people who eat them? Would zapping your skin with a laser make your vaccination work better? Could malaria-carrying mosquitoes be given a teensy head cold that would prevent them from sniffing out a human snack bar?
About 10 of the 19 largest U.S. banks being stress tested will be instructed by regulators to raise more capital, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with official talks.

Citigroup may put more employees on commission or offer them larger base salaries as it tries to retain key staffers without running afoul of laws limiting executive pay at banks that receive government funds, Reuters reported.
Tata Motors received more than 203,000 fully paid bookings for its new Nano subcompact car in just two weeks, the company reported in a statement on Monday.
Greenlight Capital, it seems, likes the look of Ford's chances amid a severe downturn among Detroit automakers.

The Obama administration's plan to restrict or shut down several widely used tax loopholes takes away many - but not all - of the sophisticated tax moves commonly used in corporate America, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning writes.
A Securities and Exchange Commission official said Monday said he advocated S.E.C. registration for hedge fund advisers, Dow Jones reported.

American International Group is expected to post a first-quarter loss on Thursday, but the embattled insurer's results will not trigger a new capital injection from the U.S. government this time, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the matter.
TPG passed on 140 leveraged buyout deals in recent months, eschewing the L.B.O. model in favor of debt investing, The Financial Times reported, citing a letter to the private equity firm's investors.
A Chicago investment banker said Monday he is assembling a group to bid on the bankrupt Sun-Times Media Group.

JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon said Monday that the bank may be called on by regulators for more acquisitions, as the U.S. banking sector is likely to see further consolidation, Reuters reported.

President Obama on Monday called for curbing offshore tax havens and corporate tax breaks to collect billions of dollars more from multinational companies and wealthy individuals.

Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, the publicly traded hedge fund firm, said Monday that it had narrowed its first quarter loss this year to $81.9 million, compared with a $268.1 million loss in the first quarter of 2008.

A government program designed to help unfreeze the credit markets may have been slow to get out of the gate since its March launch, but it seemed to be picking up speed Monday, The Wall Street Journal reported. Companies rushed to issue nearly $10 billion of bonds eligible for the Federal Reserve's Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, or TALF, The Journal said.

UBS remained wary on its immediate outlook as it braced for the full impact of the recession after confirming it had posted a first-quarter loss on yet more write-downs and client withdrawals, Reuters said.

Minority shareholders in the companies that John Malone has sought to acquire by building controlling stakes over time have sometimes felt aggrieved by the results. But the effort to merge DirecTV with a subsidiary of his Liberty Media conglomerate hasn't proved so difficult for the remaining shareholders of the American satellite broadcaster, Breakingviews notes.
Platinum Equity said Monday it completed its purchase of The San Diego Union-Tribune from Copley Press, the private equity firm's first venture in newspaper publishing.

A Taiwanese business tycoon has criticized the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett's decision to invest in a Chinese battery and car maker that faces a lawsuit accusing it of stealing trade secrets, The Associated Press said.
