Connecticut added its name on Monday to the list of public entities that have fired Aldus Equity Partners, the pension advisory firm whose founder was accused of securities fraud by federal and state authorities last week, The New York Times's Leslie Wayne reports.
MGM Mirage, the hotel and casino company controlled by billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian, said its first-quarter profit fell 11 percent as revenue fell short of expectations.
Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

In the comments here last week, several of you asked about miscarriage: Why won't people stop saying "you can try again soon"? What is the "right" amount of grief? Are there more miscarriages now or does it just seem that way? What to tell the children about the baby who will not be?

"Wash your hands when you shake hands; cover your mouth when you cough," President Obama urged us at last Wednesday's news conference when discussing the swine flu. "I know it sounds trivial, but it makes a huge difference. If you are sick, stay home. If your child is sick, keep them out of school. If you are feeling certain flu symptoms, don't get on an airplane, don't get on a -- any system of public transportation where you're confined and you could potentially spread the virus." Is such modest, homespun advice merely good manners, or is it a moral injunction?

After wringing concessions from all but one of The Boston Globe's labor unions, The New York Times Company on Monday postponed its threat to start the process of closing The Globe, leaving the newspaper's immediate future resting on talks with the largest union, the Boston Newspaper Guild.
The German government on Monday said it would consider helping the Italian automaker Fiat grab control of Opel, the German subsidiary of General Motors, the ailing American giant.

Hewlett-Packard's plans to hire a top executive away from rival EMC hit a legal snag on Monday when a Massachusetts court issued an order temporarily barring him from starting his new job, Reuters said.
Today's idea: The disastrous Treaty of Versailles ending World War I lives on 90 years later -- in 21st century Chinese nationalism.

I have a sort of love-hate relationship with large music festivals. On the one hand, they provide a chance to spend an entire day (or two or three) seeing a slew of disparate music acts, usually outdoors, and there's great people-watching. But the thought of weaving through crowds upwards of 60,000 just to get a tiny glimpse of the stage, the insanely long portable toilet lines and the mountains of trash that inevitably form, pose a strong rationale to skip them altogether and stick to small, intimate venues. Some upcoming shows in London offer a chance to see a few of the same bands in both festival and club settings.
Do I need any special ports on my laptop to use a mobile broadband card?

One of the nation’s most sought-after recruits was charged with misdemeanor breaking and entering after the police found him walking out of a vacant house in Raleigh, N.C. John Wall, 18, was detained briefly April 27, but not arrested. He and two other teenagers were cited. The police said there was no indication of forced entry at the empty house or that anything was taken.

The United States got two goals from defenseman Ron Hainsey but lost to Switzerland, 4-3, in overtime at the World Championships in Bern, Switzerland. The Americans will face Finland in the quarterfinals, avoiding a possible matchup with Canada by extending the game to overtime. Switzerland was eliminated despite winning. The host nation needed a victory in regulation to advance and held the lead twice. It won 13 seconds into the extra period.

Filippo Simeoni has handed back the winner’s jersey he claimed at last year’s Italian national championship in protest of his Ceramica Flaminia team’s being left out of this month’s Giro d’Italia. His team was not deemed strong enough to invite to the Giro.

Aston Villa ended a 12-game winless streak, beating Hull by 1-0 in the English Premier League to clinch a berth in next season’s Europa League. John Carew scored his 14th goal of the season in the 34th minute, helping Villa (16-9-10) move into fifth place, 2 points ahead of Everton (15-9-11). Hull created few problems for Brad Friedel, Villa’s American goalkeeper.

Swimmer Jessica Hardy had her two-year suspension for a failed drug test reduced to one year by the American Arbitration Association, allowing her to return to competition this summer. Hardy, 22, withdrew from the United States Olympic team last August, nearly a month after she tested positive for a low level of clenbuterol, a prohibited anabolic agent, at the Olympic swimming trials. Hardy qualified for the Beijing Olympics in two individual events — the 100-meter breaststroke and 50 freestyle — and the 400 free relay. Hardy’s suspension ends July 31, which is after the United States team selection meet for the world championships in Rome.

The Pittsburgh Steelers released inside linebacker Larry Foote, a move expected since Foote asked to be traded or cut. Foote had started every Steelers game the past five seasons, including their Super Bowl victories last season and after the 2005 season. But he was unhappy with coming off the field on passing downs for Lawrence Timmons, a 2007 first-round draft pick. With Timmons ready to start, Foote told the Steelers last week that he wanted to be traded or released. The Steelers cut him after failing to find a team willing to deal a draft pick for him. ¶Government investigators began sorting through the Dallas Cowboys’ flattened practice facility, trying to figure out why fierce winds sent the tentlike structure crashing down during a rookie workout session. Twelve people were hurt, including the special teams coach Joe DeCamillis, who underwent surgery Monday to stabilize a fractured vertebra in his neck. The most seriously injured was Rich Behm, the team’s 33-year-old scouting assistant, who was permanently paralyzed from the waist down after his spine was severed. The assistant athletic trainer Greg Gaither, 35, had surgery on his fractured right leg. DeCamillis and Gaither were expected to leave the hospital this week. collapse.

The America’s Cup champion Alinghi of Switzerland asked a New York court to disqualify the American syndicate BMW Oracle Racing as Challenger of Record if it does not provide details about its 90-foot trimaran within 30 days.
Nickname for an area of Paris home to a number of Afghan refugees.

I'd originally meant to write a post updating one from last year on the best hockey-themed commercials from around the world. But in going through YouTube clips for new ads I stumbled across a Russian phenomenon I was not previously aware of -- bears playing hockey:
One of the coolest exhibitions in town is the joint show by the artist Christian Schoeler and Another Man magazine at Modern Art on the still gritty warehouse stretch on Vyner Street.
The latest skirmish in the storied rivalry between the Yankees and the Red Sox was a verbal tussle on between Yankees’ Manager Joe Girardi and Tim Bogar, Boston’s first base coach.
Photos from the revival at Yale Repertory Theater.
During an interlude to a cold, rain-delayed game at Yankee Stadium, Manager Joe Girardi lit a fire under his chilled players, but it was not enough to prevent a Red Sox victory.

Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee, said House Democrats intended to add more than $4 billion for new equipment to the Obama administration’s request for a supplemental war-financing bill but would not provide $50 million the administration sought to pay for the closing of the Guantánamo Bay prison. Mr. Obey said the money was omitted because the White House had not yet spelled out what it intended to do with the Guantánamo detainees. Pushing back against the administration’s proposed military procurement cuts, Mr. Obey said the committee’s war-financing bill would add $2.2 billion to buy eight C-17 cargo planes and $904 million for 11 C-130 cargo jets. It also would add $2.2 billion for combat vehicles, including 225 Stryker vehicles for evacuating wounded soldiers and 35 to support engineering operations.

The teenager in Chicago who was arrested after dressing up like a police officer and going on patrol earlier this year is in trouble with the law again, after being accused of dressing like an adult to steal a car from a dealership. A spokesman for the Chicago Police Department, Roderick Drew, said the 15-year-old donned a suit and went to the dealership to take a test drive. Mr. Drew said an employee had to jump-start the car, and when he left to return equipment, the boy drove off. Mr. Drew said the boy crashed a short time later. The boy faces charges that include criminal trespass to a vehicle.

A federal judge has ruled that a history teacher at a Southern California public high school violated the First Amendment when he called creationism “superstitious nonsense” in a classroom lecture. The judge, James Selna, issued the ruling after a 16-month legal battle between a student, Chad Farnan, and his former teacher, James Corbett. Mr. Farnan’s lawsuit said Mr. Corbett had made more than 20 statements that were disparaging to Christians and their beliefs. The judge found that Mr. Corbett’s reference to creationism as “religious, superstitious nonsense” violated the First Amendment’s establishment clause. Courts have interpreted the clause as prohibiting government employees from displaying religious hostility. Mr. Corbett teaches at Capistrano Valley High School.

Lori Drew, a Missouri woman involved in a MySpace hoax on a 13-year-old neighbor girl who committed suicide, should be placed on probation for one year and fined $5,000 for her misdemeanor convictions, probation officials recommended. The recommendation was included in court documents filed by Ms. Drew’s lawyer, Dean Steward. Ms. Drew, left, could face up to three years in prison and a $300,000 fine on three counts of accessing computers without authorization. She is scheduled to be sentenced on May 18. Prosecutors said Ms. Drew violated MySpace service rules by helping create a fictitious teenage boy on the social networking site and sending flirtatious messages from him to Megan Meier, a neighbor in suburban St. Louis. The fake boy then sent Megan a message saying the world would be better without her. She hanged herself a short time later. The trial was held in Los Angeles because the servers of the social networking site are in the area.

An obituary on Wednesday about the Russian ballerina Ekaterina Maximova reported that most authorities gave her age as 70, but the obituary also noted that the English-language announcement of her death on the Bolshoi Theater Web site said she was 71. The discrepancy was the result of the Bolshoi’s mistranslation of the same announcement in Russian, which said she died “during the 71st year of her life.” She was indeed 70.

The South Orange Maplewood Board of Education voted tonight to approve a list of district employee contracts for next year which did not include the principal of South Mountain Elementary School and Annex.

The Charles Blow column on Saturday, about religious affiliation, misstated the percentage of Catholics and Protestants who became unaffiliated. The percentage for Catholics is 14, not 4, and the percentage for Protestants is 13, not 7.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about various theater developments misspelled the given name of the actress who wrote and will perform “Nightingale,” which the Manhattan Theater Club will present off Broadway in its 2009-10 season. She is Lynn Redgrave, not Lynne.

An obituary on Saturday about Maxime de la Falaise, a model, designer and muse of designers, referred incorrectly at one point to her mother, Rhoda Birley. As the wife of a knight, she was Lady Birley, not Lady Rhoda.

An article in the Escapes pages on Friday about the Hood Canal in Washington State misstated the driving time from Seattle to the canal. Because the Hood Bridge is closed for repairs until mid-June, the drive to the northwestern part of the canal would take more than an hour and a half; getting to the town of Quilcene, for example, would take about 2 hours 20 minutes. (The drive to the part of the canal featured in the article is not affected by the bridge closing and would still take about an hour and a half.).
The absence of a roof was relevant Monday as rain fell at Yankee Stadium and delayed the start of a game against the Boston Red Sox.

A picture caption on Friday with a film review about “Revanche” carried an erroneous credit. The picture, showing two actors in the film, should have been credited to Lucas Beck/Janus Films, not IFC Films.
Philippe de Montebello, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, testified about Brooke Astor’s deep involvement in the museum, at the trial of her son, Anthony D. Marshall.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a singer who performed at Terminal 5 on Saturday night rendered her stage name incorrectly and misstated the title of one of her hit singles. She is Lady Gaga, not GaGa, and the song is “Just Dance,” not “Let’s Dance.”.
The New York City schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, gives partial credit to publicity about the admissions process.

An article on Thursday about budget cuts at the J. Paul Getty Trust misidentified the objects that the Getty Research Institute, one of the trust’s divisions, will be transferring to other institutions, in addition to cutting library hours and acquisitions. They are databases, not collections.

A museums column on Saturday about the Jüdisches Museum Berlin and the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe, also in Berlin, misstated the title of W. Michael Blumenthal, a Jüdisches Museum official. He is the director, not a curator.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about Jay Leno’s return to “The Tonight Show” after canceling two appearances because of illness misidentified the television show on which Nancy O’Dell, who appeared in a videotaped skit with Mr. Leno, is a host. It is “Access Hollywood,” which she co-hosts with Billy Bush — not “Insider.”.
With classes canceled at six schools after a swine flu scare, students missed crucial exams and extracurricular activities while parents scrambled to find baby sitters or alternative programs.

An article on Monday about the new Henry Miller’s Theater, on 43rd Street, misstated the surname of an architect whose firm, Cook + Fox Architects, designed the theater. He is Rick Cook, not Fox. (His partner is Robert Fox.).
It comes as no surprise to hear that many of Albany’s politicians would rather go with a cheap political fix for public transit than one with a long-range approach.

India’s phenomenal growth in recent years was largely financed by foreign investments and loans, which have fallen sharply in the downturn.
Fighting pushed a peace deal in the Swat Valley and Buner close to collapse on Monday and drew warnings from insurgents of more attacks.

Lucas Radebe, a former star defender with Leeds United, now serves as a roving ambassador for South African tourism as the country prepares to host next month’s Confederations Cup and next year’s World Cup.
Dwight Howard had 16 points and 22 rebounds, helping the Orlando Magic hold off the Boston Celtics, 95-90, in Game 1 of their Eastern Conference semifinals.

After 9/11 and the SARS outbreak, many companies refined strategies for dealing with business travel and remote work spaces.

An effort to repeal Colorado’s death penalty law stumbled Monday in the State Senate, leaving supporters scrambling to find votes as the end of the session looms.

In an interim report, the committee that is contemplating the future of Brandeis University’s Rose Art Museum made no recommendation to keep the museum’s director, Michael Rush, whose contract expires in June, The Boston Globe reported. The Future of the Rose Committee was formed in March after widespread condemnation of a decision by the university’s trustees in January to shut the museum with the goal of selling its art to raise money. In a six-page report, the committee offered praise for Brandeis administrators, but the head of the museum board was skeptical of the committee and its findings. “It reminds me of something like a Stalinesque show committee,” Jonathan Lee, the chairman of the Rose’s board, told The Globe. “These are all hand-picked people by the administration. We didn’t get to pick who represents us.”.

Veterans of the original Woodstock festival, including Levon Helm, Paul Kantner and Country Joe McDonald, have organized a scheduled flashback of sorts: they and several other musicians who performed at that 1969 concert will play a new show on Aug. 15 to celebrate the festival’s 40th anniversary, The Associated Press reported. The new concert, whose lineup also includes the Woodstock alumni Big Brother and the Holding Company, Ten Years After, Canned Heat and Mountain, will be held at the Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in upstate New York, where the first Woodstock festival took place. Mr. Helm, who played at Woodstock as a member of the Band, will be appearing with his Levon Helm Band, and Mr. Kantner, who performed at Woodstock with Jefferson Airplane, will appear at the anniversary concert with the upgraded Jefferson Starship.

The chief justice of Malawi’s Supreme Court adjourned a hearing on Monday in which a lawyer for Madonna continued to press her efforts to adopt a second child from that African country, Agence France-Presse reported. Chief Justice Lovemore Munro said he would rule later on Madonna’s appeal of a lower court’s decision to deny her request to adopt a 3-year-old girl, Chifundo James, because the singer had not resided in Malawi for at least 18 months, as required by law. Madonna did not appear at the hearing.

Although it’s hardly been a secret that the music of Trent Reznor and his band, Nine Inch Nails, isn’t appropriate for all age groups, a Nine Inch Nails-themed application for the iPhone was rejected by Apple because it contained potentially offensive content, the Web site Pitchfork.com reported. Over the weekend, Mr. Reznor published an e-mail message that he received from Apple’s iPhone developer group at his official Web site, nin.com. Apple wrote in the message that it would not carry the Nine Inch Nails iPhone application because it offered a streaming version of the band’s song “The Downward Spiral,” which Apple said was “objectionable content,” according to the e-mail message. On his Web site, Mr. Reznor wrote that though he loved Apple products, he urged the company to “think your policies through.” Apple did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
Scientists have discovered where and when the toothed wrack and the common periwinkle took hold, and where they came from.

A lawyer for Roman Polanski said the director would not appear at a hearing this week at which a judge has offered to reconsider evidence against Mr. Polanski in a decades-old sex case, The Associated Press reported. Judge Peter Espinoza of Los Angeles County Superior Court set a deadline of Thursday for Mr. Polanski to return to the United States, before the judge would consider whether he was the victim of prosecutorial misconduct in a 1977 case in which Mr. Polanski was found guilty of having sex with a 13-year-old girl. In a document submitted to the court Monday, Mr. Polanski’s lawyer wrote that his client’s appearance was irrelevant to whether his constitutional rights had been violated.

The Pulitzer Prize-winning play “Ruined” picked up another honor on Sunday night when it won the Lucille Lortel Award for outstanding play, the Off-Broadway League announced. The play, whose author, Lynn Nottage, won the Pulitzer Prize for drama last month, tells the story of a group of women living through a civil war in Congo; Saidah Arrika Ekulona (above right, with Condola Rashad) was named outstanding lead actress for her performance in it. Other Lortel winners include John Douglas Thompson, who was named outstanding lead actor for his performance as the title character in Theater for a New Audience’s production of “Othello”; David Cromer, who was named outstanding director for “Our Town,” which also won for outstanding revival; and “Fela! A New Musical,” which was named outstanding musical.

CHANIN--Paul. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Paul Chanin of Palm Beach, FL, whose nearly two decades of service to and staunch support of the ATS and the Technion are a source of inspirational leadership. During his tenure, Mr. Chanin served in numerous capacities on the regional and national boards of directors, including former Palm Beach Chapter president and chairman of the board. He was a life trustee of the ATS Board of Regents, as well as a full member of the Technion International Board of Governors and a former chairman of its Physical Development Committee. His deep commitment to health, human needs and science was evidenced by his funding with his late brother, Marcy, of the Paul and Marcy Chanin Genetic Engineering Building. Together with Marcy and his wife, Leona, Mr. Chanin also funded the Marcy and Leona Chanin, Paul R. Chanin Family Dormitory, and two graduate fellowships. He was an engineer and real estate executive, and CEO of the Paul R. Chanin Family Foundation. A Technion Guardian, Mr. Chanin had achieved the highest level of commitment. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, Jeffrey and Steven, his beloved sister-in-law Leona, and to the entire Chanin family. A private service will be held, and the family has requested that memorial contributions be sent to the American Technion Society, 249 Royal Palm Way, Suite 502, Palm Beach, FL 33480. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. Laser, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice-President

GORDON--Albert H. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and the staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) note with great sorrow the death of Albert H. Gordon, who served for almost 50 years (from 1957 until 2006) as a member of our Boards of Overseers and Managers. As one of the leading figures on Wall Street in the 20th century, he contributed his financial acumen to help MSKCC remain fiscally healthy. Mr. Gordon served as a member of our Joint Finance and Funding Committee, where his encyclopedic knowledge of investment markets was especially helpful and greatly appreciated. A lifelong fitness enthusiast who completed his first marathon at age 81, Mr. Gordon advised those who wished to live a long life to "keep moving." We will deeply miss Albert Gordon's zest for life and his unflagging passion for all he held dear. The entire Memorial Sloan-Kettering community will be forever in his debt. We extend our sincere condolences to the Gor- don family. James D. Robinson III Honorary Co-Chairman Douglas A. Warner III Chairman Richard I. Beattie Vice Chairman Louis V. Gerstner, Jr. Vice Chairman Harold Varmus, MD President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

A memorial service for the playwright Horton Foote, who died on March 4, will be held Monday, May 11, at 4 p.m., at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center. Scheduled speakers include the playwrights Edward Albee, Romulus Linney and Mr. Foote's daughter Daisy; the actors Matthew Broderick and Harris Yulin; the director Michael Wilson; the producers André Bishop of Lincoln Center Theater, Casey Childs of Primary Stages and James Houghton of the Signature Theater; and Mr. Foote's sons, Horton Jr. and Walter. In addition, Meghan Andrews and Betty Buckley are scheduled to sing, and actors including Robert Duvall, Elizabeth Ashley, Devon Abner, Roberta Maxwell, Estelle Parsons, Lois Smith and Mr. Foote's daughter Hallie are to perform scenes from the plays of Mr. Foote in which they appeared on stage. The public is invited and admission is free. The doors will open at 3:30 p.m.

SPITZER M. James "Jimmy," 97 (almost 98) died peacefully on May 4, 2009 at the home of his son surrounded by all of his family who admired and loved him, his sons, daughters-in-law, grandchildren and great-grandchild. He was ill for only a brief time, living life fully up to the very end reading to improve his mind, debating politics, playing golf and cherishing his many friendships. He was born in New York City and resided in Purchase, NY and Longboat Key, FL. His wife and partner in life predeceased him 11 years ago, but his love and devotion to her never ended. After graduating from Evander Childs High School at the age of 16, he attended Fordham University and Fordham Law School at night graduating in four short years at the age of 20 in the Class of 1932. He maintained a close relationship with the University always grateful for the education he received and the opportunities it afforded him and he took full advantage of them. Fordham has recognized his achievements and honored him for his many accomplishments. When he started college, he began working as an office boy at the Offices of Charles Strauss to enable him both to pay for his education and to provide support for his mother and father, Minnie and Pop. That was the beginning of a career that spanned 77 rewarding years, all with the same law firm. He became its senior partner and it became Spitzer & Feldman. Throughout his long career, he unwaveringly adhered to the highest standards of ethics and of service to his clients. He was the quintessential advocate for his clients and for his friends and they were equally committed to him. He was a role model and mentor to the lawyers who worked with him at the firm including his son Jim who joined him in 1970. He was proud of their relationship as colleagues and partners as well as father and son. As dedicated as he was to his work, his first priority was always his family. He was a devoted and dutiful son supporting his family from the time he graduated Evander Childs High School. His older brother, Arthur, whom he idolized died at only 16 and it was a loss Jimmy always mourned. Through one of his many friends he met the beacon of his life Irma Louise Spitzer of Montgomery, Alabama and in 1938 they married. Their romance was forever, a fairy tale of enduring love, mutual respect and total commitment. He was a loving and always proud father, demanding but fair; he became the mentor and best friend to his two sons, M. James of Manhattan and Thomas Neil of Portland Oregon who are forever grateful for the joy and guidance their Dad bestowed for all these years. No less was his love for his daughters-in-law (he regarded them as daughters) Sheri Lagin and Mardi Schnitzer Spitzer. He was smitten with, admired and adored his three granddaughters, Ashley Fagan, Jessica Spitzer and Jamie Spitzer and he was proud of all of their considerable accomplishments. He was generous to them in every way, providing advice when asked, an ear to listen when needed and emotional support and love always. He brought joy to and enriched their lives. He made them laugh, he told them stories of growing up in a different age and he encouraged them to pursue their dreams and to fulfill their goals and he assisted them in every way possible. His three granddaughters knew how special he was and how lucky they were. They spoke with him daily often expressing their love, asking for advice or just laughing, kidding and tormenting him. Most recently he became a great-grandfather of Cameron Fagan, Ashley's son and he was overwhelmed by re-experiencing the wonders of life. The joy he experienced immediately after Cameron's birth in holding and bathing Cameron was a cherished milestone in a life which spanned six generations and was lived to its fullest. Jimmy loved life and those he encountered along the way including not only his peers and contemporaries, but making friends with people of all ages and from all walks of life. He always had stories to tell and jokes to share, advice to give, and a willingness to listen. He was passionate about playing golf and was a member of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale and the Longboat Key Club in Florida. His golfing buddies were his best friends. He was an avid reader of biographies and history, mainly American, always striving to improve his mind. He followed political events closely and was always ready for a spirited discussion. Most of all, his generosity, his joy of life, his humor, his laughter, his openness, his intellect, his respect for others, his belief in what each of us can accomplish attracted friends wherever he went. People wanted to be with him, to listen and to talk and he fully enjoyed the company of each of them and their times together. He was a remarkable man who embraced life with an unbounded optimism for what tomorrow will bring. In his multitude of roles, son, husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, counselor, advocate, friend, he will be missed and admired forever and forever. Services will be at 9:30am Wednesday, May 6 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. 212-362-6600. Contributions in the memory of M. James Spitzer may be made to Fordham University School of Law, 140 West 62nd Street, New York, NY 10023.

In the latest installment of the soap opera gripping Italy, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, 72, on Monday demanded an apology from his wife, Veronica Lario, 52, a day after she told Italian newspapers that she wanted a divorce. Mr. Berlusconi, left, said he did not think the couple could reconcile. ''I don't think so. I don't know if I want it this time,'' Mr. Berlusconi said in an interview that appeared on Monday in the leading Italian daily newspaper, Corriere della Sera. ''Veronica will have to publicly apologize to me. And I don't know if that will be enough.'' In recent days, Ms. Lario has criticized her husband for cavorting with younger women and for his center-right coalition's plans to nominate a slate of attractive women to run for the European Parliament.

In a further demonstration that ''Family Guy'' has become the center of the pop culture universe, the Fox network has ordered a second season of the ''Family Guy'' spinoff ''The Cleveland Show'' before a single episode has been broadcast, The Hollywood Reporter said. The spinoff, which will focus on Cleveland Brown, the next-door neighbor of the ''Family Guy'' protagonist Peter Griffin, was scheduled to make its debut this spring with a 13-episode run. But Fox decided to hold the premiere until the fall, while ordering an additional nine episodes. With its commitment to a second season of ''The Cleveland Show,'' Fox has ordered an additional 13 installments, bringing its total tally to 35 episodes. Fox also said that it had ordered a second season of ''Fringe,'' its supernatural investigation series.

CHANIN--Paul, age 82, born in NYC and recently of Palm Beach, Florida passed away peacefully on April 30, 2009, with his son Steven beside him. He was the second child of Sylvia and Irwin Chanin, brother of Marcy, Doris, and Joan, just-like-a-brother to Leona, father of Steven and Jeffrey, father-in-law of Karen, grandfather of Seth and Julia, first husband of Carol Chanin Stone and former husband of Carol Shellington Chanin. Paul attended school in New York at the Ethical Culture Fieldston School and Cornell University. After a hiatus during WWII as an Air Force and Navy cryptographer in the Pacific theater, Paul returned to graduate from NYU in 1948 with a BCE in civil engineering. In 1955 he joined the Navy Reserve and worked in Naval Intelligence. Paul joined his father in business for about a decade, then charted his own course as a real estate developer, civil engineer, self-taught architect, and restaurateur. He spent half his life in New York, and then experienced life, work, and love in the desert (Las Vegas), the mountains (Aspen), and the seaside (Palm Beach). A devoted philanthropist, Paul also served on the Boards of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, the American Technion Society, and the Simon Weisenthal Center Museum of Tolerance. Were he writing this, Paul would thank the Fieldston Eagles, the New York Jets, the Denver Broncos, the Miami Dolphins, Long Island Sound, and the Florida Gulf Stream for decades of enjoyment. Paul was a peaceful, generous and kind man, with a fine eye for design, a big smile, and an even bigger heart. We will miss him dearly.

A WWII veteran and gifted educator, "Mr. Lynch" taught at Sarah Hale High School in Brooklyn, St. Peter's College and St. Joseph's University. GORDON--Albert. The Board of Directors of Achilles International expresses their sorrow at the passing of Al. In 1983 he became a founding Board Member. For many years he hosted our Board meetings at Kidder. In 1986, at the age of 85, he ran the NYC Marathon as an Achilles Guide, carrying a backpack and crutches for the disabled athlete he accompanied. Each year we present the A. H. Gordon award to someone who has been personally successful and has a strong interest in others. He will be missed.

McGOVERN--Raymond E.,81, of Tarrytown, died suddenly on May 2, 2009. Beloved husband of the late Anne Marie McGovern, and cherished father of Raymond (Skip) E. Jr. (Becky); Keith (Ana); Laura Kiss (Tom); Jeff ( Linda); the late Pamela McGovern; and Kyle (Anita). Ray graduated Cum Laude from St Francis College, Brooklyn NY in 1951. Ray was first in his class upon graduation Magna Cum Laude from St. John's School of Law where he was Editor of the St. John's Law Review. Ray served for two years in the United States Navy. Ray also played semi-professional basketball for the Bridgeport Bombers in the Industrial League. Ray began his distinguished legal career at Boal, McQuade and Fitzpatrick in New York City. Ray then joined BBDO Worldwide Inc. where he served as Secretary, General Counsel and as a Member of the Board of Directors. Ray went on to become Secretary, General Counsel and served as a Member of the Board of Directors of Omnicom Group Inc., the largest holding company of advertising agencies in the world. Ray retired in 1995. Ray was a member of the Board of Trustees for the Village of Tarrytown for eighteen years, and served as Police and Recreation Commissioner. He was active and coached in Tarrytown Dad's Club baseball, Scarlets football and CYO basketball. He recently joined the Tarrytown Senior Center. In his retirement years he enjoyed traveling abroad, his workouts at the gym, eating with family at his favorite Italian restaurant. Ray especially enjoyed spending time with his fifteen beloved grandchildren: Emma, Molly, Mac, Keegan, Kyler, Kane, TJ, Ally, Ashley, Michael, Mitchell, Kyle, Maddy, Jack, and Ella Rose. Visitation will be at the Dwyer & Vanderbilt Funeral Home, Monday May 4th at 2-4pm and 7-9pm, and Tuesday May 5th at 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The funeral will be held Wednesday, May 6th at 10am at the Transfiguration Church in Tarrytown, NY, interment Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.
LEVITT--Lorraine, of Forest Hills, New York. Passed away on May 4th, 2009. Services will be held at "Schwartz Bros" 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY Tuesday, May 5th at 12:30pm. 401-954-4568.

Italy Last week, 19 of the 20 teams in the top-flight Serie A voted to form a new, independent league similar to the English Premier League unless a new agreement could be reached guaranteeing them more control over television revenue after a new contract is agreed to in time for the 2010-11 season. Serie A would leave the second-tier, financially strapped Serie B teams to fend for themselves or accept a new financial arrangement.

O'LEARY--Thomas H.,of Saratoga, WY died peacefully on April 28, 2009 at the Eisenhower Medical Center, Palm Springs, CA. The son of Arthur J. and Eleanor Howard O'Leary of New York City, Tom was born on March 19, 1934. After graduating from Holy Cross College in 1954, Tom joined the Marine Corps where he served as an aviator and achieved the rank of Captain. In 1961, Tom received an MBA from the Wharton School of Finance. Tom joined the Missouri Pacific Corporation as Assistant Treasurer in 1965. By 1974, Tom had become President of the company and served on its Board of Directors. He joined Burlington Northern, Inc. in Seattle in 1982 as Vice Chairman and was a Director of BNI from 1982 to 1992. Tom was elected President and CEO of Burlington Resources, Inc. in 1989 and Chairman of the Board in 1990. He retired from BRI in 1997. He was also a director of The Kroger Company and BF Goodrich. Tom is survived by his wife, Cheryl Westrum O'Leary, by five of his six children by his previous marriage: Timothy M., Thomas H., Denis A., Daniel G., and Mary Frances and by his sister, Susan. His eldest son, Mark E., died in March of this year. The funeral Mass will be said at 11am on Tuesday, May 5 at St. Ann's Church, Saratoga, WY, followed by burial at Saratoga Cemetery. Memorial Masses are scheduled at 11am Thursday, May 7 at Sacred Heart Church, Palm Desert, CA and 10am on Friday, May 15 at Annunziata Catholic Church, St. Louis, MO. Instead of flowers, contributions may be made to the College of the Holy Cross, Worchester, MA, the Wyoming Stock Grower's Agricultural Land Trust, Cheyenne, WY and Rescue Me Dog, Saratoga, WY.

SELVIN Renalee, of New York City, passed away on Saturday, April 25, at the age of 59 after a long and valiant battle with multiple sclerosis. She was a graduate of Boston University and the New England College of Optometry and practiced as a Doctor of Optometry for many years. She had a deep compassion for all animals and was always surrounded by her beloved pets. She was extremely athletic, a strong sports enthusiast, an avid tennis player, a voracious reader and a lover of music. Renalee will always be remembered for her inner strength and quick sense of humor. She is survived by her loving parents Eris and Seymour Zuckerman of Hohokus, NJ and her dear sister Joan Zuckerman of New York City. Contributions can be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 733 Third Ave., NY, NY 10017.

WINIK--Norman, 87, died peacefully in Palm Beach on May 4th. Adored and adoring husband of Elaine Cappel and the late Carolyn. Loving father of Mary Jacobs and the late Betty Winik, beloved stepfather of Peter and Barbara Siris, Margot and Kenneth Helphand, and Penny Goldsmith. Wonderful grandfather to Samuel, Benjamin, Jill, David, Joshua, Carolyn, Deborah, Alexander, and Tracy. Great-grandfather of Zoe, Jonah, Liela, and Addison. Yale class of '43, Marine Corps captain in WWII. Our undying thanks to Linda Chow for her love and devotion. This was a man who made the world better for everyone he knew. Go in peace my love. Funeral Wednesday, at L. J. Morris at 11am, 5411 Okeechobee Blvd, West Palm Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, please remember him in donations to UJA-Federation of New York or the West Palm Beach Jewish Federation.

SULLIVAN--Margaret (Peggie) nee Donovan, passed away on Sunday, May 3 from complications after heart surgery at the age of 78. A resident of Manhattan and Sea Girt, NJ, Peggie received her undergraduate degree from Fordham University as well as a masters degree from New York University. A dedicated educator, she worked for the New York City Public Schools for over 40 years. Throughout her long and distinguished career, she touched the lives of countless students, teachers and colleagues. Among the subjects she taught were speech, drama and English as a second language. She served as an Assistant Principal, supervisor, speech at John Jay High School in Brooklyn and Newtown High School and William Cullen Bryant High Schools in Queens. Later in her career, she worked for Citywide Services supervising teachers of children with special needs. She also spent several years as an adjunct professor at Bronx Community College. After her retirement in 1994, she and her husband traveled the world. Peggie was a proud member of the Irish-American Cultural and Heritage Association of the Board of Education. She was devoted to her family and is survived by her beloved husband of 48 years, Dan, her daughter Cathy, son Daniel, daughter-in-law Edie, and grandsons Joey and Chris. Friends may pay respects at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue on Wednesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A requiem Mass will be held at the Church of The Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71st Street, New York City at 11am on Thursday. In lieu of flowers, donations in Peggie's memory may be made to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, 1011 First Ave, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10022.

10 P.M. (Sundance) ICE PEOPLE (2008) The filmmaker Anne Aghion travels to the ''deep field'' of Antarctica to follow four geologists, above, as they search for evidence of an alpine lake ecosystem formed around 20 million years ago, when the continent was rich in vegetation. While witnessing the beauty of the six-month Antarctic night as it subsides, Ms. Aghion also documents the harsher reality of the scientists' painstaking fieldwork and the often strained dynamics between the handful of academics and the much larger support staff at the American-run McMurdo research station. Writing in The New York Times, Nathan Lee called Ms. Aghion a ''canny portraitist,'' adding: ''The film's hesitation, lack of rhetorical inflation and commitment to humble observation generate a tough poetry. 'Ice People' sticks in the mind.'' 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Reports from the 2009 Tony Award nominations; the cast of ''Billy Elliot'' performs.

Norman joined Elaine in her love for Israel and dedication to UJA-Federation's mission to strengthen the Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Elaine; to Norman's daughter, Mary Jacobs; to his stepchildren, Penny Goldsmith, Peter Siris (Barbara Wyckoff), and Margot Helphand (Kenneth); to Norman's nine grandchildren; and to his four greatgrandchildren. TIGUE--John Joseph, Jr. Morvillo, Abramowitz, Grand, Iason, Anello & Bohrer, P.C. mourns the loss of our beloved partner, Jack Tigue. Jack was a brilliant lawyer, but more importantly, he was a great friend and wonderful colleague to us all. Jack was so full of life and so thoughtful that it is hard to imagine our world without him. Our love and deepest sympathies go out to his wife, Grace, his four sons, John, James, Peter, and Michael, and his sister, Mary Sarratt. Jack received an LL.B. from New York University School of Law and became a certified public accountant in 1966. After serving as an Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, he became a partner at a law firm which ultimately bore his name, Kostelanetz, Ritholz, Tigue and Fink. Jack joined Morvillo Abramowitz as a principal in 1994. An expert on tax matters, Jack was the co-author of the book Dirty Money: A Study in White Collar Crime, and co-authored the "Tax Litigation" column in the New York Law Journal. He held the positions of lecturer at Harvard University Law School, adjunct professor of law at Fordham Law School, and adjunct assistant professor of law at New York University Graduate School of Law. He frequently wrote and spoke on tax fraud and related subjects, and regularly appeared as a commentator on Court TV. He was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. He was recognized in The International Who's Who of Business Lawyers, The Best Lawyers in America, New York Magazine The New York Area's Best Lawyers, and New York Super Lawyers. We will always miss Jack. He was an irreplaceable person.

GOLDSMITH--Dolores Our beloved friend Dolores-a woman of substance-your goodness and friendship will remain in our hearts forever. Heartfelt sympathy to Gail, Jimmy, Michelle, Bob, Ileen, Nate and grandchildren. With Love, Maxine & Skip, Leslie & Bernie, Ina & Sol.

GORDON--Albert H. Passed away on May 1, 2009 at the age of 107. The Board of Trustees, Women's Board and staff of The Boys' Club of New York express their deepest sympathy to BCNY Trustee, John Gordon and his family. Al Gordon was elected to the Board of Trustees in 1958. For over 50 years he gave unsparingly of his time and talents to help many thousands of boys to a better life. His generosity, good humor and commitment to the welfare of youth will be remembered by us all with deep affection. As friend, supporter and Trustee, Al Gordon embodied The Boys' Club of New York's core principles of character, civility and community. The Boys Club of New York

Two accidents on the stage of “American Idol” had the show scrambling to ready itself for its live broadcast on Tuesday night. But the effects were barely visible to television viewers, who were told little more than that “we had a couple of things happen here on the set” by Ryan Seacrest, the show’s host, near the start of the show.

Plácido Domingo withdrew in midperformance at the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “Die Walküre” on Tuesday evening and was replaced by Gary Lehman in the role of Siegmund, the Met said. Mr. Domingo advised the staff before the performance that he was not feeling well, the Met said, and a curtain announcement was made that Mr. Domingo would perform in spite of this, but Mr. Lehman was put into costume and makeup as a backup. He stepped into the production right away when Mr. Domingo withdrew about 40 minutes into the performance. The Met said that Mr. Domingo had recovered and was traveling to Paris to prepare for “Cyrano de Bergerac.”

After learning that he was being sued by a former bandmate, Jeff Tweedy, the lead singer and songwriter of the rock group Wilco, has responded as the front man of a mellow alternative band might be expected to, with more bemusement than rage. On Monday, Jay Bennett, who recorded with Wilco from 1994 to 2001, sued Mr. Tweedy, saying he is owed royalties from his work with the band, including its albums “Yankee Hotel Foxtrot” and “Being There” and a documentary film, “I Am Trying to Break Your Heart.” In a statement on the Web site of Paste magazine, Mr. Tweedy wrote: “I’ve read the news and I honestly have no idea what these claims are based on. It was such a long time ago. Aside from everything else, I’m being sued for not paying someone for appearing in a movie I didn’t produce. Go figure. I am truly sad it has come to this. I am equally convinced, however, that I have done nothing wrong and that this will be handled fairly and swiftly.”

If you’re a television producer waiting to learn if your show is being renewed for next season or just an entertainment news junkie dying to know how “American Idol” is stacking up against “Dancing with the Stars,” these have been frustrating days: due to a systems breakdown at Nielsen Media Research, the company that measures television viewership, no ratings have been available since Saturday.

Updated | 6:15 p.m. Bob Dylan‘s winning streak on the Billboard chart continues this week: His new album, “Together Through Life” (Columbia), became his second in a row to open at No. 1, far ahead of competition from pop standbys like “Hannah Montana,” Rascal Flatts and Rick Ross. “Together Through Life” sold 125,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan; three years ago “Modern Times” became Mr. Dylan’s first album in 30 years to reach the top slot.

A coming version of the television game show “1 vs. 100″ may be missing its familiar host, Bob Saget, and the opportunity to win a top prize of $1 million, but it will be a step forward in the merging of television and video games, The Hollywood Reporter said. Microsoft announced on Tuesday that it would bring a special edition of the show, in which a single player competes in a trivia contest against a 100-person team called the Mob, to its Xbox Live videogame network. This interactive version of “1 vs. 100″ is expected to start in the next six weeks, and will be shown on Friday and Saturday nights as part of Microsoft’s Xbox Live Primetime series, when it expects less competition from traditional television programming. Players can win Xbox Live points for use on the gaming network and enter a sweepstakes for other, tangible prizes.

Mark Fuller, the nightclub mogul and assisting manager of the group Iron Maiden, is marketing his latest investment, the new 30-room Sanctum Soho in central London, as a warren for rock stars. Not only can you have what you want when you want it, like made-to-order Nike sneakers, but you can also, at any hour of the day, "get drunk, smoke on the roof, talk amorously to your girlfriend in the hot tub - and no bouncer is going to tell you off," as Fuller recently told The Observer. When I stayed last week, I didn't actually see any rock stars or groupies boozing in the roof garden. LONDON | A stalwart fixture of the summer season in London is the BBC Proms, one of the world's biggest classical music festivals. For these promenade concerts, now in their 115th year, the main venue since 1941, the Royal Albert Hall, welcomes up to 6,000 concert goers every evening from July 17 to Sept. 12. The name Proms derives from the fact that for every concert there are tickets for up to 900 "Prommers" (those who are willing to stand in a central arena) at only 5 pounds, or $7.55 at $1.51 to the pound.

Over the last decade or so, it has become increasingly evident that one reason girls in Africa drop out of school is menstruation. Jim Balsillie — the co-chief executive of Research In Motion, the maker of BlackBerry — is looking to buy the Coyotes and move them to Ontario. The International Olympic Committee said the global economic crisis had reduced its financial investments by $34 million. The fall in financial markets has sliced about 8 percent off the I.O.C.’s overall reserves of about $400 million since January 2008, Jacques Rogge, the I.O.C. president, said in an interview with the Web site insidethegames.com. The I.O.C. also said it could lose up to $4.8 million in the Ponzi scheme tied to the disgraced financier Bernard L. Madoff. ¶Darryl Seibel announced his resignation as the chief communications officer of the United States Olympic Committee. He is the fourth executive to leave the organization since the end of the Beijing Games. Seibel, 41, said he would leave June 5 to pursue new professional opportunities, but would offer consulting help on some projects. usoc.

Cincinnati hired the Connecticut assistant Jamelle Elliott as its women’s coach. Elliott has spent most of the last two decades with the Connecticut program and Coach Geno Auriemma. As a player, she helped the Huskies win their first title, in 1995.

Last night at the Met, before the trumpet toot for dinner, I asked veteran models to tell the story behind some of their shoots. I happened to be in the 1960s room, standing next to a cover portrait of Marisa Berenson by Irving Penn when Berenson, dressed in a lovely pink Dior dress, entered with Vogue editor Hamish Bowles. I asked her about that photograph, and she gave a wonderful description of working for both Penn and Richard Avedon. Later, I talked to Carmen Dell'Orefice about an Edwin Blumenfeld cover, and then Twiggy and Stella Tennant, who recalled the scene behind an Arthur Elgort photo of her diving fully dressed (boots, too) into a swimming pool. Just as everyone was heading into dinner, I caught up with Lauren Hutton, who described working with Avedon and then explained how she thinks the fashion sitting has been changed by digital photography. Though at least one of the photo sessions took place 60 years ago, the models remembered them in detail.

An obituary by The Associated Press on Saturday about Jack Lohrke, a major league infielder who played with the New York Giants at one point, misstated the position of Don Mueller of the Giants during an October 1951 game against the Brooklyn Dodgers in which Bobby Thomson hit a pennant-winning home run in the bottom of the ninth inning. Mueller played right field — not third base, which is where Thomson played.

An obituary on Saturday about William A. Price, a reporter for The Daily News in New York who invoked the First Amendment, rather than the Fifth, when refusing to answer questions before a Senate panel in 1956 about his possible ties to the Communist Party, misstated his middle name. It was Addison, not Armstrong. The obituary also misidentified the state in which the town Plymouth Meeting, where Mary Knowles, who was indicted along with him, was a librarian. It is in Pennsylvania, not Massachusetts.

The Books of The Times review on April 23, about “Dragon Fighter: One Woman’s Epic Struggle for Peace With China,” by Rebiya Kadeer with Alexandra Cavelius, misstated the size of the Uighur and Tibetan ethnic minorities in China. Jay Bennett, a former member of the rock band Wilco, may not be trying to break his bandmates’ hearts, but he has filed suit against the group’s lead singer, Jeff Tweedy, saying that he is owed royalties from his work with the band, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Bennett, who filed his breach-of-contract suit in Cook County Circuit Court in Chicago on Monday, performed with Wilco from 1994 to 2001. He can be heard on its albums “Being There,” “Summerteeth” and “Yankee Hotel Foxtrot,” among others. In the suit, Mr. Bennett says that he received “infrequent partial payments” from the band’s income generated from sales and performances and that he is owed money from “I Am Trying to Break Your Heart,” a documentary about the making of the album “Yankee Hotel Foxtrot.” The members of Wilco have not responded to the suit.

A list of witnesses who could be called to testify against Woody Allen, below, in his lawsuit against the clothing maker American Apparel is becoming as familiar and self-referential as the director’s films. Reuters reported that in court papers filed on Monday, lawyers for Mr. Allen asked a court to prevent American Apparel from calling Soon-Yi Previn, his wife, and Mia Farrow, his former companion and Ms. Previn’s mother, at a trial scheduled to begin in New York on May 18. Mr. Allen is suing American Apparel, asserting that it improperly used a still image of him from “Annie Hall” in billboards and online advertisements. A lawyer for American Apparel has said that he would bring up elements of Mr. Allen’s personal history at the trial; the filmmaker’s lawyers said the tactics were “part of a brutish attempt to smear and intimidate Mr. Allen,” according to Reuters.

The pop singer Rihanna will not perform at a concert in Dubai scheduled for May 28, the same date that a court hearing is scheduled in Los Angeles for her companion, Chris Brown, The Associated Press reported. Yassin Matbouly, the managing director of an entertainment agency in the United Arab Emirates, said that he had been told by Rihanna’s management that “it was inappropriate timing for her to have a public concert” on that date, according to The A.P. In April, Mr. Brown pleaded not guilty to felony charges that he threatened and assaulted Rihanna during an argument in February. On Monday night, Rihanna made a public appearance at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute Gala in New York. Mr. Matbouly said he would try to reschedule the concert.

Two German art historians are challenging the legend of Vincent van Gogh’s ear, saying that the Dutch painter, top, did not slice off his left ear in a fit of madness but that he concocted the tale to protect Paul Gauguin, above, who cut off van Gogh’s ear with a sword, The Daily Telegraph of London reported. In a new book, “Van Gogh’s Ear: Paul Gauguin and the Pact of Silence,” Hans Kaufmann and Rita Wildegans say that van Gogh invented the story that his wound was self-inflicted to protect Gauguin, who they say attacked van Gogh during an argument as the two painters walked the streets of Arles, France. The historians also say that van Gogh’s suicide in 1890 was a result of his anguish over his falling out with Gauguin.

Carnegie Hall’s educational arm, the Weill Music Institute, is taking over the core programs of the Marilyn Horne Foundation, a charitable organization founded by the mezzo-soprano to support the work of young singers. In a news release, the two groups said that the transition would take place in July 2010 and that Ms. Horne, left, who created the foundation in 1993, would stay on as an artistic adviser. Among the programs that the Weill Music Institute plans to preserve is “The Song Continues”, a series of master classes and recitals at Carnegie Hall in which the institute has been a partner since 2004. Other foundation programs will be incorporated into Carnegie Hall’s Neighborhood Concert Series. In a statement, Ms. Horne said Carnegie Hall’s assumption of her foundation’s duties was “a natural path.”.

ROTHENBERG--Belle, 95, passed away peacefully on May 4, 2009 from complications of old age. Devoted wife of Isidore, loving mother of Gilda and Saul, beloved grandmother of Alissa, Anna and Eva. Hers was a long and productive life, working 20 years for the New York City Board of Education, High School Division, and held in high regard by all who knew her. Heartfelt gratitude to the owner and staff of Harbor House, Oyster Bay, where mom resided for the last four years. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York City Chapter.

PSAKI--Raoul Constantine, MD Raoul Constantine Psaki, a retired Army Colonel, passed away on Wednesday, April 29th. He is survived by his sisters Irene Sweeney, Beatrice MacDonald and Constance Ward, sons James and Michael Psaki, daughter-in-laws Anne Psaki, Josianne Collazzo and Eileen Medvey and granddaughters Jennifer, Stephanie and Kristen Psaki. He was married to his beloved wife, Mary Agnes Psaki for forty-five years until her death in 1987. After earning a medical degree from Georgetown University and completing his internship at Letterman Army Hospital in San Francisco, he was stationed as a medical officer with the 24th Infantry Division, serving in the Philippines during World War II. He later served as Chief Medical Officer of the 98th General Hospital in Neubrueke, Germany and as Chief Surgeon of the United States Army, Communications Zone in Europe and as commanding officer of the 819th Hospital Center in Orleans, France. He was responsible for the medical support of all United States Army Forces in France during the removal of these troops and the relocation of forces to Belgium, Holland, England and West Germany. His final tour of service, prior to retirement, was as Command Surgeon of the United States Army Flight Training Center in Savannah, Georgia. Following his retirement in 1968, he accepted a position as the Director of Rehabilitation Medicine at Pilgrim State Hospital in Long Island, New York and after serving several years finished his medical career as the Director of Rehabilitation Medicine at the VA Hospital in Northport, New York.

Just 45 days old and swaddled in pink, Sang Ruifeng already has a purpose in life: to bring to justice those responsible for the death of his 11-year-old brother. Ruifeng will have to ensure, his father said, that the Chinese government gives a full accounting for why thousands of students died in school collapses during the earthquake that devastated southwest China one year ago. The brother that Ruifeng never knew was among 126 students crushed to death in Fuxin No. 2 Primary School outside this lush farming town.

TIGUE--John Joseph, Jr. The Harvey and Locke families mourn the passing of Jack, who died at his home in NYC on May 3, surrounded by his sons, his wife and his sister. He fought an admirable and courageous seven month battle against esophageal cancer. We welcomed him into our large extended family after his marriage to Grace. He was a brilliant lawyer, a loving and fun husband, remarkable father, and wonderful uncle and friend. He loved to take his sons on wilderness adventure trips fishing, skiing and rafting. He and Grace went on countless trips around the world on foot, bicycle, boat, skis and just for pleasure. Together they enjoyed the company of many friends with whom they shared the cultural life of the City and the beauty of the mountains and ocean. He had many passions: the NY Yankees, animal welfare -- personified by his beloved dog, Charlie -- movies, books and tennis. He was particularly blessed with a superb sense of humor and could make a joke or story sing. He enjoyed life to the fullest, loved a good party, was reliable, intelligent, honest, kind and thoughtful. A service for Jack will be held at the All Soul's Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue on May 6, at 11 am with a viewing in the Chapel beginning at 10:30am. A burial will take place in Salisbury, CT in a private family cere- mony.

Voters on Tuesday elected Dave Bing, a former Detroit Pistons basketball star who had never run for political office, as the city's next mayor. Mr. Bing, the longtime owner of a local auto parts business, will serve the final eight months of former Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick's second term. Mr. Kilpatrick resigned in September, when he pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice and agreed to serve three months in jail for attempting, as part of an $8.4 million lawsuit settlement, to cover up an extramarital affair with his chief of staff.

Residents flooded out of the Swat Valley by the thousands on Tuesday as the government prepared to mount a new military campaign against Taliban militants and as a much-criticized peace accord with the insurgents fell apart. People crammed into cars and buses and headed south after the local government told residents to leave Swat before a government military offensive. On Sunday, black-turbaned Taliban fighters seized control of Mingora, Swat's capital.

Caitlin Victoria limbered up before auditioning for a spot at the School of American Ballet at Lincoln Center on Tuesday. Among the dozens of 7- and 8-year-olds who participated were Orianne Kaplan, left. Hundreds of children between 6 and 10 are auditioning this month for about 100 openings at the school, which has trained the majority of the dancers at the New York City Ballet. The school is celebrating its 75th anniversary.

The Easco Boiler Corporation has been making and repairing large steel boilers and tanks in New York since 1926. Richard Muller, Easco's director of sales, said the family-owned business makes sections at its factory in the Bronx, then assembles them at the installation site. ''We generally produce 200 boilers a year,'' Mr. Muller said, ''and have produced as many as 1,000 boilers in a year.'' Left, holes are drilled in steel plates used in boilers. Right, a welder works on a boiler component. Earlier pictures: nytimes.com/cityroom.

A report in some editions of the Rail horse racing roundup on Sunday about Kentucky Derby wagering misstated the payoff of the 23 winning $1 superfecta tickets, for which bettors had to select the first four horses in exact order of finish. It was $278,503.20, not $557,006.40. The report also misstated the next scheduled day of racing at Churchill Downs, where the pick 6 carryover prize is worth about $781,000. It is today; it was not on Sunday.

A performer warms up at Grand Central Terminal before an audition for a chance to participate in Music Under New York, a program of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that provides musical performances on New York City's subway and train stations. Article at nytimes.com/cityroom.

The pop singerRihanna will not perform at a concert in Dubai scheduled for May 28, the same date that a court hearing is scheduled in Los Angeles for her companion, Chris Brown, The Associated Press reported. Yassin Matbouly, the managing director of an entertainment agency in the United Arab Emirates, said that he had been told by Rihanna's management that ''it was inappropriate timing for her to have a public concert'' on that date, according to The A.P. In April, Mr. Brown pleaded not guilty to felony charges that he threatened and assaulted Rihanna during an argument in February. On Monday night, Rihanna made a public appearance at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute Gala in New York. Mr. Matbouly said he would try to reschedule the concert.

''Billy Elliot: The Musical'' opened on Broadway shortly after Election Day, at a moment when New York theater, like the nation, was full of uncertainty. Investors were skittish about putting on new shows in a recession, but theater industry leaders suggested that plays and musicals would be just fine if people had good reasons to buy tickets. Six months later the 2009 Tony Award nominations, announced on Tuesday, can be seen as rewards to the producers, actors and directors who served up those reasons. Those honored were about hope and survival (''Billy Elliot,'' ''Hair,'' ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone''), family and love (''Next to Normal,'' ''Shrek the Musical''), and stars taking risks (four actors making fools of themselves in ''God of Carnage,'' and Jane Fonda returning to Broadway after 46 years, among other memorable moments).

APPEL--Alfred, Jr. (born January 31, 1934), Professor of English Emeritus at Northwestern University, where he taught for over thirty years, died on May 2, 2009, in Evanston, Illinois, at 75, from heart failure. A service will be held at 11am, on Wednesday, May 6, 2009, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., NY, NY. He received his BA and Ph.D. in English Literature from Columbia University. A former student and a foremost scholar of Vladimir Nabokov, Mr. Appel published "The Annotated Lolita" (in print since 1970; rev. ed. 1991) and "Nabokov's Dark Cinema" (1974). Later in his career, he turned his attention to modern art in all its forms -- literature, photography, painting and music -- and published, all with Alfred A. Knopf, "Signs of Life" (1983); "The Art of Celebration: The Expression of Joy in 20th Century Art, Literature, Photography and Music" (1992); and "Jazz Modernism: From Ellington and Armstrong to Matisse and Joyce." "Jazz Modernism" won the 2003 ASCAP Deems Taylor Award for outstanding coverage of music. Appel also received a Fellowship from the Guggenheim Foundation; a Fellowship from The Rockefeller Foundation; and was awarded one from the National Endowment for the Arts as well. At the time of his death, Appel was deeply immersed in a new book about World War II and the effects upon the nation of subtle propaganda designed to prepare the public for the coming war. He was also working on a book about Louis Armstrong. Appel is survived by his wife of 51 years, Nina S. Appel, the Dean Emerita and Professor of Law at Loyola University School of Law in Chicago; his mother, Beatrice H. Appel of New York, New York; his two children, Karen A. (Gene) Oshman of Houston, Texas, and Richard Appel of Venice, California; four grandchildren (Stephen and Katherine Oshman and Gabriel and Grace Jandall-Appel); his sister, Elizabeth A. (Paul) Schaffer of New York, New York; and his brother, John Appel (Barbara Walkowitz) of Chicago, Illinois. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Mr. Appel's name to the Delaware Art Museum, 2301 Kentmere Pkwy., Wilmington, Delaware 19806.

Senator Arlen Specter, Republican-turned-Democrat of Pennsylvania, seems to be off to a bit of a rough start on the other side of the aisle. In his first two big votes as a Democrat, Mr. Specter voted against his new party, opposing the budget resolution supported by President Obama, and helping to kill a measure to allow bankruptcy judges to modify mortgage terms for homeowners.

He was our friend and our guide and was devoted to the strong bond of friendship between the people of the United States and Israel. We are grateful that in a life devoted to public service on behalf of the United States and to excellence in his sports and public interest concerns, he shared his friendship and leadership skills with so many others. Our thoughts and prayers are with Joanne, Jack, Jimmy and his 17 grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Kenneth J. Bialkin, Chairman Harley Lippman, President Charlotte K. Frank, Chair, Executive Committee

BEECHER--Robert W. 77, of 32 Mill Pond Road, New Castle, NH died Monday, May 4, 2009 at his home. Born in Boston and raised in Somerville, MA, Bob was drafted and served with the 25th Infantry Division in Korea. Assisted by the GI bill, he then attended Boston University's School of Management, graduating in three years, summa cum laude. Bob then passed the CPA exam with honors and commenced his professional career with KPMG, one of the Big Four accounting firms. When he retired in 1990, Bob had responsibility for the firm's U.S. practice and had been a member of KPMG's Board of Directors for 12 years. Other key positions he held were Managing Partner in White Plains, NY, 1968-1976, Managing Partner in Boston, MA 1976-1981 and Northeast Regional Vice Chairman, 1981-1984. During his career he was also involved in a variety of community organizations, including the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce, Boston Municipal Research Bureau, Museum of Science, Boston University, MA Foreign Business Council and Newton-Wellesley Hospital. More recently he has served on the Planning Board and the Budget Committee of the town he adopted in retirement, New Castle, NH, where he was elected a Selectman in 1998 and reelected in 2001 and 2004. Bob was also a Trustee of The Riverwoods Company of Exeter, NH, a continuing care retirement community from 1997 to 2008. He was Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Treasurer, Chair of the Finance Committee and a member of the Executive Committee. He thoroughly enjoyed his retirement years in New Castle and spent as much time as possible with his grandchildren, all of whom call him Grandpa Bob. He leaves his wife, Georgina M. (Canty); five children: Joy Emerson of Mansfield, CT, Gregory of Winchester, MA, Joel of Arlington, MA, Jennifer Cooper of Natick, MA, and Pamela Zeppieri of Glastonbury, Ct; nine grandchildren all of whom are special; a brother, Arthur of Scituate, MA and a sister, Ruth of Somerville, MA; also a niece, two nephews, and four great-nieces. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in Robert's memory may be made to Seacoast Hospice, 10 Hampton Road, Exeter, NH 03833-4806. Services are by the J. Verne Wood Funeral Home-Buckminster Chapel, Portsmouth. For online condolences please visit jvwoodfuneralhome.com

The Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday accused the father-and-son team that operated the Reserve Primary Fund of securities fraud, contending they had lied to investors when the fund ''broke the buck'' last fall and created a near panic in the money market fund industry. Bruce Bent Sr. and his son, Bruce Bent II, were charged in a civil lawsuit with ''falsely assuring'' shareholders, the fund's board and rating agencies that their flagship fund remained safe and liquid at a time when the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers had made the fund far more precarious than investors realized.

A list of witnesses who could be called to testify against Woody Allen, below, in his lawsuit against the clothing maker American Apparel is becoming as familiar and self-referential as the director's films. Reuters reported that in court papers filed on Monday, lawyers for Mr. Allen asked a court to prevent American Apparel from calling Soon-Yi Previn, his wife, and Mia Farrow, his former companion and Ms. Previn's mother, at a trial scheduled to begin in New York on May 18. Mr. Allen is suing American Apparel, asserting that it improperly used a still image of him from ''Annie Hall'' in billboards and online advertisements. A lawyer for American Apparel has said that he would bring up elements of Mr. Allen's personal history at the trial; the filmmaker's lawyers said the tactics were ''part of a brutish attempt to smear and intimidate Mr. Allen,'' according to Reuters.

DEEMS--Richard E. 96, trustee of The Hearst Family Trust and a member of the Board of Directors of Hearst Corporation and the two Hearst Foundations, as well as a former chairman and president of Hearst Magazines and a longtime force in the publishing industry, passed away Monday, May 4, 2009 at his apartment in New York City. "Dick served Hearst Corporation faithfully for decades and was instrumental in building Hearst Magazines into the industry leader it is today," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., vice chairman and chief executive officer of Hearst Corporation. "He was one of the people who shaped the modern mainstream publishing industry and helped give it its vibrancy. We will all miss him greatly." "He truly was a force in publishing," said George R. Hearst, Jr., chairman of the board of Hearst Corporation and president of The Hearst Foundation, Inc. "Very few executives have the ability to excel on both the publishing and editorial sides of the business, but Dick did. Our magazines are successful today in large measure because of his work. The Hearst family extends its condolences." Final services will be conducted in private. A memorial service will be held at Saint Thomas Church in Manhattan sometime in June. Rather than flowers, Deems' wish was that donations be made for leukemia research at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

TIGUE--John Joseph, Jr. Morvillo, Abramowitz, Grand, Iason, Anello & Bohrer, P.C. mourns the loss of our beloved partner, Jack Tigue. Jack was a brilliant lawyer, but more importantly, he was a great friend and wonderful colleague to us all. Jack was so full of life and so thoughtful that it is hard to imagine our world without him. Our love and deepest sympathies go out to his wife, Grace, his four sons, John, James, Peter, and Michael, and his sister, Mary Sarratt. Jack received an LL.B. from New York University School of Law and became a certified public accountant in 1966. After serving as an Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, he became a partner at a law firm which ultimately bore his name, Kostelanetz, Ritholz, Tigue and Fink. Jack joined Morvillo Abramowitz as a principal in 1994. An expert on tax matters, Jack was the co-author of the book Dirty Money: A Study in White Collar Crime, and co-authored the "Tax Litigation" column in the New York Law Journal. He held the positions of lecturer at Harvard University Law School, adjunct professor of law at Fordham Law School, and adjunct assistant professor of law at New York University Graduate School of Law. He frequently wrote and spoke on tax fraud and related subjects, and regularly appeared as a commentator on Court TV. He was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. He was recognized in The International Who's Who of Business Lawyers, The Best Lawyers in America, New York Magazine The New York Area's Best Lawyers, and New York Super Lawyers. We will always miss Jack. He was an irreplaceable person.

Two German art historians are challenging the legend of Vincent van Gogh's ear, saying that the Dutch painter, top, did not slice off his left ear in a fit of madness but that he concocted the tale to protect Paul Gauguin, above, who cut off van Gogh's ear with a sword, The Daily Telegraph of London reported. In a new book, ''Van Gogh's Ear: Paul Gauguin and the Pact of Silence,'' Hans Kaufmann and Rita Wildegans say that van Gogh invented the story that his wound was self-inflicted to protect Gauguin, who they say attacked van Gogh during an argument as the two painters walked the streets of Arles, France. The historians also say that van Gogh's suicide in 1890 was a result of his anguish over his falling out with Gauguin.

Dom DeLuise, a pudgy actor whose manic grin and air of desperation added comic bounce to films like ''The Twelve Chairs,'' ''Blazing Saddles'' and ''The Cannonball Run,'' died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 75 and lived in Pacific Palisades. His agent, Robert Malcolm, told The Associated Press that Mr. DeLuise had diabetes and high blood pressure, but gave no cause of death.
