When the Los Angeles Dodgers set the National League record for home victories to start the season Monday night, they passed a team their manager, Joe Torre, was awfully familiar with: the 1983 Atlanta Braves, whose manager was Torre. The Dodgers' 11-0 start at Dodger Stadium pushed them past those Braves, who began 10-0 at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium. But Torre told reporters that the comparisons ended there. He said the 2009 Dodgers were a much better team.

SPITZER M. James "Jimmy," 97 (almost 98) died peacefully on May 4, 2009 at the home of his son surrounded by all of his family who admired and loved him, his sons, daughters-in-law, grandchildren and great-grandchild. He was ill for only a brief time, living life fully up to the very end reading to improve his mind, debating politics, playing golf and cherishing his many friendships. He was born in New York City and resided in Purchase, NY and Longboat Key, FL. His wife and partner in life predeceased him 11 years ago, but his love and devotion to her never ended. After graduating from Evander Childs High School at the age of 16, he attended Fordham University and Fordham Law School at night graduating in four short years at the age of 20 in the Class of 1932. He maintained a close relationship with the University always grateful for the education he received and the opportunities it afforded him and he took full advantage of them. Fordham has recognized his achievements and honored him for his many accomplishments. When he started college, he began working as an office boy at the Offices of Charles Strauss to enable him both to pay for his education and to provide support for his mother and father, Minnie and Pop. That was the beginning of a career that spanned 77 rewarding years, all with the same law firm. He became its senior partner and it became Spitzer & Feldman. Throughout his long career, he unwaveringly adhered to the highest standards of ethics and of service to his clients. He was the quintessential advocate for his clients and for his friends and they were equally committed to him. He was a role model and mentor to the lawyers who worked with him at the firm including his son Jim who joined him in 1970. He was proud of their relationship as colleagues and partners as well as father and son. As dedicated as he was to his work, his first priority was always his family. He was a devoted and dutiful son supporting his family from the time he graduated Evander Childs High School. His older brother, Arthur, whom he idolized died at only 16 and it was a loss Jimmy always mourned. Through one of his many friends he met the beacon of his life Irma Louise Spitzer of Montgomery, Alabama and in 1938 they married. Their romance was forever, a fairy tale of enduring love, mutual respect and total commitment. He was a loving and always proud father, demanding but fair; he became the mentor and best friend to his two sons, M. James of Manhattan and Thomas Neil of Portland Oregon who are forever grateful for the joy and guidance their Dad bestowed for all these years. No less was his love for his daughters-in-law (he regarded them as daughters) Sheri Lagin and Mardi Schnitzer Spitzer. He was smitten with, admired and adored his three granddaughters, Ashley Fagan, Jessica Spitzer and Jamie Spitzer and he was proud of all of their considerable accomplishments. He was generous to them in every way, providing advice when asked, an ear to listen when needed and emotional support and love always. He brought joy to and enriched their lives. He made them laugh, he told them stories of growing up in a different age and he encouraged them to pursue their dreams and to fulfill their goals and he assisted them in every way possible. His three granddaughters knew how special he was and how lucky they were. They spoke with him daily often expressing their love, asking for advice or just laughing, kidding and tormenting him. Most recently he became a great-grandfather of Cameron Fagan, Ashley's son and he was overwhelmed by re-experiencing the wonders of life. The joy he experienced immediately after Cameron's birth in holding and bathing Cameron was a cherished milestone in a life which spanned six generations and was lived to its fullest. Jimmy loved life and those he encountered along the way including not only his peers and contemporaries, but making friends with people of all ages and from all walks of life. He always had stories to tell and jokes to share, advice to give, and a willingness to listen. He was passionate about playing golf and was a member of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale and the Longboat Key Club in Florida. His golfing buddies were his best friends. He was an avid reader of biographies and history, mainly American, always striving to improve his mind. He followed political events closely and was always ready for a spirited discussion. Most of all, his generosity, his joy of life, his humor, his laughter, his openness, his intellect, his respect for others, his belief in what each of us can accomplish attracted friends wherever he went. People wanted to be with him, to listen and to talk and he fully enjoyed the company of each of them and their times together. He was a remarkable man who embraced life with an unbounded optimism for what tomorrow will bring. In his multitude of roles, son, husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, counselor, advocate, friend, he will be missed and admired forever and forever. Services will be at 9:30am Wednesday, May 6 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. 212-362-6600. Contributions in the memory of M. James Spitzer may be made to Fordham University School of Law, 140 West 62nd Street, New York, NY 10023.

IF I tried to sell you a new appliance that could help you save money, reduce food waste and get meals on the table faster, the only thing you'd ask would be ''How much?'' The answer is ''Nothing.'' You already own it. For just as the stove comes with a hidden and often overlooked bonus -- the broiler -- so does the refrigerator: the freezer. Why not use it?

Impressive Start for Royals' Greinke With another lights-out performance Monday night against the Chicago White Sox, the Royals ace Zack Greinke lowered his earned run average to 0.40 while winning his sixth game in six starts. According to Elias Sports Bureau, only two pitchers have ever won their first six starts while having a lower E.R.A. Fernando Valenzuela did so in 1981 for the Los Angeles Dodgers with a 0.33 E.R.A. Walter Johnson did it in 1913 with a 0.35 E.R.A. for the Washington Senators. JUSTIN SABLICH

SPITZER--M. James, "Jimmy" Fordham Law School records with profound sorrow the passing of Jimmy Spitzer, Class of 1932, a dedicated friend of the Law School, a lawyer committed to the profession's highest ethical standards, and, most importantly, a man extraordinarily devoted to his family. His dedication to the Law School was recognized in 2000 when the School honored him with its "Milton Fisher Award for Alumni Achievement". We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Jimmy's zest for life, his good humor, and his unflinching friendship enriched us all. He will always remain in the heart of the Fordham Law community. William M. Treanor, Dean

As the Obama administration prepares for talks this week with senior leaders from Afghanistan and Pakistan, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates flew to Saudi Arabia on Tuesday to seek help in pushing back Taliban advances in Pakistan that, he said, threaten the very existence of the government in Islamabad. Mr. Gates said Saudi Arabia ''clearly has a lot of influence throughout the region,'' and he cited its ''long-standing and close relationship with Pakistan.''

KEMP--Jack. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. Jack Kemp, a Boys & Girls Club of America alumnus who as Secretary of Housing & Urban Development was instrumental in helping BGCA establish Clubs inside public housing communities beginning in the mid-1980s. The 400-plus Clubs in public housing today are a testament to his vision and compassion. Jack Kemp was a tireless advocate for kids in need, and always had a special place in his heart for Boys & Girls Clubs. He will be missed. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Robbie Bach, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President/CEO

At a special election on May 19, California voters will consider six budget-related propositions backed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger: 1A: To increase the size of the state's ''rainy day'' fund to 12.5 percent of the general fund, up from 5 percent; impose spending caps; and maintain a sales tax increase through 2013.

SHIPMAN--Peter H.,74, of Naples, Florida, died May 3, 2009 at his home following a long battle with cancer. Peter was born in London, Ontario Canada on August 25, 1934, the son of Cora (Foster) and Gerald Totten Shipman. Pete was a 1956 graduate of Dartmouth College and served proudly in the United States Marine Corps. Peter's life was defined by his family loyalty, unwavering determination and generosity to all. Anyone that knew Peter was the beneficiary of his enormous heart. His passion for the financial markets, after years as a Wall Street executive, was only outweighed for his passion for his family and Dartmouth Baseball. Pete is survived by his best friend and beloved wife of 47 years Joan Chessman Shipman of Naples FL; daughter Julie Shipman of Buda, TX and her son Caleb (11); son Jim Shipman of Salt Lake City, UT, his wife Julie and their three sons Peter (17), Hank (14) and Jack (10); son Jerry Shipman of New York, NY; and several nieces and nephews. The Shipman family will hold a Celebration of Peter's Life Thursday, May 7 at 3pm at the Club at Pelican Bay, 707 Gulf Park Drive, Naples, FL. Peter's family has requested that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to: "Friends of Dartmouth Baseball" sent to Bob Whalen, Baseball Office, Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH 03755.

A museum in New Zealand announced that it had received a donation of works including paintings by Cézanne, Picasso, Matisse, Gauguin and Mondrian that it said was the largest gift ever made to an art museum in the Australasian region. In a news release, the Auckland Art Gallery said that it had received the gift from the New York collectors and philanthropists Julian H. Robertson Jr. and Josie Robertson, consisting of 12 paintings and 3 works on paper, including portraits by Picasso from 1938 and 1951, a landscape by Gauguin from 1884 and an abstract geometric painting by Mondrian from around 1920. The National Business Review of New Zealand placed the total value of the collection at between about $120 million and $150 million. The Robertsons told the National Business Review that they wanted to give the museum an international-quality exhibition.

When Woody Allen took up the task of directing the Puccini opera “Gianni Schicchi” for the Los Angeles Opera, he said, “I have no idea what I’m doing.” Now Mr. Allen will have a second chance to prove that when his production of “Gianni Schicchi” is performed at the opening of the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy. The organizers of the annual festival of music, dance and art founded by the composer Gian Carlo Menotti said that this year’s event would begin on June 26 with Mr. Allen’s version of the comedic opera, about a character from Dante’s “Inferno.” Other events include a production of Beckett’s play “Krapp’s Last Tape,” performed and directed by Robert Wilson; and the ballet program “Russian Seasons,” choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky. Giorgio Ferrara is the artistic director and this year’s dance director is Alessandra Ferri. A complete program can be found at festivaldispoleto.com.

The cast for what might be the in-town Broadway tryout of “The Wiz” — more accurately described as the Encores! Summer Stars production of the musical — is now complete. The actor and comedian Orlando Jones (of “Mad TV” and “Rules of Engagement”) will play the title character and LaChanze, a Tony Award-winner for the musical “The Color Purple,” will play Glinda the good witch. They join the R&B star Ashanti, who was previously announced to play Dorothy. Other cast members include Tichina Arnold (“Everybody Hates Chris”) and Dawnn Lewis (“Hangin’ with Mr. Cooper”) as the witches Evillene and Addaperle. Joshua Henry will play Tinman, James Monroe Iglehart is cast as Lion and Christian White will play Scarecrow. The Encores! production of “The Wiz,” directed by Thomas Kail and choreographed by Andy Blankenbuehler with music direction by Alex Lacamoire, will run at New York City Center from June 12 through July 5.

A publicist and manager for Michael Jackson has sued the pop singer for $44 million, saying that she had not been paid for several deals she negotiated for him, The Associated Press reported. In a lawsuit filed Tuesday in United States District Court in Washington, Raymone Bain, a lawyer who has also represented clients including Muhammad Ali, Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds and Serena Williams, said that Mr. Jackson had agreed to pay her 10 percent of any agreements that she handled for him. She said that the deals she struck for him include the release of a 25th anniversary edition CD of his album “Thriller” album, the refinancing of a loan Mr. Jackson used to retain his rights to the Beatles’ song catalog, and negotiations that led to his coming concert series in London. In a statement, Ms. Bain said: “I have no regrets. Michael Jackson, in my opinion, is the ‘King of Pop.” There was no immediate comment from Mr. Jackson or his representatives.

Jay Leno announced Thursday the guest lineup for his final week with “The Tonight Show” — though he held back the name of the guest for his final night, May 29. That week will be headlined by Mel Gibson on May 25 with musical guest Lyle Lovett. On May 26, the guests will be Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California with Dwight Yoakam as the musical guest. On May 27, Wanda Sykes will appear, with Sarah McLachlan performing. The show on May 28 will reach back to Mr. Leno’s first night as host in 1992, with Billy Crystal, who was his very first guest, returning with Prince. Mr. Leno will announce the guests for his final show during a news conference on May 14.

Your reaction to any particular crossword puzzle, like your reaction to any other work of art, will be different than mine. Art works because it taps into universal or at least broad emotional touch points, but the specifics of where your personal experiences overlaps with, say, today's puzzle puzzle will be unique. All this is to explain that I love this puzzle, but I realize I can't tease apart an objective analysis from my emotional connections. Not only that, I don't want to! I'm happy to just love the puzzle. Let me explain.

Paul Conlon confirmed a report in the Star Ledger last night that three Maplewood police officers would be laid off effective June 30, after federal stimulus funding for the township appeared less certain. The layoffs, announced in March, were postponed when it looked likely that federal funds would cover their jobs. "There was no definitive timetable regarding when that money would be approved, and with how competitive the grant process is, there's no guarantee that we'd get that money either," said Captain Conlon, who wrote the grant request for the department. "From what we're hearing it could take as long as September for that money to be distributed."

NBC said that its coverage of the Kentucky Derby was the most viewed in 20 years. What is the difference between fashion and fine art photography? Perhaps no photographer was more plagued by the dichotomy (if there in fact is one), than the late great, Richard Avedon, who pretty much disowned his fashion work in favor of his large format portraiture. The exhibition, "Avedon Fashion 1944-2000," opening May 15 at the International Center of Photography, presents this disowned work as a seminal body of fashion photography. And none of it looks at all shabby. Co-curator Carol Squiers notes, "Fashion photography we know nominally as a woman in a dress. It's a beauty picture with a commercial purpose to sell something. But with the best fashion photographers, it was not about promoting a particular dress. You have them doing extraordinary things." (See the slide show below for proof.) According to Squiers, in Avedon's view, fashion and portraiture were one and the same. "I can't speak for him," she says, "but my interpretation of things is that he was attacked in the late 60s for being a fashion photographer and felt he had to be taken seriously. He was never about beautiful women anyway. He was always digging into a more complex mood."

There's been a growing effort to convey the science and significance of climate change in imagery, not just words. (It's worth testing all means of communicating on this subject, given the social science illustrating how tough it would be, with words alone, to jog the public to respond to a problem laden with some irreducible uncertainty, dispersed outcomes and a long time scale.) I was involved in an early attempt, in 1992, when I wrote the companion book to "Global Warming: Understanding the Forecast," one of the first museum exhibitions on global warming, created by the American Museum of Natural History.

But the actual scores used to determine who has met standards showed much smaller gains, with signs that many students are continuing to struggle. In New York City, the number of students meeting state standards rose remarkably as well. In the sixth, grade for example, 73 percent of students met standards, compared with 53 percent last year. But using the scores as the yard stick shows a different picture, with the average score rising 10 points.

The third win-a-trip journey has begun! I'm here in West Africa with Paul Bowers, the University of South Carolina sophomore who won a reporting trip to Africa with me. ("Won" may not be the right term: at The New York Times, it's said that first prize is one trip with me; second prize is two trips with me.) We left New York Wednesday afternoon, arriving in Dakar, Senegal, in the early morning hours of Thursday. After running around a hospital in Dakar, doing interviews about childhood pneumonia - a huge killer in poor countries - we're now at the airport in Dakar again, headed for Guinea-Bissau. Paul will be blogging at this site regularly with his impressions. Stay tuned!

On Sunday, Kristin Stockschlaeder will spend another Mother's Day without her Mom. Mary Elizabeth Ball was 58 when she died of breast cancer 12 years ago. Her daughter was 27, and so much has happened in her life since then. She married her husband, Peter, whom her mom never met, and they live in Potomac, MD, with two children whom her mom would have loved. It's a different kind of emptiness, Stockschlaeder writes in a guest blog today, when you become a mother yourself.

New Jersey Transit issued a giant mea culpa yesterday evening for recent troubles that may have kept you delayed, squashed, standing or stranded.

The Maplewood Police Department reports the following incident happened Wednesday night: "A 17-year-old male reported to Police he was walking on Garfield Place near Hudson Avenue at about 9:00 pm when he was approached by a black male brandishing a handgun. The subject first walked past the victim on Garfield Place and then turned around and pointed a handgun at the victim and demanded that the victim turn over whatever he had in his pockets. As the suspect was going through the victim's pockets three other subjects surrounded the victim to keep him from running away. The victim was not injured in the incident and the only item taken was a Samsung cell phone. The one suspect, armed with the handgun, is described as a black male, late teens, 5'10" tall, medium build with a dark complexion and a mustache. He was wearing a dark colored baseball hat with a 5 star logo on it, a hooded sweat shirt, and beige cargo pants. He was reported to be in possession of a black semi-automatic handgun. The other suspects could only be described as black males wearing grey hooded sweat shirts."

Until butter became a forbidden food, it was common as a flavor booster. In classic cooking, compound butters were kept on hand and often used to enhance rich sauces. But they can also be used on their own, topping not only steak, but also leaner meats like veal and chicken, and even fish. Best of all, compound butters can be frozen and used as needed, allowing you execute elegant dishes on the spot.

The Gumball 3000 Rally, the modern-day descendant of a legendary clandestine coast-to-coast highway race, rolled into New Orleans late Wednesday with an estimated 115 of the original 135 entrants still running. The event started last Friday in Santa Monica, Calif., and is scheduled to end later this week in Miami.

His departure, announced on Wednesday evening at a meeting of the New School's board of trustees, will end a stormy tenure in which he raised the sprawling and progressive university's national profile but repeatedly clashed with faculty members and students.

We have lots of expert answers to your questions on the science of paying attention. There were so many questions in response to the Lab post and Findings column on attention research that it'll take more than one post to deal with them, but we'll get started today with answers from Robert Desimone, the neuroscientist who is director of the McGovern Institute for Brain Research at M.I.T. Tomorrow we'll have answers to your questions from Winifred Gallagher, the author of "Rapt: Attention and the Focused Life."

Chatting with a new friend recently when I had to ask her to repeat herself. I was not, in fact, mistaken when she proudly stated that she couldn't wait to move back to her home town in New Jersey. "Really?" I asked trying not to sound too shocked in case she was serious. "I love New Jersey," she answered. And, for the first time in a very long while, I was rendered speechless. Flummoxed, but grateful to my new friend for inspiring me to use the word "flummoxed".

This week, leading Israeli, Palestinian and American officials have agreed that the creation of a Palestinian state on territory in the West Bank and Gaza is essential to peace in the Middle East. But spend any time looking at a map of the West Bank as it is today, or with any of the many different proposals for how that map might be redrawn to accommodate the aspirations of both Israelis and Palestinians, and it becomes clear why any sensible mapmaker might choose to steer well clear of the challenge of drawing up that state.

Burberry is licensed to Inter Parfums, and my principal criticism of Inter Parfums-made scents, which include Christian Lacroix, Lanvin, Banana Republic and the Gap, is a general lack of daring. Inter Parfum's fragrances can be competent or incompetent, commercial misses or right on the commercial pulse, but to me they most often lack, shall we say, gonads. Now comes the feminine version of The Beat. Under the creative direction of Christopher Bailey (Burberry's creative director) and Philippe Bénacin (the chief executive of Inter Parfums), plus the three-perfumer team of Béatrice Piquet, Dominique Ropion and Olivier Polge, they have made something quite competent, quite well-tailored to the Burberry brand, and almost innovative.

Bob Dylan’s winning streak on the Billboard chart continues: His new album, “Together Through Life” (Columbia), became his second in a row to open at No. 1, far ahead of competition from “Hannah Montana,” Rascal Flatts and Rick Ross. “Together Through Life” sold 125,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan; three years ago “Modern Times” became Mr. Dylan’s first album in 30 years to reach the top slot. The soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) holds at No. 2 with 86,000 sales; Rascal Flatts’s “Unstoppable” (Lyric Street) is No. 3 with 53,000; Rick Ross’s “Deeper Than Rap” (Def Jam) fell three spots to No. 4, with 51,000; and Lady Gaga’s “Fame” (Interscope) climbed two to No. 5, with 40,000. The band Heaven & Hell opened at No. 8 with its new release, “The Devil You Know” (Rhino), selling 30,000.

The Asphalt Orchestra, a marching band created by the music organization Bang on a Can, will make its debut at the Aug. 5 opening of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival, the annual summer series of live performances. Lincoln Center said that the concert, at Broadway Plaza near Alice Tully Hall, would feature music composed by Goran Bregovic, Tyondai Braxton of the rock group Battles, and Stew and Heidi Rodewald of the band the Negro Problem. Other events in the series include a performance by the Dave Brubeck Quartet on Aug. 5 at the Damrosch Park band shell; a concert by the Derek Trucks Band on Aug. 13; and an American music festival on Aug. 23, featuring a tribute to the singers Odetta, Miriam Makeba, Abbey Lincoln and Eartha Kitt. A complete list of events can be found at LCOutofDoors.org.

Overshadowed by the Tony Award nominations on Tuesday morning were the 2009 New York Drama Critics’ Circle Awards, which were announced late on Monday night and went to “Ruined” (best play), “Billy Elliot: The Musical” (best musical), and “Black Watch” (best foreign play). ... Also on Monday, nominations were announced for the Astaire Awards, which honor dance onstage and in film. The nominees for Broadway choreography are Andy Blankenbuehler (“9 to 5: The Musical”), Karole Armitage (“Hair”), Peter Darling (“Billy Elliot”), Sergio Trujillo (“Guys and Dolls”) and Graciela Daniele (“Pal Joey”). Nominees for film choreography include Anthony Van Laast (“Mamma Mia!”), Longines Fernandes (“Slumdog Millionaire”) and Kenny Ortega (“High School Musical 3: Senior Year”). Allison Janney, above in “9 to 5,” was a nominee for best leading actress in a musical.

The bass John Relyea is the winner of the Metropolitan Opera’s Beverly Sills Artist Award for young singers, the Met announced. The award, which comes with a prize of $50,000, has been given annually since 2006 to singers between 25 and 40 who have appeared in featured solo roles at the Met. Mr. Relyea, 37, who was born in Toronto and lives in Rhode Island, made his Met debut in 2000 in the role of Alidoro in “La Cenerentola.” His performance as Méphistophélès in Robert Lepage’s production of “La Damnation de Faust” this season was broadcast as part of the Met’s “Live in HD” series.

After learning that he was being sued by a former band mate, Jeff Tweedy, the lead singer and songwriter of the rock group Wilco, has responded as the frontman of a mellow alternative band might be expected to, with more calm than rage. On Monday Jay Bennett, who recorded with Wilco from 1994 to 2001, sued Mr. Tweedy, saying he is owed royalties from his work with the band, including its albums “Yankee Hotel Foxtrot” and “Being There” and a documentary film, “I Am Trying to Break Your Heart.” In a statement on pastemagazine.com, Mr. Tweedy wrote: “I’ve read the news, and I honestly have no idea what these claims are based on. It was such a long time ago. Aside from everything else, I’m being sued for not paying someone for appearing in a movie I didn’t produce. Go figure.”.
The novelist Cormac McCarthy has won the PEN/Saul Bellow Award.

Plácido Domingo, right, withdrew in midperformance at the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “Die Walküre” on Tuesday evening and was replaced by Gary Lehman in the role of Siegmund, the Met said. Mr. Domingo advised the staff before the performance that he was not feeling well, the Met said, and a curtain announcement was made that Mr. Domingo would perform in spite of this, but Mr. Lehman was put into costume and makeup as a backup. He stepped in right away when Mr. Domingo withdrew, about 40 minutes into the performance. The Met said that Mr. Domingo had recovered and was traveling to Paris to prepare for “Cyrano de Bergerac.”.

STRESS TEST FINDINGS The results of the Obama administration's stress tests on financial institutions are to be officially released. The findings have been slowly trickling out for days, though, and it appears that the rescue funds already approved by Congress will be enough to help banks in need. FORECLOSURE BILL APPROVED The Senate approved a bill to expand federal efforts to prevent mortgage foreclosures and give renters of foreclosed properties at least 90 days' notice before eviction. [A4.]

For centuries, from the Hapsburg Empire through Communist dictatorship, peasant farmers here have eked out a living from hogs, driving horses along ancient pocked roads and whispering ritual prayers on butchering day. Old customs and jobs are dying, however, and the air itself is changing, transformed by an American newcomer: Smithfield Foods. Almost unnoticed by the rest of the Continent, the agribusiness giant has moved into Eastern Europe, assembling networks of farms, breeding pigs on the fast track and slaughtering them for every bit of meat and muscle that can be squeezed into a sausage.

KEMP--Jack. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. Jack Kemp, a Boys & Girls Club of America alumnus who as Secretary of Housing & Urban Development was instrumental in helping BGCA establish Clubs inside public housing communities beginning in the mid-1980s. The 400-plus Clubs in public housing today are a testament to his vision and compassion. Jack Kemp was a tireless advocate for kids in need, and always had a special place in his heart for Boys & Girls Clubs. He will be missed. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Robbie Bach, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President/CEO

Sam Cohn, whose nearly endless client roster of top actors, writers and directors and imaginative engineering of deals for them made him the most powerful talent broker in theater and film during the 1970s and 1980s and a progenitor of the Hollywood superagent, died Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 79. His death was confirmed by Maarten Kooij, a longtime colleague of Mr. Cohn's at International Creative Management, the mammoth talent agency widely known as I.C.M. Mr. Kooij gave no cause other than to say Mr. Cohn died after a short illness.

BEING removed from civilization doesn't mean having to forgo a precisely extracted latte or perfectly steeped cup of press-pot coffee in the morning. Although many campers leap to the defense of hardy cowboy coffee -- the backcountry standby of coffee grounds mixed in hot water and then consumed unfiltered -- others are indulging in a new crop of coffee makers that promise to prepare a satisfying brew in the middle of the woods, or anywhere else. Camping coffee makers are often lighter, more portable versions of typical kitchen products like a cone filter, French press or Italian stovetop espresso pot, and are made to be slipped into a daypack or backpack. Steve Kirbach, far right, a barista and roaster at Stumptown Coffee Roasters in Portland, Ore., who camps recreationally throughout the Pacific Northwest, tried six camping coffee makers recently and evaluated their construction, weight and ease of use. He applied his palate to the quality of coffee they produced using a Stumptown roast called Burundi Bwayi. The results, he said, varied from the undrinkable to the delicious. JENNIFER BLEYER

SEOUL, South Korea -- A homeless South Korean man died of cancer without being able to use any of his life savings of $100,000 because he could not prove his identity to his bank, officials said Wednesday. Until recently, the man pulled a cart during the day to collect and sell scrap metal and other junk and slept in the cart or a shipping container in Kwangju, in southwestern South Korea.
CROSSWORD The crossword on Wednesday gave an erroneous clue for 24-Across, seeking the answer ''Moses.'' The clue should have read, ''Adoptee in Exodus'' -- not ''Genesis.''

CALANDRIN--Margaret "Peg", of NYC, May 2, 2009. Born 1940, raised in Sea Cliff, predeceased by parents and brother. Worked for WNET until she retired as Communications Director. Active in Cabaret singing and work for the blind. Memorial Mass Monday May 11, at 10am at Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71st St.

ROSENBERG--Bernard, died May 5 of complications from Alzheimer's Disease. A CPA for 50 years, he specialized in theatrical accounting; was active in many charities, especially Jewish organizations. He graduated from Townsend Harris High School, and from City College of New York (now Baruch) in 1948. He leaves his beloved and loving family; wife Muriel, children Susan, Lisa and Sheldon and daughter-in-law Rachel, grandchildren Chloe, Mollie and Deci, sister Leona, brother Donald and wife Frances. Services Friday 11:30am at the "Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

HARRA--E. Otis. On May 5, 2009. Beloved husband of the late Marjorie. Devoted father of John and Bill. Cherished grandfather of Zachary and Rita, Brian and Evan, and dear companion of Audrey Feinberg. Services today 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

8 P.M. (HBO) CHINA'S UNNATURAL DISASTER: THE TEARS OF SICHUAN PROVINCE On May 12, 2008, some 10,000 children were among the 70,000 who died when an earthquake hit Sichaun Province in China. Entire classrooms of boys and girls were killed when poorly constructed schools collapsed. This documentary from Jon Alpert and Matthew O'Neill (the Emmy Award-winning ''Baghdad ER'') examines the earthquake's devastating toll and watches as anguished parents, like those above, grow outraged at officials who oversaw the schools' construction and at the government that focused its rescue efforts elsewhere. One mother says, ''This is a lesson of blood.'' 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Jon and Kate Gosselin discuss their rumor-fueled marriage.

KURZ--Lillian. Born April 12, 1912, died peacefully on May 5. The adored wife of the late Benjamin, beloved mother to her children, Diana, Vivian, Freddy, and the late Doriane, and cherished matriarch of the extended Kurz and Hellreich families, she is mourned by her children, numerous nieces, nephews, other relatives and a large circle of friends. All who met her were impressed by her beauty, her elegant, vivacious Viennese charm and great kindness and gentleness. Generous and spiritual, a true Aishes Chayal, she was active in Kew Gardens Chapter of Hadassah for many years and served as chapter and regional president. A lover of learning and art she was co-founder with the late Rachel Kaufman of Gallery Two in Queens. Service, Today 12pm, at Schwartz Bros (Queens Blvd and 76th) Forest Hills. For Shiva call 718-441-1715.

ROSENBERG--Bernard P. The Silverman family mourns the passing of a dear friend and much admired husband, father and professional. As "Marty's" comrade in arms with the 95th Infantry and advisor he will be sorely missed and fondly remembered.

Samsung's two new camcorders have a design feature that you may not notice at first glance. The ultracompact SMX-C14 and SMX-C10 both employ the same Active Angle Lens design as their forerunner, the $500 HMX-R10. I spent some time with the HMX-R10 at a recent Samsung event, and the Active Angle Lens design is clever. The lens is tilted, so the camcorder is out of your line of sight when shooting. In other words, there is no camcorder attached to your face. Not only that, but the lens angle means you can hold the camera in a more natural position.

FABRICAND--Burton Paul, Physicist, Economist, Financier, Author and WWII veteran was born in NYC on November 22, 1923. He died May 5, 2009 in New Milford, CT with his family by his side. Burt lived a remarkable life, and recently said he had accomplished everything he wanted in life. He held the degrees of A.B., A.M. and Ph.D. from Columbia University, and was Professor Emeritus at Pratt Institute. He was an expert in many areas and has been published widely in the fields of atomic and nuclear physics, oceanography, finance, free market economic theory, chaos theory, and, most notably, horse racing and the stock market. He and his wife Heather have travelled the world, from the North to the South Pole and all continents and countless countries in between. His steadfastness, gregarious sense of humor and generosity were just a few of his remarkable traits, and he was loved by all who knew him. His total and absolute devotion to Heather was remarkable and was admired by anyone who saw them together. Burt Fabricand is survived by his beloved wife Heather North Fabricand, children Nicole Person, Lorraine Fabricand, and stepchildren Robin James, Leslie North, Anthony North, Thaddeus North, and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the American Wing of The Metropolitan Museum, in NYC.

FELDBERG--Martin, May 4, 2009, following a brave and unrelenting fight with heart disease. Cherished husband of Natalie. Adored father of Randi (Alan), Alan (Robin) and Steven (Sally). Beloved grandfather of Adam, Stefanie, Brittany, Ariel, Pamela and Carly. War veteran, entrepreneur, mentor and patriarch. His infinite love and dedication to his family serves as an inspiration to all. Surrounded by a family whose generosity, warmth, kindness and devotion he cemented with his own, we cannot measure the depths of our loss. His marvelous personality, charm and expansive love of life shall always remain with us. His life was indeed a blessing. The family requests that donations be made in his memory to the American Heart Association, 1 Union St., Suite 301, Robins- ville, NJ 08691.

The iPhone lost its spot as top-selling smartphone to the BlackBerry Curve in the first quarter of 2009, but that doesn't necessarily spell the end of the iPhone's market dominance, said Ross Rubin, an analyst with the NPD Group, a research firm. According to an NPD survey, the five top-selling smartphones from Jan. 1 to March 31 were the BlackBerry Curve, the Apple iPhone 3G, the BlackBerry Storm, the BlackBerry Pearl (not including the Pearl Flip) and the T-Mobile G1 using the Android operating system.

SPITZER--M. James "Jimmy". My father was the Feldman in Spitzer & Feldman. He too was an office boy for Charles Strauss during law school and he was an associate when Jimmy came to Strauss. They were associates together until they became partners in the successive firm Reich Spitzer & Feldman, then Senior Partners in Spitzer & Feldman. In the fifty years together they never "had a word", their partnership agreement was a hand shake. Jimmy was a wonderful man. His kind rarely comes along. I am a better person for having known him. Good night sweet prince. Lorna Feldman Hoffman

Surprising Rookie Helps Blue Jays The Toronto Blue Jays are in first place in the American League East, and a key to their success has been the starting pitcher Scott Richmond, who was named the American League's rookie of the month on Tuesday. A citizen of New Zealand and one of two Canadian-born players on Toronto's 40-man roster, Richmond is 4-0 with a 2.57 earned run average and 26 strikeouts in five starts.

GORDON Albert H. Trustee of St. Bernard's School, 1940-68. President of the Board of Trustees, 1952-1962. Father and grandfather of six St. Bernard's boys. "Zeus among the gods," R.I.W. Westgate said. Ave atque vale.

ROTH--Sanford. Died in Chicago on May 6, 2009 at 81. Sandy Roth was born in Newark, NJ, December 26, 1927, educated in Newark public schools and, after serving in the navy, graduated from Pratt Institute. He was also a student at the Art Students League. He began his advertising career in New York in the 1950s with J. Walter Thompson, later was an art director at B.B.D.O. and the Ellington Agency. In 1968 he joined Ogilvy & Mather as a creative director and, in 1976, moved to Chicago to be a senior vice-president and creative director with Ogilvy, where his major account was Sears. He retired from Ogilvy in 1983 in order to paint; he was represented by galleries in Chicago, New York, and Palm Desert, CA. He taught painting and drawing out of his Chicago studio from 1984 to 2008. He is survived by his wife, Dorene Marcus of Chicago, a brother, Philip, of Connecticut, sons Seth of Chicago and Jonathan of Harrington Park, NJ, a daughter-in-law, Marie, and grandchildren, Trudy and Zachary. His wife, Trudy, mother of Seth and Jonathan, predeceased him in 1970. Funeral services twelve noon, Monday, May 11, Piser Chapel, 9200 N. Skokie Blvd., Skokie, IL.

FENKO--Barbara. The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, mourns the loss of this most courageous, gutsy lady, an exemplar in elegantly fighting adversity. A knowledgeable and musically talented Reconstructionist from the Havurah days, her ruach will remain with us. Our sympathies to her children and grandchildren.

Predeceased by wife Roxana and daughter Linda. Memorial gifts may be made to The Center for the Study of the Presidency and Congress, Attention: T. M. Kirlin, 1020 19th St., N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036. Interment will be private.

The N.C.A.A. has talked about an increase in the academic progress of athletes in the high-profile sports of football, baseball and men's basketball, but when it released its academic reform data Wednesday, an old story line reappeared. Almost every college that received significant punishment for poor academic progress came from leagues outside the established powers. Nothing epitomized that better than the N.C.A.A.'s first postseason bans for poor grades, which were handed out to the Centenary men's basketball team and the Tennessee-Chattanooga football team. (The Jacksonville football team is appealing its ban.) Of the 85 teams punished in football and men's basketball, only 10 came from the six Bowl Championship Series conferences. ''It's an expensive ordeal,'' said Myles Brand, the N.C.A.A. president, referring to providing adequate academic support. ''Those schools who can't afford it are more likely to run into trouble.'' More coverage at nytimes.com/sports.

HABER--Joseph (Josh). The most loving and generous of men. Survived by his wife of 52 years, Elaine, sons Eric (Ruth Colp Haber) and Kenneth (Debra Haber), grand-daughters Carly, Tess and Sophia, and more saddened friends than can be counted. Memorial service at 11:15am, Friday, May 8th, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC.

It's about time to make the annual summertime reading list, and maybe it's finally the year you tackle those classics you promised yourself to read. You now have fewer excuses not to. A 99-cent app called Classics puts 20 books on your iPhone or iPod Touch. All of them, of course, are classics.

Update | 1:34 p.m. A group of Chrysler creditors opposing the carmaker’s reorganization will disband after two more investment firms withdrew from its membership, a lawyer representing the firms told DealBook on Friday.

When you have a hit Broadway play, it’s a no-brainer that you want to keep it running (and making money) for as long as you can. But in the case of this spring’s biggest hit, “God of Carnage,” how long will it end up running with its superstar cast of Jeff Daniels, Hope Davis, James Gandolfini, and Marcia Gay Harden?

Apple has reversed itself and will allow a Nine Inch Nails-themed application to be carried in its iPhone Apps store after all, BBC News reported. Over the weekend, Trent Reznor, the front man of the band Nine Inch Nails, posted on his Web site, nin.com, an e-mail message from Apple officials who said that the application had been rejected for “objectionable content” because it offered a streaming version of the band’s song “The Downward Spiral.” Mr. Reznor said at the time that he had removed the song from his servers, and on Thursday, he wrote on his Twitter feed that Apple had approved the application, adding: “The NIN iPhone app is unchanged, the ‘issues’ seem to have been resolved.” Apple did not immediately comment on why it decided to allow the application.

Moviegoers in India are depending largely on Hollywood features and films from other regions as a dispute between Bollywood producers and Indian cinema owners continues into its second month, The Associated Press reported. The standoff began in early April when Mumbai producers said they would stop making new movies if they did not receive a larger share of the profits earned from films shown at India’s multiplex theaters, which account for 60 to 65 percent of ticket revenue in that nation. The theater owners said they would seek films they could distribute on their own. Talks between the two sides broke down on Tuesday. Richa Bose, a moviegoer in Mumbai standing in line to see “Fast & Furious,” told The A.P., “We don’t want to see it, but we don’t have a choice.”

A manager for the tenor José Carreras said that a British newspaper had misrepresented the singer’s remarks in an interview and that Mr. Carreras was not retiring from opera performance, BBC News reported. In an interview with The Telegraph in advance of the Classical Brits awards, Mr. Carreras seemed to say his opera career was at an end, adding: “If I can do concert recitals, adapting the repertoire to my needs, then no problem. But with operas, unless the right circumstances come up, my career is done.” But Michael Storrs, the singer’s international manager, told the BBC that Mr. Carreras would continue to perform opera if the right role came up. “It’s a complete non-story,” Mr. Storrs added. Mr. Carreras is to receive a lifetime achievement award at the Classical Brits in London on Tuesday.
Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete stories.)

Is it spring fever? Another week brings another relatively quiet list. Maybe it was result of the Free Comic Book Day giveaway last week, but among the few new books hitting the best seller chart is one that belongs to Green Lantern: The “Sinestro Corps War” is an adventure with nothing less than the universe up for grabs. The entire epic is already available in hardcover; the second soft cover will be available in June. The story line also serves as a setup for “Blackest Night,” which is heavily focused on Green Lantern and the recent discovery of other color-based power rings. The DC Universe blog, The Source, is showcasing the various color corps. Which deceased members of the DC Universe will be members of the Black Lantern Corps? Their group shot provides some hints.

Maya Lin is known mostly as a creator of urban commemorative sculptures, but her career has moved toward a more earth-sculpturing direction.
Mayer Kirshenblatt and Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett discuss Mr. Kirshenblatt’s paintings of the Holocaust and his memories of Poland on display at the Jewish Museum.
Residents in the Allston neighborhood of Boston are frustrated with Harvard University’s slow progress on building projects.

A 24-year-old Saudi woman, Areej Khan, has completed a most interesting thesis at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan. She has started a campaign to start a discussion about whether women should be allowed to drive in Saudi Arabia, using social networks such as Facebook and Youtube. My colleague Robert Mackey wrote about it on The Lede. Some of her supporters make the argument that always seemed strongest to me: If the Prophet Muhammad allowed women (including his wife Khadija) to drive camels, why on Earth wouldn't he approve of them driving cars. Much safer and rather less exposed, no?
David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News discuss what the new "Star Trek" film says about American society.

While Morgan Stanley received a relatively clean bill of health from the government on Thursday, analysts at Egan-Jones, the credit rating agency, aren't convinced that the firm has enough capital to weather the economic storm.

One of the key components of personal branding involves designing an effective company logo. If you mention a successful brand by name, odds are you can also visualize its logo. To help get you started, I've outlined some points to consider as you work on constructing your company's version of the golden arches.
General Ray Odierno, the top American commander in Iraq, likes golf, the New York Yankees, the movie "Sleepless in Seattle'' and the television series "24.''

We are a nation that loves a horse race, even if on occasion we have to put the cart in front of the equine to get things rolling. Consider, for example, that the crowds had barely cleared out of Radio City Music Hall after this year's NFL draft when the supposed experts were already telling us who would go in the first round of the 2010 event. Politics is no exception -- you can see an early line on the 2012 presidential race here. Likewise, speculation is heavy over the person President Obama will nominate to nominate to take Justice David Souter's spot on the Supreme Court bench. So who are the Mel Kipers of the chattering classes, and who do they see as the justice system's Matthew Stafford?

As reported in Crain's, the restaurant Tailor filed for bankruptcy on Thursday. It listed over 70 creditors and about $300,00 in debts, including more than $143,000 in disputed state sales and withholding taxes.
Pope Benedict XVI arrived in Jordan on Friday for a visit that will be closely scrutinized, as missteps in his four-year papacy have angered Jews and Muslims.

According to the Churchill Downs spokesman Darren Rogers, a Churchill Downs on-track bettor won more than $1 million on the Kentucky Derby by hitting a $1,000 exacta bet. An exacta requires the bettor to pick the top two finishers in exact order.

New York legal experts who support same-sex marriage gathered in a conference room at the New York City Bar on Thursday evening for a panel discussion on the effort to legalize it in the state. The discussion was wide-ranging and fast-paced, touching on the rapid legislative and judicial developments that have resulted in same-sex marriage becoming legal in five states -- Massachusetts, Vermont, Connecticut, Iowa and Maine -- even as the State Assembly in Albany is poised to take up the matter.The panel -- moderated by Alphonso B. David, a civil-rights lawyer who now works in the attorney general's office -- touched on an important array of historical and legal issues. (It did not include any opponents of same-sex marriage.)
We were all geared up to eat wild Alaska salmon in SoHo with Gov. Sarah Palin on Friday.

There are no cases of swine flu in Afghanistan, but there is one victim: the country's only pig, whose lonely existence got somewhat lonelier this week, when he was taken from the small, muddy enclosure he previously shared with deer and goats at Kabul's zoo and placed in quarantine.
Verizon Wireless plans to take an active role in supporting statewide efforts to ban texting while driving, the company's general counsel said in an interview today.

One of the truly hopeful signs recently for Sudan was "Mandate Darfur," the effort to get Sudanese civil society from Darfur to talk together in Addis Ababa and try to form common positions as a step toward reaching a negotiated solution. The effort was led by the Mo Ibrahim Foundation, started by the Sudanese telecoms tycoon of the same name, and it should have been an effort to put Sudanese in charge of their own destiny. And ultimately the only way the madness in Darfur will end is if Sudanese themselves hammer out their differences (and Darfuris have ancient dispute-settlement methods to do just that) and reach a peace agreement.

Efraín González, a former Democratic state senator from the Bronx, pleaded guilty Friday to charges that he had used hundreds of thousands of dollars from nonprofit groups to pay for personal expenses, including credit card bills, rent on homes, and Yankees tickets.
It's going to be Russia vs. Canada for the gold medal at the I.I.H.F. World Championship for a second straight year after both teams won their respective semifinals on Friday.
Henry Kissinger gave a toast to Brooke Astor before she addressed guests at her 100th birthday party in 2002.

As Mexico tries to jump-start its moribund tourist industry, which has been hit hard by the outbreak of influenza A (H1N1), a new report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention offers some statistics that will not help the effort.

Satellite Asset Management, a big New York hedge fund founded by former protégés of George Soros, is closing its doors after poor performance led to a rush of client withdrawal requests, according to a person briefed on the matter.

As the movie capital chatters away about how much money "Star Trek" will mint over the weekend for Paramount, it's worth remembering there is another tier of movies plugging away out there. One doing surprisingly well is the independent documentary "Valentino: The Last Emperor."

It's back. ESPN's Jeremy Schaap is reporting that the Favre-Vikings dance is back on, if it was ever off.X-rays of Favre's right shoulder have reportedly been sent to the Vikings, and if it's determined that he doesn't need major surgery, he could return:
Mark Bittman demonstrates how to make this sophisticated but simple French dish.

On Thursday, Apple told developers that it would only accept mobile apps that work with its new operating system, 3.0, which hints that the release is getting near. Apple never gave a date for the release, promising only it would be in the summer.

The news of dramatic increases in the number of students meeting state standards in New York City schools and the rest of the state was greeted with cheers from many corners, particularly from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Chancellor Joel I. Klein. There was skepticism, though, as the State Education Department pointed out that although the percentage of students reaching proficiency improved impressively, the scores used to show who has met proficiency levels showed much smaller gains.
Is there a burger competition afoot in the White House?

Among the dozens of gorgeous gowns on the red carpet this week at the Costume Institute Gala, the most photographed was Madonna's universally lampooned Louis Vuitton Puss-'n-Boots-plus-bunny-ears get-up. But this seemingly ill-conceived outfit illustrates a modern truism for stars competing for attention: good fashion goes in the prestigious glossies, but bad fashion goes everywhere.

I am burger lover, so when I met the members of the BoTM (Burger of the Month) club a week ago -- I was putting together the multimedia that appeared online with Jodi Rudoren's article -- we talked burgers for a few minutes as they were leaving. I suspect that a lot of people give them suggestions about burgers to try, and I did too. My favorite burger in New York City, I told them, is at Diner in Brooklyn, a restaurant in an old dining car that sits right near the Williamsburg Bridge. It's a good size, salty and juicy with a nice crust, and when you ask the kitchen to cook it medium-rare, it's a true, red medium-rare.

If you're like me, you have thousands of digital photos stored on your computer, and backed up on a separate hard drive. (You have that backup, right?) That's good for today, but what about 10 years from now?

The director of the White House Military Office has resigned, an administration official said Friday, two weeks after he authorized an Air Force One backup to fly over the Statue of Liberty that terrified thousands of people in New York City. The director, Louis Caldera, who served as the secretary of the Army in the Clinton administration, had apologized for approving the flyover. He submitted his resignation on Friday, after the president ordered an internal White House review. Copies of the resignation letter and the review [both pdf's] have been made available as well.

French photographer Guy Bourdin is among that lot of macabre but gloriously talented artists (think Stanley Kubrick), whose work equally disturbs and intrigues. The influential French Vogue contributor was rumored to be whiney, stung by the abandonment of his mother at a young age and unfairly demanding. There was no doubt that Bourdin was struggling with some dark demons: You need not look further than his photographs, which often feature an unholy mix of death and desire, misogyny and eroticism (the leggy, usually nude, models he used often had their heads cropped off or hidden). Despite the twisted subject matter, his photos are highly cinematic as well as glamorous and inspired a legion of photographers including Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott, Jean Baptiste Mondino, Nick Knight and David LaChapelle.
The police were called to a job fair in Brooklyn on Friday because it was flooded by three times the number of applicants expected by the organizers.

The director of the White House Military Office submitted his resignation on Friday, less than two weeks after he authorized a flyover by an Air Force One backup of the Statue of Liberty that terrified thousands of people in New York City.
Should Rachel Alexandra run in the Preakness she will not have history on her side. This has been a rough race on fillies.
The White House announced on Friday that President Obama planned to give a major policy speech on relations with the Muslim world in Egypt on June 4.

In final numbers for Tuesday and Wednesday, which Nielsen released on a delay from its regular schedule, Fox finished No. 1 on both nights largely because of "American Idol," which earned well over 23 million viewers on each night. On Tuesday, "Idol" delivered 23.4 million viewers, followed by "Fringe" at 9 p.m. (9.2 million), while on Wednesday, "Idol" garnered 23.6 million at 9 p.m. after an episode of "Lie to Me" at 8 p.m. drew 8.7 million viewers.

Months ago I became enamored both of Pandora, a Web site that plays music for you that it thinks you will like, and of a thread on Maplewood Online's Virtual Cafe where people were making a list of the most heart-wrenching songs they knew.

I am a college student in upstate New York, and I am renting a house with seven others. The landlord sends in maintenance workers without notifying all of us. Is this legal? I feel extremely uncomfortable having these men in my house without prior notice.

I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in New York City, and I did not sign the lease renewal form that the landlord sent me because I am planning to leave. I recently received a letter from my management company stating that because I did not give notice within 60 days of the end of the lease, the lease is deemed to be in effect for another year and I will be responsible for the next year's rent unless someone is found to rent the apartment. The lease ends on May 31. If they don't rent the apartment, am I responsible for the rent for the next year?

Some phone users can't commit to monthly plans. Instead these so-called prepaid users pay for buckets of minutes -- effectively paying as they go.

The writers of the NBC sitcom "30 Rock" are fiendishly ingenious when it comes to weaving paid references to products and brands into the plot lines of their series. Their skills have a downside, though: Some viewers wonder whether any reference to a brand or product in an episode is sponsored rather than just a way to make dialogue seem more realistic.
Just in time for Mother's Day, the ungrateful brats at BookFinder.com have compiled a list of the worst literary moms ever.

Shortly after Honda announced that its new Insight hybrid would start at $19,800, Toyota said last month that it would offer its own starter Prius with a base price of $21,000. But if that unexpectedly low price has you reaching for your checkbook, good luck. According to Wade Hoyt, a Toyota spokesman, the stripped-down "Prius I" will mostly be sold to fleets. Getting one for civilian use in many parts of the country may require a special order, he said.

Following is the third and final set of answers from Nancy E. Dunphy, the deputy commissioner for employment security for the state's Department of Labor. She answered readers' questions about unemployment insurance benefits in New York City: how to apply, what to do if your benefits run out, historical trends, fraud, how the agency is coping with the volume of applicants and others.

Back in March, American International Group announced that longtime executive Edmund S.W. Tse, who headed the American International Assurance Company and was A.I.G.'s top executive in Asia, would be stepping down on May 13, at A.I.G.'s annual meeting.

Terry McAuliffe is running for governor of Virginia but doesn't seem constrained by the rules of behavior that govern most candidates.

Is manure an appropriate fertilizer for the kitchen garden? As weighty questions go, it's not exactly up there with why God allows innocents to suffer and what preceded the Big Bang. But with chickens becoming one of the drollest backyard accessories since Jarts, the safety of manure has become a fragrant debate.
Can balancing the responsibilities of motherhood and medicine bring out the best in us?

Many investors are beginning to believe the government's efforts to fix the financial crisis are finally bearing fruit. But at least one hedge fund manager thinks the government's actions are sowing the seeds of a future economic catastrophe.

Portland, Ore., has gotten some attention from The Times in recent months: its bicycle culture and its economic woes, its environmental friendliness and its political sex scandals. This weekend, however, in "Frugal Portland," I try to get to the heart of what makes the city worth visiting for budget travelers.

We just received a press release announcing that Isabel Toledo's upcoming mid-career retrospective at the Museum at F.I.T. will include the glimmering ensemble (in the color of lime-light itself!) that Michelle Obama wore to the presidential inauguration. Certainly the inclusion of this now famous dress and matching coat will help drive foot traffic to the show (even if M'Obama's choice of American labels from J.Crew to Jason Wu has done surprisingly little to drive shoppers into stores), but how about this for a news flash: Isabel Toledo, who prefers to consider herself a "seamstress" rather than a fashion designer, has been quietly making beautiful and beautifully innovative clothes for decades.

The trustee charged with recovering assets for investors defrauded by Bernard L. Madoff has started a "hardship program" for individual victims to accelerate payments from the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

Just about the only thing that makes New York's deteriorating roads look good? The neighbors. A nationwide study of surface conditions on major roads and highways has given particularly low marks to New York, Connecticut and New Jersey. Those states had among the lowest percentage of roads classified as in good shape, ranking 43rd, 44th and 50th, respectively.
The jobs picture keeps getting worse, but it is getting worse at a slower pace. That strikes some people as good news, but may not look that way to those who did lose their jobs.

GMAC will get "substantial support" from the Treasury Department following the release of government stress test results that show the firm needs $11.5 billion in additional capital, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner told Reuters television.

Today The Times's Alessandra Stanley reviews "The Alzheimer's Project," a new four-part documentary series to begin on Sunday on HBO. The series, made with the assistance of the National Institute on Aging, suggests that breakthroughs in prevention and treatment are not far away. Still, Ms. Stanley writes, "It is almost impossible to watch even a portion of 'The Alzheimer's Project' on HBO without worrying."

Even though I don't think the moniker "organic" necessarily means much, it's worth a glance at this very cool map to see just where organic farms are concentrated in the U.S. - which turns out to be pretty much where you'd imagine.

The front line of the battle between the N.H.L. and the Jim Balsillie-Jerry Moyes plan to relocate the Phoenix Coyotes to Southern Ontario has now moved to Judge Redfield Baum's courtroom in downtown Phoenix, where the legal arguments will be heard starting May 13.

Basements are where the suburbs get really interesting. I realized this years ago when house-hunting in Maplewood. We saw a basement with His and Hers spa baths, one with a makeshift karaoke lounge, another with a wood paneled bar that looked fit for the Elk Lodge. I know people who do business from their basement, who paint, play music or record in it.

But Stephen Friedman's quick resignation from the New York Fed after a Wall Street Journal article reported that his multiple roles "raised questions" revealed that the former Goldman Sachs chief had no desire to sit in the public dunk tank.

A post on Tuesday about the legal status of a 17-year-old Millburn driver involved in a fatal car crash in January inaccurately reported his case was going to be heard by a grand jury. The accident killed Ari Vuotila, 39, of South Orange.

Companies will soon be able to sponsor some PBS programs for as little as one week at a time, rather than a full year, Brian Stelter reports in Friday's New York Times.

No one travels the world quite like the competitors of "The Amazing Race" on CBS. This season, which concludes on Sunday at 8 p.m., the teams have done everything from transporting cheese down a steep hill in Switzerland (hilarious!) to running through Siberia in their underwear (tempting!) to eating fried starfish in China (no thanks!). The man who sees them through it all is Phil Keoghan, the host of the show, who himself has been on a cross-country bike tour since March 28. Sponsored by GNC, the trip is part book tour for Keoghan's "No Opportunity Wasted," part casting call for season 15, and part fundraiser for MS research. During a pit stop in Baltimore - "We didn't have to bike in the rain today; that was a blessing" - Mr. Keoghan called in to answer a few questions.

Preliminary development work is starting on Glenconner Beach, a project on the Caribbean island of St. Lucia under the direction of Colin Tennant, Lord Glenconner, who was once a fixture of Britain's high society.

When Michael Murray was a student at Oberlin College, he liked to walk to each dorm, read the electrical meters, and plot the biggest consumers on a Web site. This was the most scientific way, he explained, to find the greenest residents with the greatest devotion to minimizing energy usage.

"The Simpsons" "got their own postal stamps on Thursday, becoming the first television series to be featured as the sole subject of a U.S. stamp set while still in prime-time production," Reuters reports. My recent post, "Just How Bad Is the U.S. at Controlling Health-Care Costs?" generated fierce criticism of Shikha Dalmia, whose article at Forbes.com was quoted. There are scores of books, both serious and bogus, about the science of attraction. But the dynamic that pop psychology really should try to explain is revulsion. I mean the ferocious, amoral, hatred-at-first-sight that creates jaw-dropping spectacles on reality TV. On Bravo's brilliant "Real Housewives of New York City" and on Oxygen's lesser-known "Pretty Wicked," instant enmity propels plots and derails lives.

Michael Lauer, the founder of the hedge fund Lancer Management Group, was ordered by a judge on Friday to pay $62 million to investors after being found liable for fraud in a case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Looking at the news this week, with hundreds of thousands of civilians fleeing battles in Pakistan and Sri Lanka as a result of counterinsurgency campaigns, it is hard not to notice that there is one major difference in the way the two governments are dealing with their displaced citizens. While the Sri Lankan government has set up internment camps and is locking up all of the Tamils that leave the battle zone in the country's northeast, to prevent Tamil Tigers militants from escaping, Pakistan's government is simply allowing hundreds of thousands of people to drive away, with no comparable effort to ensure that members of the Taliban are not slipping away from the front lines disguised as civilians.
From Louise Story, a DealBook colleague:

On the surface, the people who swim regularly off Brighton Beach don't seem to have much in common. James Tiberius Kirk returns to movie screens on Friday in J.J. Abrams' reboot of the 43-year-old "Star Trek" franchise, and Hollywood is having trouble thinking about anything other than how well it will do in theaters this weekend. Paul Dergarabedian, of Hollywood.com Box Office, told Reuters he expected a massive opening of somewhere between $80-million and $100-million. That would be considerably more than the $65-$75 million that many other box office analysts were predicting. Box Office Guru, for instance, predicts $74 million, including Thursday night's "preview" screenings. EW's Hollywood Insider goes lower, guessing $65 million. Paramount, which is releasing the film, was trying to keep expectations low, saying some of its recent research pointed to an opening closer to $50 million. It's a particularly difficult opening to predict, analysts said, because no one really knows how many hard-core fans will accept this new, younger cast or whether younger audiences will want to engage with their parents' sci-fi franchise. But reviews have been almost uniformly ecstatic. Metacritic, which keeps track of such things, says 84 percent of reviews have been positive compared to only 43 percent positive reviews for last weekend's "X-Men Origins: Wolverine," which went on to an $85 million opening.

A museum in New Zealand announced that it had received a donation of works including paintings by Cézanne, Picasso, Matisse, Gauguin and Mondrian that, it said, was the largest gift ever made to an art museum in the Australasian region. Robertson Jr. and Josie Robertson; it consists of 12 paintings and 3 works on paper, including portraits by Picasso from 1938 and 1951, a landscape by Gauguin from 1884 and an abstract geometric painting by Mondrian from around 1920. OTTO SCHENK'S production of the epic ''Ring des Nibelungen'' at the Metropolitan Opera, whose blend of literalism and restrained fantasy has variously beguiled or infuriated Wagnerites for more than two decades, will breathe its last on Saturday evening, with a final outing of ''Götterdämmerung.'' Meanwhile, a cycle of a different sort but similar scope began to displace it at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, as the Staatskapelle Berlin and its music director, Daniel Barenboim, embarked on a 12-day series of Mahler concerts comprising the nine completed symphonies in chronological order, the Adagio from the truncated 10th, ''Das Lied von der Erde'' and other orchestral song settings.

NAVIDI--Dr. Marjorie, age 91, passed away peacefully on May 1st after a brief illness. Marjorie was born in Evanston, Ill., grew up in Kansas City, and came East to Connecticut College, eventually earning her doctorate in Physical Chemistry at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. She went on to enjoy a distinguished career as a professor of Chemistry at Queens College, and settled in Plainview, L.I. During this time she, along with fellow professor Stanley Radel, wrote "Chemistry", a widely used university-level Chemistry textbook. After her retirement from Queens College in 1988, she took great satisfaction in teaching English as a second language in a one-on-one setting through the Nassau County Public Library literacy program. She was a world traveler and a lover of the outdoors throughout her life, and gave generously to many charitable causes. She is survived by her sons William and Joseph, her sister Pat, and grandchildren Sarah and Thomas. She will be remembered fondly by all who knew her for her generosity and kind spirit. Contributions may be made in her memory to the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference (nynjtc.org).

O'ROURKE--Innis, Jr.,of Locust Valley, NY and Venice, FL, died April 29, 2009 after complications from a stroke at age 87. He was the son of Innis O'Rourke, Sr. and Augusta Linherr Travers. He was born in Kings Point, Queens, NY on September 22, 1921. He graduated from The Buckley Country Day School, The Hotchkiss School, and Yale University '43. He served in The United States Naval Service during WW II on several destroyers in the Asiatic -pacific theatre as a lieutenant. After the war, he joined the family business, and became president of Precast Inc. and Concrete Conduit Corp. in Queens, NY. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Louise Fraser O'Rourke, two children, Innis O'Rourke III, M.D. (wife Allison) of Upper Brookville, NY, and Colleen Louise O'Rourke Carson (husband Phil) of Beverly Hills, CA, and three grandchildren, Innis O'Rourke IV, Shea Gilchrist O'Rourke, and Connor Travers O'Rourke. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Freedom Institute of New York City or to a charity of one's choice. A memorial service will be held at St. Dominic R.C. Church in Oyster Bay, NY on Friday May 29th, 2009 at 11am.

The Board of Directors and Staff of Citizens' Committee for Children of New York mourn the passing of Sister Mary Paul Janchill, Honorary Director of CCC and Co-Founder of the Center for Family Life in Sunset Park. We extend our condolences to her family, friends and colleagues who share our deep respect for her legendary commitment to New York Citys' children and families. Sister Mary Paul became a Board Member of CCC in 1970; Received the CCC Founders' Award in 1991; CCC's Eleanor Roosevelt Award in 2003; and became an Honorary Director in 2006. As a practitioner, educator, mentor, advocate and friend, Sister Mary Paul advised Mayors, taught Commissioners, prodded colleagues, inspired advocates and trained scores of workers, setting the gold standard in her work with children, families and the community. She will be greatly missed. Maryann Marston, Chairman Marcy Sandler, President Jennifer March-Joly, Executive Director

The largest beneficiaries of European Union farm subsidies include an Italian bank in Milan, a French chicken giant and an Irish producer of Weight Watchers meals and Yorkshire pudding, according to previously undisclosed data for 2008. The statistics, for subsidies in 2008, show that an elite class of beneficiaries got more than 700 payments of at least 1 million euros ($1.33 million). The largest payment, 140 million euros, went to the Italian sugar company Italia Zuccheri. An Italian bank, ICBPI, got more than 180 million euros in five payments.

When the painter Winslow Homer left New York City for this Catskills hamlet in the summer of 1878, he was reported to be ''a little under the weather.'' He was probably suffering a nervous breakdown. Whether the cause was a failed romance or despair at seeing the Gilded Age shatter around him, we don't know. But he felt unmoored and clung to the natural world. The dozens of watercolors he did that summer were landscape-filled, with sloping pastures and wall-like mountains dwarfing human figures, idylls so perfect that they look unreal. The New York State Thruway buzzes through that landscape now. Most of the pastures are gone, but the mountains are still here: Schunnemunk, behind a series of ridges; Storm King, running high and long before dropping into the Hudson. And recently, some new additions, baby mountains, have appeared: seven undulating, grass-covered ranges of them.

Sometimes it takes a family, and a persistent one at that. So it was with Mayer Kirshenblatt, a reluctant painter and accidental memoirist whose words and images form an extraordinary exhibition at the Jewish Museum. ''They Called Me Mayer July: Painted Memories of a Jewish Childhood in Poland Before the Holocaust'' contains nearly 70 canvases and a dozen works on paper. Nearly all depict scenes of Jewish (and some gentile) life in between-the-wars Poland with a charming combination of poignancy and precision.

Ben Crane led a surprising first-round assault on par at the T.P.C. Sawgrass in the Players Championship on Thursday, taking advantage of benign conditions and a generous setup to shoot a seven-under-par 65 that was one stroke better than the threesome of John Mallinger, Richard S. Johnson and Alex Cejka, and two strokes clear of a group of nine tied at 67. The low scoring began early in the day on a course softened by rain from thunderstorms that swept through the area at about midnight. Making the most of the party atmosphere were some players who were not household names: Mallinger, 29, has not finished higher than third in two and a half seasons on the tour; Cejka, 38, of the Czech Republic, had two wins on the tour at tournaments that no longer exist, in 2003 and 2004; Johnson, 32, of Sweden, won last year in Milwaukee and has missed two cuts in three Players appearances.

The cast for what might be the in-town Broadway tryout of ''The Wiz'' -- more accurately described as the Encores! Summer Stars production -- is now complete. The actor and comedian Orlando Jones (of ''Mad TV'' and ''Rules of Engagement''), top right, will play the title character, and LaChanze, bottom right, a Tony Award-winner for the musical ''The Color Purple,'' will play Glinda the Good Witch. They join the R&B star Ashanti, middle right, who was previously announced to play Dorothy. Other cast members include Tichina Arnold (''Everybody Hates Chris'') and Dawnn Lewis (''Hangin' With Mr. Cooper'') as the witches Evillene and Addaperle. Joshua Henry will play Tinman, James Monroe Iglehart is Lion, and Christian White will play Scarecrow. The Encores! production of ''The Wiz,'' directed by Thomas Kail and choreographed by Andy Blankenbuehler with music direction by Alex Lacamoire, will run at New York City Center, June 12 through July 5.
