LEVIN--I. Victor died peacefully at his home in Pam Beach, Florida on May 5. He was 97 years of age. Born January 10, 1912 in New Brunswick, New Jersey, he graduated from Rutgers University. During World War II, he served in the United States Army Air Forces. Mr. Levin was a partner of the specialist firm, Scholl & Levin, and a member of the New York Stock Exchange, until his retirement at 82 years of age. Previously, he was principal owner of Taylor-Stevens Insurance in New York. Mr. Levin was a member of the High Ridge Country Club in Lantana, Florida. Additionally, he held memberships in the Harmonie Club and City Athletic Club in New York. He is survived by his wife, Behna Marks Levin of Palm Beach; his children, Eileen Robert of New York and Steven Levin of Acworth, NH; his grandchildren, Tracey Alexandra Robert Gordon of San Francisco, CA and Elisabeth Robert of New York; and his great-grandchildren, Eli and Zach Gordon. Funeral services are to be held at 11:30am on Monday, May 11th at Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Burial will follow at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY. A Memorial Service has been scheduled in Palm Beach, Florida on May 31st. The family kindly would request that a contribution be made to Congregation Emanu-El (New York) or UJA-Federa- tion in lieu of flowers.

EVERY other summer Friday, I board a morning Amtrak Acela Express from Penn Station in New York to Boston, then catch the Bay State Cruise Company's fast ferry to Provincetown on the tip of Cape Cod. That's where, six hours later, I join my partner, a full-time P-town summer resident, for several days of carefully balanced work and relaxation in our bayside condominium. I've had the routine for six summers now, and one of the highlights of each getaway is my Friday-morning train ride -- the mellow, pretty-much-on-time Acela journey up the Connecticut coastline past Long Island Sound's saltwater marshes, sandy beaches and glistening coves.

At one bank in Alabama, the problem is a construction bust. At two in Ohio, the trouble is real estate. And in San Francisco, at Wells Fargo, the worry is credit cards -- a staggering 26 percent of that bank's card loans, federal regulators have concluded, might go bad if the economy takes a turn for the worse. The stress tests released by the Obama administration Thursday painted a broad montage of the troubles in the nation's banking industry and, for the first time, drew a stark dividing line through the new landscape of American finance.

A museum in New Zealand announced that it had received a donation of works including paintings by Cézanne, Picasso, Matisse, Gauguin and Mondrian that, it said, was the largest gift ever made to an art museum in the Australasian region. In a news release, the Auckland Art Gallery said it had received the gift from the New York collectors and philanthropists Julian H. Robertson Jr. and Josie Robertson; it consists of 12 paintings and 3 works on paper, including portraits by Picasso from 1938 and 1951, a landscape by Gauguin from 1884 and an abstract geometric painting by Mondrian from around 1920. The National Business Review of New Zealand placed the total value of the collection at $120 million to $150 million. The Robertsons told the National Business Review that they wanted to give the museum an international-quality exhibition.

The entire Purchase College community joins me in extending to you and your family our sincerest condolences. Thomas J. Schwarz President Purchase College
COHN--Sam. A complete and utter original, a passionate advocate and a tireless friend. Sam made his own community. We mourn the loss of a great man. Scott Rudin

KISSEL--Michael Case. Age 60 died at home on May 5 from brain cancer. Michael graduated from St. George's School and attended Yale University. He founded KMA Music, the writers studio and achieved widespread success in several genres of music including blues, soul and R&B. Michael was an accomplished tennis and squash player. He was known for his storytelling and marvelous sense of humor. He is survived by his loving wife of 24 years and three adoring daughters, Siena, Lucy and Rosalie. Michael succeeded in the music business but said that his biggest success was "his marriage and his family". Donations can be made to Advanced Medical Research Foundation, 1101 Beacon St., Suite 2W, Brookline, MA 02446. Services at Church of the Heavenly Rest, May 13, 4pm.

BENOIT--Etta Fleming, died peacefully on Wednesday, April 29, 2009 in Philadelphia, PA. She was the widow of Emile Benoit. A lifetime Quaker, she served for over two decades as an economist for the United Nations. She enjoyed cross-word puzzles, Scrabble, reading and going to concerts. Surviving are her daughters Hilary and Alison, step-son, Jack; grandchildren Brian, Jessica, Emma, Sari and Eric, great-grandchild Benjamin, and brother-in-law, Raymond Smullyan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UNICEF.

The 10 warning signs listed online by the Alzheimer's Association include not recognizing oneself in the mirror and giving large amounts of money to telemarketers. Also, Cognitivelabs.com offers free instant memory tests, but the scoring system at the end can be confusing. These tips are offered here because it is almost impossible to watch even a portion of ''The Alzheimer's Project'' on HBO without worrying. Many viewers will be tempted to search the Internet or call 877-IS IT ALZ in a sudden panic over blank spells: ''Did I already take my Lipitor?'' and ''That funny blond actress, you know, the one in that old movie about Washington with the guy who was in 'Picnic'?'' (Judy Holliday, ''Born Yesterday,'' William Holden.)

COTTON--John H. The Segal Company mourns the sudden passing of John Cotton, Senior Vice President and member of the Board of Directors. During a 36-year career, he served as a benefits consultant, head of the Boston office, senior manager and Board member. John believed in rendering candid opinions and his ability to analyze complex financial issues was prized by all. He made innumerable contributions to our clients, the Company and his colleagues. John was deeply respected and loved by everyone. He was a passionate and life-long Yankee fan and a committed runner who grew up less than a half marathon away from Fenway Park the epicenter of Red Sox nation. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the Cotton family. Howard Fluhr, Chairman Joseph A. LoCicero, CEO & President The Segal Company

Alonzo King is an interesting phenomenon. His work is balletic in some ways and curvaceously contemporary in others, creating a movement vocabulary that mines William Forsythe's hyper-extended, improbable shapes and forms; the undulating, grounded motifs of African dance; and shuddering, jittering, twitchy-gestured inventions of his own. It's an appealing combination: balletic enough to reassure, strange enough to let audiences feel they are venturing onto new terrain. But the two works on the current program by his company, Lines Ballet, at the Joyce Theater reveal that for Mr. King this is a reliable formula rather than an attempt to push boundaries.

ERIKSON--Dr. George "Erik", 88, died on January 15, 2009 in Norton, MA. He was most admired by his many students first as assistant professor at Harvard Medical School from 1955 until 1965, and as full professor at Brown University Medical School from 1965 until 1990. He was senior anatomist at the Dept. of Surgery, Mass. General Hospital, Boston and on the faculty of the R.I. School of Design, Providence, RI. Listed in Marquis Who's Who in the World, Dr. Erikson received many awards: among them, a Guggenheim Fellowship for the study of primates in South America in 1949; the Alpha Omega Honor Medical Society from Harvard Medical in 1957; and the Wiley A.J. Ladman Exemplary Service Award from the American Association of Anatomists, 1999. In 1990, he founded the Erikson Biographical Institute in Providence. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Suzanne Henderson Erikson, and his four children: Ann Febiger of Gloucester, MA; David of Weare, NH; John of Vermillion SD; Tom of Oakland CA; and seven grandchildren. Donations may be sent in Dr. Erikson's name to: Doctors-Without-Borders, 333 Seventh Ave., 2nd floor, New York, NY, 10001-5004. A memorial service will held at 1pm on Saturday, May 30th in the Crystal Room, Alumnae Hall, Brown University, Meeting St., Providence, RI.

Raymond J. Saulnier, the staunchly conservative chief economic adviser to President Eisenhower in the 1950s, died April 30 in Chestertown, Md. He was 100. His death was confirmed by his son, Mark McA. Saulnier.

9 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER Cesar Millan ventures inside the world of puppy mills, where each year millions of dogs are mass-produced and where neglect and abuse often run rampant. Using hidden cameras, members of Last Chance for Animals, an animal-rights group, spot-check Los Angeles County kennels and rescue 11 dogs discarded by breeders, after which Mr. Millan (above center) teaches Last Chance how to rehabilitate the traumatized animals. At 10 ''DogTown'' follows up on some of the facility's favorite patients, including Tuffy, the pointer mix found near death in the desert; the inseparable hounds Remington and Ruger; Aristotle, the nearly bald Jack Russell; and Wiggles, the abandoned bulldog with a neurological condition. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY From Miami, this annual ''Mom's Dream Come True'' episode bestows big surprises on four members of the all-mothers audience.

JANCHILL--Sister Mary Paul. The Board of Directors and Staff of Lawyers For Children note with deep sorrow the death of our board member and dear friend, Sister Mary Paul Janchill. As the Co-Founder and guiding light of the Center For Family Life in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, Sister Mary Paul tirelessly enriched the lives of every one she so carefully and lovingly touched. Sister Mary Paul's wisdom, strength, and kindness will always guide us as we attempt to honor her memory by pursuing her goal of providing care and support to children and families in need. We will never forget the inspiring dedication and compassion of this tiny giant of a woman. We extend our deepest sympathy to Sister Mary Paul's enormous extended family at the Center For Family Life.

My Mother's Day Column is about a disease that perhaps causes more grief to more mothers than any other -- pneumonia. And I should say right off the bat that I seek pardon from my wife for not being there with flowers today, although I know that she believes at least as much as I do that the best way to celebrate Mothers Day is to try to improve the lot of mothers worldwide -- which means keeping their children alive.

I think of today's challenge as being a classic Sunday puzzle. There are seven long answers and each contains a pun around the central theme of "golfing around." We have our favorite cookie, the ubiquitous blue-packaged OREO, we have the two most common words in all of crosswords, AREA and ERA, and we even have a mimicry-free clue for APE. It's not incredibly innovative but it's familiar and even timeless.

Apple has reversed itself and will allow a Nine Inch Nails-themed application to be carried in its iPhone Apps store after all, the BBC News reported. Last weekend, Trent Reznor, right, the front man of the band Nine Inch Nails, posted on his Web site, nin.com, an e-mail message from Apple officials, who said the application had been rejected for what they called objectionable content because it offered a streaming version of the band’s song “The Downward Spiral.” Mr. Reznor said at the time that he had removed the song from his servers, and on Thursday he wrote on his Twitter feed that Apple had approved the application, adding, “The NIN iPhone app is unchanged, the ‘issues’ seem to have been resolved.” Apple did not immediately comment on why it had decided to allow the application.

Ned Rifkin, the former undersecretary for art at the Smithsonian Institution, was named the director of the Blanton Museum of Art at the University of Texas at Austin, the museum announced Friday. In a release, the museum said the appointment of Mr. Rifkin, who left the Smithsonian last year, would be effective on May 1. He also has served as the director of the Smithsonian’s Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, the Menil Collection and Foundation in Houston and the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. In September Mr. Rifkin will be named a professor of art and art history at the university as well as a special adviser to its president, William Powers Jr. Mr. Rifkin succeeds Jessie Otto Hite, who retired last year; Ann Wilson, the associate director, has been the interim director.

A bibliographical note on Page 13 of the Book Review this weekend about “Charles and Emma: The Darwins’ Leap of Faith,” by Deborah Heiligman, misstates the age range of the book’s intended readers. It is 12 and up, not 9 to 12.

An art review and headlines on Friday about a new installation by Maya Lin at the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y., misidentified the region of New York State where the center is. It is in the Hudson Valley, not the Catskills.

An article on Thursday about the new mayor of Detroit, Dave Bing, overstated the historical significance of his election on Tuesday. While Mr. Bing was elected in his first try for political office, he is not the first political novice since 1890 to win the post. Jerome P. Cavanaugh was elected mayor in 1961, having never run for office before.

An article on Wednesday about private equity firms and their effort to invest in banks misstated the title of William C. Dudley, a Federal Reserve official who met with a group of private equity firms. He is the president and chief executive of the New York Fed, not its chairman.

MICHELMAN--Stanley Brent, 67, a well-known adoption attorney who devoted his life to eradicating the devastating effects of childhood genetic diseases, died May 7, 2009 in Ft. Lee, New Jersey. Cause of death was a heart attack. Through his private adoption practice, Mr. Michelman was instrumental in arranging adoptions for more than 5,000 adoptive parents. His book, Private Adoption Handbook, provided guidance for hopeful adoptive parents. After the loss of his grandson, Evan, Mr. Michelman turned his attention to battling childhood genetic diseases. He founded the Evan Lee Ungerleider Foundation, in his grandson's honor, as well as the Jewish Genetic Disease Consortium and the Genetic Disease Foundation, affiliated with Mt. Sinai Hospital. In his capacity as co-president of National Tay-Sachs and Allied Diseases Association, New York Area, Mr. Michelman helped to raise funds to further research to find a cure for Tay-Sachs and Allied Diseases and to increase early awareness through genetic testing. In 2004, together with Ira Bailey, Mr. Michelman formed M&B Funding, a financial firm. Mr. Michelman was born July 29, 1941 in Brooklyn, New York. He is survived by his wife, Marilyn. His first wife, Lenore and first grandson Evan predeceased him. Mr. Michelman is also survived by two daughters by his first wife, Shari Ungerleider of Wayne, New Jersey and Marcy Michelman of Nanuet, New York, three grandchildren, Justin, Leigh, and Sydney and two step children, Lauren and Justin Kotcher of Manhattan, New York. He is also survived by his brother, Harvey Michelman of Hopactcong, New Jersey. A private service will be held. Contributions in Mr. Michelman's honor can be made to the Evan Lee Ungerleider Foundation. For further information regarding contributions contact the Evan Lee Ungerleider Foundation ELUF/ NTSAD, 6 Jenny Lane Wayne, New Jersey 07470. 888-354-7788 * 212-431-0431 * Fax: 888-354-4884

Inventories at wholesalers fell in March for the seventh consecutive month after a record drop in February, as distributors focused on eliminating excess supply from their shelves. Stockpiles fell 1.6 percent, the Commerce Department said Friday in Washington. A revised 1.7 percent decrease in February was bigger than previously estimated. Still, sales plunged 2.4 percent to the lowest level since 2005.

PARDES--Richard S.,December 31, 1927 - May 7, 2009. Richard was born of humble beginnings and graduated the City University of New York and New York University School of Law on scholarship. He began his law career with Tenzer, Greenblatt and became a well regarded litigator, winning precedent setting cases and recognition in Who's Who in American Law. Later in his career he became a successful real estate investor, founder of Scarsdale Funding Company and, in 1981, Columbia Equities, Ltd. the largest full service mortgage banking company headquartered in Westchester County New York with over 100 employees which he later sold to a publicly traded banking institution in 2000. His professional successes were surpassed by his strong commitment as President and Chairman of Midchester Jewish Center in Yonkers, New York, and Vice President and Ritual Chairman of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, where he resided with his family for 27 years. He and Dorothy were honored by the UJA for their charitable leadership and Richard took special pride in the accomplishments of his children and grandchildren. He is survived and loved dearly by his wife of 52 years, Dorothy, his three children, Robert, Jeffrey and Cindy and their spouses, and his seven grandchildren Zachary, Samantha, Mitchel, Jason, Jordan, Amanda and Andrew. He will always be remembered for his honesty, integrity and humility and the high regard that he had for his family, friends and employees. Funeral Service Sunday 10am at JCC of Harrison followed by interment at Cedar Park Cemetery. For more information, Zion Memorial Chapel 914-381-1809.

O'ROURKE--Innis. The Directors Emeriti, Board Members, Management and Staff of the former GreenPoint Bank are saddened by the loss of their friend and board member, Innis O'Rourke. We extend our deepest sympathies and prayers to his wife, Louise, and their loved ones.

10 P.M. (Sundance) LOVE SONGS (2007) Christophe Honoré harks back to the early French New Wave in this musical romance about a group of young, polysexual Parisians swimming in love, loss and intimacy. Louis Garrel, Clotide Hesme, Grégoire Leprince-Ringuet, Yannick Renier, Brigitte Roüan and, above from left, Ludivine Sagnier and Chiara Mastroianni lead the cast. Alex Beaupain composed 13 songs for the soundtrack, which A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, said ''belong to a strain of contemplative, literate French pop that is, for music fans not from France, something of an acquired taste.'' He added: ''The melodies are charming, though. And so, for the most part, is 'Love Songs,' even if it doesn't entirely work.'' 11:30 A.M. (13) TO THE CONTRARY WITH BONNIE ERBÉ A discussion of the pressure on President Obama to nominate a woman to the United States Supreme Court; Representative Jackie Speier, Democrat of California, is a guest.

A North Korean official said Friday that it had become useless to talk with the United States, saying that ''unchanged'' American hostility had caused the country to resume and bolster its nuclear efforts. The comments came a day after an American diplomat had offered new talks on North Korea's nuclear program. An unidentified spokesman for the North Korean Foreign Ministry, in comments carried by the country's official news agency, KCNA, said, ''The study of the policy pursued by the Obama administration for the past 100 days since its emergence made it clear that the U.S. hostile policy toward the D.P.R.K. remains unchanged.'' The spokesman used the initials for the nation's formal name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. ''There is nothing to be gained by sitting down together with a party that continues to view us with hostility,'' he added.

Paul Jeune started working in his father's vineyard at the age of 14 and has traced his family's winemaking history back to an ancestor born in 1775. But he says his way of life is under threat from plans to legalize in France the winemaking methods pioneered in America and Australia. Mr. Jeune, along with most French winemakers, opposes European Union plans to relax strict rules governing the making of rosé, or blush, wines just as they are starting to gain respect -- and sales.

JANCHILL--Sister Mary Paul. The Board of Directors, Bob McMahon and the Staff of SCO Family of Services are deeply saddened by the passing of Sister Mary Paul Janchill, co-founder of SCO's Center for Family Life in Sunset Park. Over the thirty years that Sister Mary Paul was part of SCO Family of Services, we were inspired both personally and professionally by this visionary woman who devoted herself to the belief that people are nurtured and enriched in a family, and a family is enhanced by its community. This was the belief upon which she and Sister Geraldine built the Center for Family Life which is celebrating its thirtieth anniversary. Until the last, her spirit and passion did not diminish. We extend our condolences to her family, to Sisters of Good Shepherd, her friends, the staff at the Center for Family Life, and to the people of Sunset Park.

President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Friday disputed criticism by the Obama administration that his government was not doing all it could to fight corruption. He said instead that any gulf between the countries had more to do with the civilian toll of American airstrikes in Afghanistan. In a wide-ranging round table with reporters at the Willard Hotel here, Mr. Karzai called news reports of a widening chasm with Washington overblown, although he acknowledged that his relationship with President Obama had yet to warm to the levels that he shared with President George W. Bush.

HART--Sandra. Conde Nast Traveler records with great sorrow the passing of Sandra Hart, a contributing editor at the magazine for the past 15 years. Since the early 1960s, when Sandra embarked on her publishing career as an assistant travel editor at Glamour, her devotion to Conde Nast was unwavering. Sandra's colleagues will miss not only her deep knowledge and love of the Caribbean but also her graceful manners, wit, and warmth.

Second Stage Theater’s postponed production of “Mr. & Mrs. Fitch,” a new play by Douglas Carter Beane (“The Little Dog Laughed”), is now being slotted as the second production of the theater’s 2009-10 season, the theater said. The play was delayed this season because of a scheduling conflict for its director, Scott Ellis, and will now open in the winter. The theater also announced that a new play by Paul Weitz, “Trust,” will have its world premiere at Second Stage in summer 2010. Mr. Weitz’s plays “Show People” and “Privilege” both had premieres at Second Stage. The theater’s first production of 2009-10 is the previously announced “Let Me Down Easy,” written and performed by Anna Deavere Smith. The fourth production is still to be determined.

The Mets' run of strong starting pitching -- seven consecutive quality starts and counting -- has delighted Jerry Manuel for reasons other than the obvious. With the starters logging a greater share of the innings, the early-season stress on the bullpen has been eased. The relievers have pitched 18 2/3 innings during this seven-game winning streak, allowing four earned runs (two each by the former Mariners, J.J. Putz and Sean Green) for a 1.93 earned run average. Instead of pondering how to split up their workload, Manuel is now in the enviable position of making sure they get enough work.

Madonna's quest to adopt a second child -- a 3-year-old girl -- from Malawi has once again put the celebrity in the spotlight and stirred debate about international adoptions. Save the Children (U.K.) has said that the girl Madonna wants to adopt and children like her would be better off in their home countries, and that most children in orphanages have extended family. (A man claiming to be the father of the girl, Chifundo James known as Mercy, has come forward demanding custody.) This view of international adoption is also held by Unicef.

Thanks to Christopher Buckley (April 26) for “outing” the inner landscape of middle-aged orphans through his poignant and funny portrayal of his relationship with his parents near the end of their lives. His appraisal of “Mum and Pup” was cleareyed and, given that their behavior was often unlovable, all the more impressive for its uncompromised devotion. I felt a sympathetic sting for the author when he wrote that upon completion of his last book before his father died, which had been well reviewed, he received a callous and dismissive remark from his father.

As a former Zen Buddhist monk who turned to psychoanalysis in the late ’80s in order to sort out the difference between psychological dysfunction and religious aspiration, I applaud the effort to use the strengths of one orthodoxy to address the deficits of another, as both the Zen master Lou Nordstrom and the psychoanalyst Jeffrey Rubin have done (Chip Brown, April 26). I know from personal experience that it’s misguided to pursue ideological purity of any kind — religious or otherwise. Real sanity lies in embracing what we find useful in all kinds of approaches, without having to swear unwavering allegiance to any of them.

To the Editor: Regarding, “Personal Journeys: Meals Worth a Flight (Or a Cab Ride)” by Mimi Sheraton (April 26): What a pleasure to see an essay again on the back page. For many, the absence of the personal essay in the Travel section has felt like the death of friends with whom we’ve corresponded for years. Ms. Sheraton’s musings made me hungry, less for eel and bauernwurst, than for reading about a fellow traveler’s thoughts and adventure. Please bring back the Sunday essay. Roscoe F. Ward.

The percentage of Republican voters in the state has dropped in each of the past 15 years, leaving G.O.P. lawmakers badly outnumbered, but the party sees no need for introspection.
At La Taberna, presentation and cuisine are graceful and restrained, making dining at the restaurant an experience not to be missed.
As barbecue season returns, one point of agreement is the importance of starting with great quality meat. That’s where Greenwich Prime Meats comes in.
You needn’t be an industry insider to attend a Delhi book party, which brings together an artsy, youngish crowd.
Charles S. Dutton plays Arthur Miller’s character at the Yale Repertory.
A posh shopping district displays more vacant storefronts than anyone can remember.
The city’s evolution from day trip to destination is such that you can spend a long weekend there without visiting any historic sites, and not even miss them.
To take a piece of rumpled material and transform it into a welcome and useful item is the stuff of household heroism.
A Korean immigrant remembers childhood and his adjustment to life in suburban New Jersey.
The menu at the Brass Rail offers tempting dishes, some, like the tender barbecued ribs, priced as low as $5.
Two exhibitions at Art Sites in Riverhead draw their inspiration from ideas of home and domesticity, themes that underlie several centuries of still life and genre painting.
The decline in consumer spending on Long Island is evident in plummeting sales tax revenues, which are crippling government budgets and forcing midyear cuts.
Two picture-book biographies of Jacques Cousteau, and a third book about the undersea world.
A book about the question at the heart of Darwin’s marriage to Emma Wedgwood; and a picture-book introduction to Darwin and his dangerous ideas.

An essay on April 26 about David Foster Wallace’s commencement address at Kenyon College in 2005, which has now appeared in book form as “This Is Water,” misstated the speech’s publishing history. It was included in the collection “The Best American Nonrequired Reading 2006”; it is not the case that Wallace, who died in September, “never published” the address.
“William Logan, whose book “Our Savage Art” was reviewed by Mark Ford (April 26), is on to something in his criticisms; so much of contemporary poetry seems very little different from prose ...”
Officials hope the cameras, used to capture traffic violations at intersections, bring in money and increase safety.
While many budget and midscale hotel chains have given up on charging for Wi-Fi, travelers still must pay at some upscale hotels.
Moses Pendleton on Momix, his for-profit dance company, and on “Botanica,” a bouquet of dance, athleticism and fantasy created as an herbal remedy for an ailing world.
The bill, which passed the House of Representatives last month, would phase out the use of BPA from children’s products and certain reusable containers.
A recipe for Pan-Fried Shrimp Cakes.
For a child with food allergies, some foods once classified as deadly, one by one, became safe again.
The boxed set “Alexander Korda’s Private Lives” offers a subjective, frequently sardonic view of history, centered on immediate physical needs.
A network of German filmmakers known as the Berlin School tells stories about the present rather than excavating the past.
By the time Ron Howard’s “Angels & Demons” opens on May 15, the movie will already be officially controversial.
Quentin Tarantino’s violent revenge caper pits Brad Pitt and others against the Nazis. “Inglourious Basterds” is on DVD.
The rocker has written a musical based on his life that has its premiere June 4 in Dix Hills.
The largest overseas deployment of the New Jersey National Guard since World War II is scheduled to come home, 2,850 soldiers returning to their loved ones.
Because of an editing error, a letter last Sunday in response to an article about Andy Warhol’s album covers misstated the given name of the writer of the article. He is Fred Kaplan, not Stanley.

The DVD column last Sunday, about “The Goldwyn Follies,” misstated the year of the release of the Disney film “Fantasia,” whose “Dance of Hours” sequence was possibly influenced by “Follies.” It was released in 1940, not 1942.
What one woman learned from four decades of psychotherapy, three hospital stays and the ever-present fear of returning to the psychological dungeon.
Las Vegas is turning increasingly to familiar and reliable profit makers like Disney’s “Lion King” and Cirque du Soleil productions to be hedges against the recession.
A play by Chiori Miyagawa is the centerpiece of the Hiroshima Project, a festival that focuses on the stories of Japanese victims of the nuclear attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
The newest Democratic senator talks about leaving his party, questioning Anita Hill and why he still wants Norm Coleman to beat Al Franken.
Intern use; ID abuse.
Instant antagonism has become one of reality TV’s favorite conceits.
The 51-year-old patient had not had a good night’s sleep in more than a decade. He fell asleep all the time but he could not stay asleep.
An article on April 26 about Rome on $250 a day misstated the cost of a two-course meal, with a house wine, at Grappolo d’Oro Zampanò. The meal costs approximately 50 euros for two people, not one.
An article on April 26 about Copenhagen on $250 a day misstated the name of the Danish open-faced sandwiches sold at the restaurant Ida Davidson. They are called smorrebrod, not smorgasbord.

An article on April 26 about meals a food critic found worth a flight across the Atlantic referred incorrectly to the Eccles cake served at St. John Bar & Restaurant in London. The cake is filled with currants, not nuts.
“Nudge,” by Richard H. Thaler and Cass R. Sunstein, has been inching up the paperback nonfiction extended list.

FURMAN--Jeffrey. April 11, 1945 - April 30, 2009. Beloved son of the late Sol and Sally Furman, brother of Lynda Yablon, father to Daedre Furman, and beloved fiance of Carol Press and stepfather to Danielle and Lauren Press, passed away after a heroic struggle with cancer. He was loved and respected by all who knew him. He was generous, kind, caring, giving and selfless to everyone he knew. We love you and will miss you so much. Life will never be the same without you. We hope you are finally at peace, by the Lord's side.

GOODMAN--Joyce (Blum), died peacefully at home in Scarsdale surrounded by her family on May 9. Beloved wife of 44 years to Dr. Stephen F. Goodman, adoring mother of Andrew, Jennifer (Mark Feldman) and Robert (Stephanie), and cherished grandmother Mimi to Jared, Sydney, Jake and a fourth grandchild expected in July. She was born in Reading, PA to the late Samuel and Eleanor Blum. Her beloved brother Mel (Sue) Blum still resides there. Joyce graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and was an active and enthusiastic member of the Penn community throughout her life. She was the consummate volunteer and ultimate networker, actively involved in many organizations. A funeral will be held at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison on May 12 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the University of Pennsylvania or the NYU Cancer Center.

BOOK REVIEW A bibliographical note on Page 13 of the Book Review this weekend about ''Charles and Emma: The Darwins' Leap of Faith,'' by Deborah Heiligman, misstates the age range of the book's intended readers. It is 12 and up, not 9 to 12.

GOLDFARB Ellen. Beloved wife of Mort; devoted mother of Lori and Ilyssa; proud mother-in-law of Matt and Steve; cherished grandmother of Lucas Henry; dear daughter of Doris. Dedicated music teacher, she shared her passion of the arts with the children and families of the Whitestone community. Loving friend to all. Her amazing spirit touched and influences the lives of so many, Services Monday 1:45pm, "Sinai Chapels", 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

LEVIN--I. Victor died peacefully at his home in Pam Beach, Florida on May 5. He was 97 years of age. Born January 10, 1912 in New Brunswick, New Jersey, he graduated from Rutgers University. During World War II, he served in the United States Army Air Forces. Mr. Levin was a partner of the specialist firm, Scholl & Levin, and a member of the New York Stock Exchange, until his retirement at 82 years of age. Previously, he was principal owner of Taylor-Stevens Insurance in New York. Mr. Levin was a member of the High Ridge Country Club in Lantana, Florida. Additionally, he held memberships in the Harmonie Club and City Athletic Club in New York. He is survived by his wife, Behna Marks Levin of Palm Beach; his children, Eileen Robert of New York and Steven Levin of Acworth, NH; his grandchildren, Tracey Alexandra Robert Gordon of San Francisco, CA and Elisabeth Robert of New York; and his great-grandchildren, Eli and Zach Gordon. Funeral services are to be held at 11:30am on Monday, May 11th at Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Burial will follow at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY. A Memorial Service has been scheduled in Palm Beach, Florida on May 31st. The family kindly would request that a contribution be made to Congregation Emanu-El (New York) or UJA-Federa- tion in lieu of flowers.

AYMES--Edward. Cherished husband of Barbara for 63 years, and devoted father to Bruce, passed away peacefully on Sunday May 3rd, at home in Boca Raton. A WWII 1st Lieutenant in 98th Bomb group and B-24 pilot. Attended Alleghany College, and the Juilliard School of Music. His worldly interests, multi-talents, sense of humor and warm friendships were an inspiration to his family and all who knew him. His passion for creative writing, golf and bridge, made his retirement years all the more enjoyable. Dad, you fought the good fight, now tee it up with your buddies, no "MULLIGANS" allowed! In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

O'ROURKE--Innis, Jr.,of Locust Valley, NY and Venice, FL, died April 29, 2009 after complications from a stroke at age 87. He was the son of Innis O'Rourke, Sr. and Augusta Linherr Travers. He was born in Kings Point, Queens, NY on September 22, 1921. He graduated from The Buckley Country Day School, The Hotchkiss School, and Yale University '43. He served in The United States Naval Service during WW II on several destroyers in the Asiatic -pacific theatre as a lieutenant. After the war, he joined the family business, and became president of Precast Inc. and Concrete Conduit Corp. in Queens, NY. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Louise Fraser O'Rourke, two children, Innis O'Rourke III, M.D. (wife Allison) of Upper Brookville, NY, and Colleen Louise O'Rourke Carson (husband Phil) of Beverly Hills, CA, and three grandchildren, Innis O'Rourke IV, Shea Gilchrist O'Rourke, and Connor Travers O'Rourke. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Freedom Institute of New York City or to a charity of one's choice. A memorial service will be held at St. Dominic R.C. Church in Oyster Bay, NY on Friday May 29th, 2009 at 11am.

JAY LENO Just a day after saying he wouldn't go anywhere in confined places like an aircraft or a subway because of the swine flu, Vice President Biden rode a train from Washington to Delaware. You know what that means? Not even Joe Biden listens to Joe Biden.

FABRICAND--Burton Paul, Physicist, Economist, Financier, Author and WWII veteran was born in NYC on November 22, 1923. He died May 5, 2009 in New Milford, CT with his family by his side. Burt lived a remarkable life, and recently said he had accomplished everything he wanted in life. He held the degrees of A.B., A.M. and Ph.D. from Columbia University, and was Professor Emeritus at Pratt Institute. He was an expert in many areas and has been published widely in the fields of atomic and nuclear physics, oceanography, finance, free market economic theory, chaos theory, and, most notably, horse racing and the stock market. He and his wife Heather have travelled the world, from the North to the South Pole and all continents and countless countries in between. His steadfastness, gregarious sense of humor and generosity were just a few of his remarkable traits, and he was loved by all who knew him. His total and absolute devotion to Heather was remarkable and was admired by anyone who saw them together. Burt Fabricand is survived by his beloved wife Heather North Fabricand, children Nicole Person, Lorraine Fabricand, and stepchildren Robin James, Leslie North, Anthony North, Thaddeus North, and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the American Wing of The Metropolitan Museum, in NYC.

LEE--Mildred Schiff. The Trustees, National Committee and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art express with great sadness the passing of Mildred Schiff Lee, beloved wife of Herbert C. Lee and devoted mother of Board Vice President Thomas H. Lee and National Committee Chair Jonathan O. Lee. A lifelong friend and advocate of the arts, her passion and dedication have forever enriched the arts community in the US and abroad and she will be deeply missed. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to Herbert Lee, Tom Lee and Anne Tenenbaum, Jon and Barbara Lee, Richard Lee and Elizabeth Berardi and to her many grandchildren and loved ones. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chair Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chair Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director

BURCH--Edwin H. IV, July 15, 1930-April 28, 2009, Elmhurst NY. Retired New York court clerk. Friend, humanitarian, raconteur, and daily player New York Times crossword puzzles 30 plus years. Services Hillebrand Funeral Home May 5, 12:30pm.

RUGGIERI--Bernard J. of New York and Southampton died May 8th, aged 83. Born in Brooklyn, he was the son of the late Joseph and Mary Ruggieri. He was a graduate of Poly Prep, Brown University and Brooklyn Law School. He served in the U.S. Army as a second lieutenant. Mr Ruggieri was assistant counsel to the late Governor Averell Harriman, legislative representitive of the City of New York under the late Mayor Robert Wagner of New York and he was New York City's liaison to the administration of Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. He later served as counsel to both the majority and minority leaders of the New York Senate. Mr. Ruggieri was head of the government relations department at the firm of Shea and Gould, representing the legislative and executive branches of New York State as well as New York City. In 1972 he was elected head of the New York City Democratic Party. He served on the boards of Daytop Village and St. Vincent's Hospital. He was a member of the Meadow Club and The Bathing Corporation of Southampton. He is survived by his wife, Martha McLanahan, his daughters Christina and Kate as well as their half sister Lisa Hearst Hagerman. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his name to Daytop Village, 43 West 38th Street, New York 10018 or to NYU's Langone's Brain and Aging Dementia Research Center, NYU School of Medicine, MLH 321, 550 First Avenue, New York 10016. Friends may call May 12th from 5 to 7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. On May 13th at 11am, there will be a funeral mass at St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 67th Street.

THE NEWS The number of houses under contract for sale unexpectedly rose in March, as did construction spending, according to new figures from the National Association of Realtors and the Commerce Department. BEHIND THE NEWS Troubles in housing -- falling prices, mortgage defaults, foreclosures and weak demand -- have been at the core of the economic slump, so hints that the housing industry has arrested its slide are welcome. Though prices and sales have continued to deteriorate nationally, they are starting to revive in some of the markets that were hit first and hardest by the downturn, like Sacramento, Calif., Las Vegas and parts of Florida.

MOTT--Peter and Elaine. In loving memory of Peter and Elaine Mott. Peter was born in Hartford, CT in 1946. He received his Ph.D. from Columbia University, and was an English professor at Nassau Community College. An avid sculptor, his welded steel art can be seen at the Peter Mott Sculpture Garden in Mountaindale, NY. Elaine was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1946. CROSS-COUNTRY BY AMTRAK My husband and I find traveling in the cramped space of air coach increasingly uncomfortable as we've aged and acquired some medical problems, but first class is very expensive. We wonder if traveling across the country from Davis, Calif., to Washington by Amtrak, and especially via the California Zephyr, is a better alternative to flying. How are the accommodations? Can we put our feet up during the day? Would we be able to get exercise?

MAGAZINE An article on April 19 about the development of electric-car batteries referred incorrectly to a report by a consulting firm about the cost of getting electric cars on the road, and a correction last Sunday misstated part of that cost. The amounts of $49 billion -- not million -- for developing cars and batteries and $21 billion for building charging networks referred to the creation of 17 million electric and low-carbon-dioxide-emitting cars for Europe; the amounts did not refer to 1.5 million electric cars for the United States, Europe and Japan.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''8 Years Old, Going on 60 Miles Per Hour,'' May 4: It's bad enough that parents push their children into baseball and soccer with such intensity that they are tearing A.C.L.s and rotator cuffs. But in moderation, these activities promote exercise, fitness and healthy lifestyles. Thus they are sports. Driving a car, no matter how fast, is not a sport. Ari Ofsevit

MUNSON--Nancy K. The Brooklyn Home for Aged Men mourns the untimely passing of its' esteemed and beloved president, Miss Nancy K. Munson. During her 22 year tenure as president, Miss Munson provided exceptional leadership and inspiration. She presided over benevolence amounting to millions of dollars to comfort the elderly in their twilight years. In 2008, to acknowledge her noble efforts, The Brooklyn Home established the Nancy K. Munson Endowment at the College of Staten Island. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her, but her legacy of good works will live on. Jean C. Weber Secretary

HART--Sandra. Conde Nast Traveler records with great sorrow the passing of Sandra Hart, a contributing editor at the magazine for the past 15 years. Since the early 1960s, when Sandra embarked on her publishing career as an assistant travel editor at Glamour, her devotion to Conde Nast was unwavering. Sandra's colleagues will miss not only her deep knowledge and love of the Caribbean but also her graceful manners, wit, and warmth.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week are Laurie Halse Anderson, author of ''Wintergirls''; Peter Brown, author of ''The Curious Garden''; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. The podcast is also broadcast in New York as ''Inside The New York Times Book Review'' on Fridays at 6:05 p.m. on WQXR 96.3 FM. Paper Cuts The Book Review's blog covers books and other forms of printed matter.

HEADING HOME This past week, Manny Ramirez became the latest superstar associated with performance-enhancing drugs. So what is happening to the national pastime? Is every great player on the stuff? My mom has always been a big part of how I evaluate what to do when faced with a choice. She taught me to look at the big picture. A lot of people have asked me whether I'm bitter about having played the game ''clean'' while competing for my job with some opponents and teammates who weren't. But my mom sat on my shoulder (even from 1,000 miles away), reminding me that those who made the other choice could pay a big price.
AAYER--Abetha, 7 years. My life's blessing and guardian angel still. Aaron

To the Sports Editor: In recent years, I have seen many more rain delays like that of the May 4 Yankees-Red Sox game, which lasted more than two hours. What happened to rainouts? What is happening to the enthusiasm of the baseball-loving fan who needs to get up the next morning to get to school or to work? What is Major League Baseball thinking? Debbie Bell

ALMOST 400 vintage cars will participate in the Mille Miglia in Italy this week, a historic revival that pays tribute to what was once considered the most dangerous race in the world, which took place from 1927 to 1957. The original Mille Miglia was begun by the Brescia Automobile Club, partly as a response to the town's loss of the Italian Grand Prix, which in 1922 had been moved to a new circuit in Monza. The race was from Brescia, near Milan, to Rome and back, a distance of about 1,000 miles, as the event's name suggests. According to the race's Web site (1000miglia.eu) Italian automakers supported the event because it would help them reach potential buyers in more remote regions of the country.

JOCKEYING FOR POSITION The Hall of Fame jockey Mike Smith is believed to be the top choice of Mine That Bird's owners to replace Calvin Borel if Rachel Alexandra runs in the Preakness Stakes. Chantal Sutherland was also hoping to get the mount. She said her agent called Mine That Bird's connections but had not received a response.

NAVIDI--Dr. Marjorie, age 91, passed away peacefully on May 1st after a brief illness. Marjorie was born in Evanston, Ill., grew up in Kansas City, and came East to Connecticut College, eventually earning her doctorate in Physical Chemistry at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. She went on to enjoy a distinguished career as a professor of Chemistry at Queens College, and settled in Plainview, L.I. During this time she, along with fellow professor Stanley Radel, wrote "Chemistry", a widely used university-level Chemistry textbook. After her retirement from Queens College in 1988, she took great satisfaction in teaching English as a second language in a one-on-one setting through the Nassau County Public Library literacy program. She was a world traveler and a lover of the outdoors throughout her life, and gave generously to many charitable causes. She is survived by her sons William and Joseph, her sister Pat, and grandchildren Sarah and Thomas. She will be remembered fondly by all who knew her for her generosity and kind spirit. Contributions may be made in her memory to the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference (nynjtc.org).

MAGAZINE The ''Questions For'' column on Page 15 this weekend quotes Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, who recently switched his party affiliation from Republican to Democrat, as saying that the courts in Minnesota still have time to ''do justice and declare Norm Coleman the winner.'' Former Senator Coleman, a Republican, is contesting the results of a protracted recount of last November's election that show a narrow victory by his Democratic challenger, Al Franken. Senator Specter ''conclusively misspoke,'' he admitted to Congressional Quarterly after The Times article became available online on Tuesday, explaining, ''In the swirl of moving from one caucus to another, I have to get used to my new teammates.''

THE Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to make an important and far-reaching decision this year that will affect more than 500 million gasoline engines powering everything from large pickups to family cars to lawn mowers: whether to grant the ethanol industry's request to raise the maximum amount of ethanol that can be added to gasoline. That request has engine manufacturers and consumer advocates worried about possible damage, service station owners in a tizzy over the financial and legal implications and a leading petroleum industry group saying the move is unwise and premature.

THE Gumball 3000 Rally, the modern-day descendant of a legendary clandestine coast-to-coast highway race, rolled into New Orleans late Wednesday with an estimated 115 of the original 135 entrants still running. The event started on May 1 in Santa Monica, Calif., and was scheduled to end last Friday in Miami. Victor Carrillo, a rally spokesman, speaking on a cellphone from the road, said about 85 percent were still engaged. ''Some have experienced car problems,'' he said. ''Some have experienced other problems. Some have dropped out. Some didn't plan to go all the way anyway.''

PRYDE--Harry. Long time advocate for affordable housing, passed away March 30, 2009, following a three year illness. Born to Ruby and Aubrey Pryde, on a depression-era farm near Sunnyside, Washington, Harry planned a life trajectory that would take him from asparagus fields in the Yakima Valley, to Seattle, to Washington D.C., and to most of the world. After completing his degree in Economics and Business at Washington State University, he served two years as an officer in the U.S. Air Force, with an extended posting in (then French) Morocco. Following his military service he entered the University of Washington in what is now the Evans School of Public Affairs to earn a Master's degree in Public Administration. There he met his future wife, Ann Catoni, in an Administrative Law class. Before completing his studies, Harry held an internship as Assistant City Manager of Port Angeles. Following graduation, he worked at the University of Washington in the Association of Washington Cities and the Institute of Governmental Research, an experience that he often remarked he greatly valued. It was in these years that Harry confirmed his belief in the interplay of higher education and the formation of public policies on critical issues such as urban planning and housing. Harry entered the business world as a home builder, starting with a few houses in the Northgate area. In time he founded Pryde Corporation, a diversified company responsible for developing and building homes, apartment complexes, office buildings, convalescent centers and condominiums. He built one of the first condominium buildings in Seattle in 1970 on Capitol Hill overlooking Lake Union. Harry devoted many years to working on national and local housing issues. In 1983, he was elected president of the National Association of Home Builders the first builder from the northwest to be elected to this position. He had also been president of the Seattle and Washington State Master Builder's Association. He was inducted into the National Housing Hall of Fame, as well as the local and state Master Builder's Association Hall of Fame, and the University of Washington Construction Hall of Fame. He served on numerous civic, state, and national boards, including the Seattle Housing Authority, Washington State Affordable Housing Commission, Washington State Housing Finance Commission, and the Washington State Housing Task Force. He was a founder of Enterprise Bank in 1988, and on the Board of Directors of both the Seattle and Bellevue Chambers of Commerce. He was a Director of DASH (non-profit housing for low income families). He also was a Director of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle. In his private capacity and as a friend and advisor of public figures, Harry Pryde continued to emphasize the importance of affordable housing. His ongoing multiple interests in public policy and economics in housing were recognized when he received the 2006 Distinguished Alumnus Award from the Graduate School of Public Affairs at the University of Washington. He established a fellowship in 2002 to provide internships in Washington D.C., for graduate students in the Evans School of Public Affairs so students may gain insight into national and global policy. Having learned to play the violin as a boy, Harry remained devoted to musical and other cultural activities. He enjoyed attending concerts of the Seattle Symphony as well as lectures and seminars on public affairs. Harry and his wife Ann have been donors to many cultural, civic, and academic organizations. Harry had a fascination for the world at large. He was a prolific traveler with a global curiosity, seizing every opportunity to visit other nations. He sought to expand and encourage knowledge and understanding through the experience of travel, as when he led his family on a historical tour of Europe and the Aegean Sea in 1973. Other family activities included riding the rapids through the Grand Canyon, sailing the Gulf Islands and around Vancouver Island, and weekly skiing at Crystal Mountain. He enjoyed golf, his time boating and skiing with family and friends, and his many walks on the beach. He was a voracious reader, well-informed and forthright in his opinions. He remained active and engaged with the world throughout his life falling ill while skiing in Sun Valley. Harry Pryde valued principles of hard work, established in his early childhood on the family farm. He constantly sought to expand his and others' knowledge of the world. His family expresses great admiration and a deep appreciation for all he accomplished and for all he gave, his love and his caring. He is survived by Ann, his wife of 52 years, three children, six grandchildren; by his sister, sister-in-law and brother-in-law, several nieces and nephews and many devoted friends. A celebration of his life was held on Sunday, April 19 at 3pm at the Seattle Yacht Club.

SHARING A PHOTOGRAPH, ODDAPALLI, INDIA, NOV. 20, 2008 Dr. Dagmar Schmidt Etkin, 53, an environmental research consultant, shows a newly snapped photo to a child in a small village in southern India. ''My son had volunteered for the Shanti Bhavan school in 2006, which teaches dalit children, or untouchables, in order to help them get out of poverty and become community leaders. He went back again last year, so I decided to go for a month and see it for myself and do some volunteer work. Each day, we started at 5 a.m. and went until at least 10 at night. I'd take the kids on nature walks, and then I taught classes -- chemistry, environmental sciences. The picture is from when I went to see the villages where some of the children come from. They live in fairly nice circumstances at school, but all of them come from very impoverished backgrounds, and it was helpful for me to be able to put everything in context. I really made a connection with the children and staff at the school. I feel like they're part of my family now. Besides being a chance to be with my son, it was, personally, a wonderful experience.'' As told to Austin Considine

JANCHILL--Sister Mary Paul. With great sadness, Center for Family Life mourns the passing of Sister Mary Paul Janchill. In partnership with her beloved Sister Mary Geraldine Tobia, Sister Mary Paul founded Center for Family Life in 1978. She lived at the Center, in Sunset Park, Brooklyn for over 30 years. She deeply loved her neighborhood and the children and families in it. She recognized the strengths and resilience in people and devoted herself to promoting neighborhood-based supports to nurture families and promote the well being of all residents. A tireless advocate for humane government responses to family needs, she worked from "case to cause" to impact public policy. She inspired us every day, teaching by her example that each individual is a precious and irreplaceable part of a living community. We were immensely fortunate to have learned from Sister, and are deeply grateful to carry on her work and the fulfillment of her vision.

A FEW months ago the Criterion Collection offered as part of its no-frills Eclipse line a fascinating set of Roberto Rossellini's historical films, made for European television in the 1970s. The newest Eclipse release, a four-film set titled ''Alexander Korda's Private Lives,'' also consists of historical dramas, but of a much different sort. Where Rossellini tried to film the complex interplay of social, technological and economic forces surrounding figures like Cosimo de' Medici, René Descartes and Blaise Pascal, these four films produced by Korda in England between 1933 and 1936 offer something else: a subjective, frequently sardonic view of history, centered not on great, abstract forces but on immediate physical needs.

MICHELMAN--Stanley Brent, a well-known adoption attorney who devoted his life to eradicating the devastating effects of childhood genetic diseases, died May 7, 2009 in Ft. Lee, New Jersey. Cause of death was a heart attack. Through his private adoption practice, Mr. Michelman was instrumental in arranging adoptions for more than 5,000 adoptive parents. His book, Private Adoption Handbook, provided guidance for hopeful adoptive parents. After the loss of his grandson, Evan, Mr. Michelman turned his attention to battling childhood genetic diseases. He founded the Evan Lee Ungerleider Foundation, in his grandson's honor, as well as the Jewish Genetic Disease Consortium and the Genetic Disease Foundation, affiliated with Mt. Sinai Hospital. In 2004, together with Ira Bailey, Mr. Michelman formed M&B Funding, a financial firm. Mr. Michelman was born July 29, 1941 in Brooklyn, New York. He is survived by his wife, Marilyn. His first wife, Lenore and grandson Evan predeceased him. Mr. Michelman is also survived by two daughters by his first wife, Shari Ungerleider of New Jersey and Marcy Michelman of New York, a son-in-law, Jeff Ungerleider, three grandchildren, Justin, Leigh, and Sydney and two step children, Lauren and Justin Kotcher of Manhattan. He is also survived by his brother, Harvey Michelman of New Jersey. Contributions in Mr. Michelman's honor can be made to the Evan Lee Ungerleider Foundation.

MONTGOMERY--S. Phelps, of Palm Beach, FL died on May 3, 2009 at Good Samaritan Medical Center in West Palm Beach, FL. He was born on January 13, 1932 to Shannon Montgomery and Helen Davis Duke in Franklin, TN, where he attended Battle Ground Academy High School. Phelps graduated from Vanderbilt University in 1954, where he was President of Sigma Alpha Epsilon, a member of ODK and Editor of the Commodore Yearbook. After fulfilling an NROTC scholarship he served as a Lieutenant JG in the United States Navy (USS Rankin "AKA 103") for four years. Phelps was a Senior Vice President with JP Morgan Trust Company of New York and retired as President of the Morgan Trust Company of Florida, Palm Beach, in 1989. He is survived by his children, Robert Montgomery and Chloe Smeed (David). Phelps was a proud American who was very charismatic. He had much love in his heart and lived life to the fullest. He had good friends and caregivers along his journey. With Manny Ramirez serving a 50-game suspension, Juan Pierre figures to get some playing time for the Dodgers. The at-bats will likely reduce Pierre's gaudy .378 batting average (through Friday), but they will also give him a chance to do what he does best: run. Although Pierre, left, has been on base a lot this season, he has just two stolen bases. But he had 11 steals in spring training, so Manager Joe Torre could give him a green light. The recently promoted Xavier Paul could steal some of those at-bats. The Orioles are the latest team with questions about the back of its bullpen. After George Sherrill blew his second save of the season, Manager Dave Trembley started talking about a committee. A change in his stride helped Sherrill increase his velocity and notch his fifth save. Arizona GRAND CANYON MUSIC FESTIVAL Sept. 11-26. This small festival tempts the eyes and ears with fine music making amid spectacular scenery. The lineup in the Shrine of the Ages, near the south rim of the canyon, includes the adventurous string quartet Ethel, the pianist Joel Fan, the Enso String Quartet, the violinist Maria Bachmann and the soprano Amy Burton, who will perform works from Mozart to Corigliano. (800) 997-8285, grandcanyonmusicfest.org.

It’s a good thing Tintin’s hair is already standing on end — even he might be surprised by an auction held on Sunday in Belgium at which more than $1.57 million in Tintin-related artwork and items were sold, Agence France-Presse reported. The sale, held in Namur by the auction house Rops, offered nearly 600 lots related to Tintin, the cartoon boy adventurer created in 1929 by Georges Remi (better known by his alias, Hergé). The highest-priced item was a hand-drawn page from the 1963 book “The Castafiore Emerald,” featuring Tintin, his dog, Snowy, and their fellow adventurer Captain Haddock, which was purchased by an anonymous collector for more than $424,000; the same collector also purchased original artwork of a car crash from the 1956 book “The Calculus Affair.” The total presale estimate for the auction was less than $900,000, Agence France-Presse said.

Still surging from its 15 Tony Award nominations, the Broadway musical “Billy Elliot” picked up seven awards from the Outer Critics Circle on Monday including one for outstanding new Broadway musical, and its three young stars David Alvarez, Trent Kowalik and Kiril Kulish were among the Theater World Award winners for outstanding Broadway or Off-Broadway debut performances. The Outer Critics Circle also offered special achievement awards to the three “Billy Elliot” leads; “God of Carnage” was named outstanding new Broadway play; “The Norman Conquests” won for play revival and “Hair” won for musical revival. The Outer Critics Circle awards also had a rare tie in the category of outstanding actress in a musical; that award went to both Sutton Foster (for “Shrek the Musical”) and Josefina Scaglione (for “West Side Story”).

The author Martin Amis said that Spain should be grateful to the militant organization ETA for assassinating a former prime minister who was in line to replace Francisco Franco, Agence France-Presse reported. At an appearance over the weekend at the Hay Festival Alhambra in Granada, Mr. Amis said that ETA, the Basque separatist group that is considered a terrorist organization by the State Department, should be thanked for killing Admiral Luis Carrero Blanco in a bomb attack in 1973, six months after he was named prime minister. “There are not many reasons to thank ETA for something, but in this case yes,” Mr. Amis said, according to Agence France-Presse. At Franco’s death in 1975, Spain made the transition from a dictatorship to a constitutional monarchy under King Juan Carlos.

Just in case Noel and Liam Gallagher, the front men of the British rock band Oasis, didn’t think highly enough of themselves already, the British government is warning that a coming Oasis concert could delay voting in the election for Britain’s members of the European parliament, BBC News reported. Oasis is scheduled to play the first of three sold-out outdoor concerts at Heaton Park in Manchester on June 4, the same day that the election is scheduled. Two of the area’s main roads that border the park will be closed in advance of the concert, a half-hour before polling places close. Election officials are encouraging prospective voters to apply for mail-in ballots, fearing that people will be discouraged from voting in person if they find the roads are closed.

The Tony Award winners Nathan Lane (“The Producers,” “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum”) and Bebe Neuwirth (“Chicago,” “Sweet Charity”) will play Gomez and Morticia Addams in the new Broadway musical “The Addams Family,” its producers said on Monday in a news release. The show, with a book by Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice (“Jersey Boys”) and music and lyrics by Andrew Lippa (“The Wild Party”), will revolve around the couple’s daughter Wednesday, now 18, and her family’s adjustment to her coming of age, her new boyfriend and his parents. Wednesday will be played by Krysta Rodriguez (“In the Heights”); Wesley Taylor will play the boyfriend and Terrence Mann (“Les Misérables”) and Carolee Carmello (“Parade”) will play his parents. Rounding out the Addams family are Adam Riegler (“Cubby Bernstein,” “Shrek the Musical”) as Pugsley, Jackie Hoffman (“Hairspray”) as Grandmama, Kevin Chamberlin (“Seussical”) as Uncle Fester and Zachary James as Lurch. The musical is scheduled to begin previews on Broadway on March 4 and to open on April 8.

The New York Philharmonic said that Esa-Pekka Salonen, the outgoing music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, had withdrawn from a series of concerts scheduled for Wednesday through Saturday with the New York orchestra because of back trouble. In a news release, the New York Philharmonic said that Mr. Salonen would be replaced by David Zinman, the music director of the Tonhalle Orchestra in Zurich. He will conduct the Rush Hour Concert on Wednesday night, which will now feature Mussorgsky’s “Night on Bald Mountain” and Shostakovich’s Violin Concerto No. 1, with Christian Tetzlaff as soloist. In concerts on Thursday and Saturday, he will conduct those works as well as Sibelius’s Symphony No. 5; Friday’s concert will focus on the Sibelius work. Gustavo Dudamel is to take over from Mr. Salonen at the Los Angeles Philharmonic in September.

The blue whale, the biggest animal that has ever inhabited the planet, seems to be on the move in the Pacific Ocean in ways that could reflect the revival of old migratory patterns disrupted by decades of intensive whaling in the 20th century. A new study reports 15 instances since 1997 in which individual whales known from waters off southern California were also identified through photographic comparisons as far north as the Gulf of Alaska. The species had once been common in northern waters, but has rarely been seen there in recent decades. The matches were made by sifting through archives of photographs of the dorsal fin and arching back of the great whales -- the only portion that is visible as they break the surface when they rise for a breath. The findings are reported in a paper that has just been posted online and will be published later this year in the journal Marine Mammal Research.

Before her death, Brooke Astor was losing ground cognitively, a procession of friends testified last week in a Manhattan courtroom. She no longer recognized people she had been close with for decades. She wandered. She was unable to draw a clock face accurately, according to the geriatrician who diagnosed her Alzheimer's disease. But was she competent to make significant changes to her will at age 101? That legal question lies at the heart of the fraud and conspiracy trial of her son, Anthony D. Marshall, 84, and the lawyer Francis X. Morrissey Jr., 66, who are accused of diverting tens of millions of dollars from her estate. Experts say questions of competence are not always simple to answer, even after a dementia diagnosis.

Part music label, part multimedia incubator, the W+K Tokyo Lab is a hotbed of creative activity that brings together artists and musicians like Takagi Masakatsu, DJ Uppercut and Hifana, among others, to offer a unique take on Japanese audiovisual culture. (The lab works under the auspices of the W+K advertising agency but is under no pressure to produce results for clients.) The video, "Maledict Car," was commissioned for a recent a DVD, book and blog compilation that chronicles W+K Tokyo Lab's output since its inception five years ago. Directed by the emerging talent Kosai Sekine, "Maledict Car" is a geometric visual journey through Tokyo, set to music by the label's latest find, Jemapur. Explains Eric Cruz, W+K's creative director: "We took Tokyo's daily visual patterns and transformed them into a surreal, infinite loop - a kaleidoscopic mandala, if you will. The video presents us with a floating view of Tokyo - its beauty, perversion, disorientation, confusion and systematic order - all in one, re-experiencing the city as we read between the lines, capturing Tokyo's pulse, vitality and flow." If only all adventures in advertising were so daring.

With the J.J. Abrams reboot of Paramount's venerable "Star Trek" franchise landing solidly at the box-office over the weekend, with a take of $76.5 million, including millions from special "preview" showings on Thursday night, Hollywood is wondering how big the film will eventually go. Hampering the effort, the Los Angeles Times notes, is that "Star Trek" did not do as well in foreign markets as other recent summer blockbusters have done. Still, it performed better than earlier "Star Trek" films have done overseas. On the plus side, the Hollywood Reporter says that "Star Trek" was able to build on great word-of-mouth and extend the franchise's fan base beyond its aging core. Another sign of the film's strong word-of-mouth, Variety writes, is that its box-office improved from Friday to Saturday.

Commuter railroad fares will rise on June 17. And tolls on the bridges and tunnels operated by the authority will rise on July 12.

Formula One: Jenson Button and Rubens Barrichello finished first and second for Brawn GP at the Spanish Grand Prix -- the second time the drivers have done it this season. But for a moment it looked like the order would be the other way around: Barrichello beat Button off the start and opened a gap during the first stint. The two drivers were on different pit strategies, however, and Button wound up ahead of Barrichello, who pitted three times to Button's two. Conspiracy theorists might say that the reversal of fortune was intentional, disguised as pit strategy, to give Button yet another win (his fourth in five races this year).

The Critics’ Choice column on April 27, about new CDs, including “Together Through Life” by Bob Dylan, misstated the history of Mr. Dylan’s use of the pseudonym Jack Frost when he works as a producer, as he did on “Together Through Life.” He started using it in 1990, when he was one of the producers of his album “Under the Red Sky,” not in 2001 with his “Love and Theft” album.
A music column last Monday about the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival misstated the name of a group that performed. They are the Midnite Disturbers, not the Midnite Runners.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about President Obama’s plan to cancel an alternative engine for the F-35 fighter jet misspelled the surname of the president of the team from General Electric and Rolls-Royce that is developing the engine. She is Jean Lydon-Rodgers, not Lyndon-Rogers.

An article on Wednesday about the political maturation of Korean-Americans in New York City misspelled the surname of Councilman John C. Liu’s chief of staff, a Korean-American who is a possible candidate for the City Council, and misstated the date of primary elections in New York. The chief of staff is John Choe, not Chou, and the primaries will be held on Sept. 15, not Sept. 8.

A credit on April 18 for an Associated Press picture with the continuation of a front-page article about President Obama’s overtures toward Cuba misspelled the given name of the photographer in some editions. WEINBERG--Pearl (Oksner), died peacefully at her home in Lake Success, NY on Friday (May 8, 2009). She was born June 28, 1921 in New York City. She graduated from Evander Child High School, attended Hunter College and graduated with an RN degree from Brooklyn State Nursing College. She then joined the Navy attaining the rank of Ensign. Following her discharge she worked as an RN at Beth-El Hospital in Brooklyn where she met her future husband Samuel Weinberg, M.D. They were married in 1948 and remained so until Samuel's death in 2007. Pearl worked side by side with Samuel in his medical practice for over 50 years. She is survived by her brother Harry Oksner, son Ronald Andrew Weinberg, daughter Robin Ann Weinberg, son-in-law Scott Anderson, and two grandsons Eric Charest Weinberg and Alex Charest Weinberg. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, May 12 at 1:45pm at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. The family will be sitting Shiva at the family home at 1 Lake Rd. North, Lake Success. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to: CLL Research Fund, Attn: Dr. Kanti Rai, Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park, NY 11040.

Amy Winehouse had just landed on these shores, using the tools of the 1960s as building blocks toward a more modern soul sound, and the heritage-minded neo-soul movement had cycled past the innovation stage through a backlash and into acceptance.

FINA--Charles, Executive Vice President of Michael C. Fina Co., died on May 9, 2009, after a long battle with acute myelogenous leukemia. Born in 1945, he was the younger son of Rose and Michael Fina, who founded the Michael C. Fina Co. in 1935. Charlie and his brother George were involved in the family business since they were young. Throughout his childhood and adulthood, Charlie helped grow a small store into a New York-based icon known worldwide for offering silver, jewelry, china and gifts for weddings and all occasions. Following the unexpected death of their father, Charlie and George took on the management of the business with their mother. Charlie was totally committed to his work, rising before 5am to be the first in the office each day. While working, Charlie attended Hofstra University earning a degree in business management. He had a deep and loving bond with his brother George. They helped each other in business and life and were the closest of friends. For the nearly 45 years they were in business together, they always shared an office with two desks facing each other. Charlie drove the creation of the Michael C. Fina Corporate Recognition division in the 1990s. Today, Michael C. Fina provides recognition gift programs for leading companies worldwide with sales offices throughout the United States, Europe and Canada. At the same time, the retail business, located on 5th Avenue, has continued its success. Charlie led a full life outside of work as well. The love of his life was his devoted wife, Jane, who spent every hour of his last years and days by his side. He also shared a close relationship with his three sons, all of whom help run the family business. His biggest passions were fishing and boating. A committed philanthropist, Charlie and his family were major supporters of the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society and Michael C. Fina is a National Supporting Sponsor. Charlie found his greatest happiness from his large but close-knit family. He is survived by his wife, Jane, sons Michael (and wife Danielle), Jeffrey (and wife Brooke), and Steven (and wife Elizabeth), grandchildren Samantha, Jason, George, Jack and Brandon, his beloved brother George (and wife Lynne), his niece Ashley and his nephews Bret and Cord and their families. Services celebrating the life of Charles Fina will take place on Monday, May 11th at 11am; Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd (at 76th Rd.) Forest Hills, NY 11375, 718-263-7600. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to The New York Chapter of the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, 475 Park Avenue South, 8th Floor, New York, New York 10016.

SMITH--Alvin. Alvin was a wonderful person and friend. Our prayers go out to Blanche, Carol, Susan, Laura, and the entire family. We will miss Alvin, and he will always be in our hearts. Lisa and Michael Epstein

The Kachin tribesmen who inhabit the hills along Myanmar's border with China have a reputation as stealthy jungle warriors, famous for repelling Japanese attacks in World War II with booby traps and slicing off ears to tally their kills. Now, as they have many times in their war-scarred history, the Kachin are hoping for peace but are prepared for battle -- this time with Myanmar's central government.

FISHMAN--Abraham, 91, of Pompano Beach FL (formerly of Hicksville, L.I.), on May 8, after a long illness. He is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Sylvia; by their three children: Mitchell, of Litchfield, CT (spouse Mary Ellen Spiegel), Lois of Los Angeles, CA (spouse Henry D. Fetter), and Sheila, of New Paltz, NY; and by three grandchildren: Danielle, Matthew and Jeremy. He also leaves his two sisters, Sylvia Shapiro and Natalie Lindseth; a brother, Harold, predeceased him. A native of the Bronx, Abe graduated from the City College of New York in 1937 with a bachelor's degree in business administration. He served in the U.S. Army from 1942-1945, including 17 months in France as an intelligence and public relations specialist; his wartime service marked the beginning of a long love affair with French literature and culture. After the war, Abe worked as a field examiner for the U.S. Bureau of Internal Revenue and received his law degree from NYU Law School, which honored him with the Benjamin F. Butler prize. In 1954, he also earned a master's of law (LL.M.) degree in taxation from NYU. Abe practiced law for more than 40 years, first in Manhattan with the firm of Simons, Schur & Straus, then independently and, starting in the 1970s, in Mineola, L.I., primarily in the fields of taxation, real estate development and estate planning. Among his clients were several prominent television personalities. For many years, he also taught business law as an adjunct professor at Dowling College (Oakdale campus) and the NY Institute of Technology. After moving to Long Island in 1955, Abe was active in civic affairs in Hicksville, and served as a member and president (1967-1968) of the Hicksville Public Library board. He was a life-long lover of books, classical music, jazz, dance and the arts generally. Memorial service at 1pm Monday, May 11, at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Alzheimer's Disease Research (www2.AHAF.org/goto/ Abraham) or Vitas hospice, 5420 N.W. 33rd Avenue, Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33309.

She was a member of the Mountain Ridge Country Club of West Caldwell and a member of B'nai Jeshurun of Short Hills for over seventy-five years. Predeceased by Lawrence Zavell, her first husband, and Dr. Isadore Herman, her second husband.
