A graveside funeral with immediate family will take place on Monday, May 11th. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hospice of New Jersey would be greatly appreciated.

DALESSANDRO--Frances Wynne Callahan of New York and Southampton, NY, died peacefully at her New York home on May 8th after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Fran was 68. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 37 years, John J. Dalessandro, Jr. Fran leaves behind her three brothers, J. Michael Callahan and his wife, Tina, Alfred J. Callahan, Jr. and Charles W. Callahan and his wife Beatrice. She also leaves behind her beloved nephew, Alfred (Alfie) J. Callahan III, and her two nieces, Victoria Pollard and Ya Ya Callahan and one grandniece, Finley Nae Pollard. Fran graduated from Georgian Court College, Lakewood, NJ class of 1962. After college, Fran worked for Mademoiselle magazine and became associate merchandising editor. She then was employed by the May Company in their New York office. Fran began as an assistant buyer and had the distinction of being the first female buyer for men's clothing in the industry. She traveled the world over the course of 30 years in business and retired as Senior Vice President -Creative Merchandising for what was then a $12 billion corporation, According to Cathie Black, Fran broke the "glass ceiling" as one of the highest-ranking women in fashion publishing and retail merchandising. She was a mentor to many young women on their way up, always pointing the way and gladly sharing her experiences. Fran was a member of the Bathing Corporation of Southampton, the Meadow Club of Southampton, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, The Colony Club of New York and the Sailfish Club of Palm Beach. Her family will receive friends at the O'Connell Funeral Home, Southampton, NY on Tuesday, May 12th from 2 to 4 and from 7 to 9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said in celebration of her life at The Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church in Southampton on Wednesday, May 13th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in her name to the Southampton Fresh Air Home.

Congress has asked the Federal Communications Commission to develop a national policy for broadband deployment. But it may be more important to think through how the country will handle the aging and increasingly less relevant copper phone network. You can see the problem building every quarter, when the phone companies report serving ever fewer landlines. They are mainly losing customers to cable companies, which offer competing broadband and voice services that make copper phone lines unnecessary. More people are also abandoning landlines for cellphones.

Zinsser and his wife, Caroline Zinsser, also survive her as do many nieces and nephews. Funeral service is private. Gifts in her memory may be made to Smith College, Northampton, MA.

According to NPD, more than half of American households owned an mp3 player in 2008. Still, demand is substantial for so-called shelf systems, which are built around CD players. Market share is more evenly spread among companies that make shelf systems, and Apple's iPod family dominates the portable music player market. Shelf systems have changed little in the last decade. But, where they were once equipped with dual cassette players, newer models have cradles for mp3 players. SHELLY FREIERMAN

SMITH Alvin J. Died May 9 at the age of 85 after a brief illness and an eventful life. Raised in the Bronx, he joined the Army in 1943, and trained as a Japanese interpreter. The war ended before he got overseas, and he went into the family millinery business. When hats disappeared in the 1960s, he mastered an entirely new career, eventually establishing his own investment firm. He married Blanche Stern in 1947. They were the happiest of couples: for 62 years each was a source of strength and delight to the other. Next to his family, Alvin loved sports best, especially horse racing, and he could dash through challenging crossword puzzles in ink and in minutes. This witty, generous, sardonic and most sociable man is mourned by his many friends, by his wife, by his daughters Susan, Carol and Laura, by his sons-in-law Neil Meltzer, Richard Snow, and Richard Rosenberg, by his grandchildren Joshua, David, Emily (and her husband Evan), Michael, and Rebecca, as well as his friend of fifty years, Mattie Smith; his son, Richard, died in 1990. Services are at noon today at Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, 11403 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Richard Mark Smith Fund, North Shore-LIJ Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021.

DARCY JAMES ARGUE'S SECRET SOCIETY ''Infernal Machines'' (New Amsterdam) Four years ago Darcy James Argue's Secret Society played its first show, at a Lower Manhattan club that no longer exists. The music, written and arranged by Mr. Argue, an intense young composer from Vancouver, British Columbia, felt crowded with ideas: about jazz orchestration, minimalist rhythmic devices, post-rock textural dynamics. ''Transit,'' which closed the set, paired a driving swing tempo with a dronelike harmonic underlay, creating a dual impression of progress and stasis. It was early in the life of the Secret Society, an 18-piece big band, but already there were the stirrings of an identity.

EL GRUPO NUEVO DE OMAR RODRIGUEZ LOPEZ ''Cryptomnesia'' (Rodriguez Lopez Productions) So many jumpy, frenetic, whipsawing guitar lines go zooming through Omar Rodriguez Lopez's head that his main band, the Mars Volta, can't hold them all. That's why he has his own extensive catalog of solo albums and collaborations, largely (but not entirely) instrumental works like ''Old Money'' (Stone's Throw), which was released earlier this year. (The next Mars Volta album is due in June.)

MALAMED--Paul, passed away from congestive heart failure at St. Francis Hospital May 9, 2009 after a prolonged battle with heart disease. He was 86 years old, lived life and enjoyed, loved and cherished his family so very much. World War II veteran who served in the U.S. Army Air Corps, and former basketball player at City College of NY in late 40s. He was a proprietor who ran Durable Dies Inc., until he retired at 61 years of age. He never complained a day in his life and always maintained and preached a positive attitude. Passover was his favorite holiday and thankfully Paul managed to get to one last holiday down in Florida this past April. He is survived by his devoted and loving wife Marylyn Malamed who was his rock and best friend. Paul was a loving and devoted father survived by his children who cherished his love and being around him, Lori Doris and husband Brian, David Malamed and wife Lisa, Jimmy Helman and wife Sharlene, and Nancy Porush. Poppy's 10 grandchildren meant the world to him and lit him up like no other medicine could. Also survived by his loving sister Adele Pollack and husband Walter, and sister-in-law Shirley Malamed.

Start an animated series with Mitchell Hurwitz, the creator and producer of the short-lived Fox comedy “Arrested Development,” populate it with the voices of Jason Bateman, Will Arnett and other alumni of that abruptly canceled show and…well, you know where this is going. Variety reported that Fox has pulled the final episode of its animated series “Sit Down, Shut Up,” which Mr. Hurwitz adapted from a live-action Australian high school comedy of the same name. The Fox show debuted on April 19 in a Sunday time slot between the network’s hit cartoon series “The Simpsons” and “Family Guy,” but failed to match the ratings of either show. A fifth episode scheduled for Sunday has been pulled and the show is unlikely to be renewed for next season.

Updated | 12:15 p.m. Construction on Guangzhou Opera House, a $100 million structure in China designed by the architect Zaha Hadid, was halted after the building caught fire on Saturday, The Architect’s Newspaper reported. In a statement, Ms. Hadid’s office said that the fire broke out at the opera house’s construction site just before 8 a.m. on Saturday and was contained by firefighters in an hour with no injuries reported. The architect’s office said that an inspection of the opera house’s structure showed it to be intact after the fire, but that an investigation into the cause of the fire would continue. A delay in the building’s opening, scheduled for later this year, was possible. In February, a tower in Beijing designed by Rem Koolhaas caught fire when it was ignited by illegal fireworks, killing at least one person.

George O’Dowd, better known to 1980s-adoring pop-music fans as Boy George, was released from a British prison on Monday after serving four months of a 15-month sentence, The Guardian reported. In January, Mr. O’Dowd, the former front man of the band Culture Club, was convicted of falsely imprisoning a male escort named Audun Carlsen by handcuffing him to a wall in Mr. O’Dowd’s London apartment in 2007. Mr. O’Dowd said that Mr. Carlsen had tried to take photographs from his computer, but at his sentencing, Judge David Radford of Snaresbrook Crown Court in East London said the singer was guilty of “gratuitous violence.” The Guardian said Mr. O’Dowd is expected to wear an electronic tag for the remaining 11 months of his sentence.

Last week we reported that casting was complete for New York City Center’s coming Encores! Summer Stars production of “The Wiz.” Turns out we jumped the gun on that announcement: on Tuesday, it was announced that the final, critical role of Toto has at last been filled.

Updated | 12:42 p.m. The Vatican has opened its Secret Archives, the repository of centuries worth of documents pertaining to the Holy See, to let the world get a closer look at a document presaging England’s split from the Church of Rome. Dated July 13, 1530 and addressed to Pope Clement VII, the letter asks for the annulment of Henry’s marriage to Catherine of Aragon and includes the seals of dozens of peers of England who concurred with the request. A facsimile of the document will go on sale next month for about $68,000 from Venice-based publisher Scrinium, which plans a limited run of 199 copies. A second, more damaged, copy of the document is in England’s National Archives in Kew. The facsimile and accompanying scholarly texts will allow for closer perusal of “the cause of Henry VIII,” Monsignor Sergio Pagano, the archive’s Prefect, told journalists on Tuesday. It will be officially presented in June, on the occasion of the 500th anniversary of Henry’s coronation, but the timing is a coincidence, Monsignor Pagano said. “We do not celebrate kings, only popes.”

James Spader blazed bright first in films as the ’80s bad boys Steff in “Pretty in Pink” and Rip in “Less than Zero” before moving to television and winning three Emmys as the attorney Alan Shore in ABC’s “The Practice” and “Boston Legal.” Next up, theater: Mr. Spader will make his Broadway debut this fall in the new play “Race,” written and directed by David Mamet. The producer Jeffrey Richards, in announcing the casting on Tuesday, maintained his weeks-long silence on the plot of the play (presumably a marketing strategy to heighten public curiosity); he also would not say anything about Mr. Spader’s role, though he did disclose there are other characters in the play. “Race” is scheduled to begin previews at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Nov. 17 and to open on Dec. 6.

The idea was fairly simple: Take a group of bright and energetic recent college graduates, assign them to work with high-level New York City officials, and expose them to the joys (and frustrations) of municipal government. The year was 1969, and idealism about public service was in the air, when an assistant city administrator, Sigmund G. Ginsburg, part of a team of young aides to Mayor John V. Lindsay, invented the Urban Fellows program.

The Web site Pakistan Daily is an Islamabad-based hub for Pakistani citizen journalism, promising Pakistani readers: "Your News. Powered by You." It is also an excellent place to turn if you want to read in on the latest conspiracy theories making the rounds in that country. Or just get very scared.

PRAGUE | Along the alleys of the Jewish Quarter lined with ''Czech-me-out'' t-shirts and tacky Russian nesting dolls, there is a mute monster ready to trample errant tourists or save locals from the latest plague (or financial crisis, as written about here.)
Over at our sib-blog, Bits, Steve Lohr examines the emerging policies on health technology.
Sometimes a movie that looks like a flaming disaster out of the gate can quietly turn itself around.
Ovechkin vs. Crosby in Game 7 -- a matchup made in hockey heaven. Not only is their rivalry an aesthetic and dramatic success, it seems to be sparking a general renaissance in scoring in the N.H.L.

Congratulations to Hayden Metsky, a senior at Millburn High School, who won an expense-paid trip to the International Science and Engineering Fair this week in Reno, with his science research teacher, Dr. Paul Gilmore. Hayden's created software to make computer translation more accurate. And at the North Jersey Regional Science Fair, seniors Emily Bick, Rachel Scharf, and Alexandra Untracht, juniors John Liu and Benjamin Lieber, and sophomore Alison Bick received a variety of honors. Details can be found at the school system's homepage, under district news.

Rekindling the 17-month debate over the proposal by St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan to modernize its facilities in the Greenwich Village Historic District, members of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday sharply criticized the height and mass of a planned luxury condominium on Seventh Avenue that is the financial linchpin of the hospital's two-tower, $1.63 billion reconstruction proposal.
Google unveiled a grab bag of enhancements to its Web search engine and new experimental features on Tuesday that aim to keep the company ahead of rivals.
The current quarter is "a little better than we had expected," Intel's chief executive, Paul Otellini, said Tuesday at an event for financial analysts in Santa Clara, Calif.
A robust fish in a pungent tomato sauce.

Although it was soft-launched and publicly accessible as of last Thursday, today Times Wire is officially live. And the next few days should be very revealing - I'm looking forward to seeing how it's received.
John Feinblatt, the mayor's criminal justice coordinator, decided Tuesday that he would not run for Manhattan district attorney, according to Jason Post, a spokesman for Mr. Feinblatt.
Shares of BankUnited Financial more than doubled Tuesday following reports that the former chief executive of North Fork Bancorp, John Kanas, would lead a takeover attempt of the Florida-based bank.
Recent sales trends in the Caribbean reveal some "unexplained oddities," according to a recent report from Global Property Insight.
Organizers of the Preakness want a tamer experience for the 134th running of the race Saturday, so fans can no longer bring their own beverages to the infield.

"Tochno Sega" is the title of a duet between the 31-year-old Azis - Bulgaria's biggest pop star - and the rapper Ustata. Azis has been heavily involved with Euroroma, his country's socially liberal Roma's rights party, and was recently voted the 21st greatest Bulgarian of all time. (He is also known for simulating sex with men onstage.) Ustata supported 50 Cent on the Bulgarian leg of his tour back in 2006, and is responsible for the song "Clothes are Just an Obstacle to Me."Both Azis and Ustata perform Chalga, a form of Bulgarian folk-pop that combines Roma, Turk and Bulgarian folk strings and brass with electro beats and over-the-top lyrics. In their mind-blowing video, the slightly heavy Asiz imitates Bollywood stars while dressed as a bearded Eastern European gangster's moll; meanwhile, Ustata lounges in a limo and pets a cheetah, perhaps channeling both Biggie Smalls and Ramzan Kadyrov, Chechnya's thuggish, 32-year-old president, who has a well documented penchant for tigers. Our Bulgarian is not quite what it used to be, so we're not really sure what the song is about, but one thing is certain: this duo is challenging not just musical conventions, but just about every traditional notion of masculinity.

A name has been chosen for the Italian restaurant formerly known as Ago, which is set to open next Tuesday. It will be called Locanda Verde, a name that Andrew Carmellini, the executive chef and co-owner, came up with in tandem with Robert De Niro, another owner, after some back and forth. (They rejected Greenwich Kitchen, after the Greenwich Hotel, where the restaurant is located.) Andrew Carmellini is executive chef and co-owner; Karen Demasco is pastry chef. The interior is getting a speedy makeover by Ken Friedman and Meyer Davis, the firm that designed Boqueria and Mas Farmhouse.

[UPDATE, 10:35 pm: Late in the day, as many readers noted and John Broder reported in an update, the White House said the memo did not represent the administration's position.] Over at Green Inc., John Broder has written about a fascinating White House document that conservative lawmakers are calling "a smoking gun" showing that the Obama administration was warned of weaknesses in the finding by the Environmental Protection Agency that greenhouse gases threaten health and welfare. The document is at the federal Regulations.gov Web site. A video snippet from a Senate hearing this morning captures a classic bit of Capitol Hill theatrics focused on the document.

After a lively Spanish Grand Prix weekend in which the controversy on the track was matched by controversy off the track, the post race news is just as hot. In Barcelona, Toyota, Red Bull and Toro Rosso said they would not join in Formula One next season if the rules laid out by the International Automobile Federation concerning the two-tier regulations and budget caps were not altered. Today Ferrari joined in and said that it too would withdraw from Formula One.

Update | 4:55 p.m. The chief investment officer for the Stanford Financial Group was indicted on Tuesday by a federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy and obstruction of justice, The New York Times's Clifford Krauss reports from Houston.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics released its March Job Openings and Labor Turnover Summary data today. The takeaways: Few employers are hiring, and many workers are leaving their jobs (voluntarily or otherwise, though it appears primarily otherwise).
Coach Juan Carlos Osorio could not stop raving about the colorful, healthy salad he made, which the assistant coach, Richie Williams, seemed to be shoveling fork-full after fork-full into his mouth.

BEIJING | As a city, Beijing offers a strong selection of film festivals and screening events held by art spaces, cafes and movie theaters. One accessible film festival that strives to strike a balance between more established works and lesser known films is the New Beijing International Movie Festival.

A friend is teaching in Lithuania this summer and has invited me to join him. I haven't been outside the United States in 30 years, when I covered Western Europe in a summer. I can choose where to go near Lithuania. St. Petersburg is not an option. I'll be there a week. Where should we go? Budapest? Prague?

Parents in Sweden want to name their infant son Q. No, they say, not after the James Bond character who creates things like a watch that doubles as a remote detonator or bullet deflector; but just because that is what they have taken to calling the boy since birth.

The trustee overseeing the liquidation of Bernard L. Madoff's now-defunct investment firm has sued the hedge fund Harley International for the return of $1 billion that it invested with the convicted swindler.

With a two-hour installment of "Dancing With the Stars" and the season finale of "Castle," ABC was easily the most-watched network on Monday night, but the network trailed in third place among adults 18 to 49.

On a low-rated spring night of television on Mother's Day Sunday, CBS averaged just more than 10 million viewers over the course of prime time, but it was enough to edge past its network competitors to finish No. 1 on the night for the 11th consecutive week.

After watching the two games last night in a local establishment, which was filled with hockey fans -- and the local team wasn't even playing -- John Vogl of the Buffalo News writes in his blog this morning, "You just keep figuring the NHL playoffs can't get any better. Shares of Bank of New York Mellon and U.S. Bancorp fell Tuesday after the two banks sold additional common stock to build up their capital as they begin preparing to pay back government bailout money.

Morgan Stanley said Tuesday that its chief legal officer, Gary G. Lynch, will take the additional title of vice chairman at the firm. Mr. Lynch will move from New York to London as part of his expanded position, adding another senior-level executive to the region.

When the former executive director of General Motors' fuel-cell program, J. Byron McCormick, resigned from the Department of Energy's hydrogen advisory committee, he didn't go quietly. On Monday, he sent the energy secretary, Steven Chu, a letter critical of the agency's decision to kill funding for fuel-cell cars in the proposed 2010 budget, reported The Hydrogen & Fuel Cell Letter.

In a 4-to-3 ruling, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled on Tuesday that the State Police violated a criminal suspect's rights under the State Constitution when it placed a GPS tracking device inside the bumper of his van without obtaining a warrant.

In 2007, Richard Sandomir (a sportswriter for The Times) and Mark Reiter published a fun little miscellany, "The Enlightened Bracketologist: The Final Four of Everything," which applied the "science" of sports tournament brackets to everything from cheese (the winner: sbrinz) to male opera arias ("Nessun dorma").

The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the artist Wes Lang shares his essentials. Lang and the artist Ryan Schneider have a show, "Carry On," at the Eighth Veil gallery in Los Angeles opening on May 15. Lang and Eddie Martinez have a two-man show at AliceDay contemporary art gallery in Brussels through May 23. The 62nd Cannes Film Festival kicks off Wednesday with an opening night screening of Pixar's latest animated feature, "Up," which is also the studio's first 3-D film (though they intend to unveil newly 3-D versions of both "Toy Story" and "Toy Story 2" later this year). "Up" follows the adventures of a retired, 78-year-old balloon salesman who floats away with his entire house, and an eight-year-old stowaway, on a quest to South America. This marks the first time that the venerable festival has opened with either an animated film or a 3-D one. The Associated Press' preview of the event notes all the big name directors who are involved this year, including Quentin Tarantino, Pedro Almodovar, Ang Lee and Jane Campion. Reuters opts to point out that the global economic woes are putting the squeeze on everyone's enjoyment of this year's festival. Still, they also note, where Hollywood executives go, hope springs eternal. The Hollywood Reporter says the difference is visible this year. There are simply many fewer giant movie billboards along the Croisette, which links the main festival hall to the glitzy waterfront hotels.

I can't imagine a worse waterway to end up in than the Gowanus Canal -- maybe circa 1980s Charles River in Boston? -- but a man drove his Volvo into the canal in Brooklyn on Saturday.

Maybe I wrote the wrong headline for the post, "What If Scientists Didn't Compete?" It was about an experiment in cooperative science, published in the journal Science, that was conducted by Sean Cutler, an assistant professor of plant cell biology at the University of California, Riverside. The post prompted many readers to insist that competition is essential to science -- and Dr. Cutler says he agrees with them. A better headline, he suggests, would be: What if scientists competed differently?

I'm a recent immigrant to New Jersey, and I guess you could say I'm still getting my bearings. Like a lot of people in our towns, my husband and I moved here from an apartment in the city, where the only interaction I had with a plant was when my daughter once brought home a little pot with a geranium from preschool. When it died a week later, we threw it out, pot included; it would take up too much space. I was content to get my greens in the form of sauteed dried string beans from the Chinese place on Third Avenue.

Last week at the Microsoft Enterprise Developer and Solutions Conference, we announced the availability of the New York Times API Silverlight Toolkit. The Toolkit, developed in conjunction with Microsoft, covers the full spectrum of NYT APIs and greatly simplifies development with our APIs and the Silverlight platform. The Toolkit is open source, and we hope it will enable the vast Microsoft developer community to leverage our APIs. Head on over to the MSDN Code Gallery to download the Toolkit and browse the documentation.

In a new suburban district of Freiburg, Germany that discourages driving -- a "car-reduced" community called Vauban -- there are only two places to park a car, and both are at the edge of the development. As I note in my story in Tuesday's New York Times, 70 percent of Vauban's families do not own cars, and 57 percent sold a car to move there.

On tap at the White House on Tuesday night? A poetry jam - with smooth jazz, cool verses and spoken word. The literary and musical event in the East Room will include the actor James Earl Jones, the writers Michael Chabon and Ayelet Waldman (who are husband and wife), the jazz singer and bassist Esperanza Spalding and the pianist Eric Lewis. Lin-Manuel Miranda, who wrote and starred in "In the Heights," the Broadway musical that won a Tony last year, will also perform. It is part of an effort by the Obamas to open up the White House and celebrate the country's diverse art scenes. The event, which is scheduled to begin at 7:45 p.m., will be shown live at www.whitehouse.gov.

AMSTERDAM | At noon on a recent Wednesday, the line outside the Concertgebouw's (Concertgebouwplein 2-6) main performance hall stretched all the way to the swinging doors some 40 yards back. Fifteen minutes remained before the doors would open for the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra's 30-minute "open rehearsal" with guest conductor, Daniel Harding, and the end of the line, by now, was out of sight. So, newcomers simply formed a second line: conveniently, at the doors just outside the main entrance. No-one called them out on it. This is the Netherlands, and rules are easily set aside when the situation warrants. Besides, the show was free.

On June 7, 2005, Julie Turner of Sheffield, England, told her partner, Darren Akers, that she was heading out to do some shopping. But as the clock inched toward midnight and Ms. Turner, 40, failed to return, Mr. Akers began to panic. Two days later, on June 9, he received a cryptic text message: “Stopping at jills, back later need to sort my head out.” He was baffled — he didn’t know anyone named Jill, and Julie didn’t usually send text messages. Soon afterward, Mr. Akers received another message: “Tell kids not to worry. sorting my life out. be in touch to get some things.” He knew Julie was always careful to let her children know where she would be, and he couldn’t shake a feeling that something was off about the text messages.

In the 1980s and 1990s, a faceless killer stalked young women in the Seattle-Tacoma area. Dozens of women, mostly prostitutes, eventually disappeared, sometimes only a few days apart, sometimes only once or twice a year. The killer had a consistent modus operandi: he would rape the women, strangle them with his hands or a ligature, and then discard their bodies near the Green River. The police compiled a short list of suspects, including Gary Ridgway, a factory worker. But DNA testing was still in its infancy in the 1990s, and since officers lacked enough physical evidence to tie Mr. Ridgway to the crimes, they were unable to arrest him. “The case had basically come to a standstill,” said Beverly Himick, a forensic scientist at the Washington State Patrol Crime Laboratory.

Life seemed to be coasting along smoothly for Mary Blandy. The daughter of Francis Blandy, a well-known lawyer in Oxfordshire, England, Mary was all grown up by the mid-1740s and preparing to marry the love of her life, Capt. William Henry Cranstoun, who was descended from Scottish nobility. But the relationship hit a snag when Mary’s father discovered that Cranstoun had concealed his marriage to a Scottish woman named Anne Murray. Intent on securing the £10,000 dowry that Francis Blandy had advertised to any man who married Mary, Cranstoun decided to take matters into his own hands — or, more accurately, to entrust them to his lover.

The New York Philharmonic said that Esa-Pekka Salonen, above, the outgoing music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, had withdrawn from a series of concerts scheduled for Wednesday through Saturday with the New York orchestra because of back trouble. In a news release, the New York Philharmonic said that Mr. Salonen would be replaced by David Zinman, the music director of the Tonhalle Orchestra in Zurich. He will conduct the Rush Hour Concert on Wednesday night, which will now feature Mussorgsky’s “Night on Bald Mountain” and Shostakovich’s Violin Concerto No. 1, with Christian Tetzlaff as soloist. In concerts on Thursday and Saturday, Mr. Zinman will conduct those works as well as Sibelius’s Symphony No. 5; Friday’s concert will focus on the Sibelius work. Gustavo Dudamel is to take over from Mr. Salonen at the Los Angeles Philharmonic in September.

Still surging from its 15 Tony Award nominations the Broadway musical “Billy Elliot” picked up seven awards from the Outer Critics Circle on Monday, including one for outstanding new Broadway musical. And its three young stars — David Alvarez, Trent Kowalik and Kiril Kulish, who alternate in the title role — were among the Theater World Award winners for outstanding Broadway or Off Broadway debut performances. The Outer Critics Circle also offered special achievement awards to the three “Billy Elliot” leads; “God of Carnage” was named outstanding new Broadway play; “The Norman Conquests” won for play revival, and “Hair” won for musical revival. The Outer Critics Circle awards had a rare tie in the category of outstanding actress in a musical; that award went to both Sutton Foster (for “Shrek the Musical”) and Josefina Scaglione (for “West Side Story”).
The season’s penultimate episode of ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” was Sunday’s most-watched program.

It’s a good thing Tintin’s hair is already standing on end — even he might be surprised by an auction held on Sunday in Belgium at which more than $1.57 million in Tintin-related artwork and items were sold, Agence France-Presse reported. The sale, held in Namur in southern Belgium by the auction house Rops, offered nearly 600 lots related to Tintin, the cartoon boy adventurer created in 1929 by Georges Remi (better known by his alias, Hergé). The highest-priced item was a hand-drawn page from the 1963 book “The Castafiore Emerald,” featuring Tintin; his dog, Snowy; and their fellow adventurer, Captain Haddock; it was bought by an anonymous collector for more than $424,000. The same collector also purchased original artwork of a car crash from the 1956 book “The Calculus Affair.” The total presale estimate for the auction was less than $900,000, Agence France-Presse said.

The Tony Award winners Nathan Lane (“The Producers,” “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum”) and Bebe Neuwirth (“Chicago,” “Sweet Charity”), both at right, will play Gomez and Morticia Addams in the new Broadway musical “The Addams Family,” its producers said on Monday in a news release. The show, with a book by Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice (“Jersey Boys”) and music and lyrics by Andrew Lippa (“The Wild Party”), will revolve around the couple’s daughter Wednesday, now 18, and her family’s adjustment to her coming of age, her new boyfriend and his parents. Wednesday will be played by Krysta Rodriguez (“In the Heights”); Wesley Taylor will play the boyfriend and Terrence Mann (“Les Misérables”) and Carolee Carmello (“Parade”) will play his parents. Rounding out the Addams family are Adam Riegler (“Cubby Bernstein,” “Shrek the Musical “) as Pugsley, Jackie Hoffman (“Hairspray”) as Grandmama, Kevin Chamberlin (“Seussical”) as Uncle Fester and Zachary James as Lurch. The musical is scheduled to begin previews on Broadway on March 4 and to open on April 8.

As befits a producer whose films are well known for large quantities of things blowing up, Jerry Bruckheimer (of the “National Treasure” and “Pirates of the Caribbean” movies) has hired for his video game studio two industry veterans with plenty of shoot-’em-up experience. In a news release Jerry Bruckheimer Games announced that it had hired Jim Veevaert, the executive producer of the Xbox 360 action game Halo 3, as its president for production. The company has also hired Jay Cohen, who has worked on the Tom Clancy-inspired video games Splinter Cell and Rainbow Six, as its president for development. The new studio will develop titles for MTV Games, some of which will have a strong emphasis on action. “Those are the things that we’ve been very successful with in movies,” Mr. Bruckheimer said in an interview, “so hopefully that can cross over into games.”.

A PIANO PRACTICED In the Travel Arts

NEARLY all my traveling was by car when I was a youth. My family drove around the country every summer in the iconic family station wagon. Now it's a different story. I practically live in a plane. I know that I should put together a checklist of things to pack, but I can't bring myself to do so. Of course, I always forget something. Usually, it's a minor item, but on one business trip to Australia, I forgot to pack pants.

In January 2007 the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission received a proposal for the creation of a new South Village Historic District to protect what advocates say is an area important for its architecture and its place in the city's heritage. In the months after, as the commission studied the proposal, owners of buildings in the area began filing for permits to alter or demolish their properties. At 12 Leroy Street, an 1835 town house with elements of both the Federal and Greek Revival styles, the owner obtained a permit to alter the existing two-family home; part of the facade has already been destroyed.

FINA--Charles. The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society mourns with profound sadness the passing of Charles Fina, who together with his family, built a legacy of generosity and dedication to the cause. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Jane; to his children, Michael, Jeffrey and Steven; to his brother, George; and to the entire Fina family.

BERKMAN Deborah Levy, of Cambridge, MA, age 71, on May 9, 2009. Deborah Fels Levy was born in 1938 in Boston, MA, the daughter of the late Benjamin Levy and Shirley (Rome) Levy of Waban and Wellesley. She graduated from The Winsor School and Bryn Mawr College. She married Marshall L. Berkman of Pittsburgh, PA in 1960. After raising their three daughters, Debby earned her M.B.A. from the University of Pittsburgh School of Business, and thereafter served as a Vice President with Kidder Peabody. In 1994 her husband of 35 years died unexpectedly, and she moved from Pittsburgh to Santa Fe, New Mexico. There she developed a host of new friendships and become a highly valued supporter of the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival and the Santa Fe Opera. Six years later, she married Dr. Anton Kris, then of Brookline, MA. In the very brief time between returning to Boston and the onset of her illness two and one-half years ago, she made many new friends and participated in a number of benevolent groups and projects. She leaves her husband of eight years; her three daughters and their husbands, Laura Coleman and her husband Steven of Lexington, MA, Ellen Berkman and her husband David Bryant of Brookline, MA and Martha Winfield and her husband David of London, England; her two stepsons and their wives, David Kris and his wife Jody of Bethesda, MD and Michael Kris and his wife Deborah of Berkley Heights, NJ; her six grandchildren, Sarah and Madeline Coleman, Benjamin and Lily Bryant, and Marshall and Rachel Winfield; two step-granddaughters, Hannah and Audrey Kris; her brother, Frederick Levy; and her father-in-law, Louis Berkman. She also leaves many other family and friends from, among other places, Pittsburgh, Santa Fe and Boston. Her family and friends will remember her as loving, generous, gracious, smart, vigorous and strong. There will be a memorial service at Temple Israel, 477 Longwood Avenue (parking available on the Riverway), Boston, MA on Thursday, May 14, 2009 at 1pm. Burial will be private. Contributions in memory of Deborah Berkman may be made to Temple Israel, Boston, 02215 or the Dana Farber Gynecologic Caner Treatment Center, 10 Brookline Place West, 6th Floor, Brookline, MA 02445-7226.

GOODMAN--Joyce. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed member. We express deepest sympathy to her husband Stephen, her children Andrew, Jennifer, and Robert and to the entire family. Aubrey L. Glazer, Rabbi Israel Singer, Cantor Karen Goldstick, Pres. Ken Brown, Chair.

LEE--Mildred. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Mildred "Micki" Lee, and extends sincere sympathy to her husband, Herbert and other members of her family. Arthur S. Loring, President George M. Ross, Secretary

WEINBERG--Pearl (Oksner), died peacefully at her home in Lake Success, NY on Friday (May 8, 2009). She was born June 28, 1921 in New York City. She graduated from Evander Child High School, attended Hunter College and graduated with an RN degree from Brooklyn State Nursing College. She then joined the Navy attaining the rank of Ensign. Following her discharge she worked as an RN at Beth-El Hospital in Brooklyn where she met her future husband Samuel Weinberg, M.D. They were married in 1948 and remained so until Samuel's death in 2007. Pearl worked side by side with Samuel in his medical practice for over 50 years. She is survived by her brother Harry Oksner, son Ronald Andrew Weinberg, daughter Robin Ann Weinberg, son-in-law Scott Anderson, and two grandsons Eric Charest Weinberg and Alex Charest Weinberg. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, May 12 at 1:45pm at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. The family will be sitting Shiva at the family home at 1 Lake Rd. North, Lake Success. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to: CLL Research Fund, Attn: Dr. Kanti Rai, Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park, NY 11040.

GREENBERG--Leah (nee Koenigsberg), passed away peacefully May 9th in her 99th year. She was the beloved wife of the late Hy Greenberg and the proud mother of her adoring daughter Shelley Greenberg Meyer and son in law Harvey Joel Meyer. She was the family matriarch, a mensch and a spitfire, cherished by her Koenigsberg clan of nieces, nephews and cousins and loved by her extended family of friends, neighbors and "adopted daughters."

KRULWICH--Andrew S. Washington, DC. Beloved father of Allison, Benjamin, and Thea Krulwich. Brother of Jeffrey and the late Theodore Krulwich. Adored uncle, cousin, colleague and friend. He will be deeply missed. Funeral services Tuesday, May 12, at 12:30pm, at Ohr Kodesh Congregation in Chevy Chase, MD. In lieu of flowers, kindly donate to Jewish Federation of Greater Washington.

Roger Clemens, who has essentially made himself unavailable to reporters since he testified before Congress in February 2008, is scheduled to be interviewed on ESPN's ''Mike & Mike in the Morning'' on Tuesday, the show said in a statement. Shortly after the Mitchell report was released in December 2007, Clemens was interviewed by Mike Wallace on CBS's ''60 Minutes.'' In that interview Clemens adamantly denied the assertions in the report by his former trainer Brian McNamee that Clemens had used steroids on numerous occasions from 1998 to 2001. In February 2008, Clemens and McNamee testified before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform and, after Clemens's testimony contradicted that of McNamee, the committee asked the Justice Department to investigate Clemens for perjury. Since then, Clemens has said little publicly.

HADDAD--Mac A.,passed away on May 8, 2009 at the age of 100. Born in Aleppo, Syria, he arrived in America as an infant in 1910. Raised in Manhattan's Lower East Side tenements, he went to work at the age of 13 to help support his family of 12. He served this country as a sergeant in World War II, as a machine gunner in North Africa and Italy. In 1947, he and his brothers Hy and Joe founded Haddad Brothers, Inc., a children's wear company. Devoted to serving his community, he was an officer and significant contributor to the building of Congregation Shaare Zion, a founder of Congregation Beth Torah in Brooklyn, and President of Magen David Synagogue of Bradley Beach, NJ. He was tireless in his efforts on behalf of Camp Seven and Sephardic Renaissance, both of which served underprivileged children. He was a Past Master Mason. He neither asked for nor sought recognition for his many acts of charity, benevolence and kindness. A self-made man with integrity, character, warmth and humor, he was rarely seen without his cigar. He was a shining example of the "Greatest Generation" and his passing marks an end of an era. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife Mona, and four children Barbara, Alan, Lori, and Mitchell, his 12 grandchildren, and one great-grandchild, two brothers and three sisters. Dad, you are our hero and role model. Your love, generosity, wisdom, humor and kindness will be greatly missed. You made the world a better place for all those who had the good fortune to know you. We promise that the glowing embers of your precious memory will forever burn in our hearts bringing with it the warmth and comfort of your everlasting love, broad smile and eternal blessings.

At last count YouTube listed seven pages of fan videos under the subject heading Huddy, the Brangelina-ized coinage meant to designate the fractious love connection between Doctors Cuddy and House on the Fox series ''House.'' One of these videos abjures all the cheesy sentiment that the show, which ended its fifth season on Monday, has aggressively rejected. Alluding to the impediments presented by House's painkiller addiction, the video is in French and titled: ''Je Me Sens Si Seul (Sans Ma Vicodine),'' or ''I Feel So Alone (Without My Vicodin).'' Among the non-Euro entries, some toss reality out altogether, extrapolating from random House-Cuddy scenes to completely fabricate plotlines. I point you to ''House/Cuddy -- Kissing You,'' by someone who calls herself Duchesscloverly, a video that imagines Cuddy pregnant with House's baby and then enduring a miscarriage that we are meant to believe bonds them further.

RUGGIERI--Bernard J. of New York and Southampton died May 8th, aged 83. Born in Brooklyn, he was the son of the late Joseph and Mary Ruggieri. He was a graduate of Poly Prep, Brown University and Brooklyn Law School. He served in the U.S. Army as a second lieutenant. Mr Ruggieri was assistant counsel to the late Governor Averell Harriman, legislative representitive of the City of New York under the late Mayor Robert Wagner of New York and he was New York City's liaison to the administration of Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. He later served as counsel to both the majority and minority leaders of the New York Senate. Mr. Ruggieri was head of the government relations department at the firm of Shea and Gould, representing the legislative and executive branches of New York State as well as New York City. In 1972 he was elected head of the New York City Democratic Party. He served on the boards of Daytop Village and St. Vincent's Hospital. He was a member of the Meadow Club and The Bathing Corporation of Southampton. He is survived by his wife, Martha McLanahan, his daughters Christina and Kate as well as their half sister Lisa Hearst Hagerman. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his name to Daytop Village, 43 West 38th Street, New York 10018 or to NYU's Langone's Brain and Aging Dementia Research Center, NYU School of Medicine, MLH 321, 550 First Avenue, New York 10016. Friends may call May 12th from 5 to 7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. On May 13th at 11am, there will be a funeral mass at St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 67th Street.

President Obama welcomed Coach Roy Williams and the University of North Carolina men's basketball team to the White House on Monday, praising the Tar Heels for winning the N.C.A.A. championship last month. ''Congratulations on bringing Carolina its fifth national championship,'' Mr. Obama said. ''And, more importantly, thanks for salvaging my bracket and vindicating me before the entire nation. That first round was rough on me.''

CLUB Necaxa, a Mexican club founded in 1923, was relegated from the top division on Sunday for the first time in team history. The Rayos (Lightning Bolts), owned by Emilio Azcárraga Jean, the chief executive of the TV company Grupo Televisa, moved to a 25,000-seat stadium in Aguascalientes in 2003, leaving behind Estadio Azteca in Mexico City. PLAYER In England, the American goalkeeper Tim Howard broke Neville Southall's Everton record for shutouts in a league season when he recorded his 16th in a 0-0 tie with Tottenham. Everton is assured of finishing among the top six in the Premier League, earning a spot in next season's Europa League, the revamped tournament formerly known as the UEFA Cup. Everton will play Chelsea in the F.A. Cup final on May 30 at Wembley Stadium.

Correction Appended Maria Sharapova, a former world No. 1, will play next week in the Warsaw Open, her first singles tournament since being sidelined with a shoulder injury in August. Sharapova, 22, missed the Beijing Olympics, the United States Open and the Australian Open. She had surgery on her shoulder in October and recently pulled out of Rome and Madrid, two warm-up events for the French Open. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

Still surging from its 15 Tony Award nominations the Broadway musical ''Billy Elliot'' picked up seven awards from the Outer Critics Circle on Monday, including one for outstanding new Broadway musical. And its three young stars -- David Alvarez, Trent Kowalik and Kiril Kulish, who alternate in the title role -- were among the Theater World Award winners for outstanding Broadway or Off Broadway debut performances. The Outer Critics Circle also offered special achievement awards to the three ''Billy Elliot'' leads; ''God of Carnage'' was named outstanding new Broadway play; ''The Norman Conquests'' won for play revival, and ''Hair'' won for musical revival. The Outer Critics Circle awards had a rare tie in the category of outstanding actress in a musical; that award went to both Sutton Foster (for ''Shrek the Musical'') and Josefina Scaglione (for ''West Side Story'').

ENNIS--Jerome, M.D.,of New York City and Sharon, CT, died peacefully on May 11, 2009, at age 84. A psychiatrist and psychoanalyst for over 50 years, Jerry loved his profession and worked until his recent illness. He was a member of The New York Psychoanalytic Society and a faculty member of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute. He was cherished beyond words by his loving wife Fay, devoted daughters Susie and Betsy, adoring granddaughters Emma and Sarah, and son-in-law Richard Olcott.

Ichiro Ozawa, the Japanese opposition leader, announced his resignation on Monday, saying he wanted to prevent a campaign finance scandal involving one of his aides from hurting his party's chances of unseating the long-governing Liberal Democratic Party. Mr. Ozawa told a hastily gathered news conference that he would step down as head of Japan's main opposition Democratic Party, whose lead in public opinion polls has shrunk as a result of the scandal. The scandal erupted in early March, when prosecutors arrested one of Mr. Ozawa's aides, who is accused of taking illegal donations from a construction company.

IT is the best of evidence, and the worst of evidence. DNA is the gold standard. But much of forensic science has been labeled unscientific and unreliable, like identification of individuals by fingerprints and bite marks. Now, some researchers are aiming to turn the field around with new developments in pattern recognition, new studies of how humans lie, new advances in following the Internet tracks of wrongdoers. It's the new forensics, and it may even rehabilitate fingerprints.

Residents of this upscale community are suburban pioneers, going where few soccer moms or commuting executives have ever gone before: they have given up their cars. Street parking, driveways and home garages are generally forbidden in this experimental new district on the outskirts of Freiburg, near the French and Swiss borders. Vauban's streets are completely ''car-free'' -- except the main thoroughfare, where the tram to downtown Freiburg runs, and a few streets on one edge of the community. Car ownership is allowed, but there are only two places to park -- large garages at the edge of the development, where a car-owner buys a space, for $40,000, along with a home.

WINIK--Norman. We say farewell to Norman, a wonderful sport and our friend of over 50 years. We loved him and sympathize with his sweetheart, Elaine, whose gentleness graced his life. The Saturday Game

DALESSANDRO--Frances Wynne Callahan of New York and Southampton, NY, died peacefully at her New York home on May 8th after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Fran was 68. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 37 years, John J. Dalessandro, Jr. Fran leaves behind her three brothers, J. Michael Callahan and his wife, Tina, Alfred J. Callahan, Jr. and Charles W. Callahan and his wife Beatrice. She also leaves behind her beloved nephew, Alfred (Alfie) J. Callahan III, and her two nieces, Victoria Pollard and Ya Ya Callahan and one grandniece, Finley Nae Pollard. Fran graduated from Georgian Court College, Lakewood, NJ class of 1962. After college, Fran worked for Mademoiselle magazine and became associate merchandising editor. She then was employed by the May Company in their New York office. Fran began as an assistant buyer and had the distinction of being the first female buyer for men's clothing in the industry. She traveled the world over the course of 30 years in business and retired as Senior Vice President -Creative Merchandising for what was then a $12 billion corporation, According to Cathie Black, Fran broke the "glass ceiling" as one of the highest-ranking women in fashion publishing and retail merchandising. She was a mentor to many young women on their way up, always pointing the way and gladly sharing her experiences. Dawn Mello, a mentor at the May Company said "Fran was a warm and generous spirit. From the very start of her tenure at the May Company she displayed the strength, grace and style for which she came to be known." Fran was a member of the Bathing Corporation of Southampton, the Meadow Club of Southampton, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, The Colony Club of New York and the Sailfish Club of Palm Beach. Her family will receive friends at the O'Connell Funeral Home, Southampton, NY on Tuesday, May 12th from 2 to 4 and from 7 to 9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said in celebration of her life at The Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church in Southampton on Wednesday, May 13th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in her name to the Southampton Fresh Air Home.

On tap at the White House on Tuesday night? A poetry jam -- with smooth jazz, cool verses and spoken word. The literary and musical event in the East Room will include the actor James Earl Jones, the writers Michael Chabon and Ayelet Waldman (who are husband and wife), the jazz singer and bassist Esperanza Spalding and the pianist Eric Lewis. Lin-Manuel Miranda, who wrote and starred in ''In the Heights,'' the Broadway musical that won a Tony last year, will also perform. It is part of an effort by the Obamas to open up the White House and celebrate the country's diverse art scenes. The event, which is scheduled to begin at 7:45 p.m., will be shown live at www.whitehouse.gov. RACHEL L. SWARNS

As walk-in clinics at stores like CVS and Wal-Mart offer convenient alternatives to doctors' offices and hospital emergency rooms, some hospitals are fighting back -- with walk-in clinics at some of those same retailers. Around the country, hospitals are now affiliated with more than 25 Wal-Mart clinics. The Cleveland Clinic has lent its name and backup services to a string of CVS drugstore clinics in northeastern Ohio. And the Mayo Clinic is in the game, operating one Express Care clinic at a supermarket in Rochester, Minn., and a second one across town at a shopping mall.

RUGGIERI--Bernard J. Few stood so tall on the frontiers of hope and recovery for this town's distressed young people. Bernard Ruggieri refused to turn his back upon the anguish of a generation of the addicted-young as he took the reins of Daytop Village, a major community effort in saving young lives. For 30 years, he emblazoned the trail toward recovery from drugs for area youth. Legions of the young, present and past, won a renewed birthright. Heaven bless Bernie Ruggieri! Msgr. William B. O'Brien President, Daytop Village, Inc.

FINA--Charles. We are heartbroken to have to say good-bye to a very kind brother-in-law. Charlie was a good and generous son-in-law to my parents Howard and Marilyn Finklestein, a cherished and admired uncle to Matt and Pam Chasin and Moe and Farin Fodeman and most of all he was the most wonderful husband and best friend to my sister Jane. Beverly and Bob

It's a good thing Tintin's hair is already standing on end -- even he might be surprised by an auction held on Sunday in Belgium at which more than $1.57 million in Tintin-related artwork and items were sold, Agence France-Presse reported. The sale, held in Namur in southern Belgium by the auction house Rops, offered nearly 600 lots related to Tintin, the cartoon boy adventurer created in 1929 by Georges Remi (better known by his alias, Hergé). The highest-priced item was a hand-drawn page from the 1963 book ''The Castafiore Emerald,'' featuring Tintin; his dog, Snowy; and their fellow adventurer, Captain Haddock; it was bought by an anonymous collector for more than $424,000. The same collector also purchased original artwork of a car crash from the 1956 book ''The Calculus Affair.'' The total presale estimate for the auction was less than $900,000, Agence France-Presse said.

Photography is an invaluable tool for documenting accident and crime scenes, but critical forensic information can be lost because cameras flatten three-dimensional space into two-dimensional images. Forensic photogrammetry attempts to reverse the process, by geometrically analyzing flat images to extract three-dimensional information about the scene.

VIDEO: YO JUDE The first episode of Yo Jude -- a new video series from Personal Tech that will answer readers' questions about gadgets, software and more each week -- tackles camera flash settings. ''Jude'' Biersdorfer, the tech Q. and A. columnist, and Sam Grobart, the personal tech editor, offer their tips. nytimes.com/personaltech

Malaysia's governing party was dealt a surprise setback on Monday when a judge ruled that its takeover of one of the county's largest state governments was illegal. The struggle for control over the state of Perak in the country's northwest has served as a political proxy war between the party, which is suffering from infighting and waning support, and an ascendant national opposition movement that made historic gains in elections a year ago.

HAMMOND--Robert M.,born December 29, 1920, received his B.A. from the University of Rochester in 1942, and his M.A. and Ph.D. from Yale in 1948 and 1952. His teaching and research interests included French language, literature, and cinema. He also wrote over 40 plays, several books and poetry. He taught French at the University of Arizona until 1966, and at SUNY Cortland where he also served as chair of the International Communications and Culture Department. Upon his retirement in 1988 he moved to Paris, where he lived with his wife Marguerite until her death on June 30, 2008. The Fales Library at New York University holds the Robert Hammond Papers as well as the Hammond Film Script Collection. He died on April 16, 2009, and is survived by his children Roberta and Charles.

Seven astronauts blasted off on Monday for one last dance with the Hubble Space Telescope. The space shuttle Atlantis, commanded by Scott D. Altman, a retired Navy captain, bolted through the sky on a pillar of smoke and fire just after 2 p.m. The Atlantis is carrying 22,000 pounds of custom-designed tools, replacement parts and new instruments to slice and dice starlight and excite scientists and stargazers everywhere. The shuttle is rushing toward a Wednesday rendezvous with the telescope, which happened to be floating about 350 miles directly above Cape Canaveral at launching time.

BANKS THAT PREFER BOREDOM Community banks have hardly suffered from the credit crisis, in part because the industry prefers its business to be boring -- and safe. As one bank executive in Indiana said, ''If banking gets exciting, there is something wrong with it.'' PIRACY SPREADS TO BOOKS There has long been digital piracy of movies and music, but now there is a growing problem with the pirating of books. [A1.]

Yes, President Obama was smiling during the White House Correspondents' Association dinner on Saturday evening when the comedian Wanda Sykes made a derisive joke about Rush Limbaugh. Upon reflection, though, what did the White House think of the suggestion from Ms. Sykes that Mr. Limbaugh, the conservative commentator, was the 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 attacks ''but he was so strung out on Oxycontin he missed his flight''?

Ursula K. Le Guin, the science fiction writer, was perusing the Web site Scribd last month when she came across digital copies of some books that seemed quite familiar to her. No wonder. She wrote them, including a free-for-the-taking copy of one of her most enduring novels, ''The Left Hand of Darkness.'' Neither Ms. Le Guin nor her publisher had authorized the electronic editions. To Ms. Le Guin, it was a rude introduction to the quietly proliferating problem of digital piracy in the literary world. ''I thought, who do these people think they are?'' Ms. Le Guin said. ''Why do they think they can violate my copyright and get away with it?''
Banking should not be exciting. If banking is exciting there is something wrong with it. CLAY EWING, president of German American Bancorp., a community bank in Jasper, Ind. [A1]

FELDMAN--Claire. Dearest Claire, May 12, 1922- November 3, 1996. Were it not for the vivid memories of our shared inner thoughts and feelings, your loss would be too hard to endure. So fortunate to have had you as my sister. Love, Miriam

The top American commander in Afghanistan, Gen. David D. McKiernan, was forced out Monday in an abrupt shake-up intended to bring a more aggressive and innovative approach to a worsening seven-year war. Defense Secretary Robert M. Gatesannounced the decision in terse comments at the Pentagon, saying that ''fresh eyes were needed'' and that ''a new approach was probably in our best interest.'' When asked if the dismissal ended the general's military career, Mr. Gates replied, ''Probably.''

In treating alcohol abuse and alcoholism, ''we haven't yet reached the Prozac moment,'' says Dr. Mark Willenbring, referring to the drugs that radically changed the treatment of depression. But Dr. Willenbring, an expert on treating alcohol addiction, predicts that the day is not far off when giving a pill and five minutes of advice to an alcohol abuser will be all that is needed to keep drinking under control. Two such medications are already available, though they are not as effective as modern antidepressants have been for depression.

STEINER--Monroe, age 92, of Westport, CT on Monday May 11, 2009. Beloved husband of Marilyn; devoted father of Amy and Richard Schafrann and Cindy and Leo Asen; adored grandfather of Daniel, Allie, Pam and Sara; brother of Helen and Robert Fried, and uncle of Patti Seymour, Pam Fox Joravsky and Judy Hirsch Hahn. Founder and former owner of Darien Bootery. Loved his "mountain," family, beach, Sinatra and walks, and will be in our hearts forever. In lieu of flowers, any contributions may be made to Norwalk Hospital Foundation Circle of Caring, www.norwalkhealth.org.

The disclosures have been outrageous and ridiculous, sometimes both at once. Oliver Letwin, the head of policy for the Conservative Party, claimed $3,000 to replace a leaky pipe under his tennis court in Somerset. Barbara Follett, a Labor member of Parliament and the wife of the author Ken Follett, charged $38,000 for security patrols at her house in London after she was mugged. David Willetts, a Conservative education spokesman, charged $120 to have an electrician come to his house and change the light bulbs in the bathroom.

After failing to nab a single Tony Award nomination last week, followed by a 5 percent decline in its grosses for the week, the revival of Eugene O’Neill’s “Desire Under the Elms” appears to be on the rocks.

The 62nd Cannes Film Festival gets under way in France on Wednesday and for once, the hoopla about the look of the stars in the premiere screening may be justified.For the first time, an animated movie – a 3-D animated movie, no less – has been chosen to open the festival. “Up,” from Disney and Pixar, about a retired balloon salesman (voiced by Ed Asner) who sets his house afloat, will be the gala screening on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. The lineup also includes weightier fare, like Lars von Trier’s “Antichrist,” Quentin Tarantino’s “Inglourious Basterds” and “The White Ribbon” by Michael Hanecke. The top prize, the Palme D’Or, chosen by a jury led by the actress Isabelle Huppert, will be announced on May 24.

Sin Fang Bous is a one-man experimental rock band from Iceland, and the artist Andrew Kuo regrets that he discovered its striking debut album, “Clangour,” a year late. (It was rereleased in the United States on Morr Music in February.) (Enlarge here.)

“Guitar Hero” was just the tip of the gaming iceberg for Aerosmith. Now the group, whose music is featured in a popular version of the game released last year, will put its songs and images behind a branded lottery game, Billboard reported.

We had more than 400 comments on our discussion about whether it's possible to live without a car in most places in the United States. Readers shared their stories of doing without cars in places like Scottsdale, Ariz., Columbus, Ohio, rural Nevada, Las Vegas, Delray Beach, Fla., Boise and Salem, Mass. Others said that our forum was elitist and urban-centric and that we failed to take account of Americans' love of their cars and open spaces. Here are excerpts from the comments.

And while there are a lot of ways to get notified by phone that a flight has arrived - several airlines' Web sites provide an automated text service - timing a pick-up really requires you to know when a plane is approaching an airport, not when it's already there.

As his Capitals got ready for Game 7 against the Penguins Wednesday night at Verizon Center in Washington, the owner Ted Leonsis pointed out that his team was trying to do what its American League affiliate, the Hershey Bears, had accomplished in the playoffs Tuesday night. The Bears won a Game 7 at home over Pittsburgh's A.H.L. team, the Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Penguins in the division finals series.

There will be free screenings of "Meat the Truth," the latest in a series of movies about food production (who'd'a thunk it?) at the New York Film Academy on this Sunday, May 17, at 5 p.m. and 7 p.m. The film is presented by the Dutch Party for Animals (as far as I know, the Netherlands is the only country in the world in which animals are represented in Parliament; see meatthetruth.com); I have not seen it but love the poster.

Lady Gaga wore an orbiting head piece designed by the young milliner Nasir Mazhar on "The Ellen Degeneres Show" yesterday, a daring piece of daytime drama that deserves reflection. Mazhar, 26, who showed his first collection of outré toppers at London Fashion Week last February (Daryoush Haj-Najafi wrote about the presentation for The Moment here), has a lot in common with the pop diva: they're both young, fearless clotheshorses finding their voice in a shifting commercial universe -- Mazhar in fashion; Gaga in music -- without losing their madcap exuberance.

Ever the statesman, former Mayor David N. Dinkins refused to publicly criticize Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during the debate over term limits. Instead, he quietly called Mr. Bloomberg and conveyed his opposition to the third-term maneuver, according to those familiar with the call.

Jayson Werth of the Phillies did what Little Leaguers often do by stealing home on the catcher. But in Little League the bases are only 60 feet apart and the catcher can be someone who is playing the position for the first time or who is challenged just by catching pitches. Werth did it in the major leagues.

We can only dream of a world in which borders and race don't matter, but in the meantime fashion-conscious travelers who want to make a bit of a difference can invest in these eye-catching passport holders created by Valextra and Margherita Missoni. Part of their sale's proceeds will go to OrphanAid Africa, a non-profit organization that supports orphans and at-risk children in Ghana. They retail for $290, and are available at Barneys New York and online at www.yoox.com.

As someone who lives, eats and breathes travel, mentally I'm always in two places at once: wherever I actually am, and wherever I'm dreaming about going. (Does that make me the least Buddhist person on the planet?) Italy is always top of mind for me at this time of year - and, in fact, I usually do get there sometime in late Spring, but this year it's just not meant to be. And so I find myself turning to my most reliable conduit to the country I love best: drink.

My first look at Baltimore, home of Pimlico and the Preakness, was from the window of a descending red-eye flight from the West Coast. It was about six o'clock in the morning and what I saw seemed utterly unearthly: diffused rays of pink daybreak over the Chesapeake Bay combined with the orange glare of a burning city. Massive plumes of black smoke towered over Baltimore.

Edward M. Liddy, the chairman of American International Group, said on Wednesday that the company would probably need "three to five years'' to carry out its restructuring plan and to fully repay the taxpayer money used to bail it out.

Liddy, the chairman of the American International Group, said Wednesday that the company would probably need "three to five years" to carry out its restructuring plan and repay the taxpayer money used to bail it out, The New York Times's Edmund L. Eden Ross Lipson, who died yesterday at 66 from pancreatic cancer, was a person of superhuman energies. An editor at the Book Review for 31 years, she was most visible for the last 21 of them as The Times' children's books editor until her retirement in 2005. (Click here to read her final children's special issue.) She also wrote more than 100 articles and reviews for The Times about cultural phenomena ranging from "Harry Potter" to "The Lion King"; edited "The New York Times Parent's Guide to the Best Books for Children" (Three Rivers Press) and, for a time, The Times' internal newsletter TimesTalk. For three years, she was the volunteer librarian at the Adolph S. Ochs School, PS 111, on West 53rd Street, which had no librarian of its own and hardly any library. In 2005, Eden founded an internship program to bring young editors from children's publishers into the library to read to third-graders - visits from which she thought the editors might learn even more than the kids.

After his visit on Monday to the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial, some Israelis complained that the German-born pope spoke only in generalities about the Holocaust and did not mention Nazi Germany. Does that criticism have some validity, or is it unfair?

South Orange Village, Eden Gourmet and Sterling Properties have won a Smart Growth award from the non-profit group, New Jersey Future, for their project that features the grocery store and nearby apartment units (still under construction) near the train station. The award, in the Main Street Development category, honors projects "that reflect the most forward-looking development and redevelopment practices in New Jersey." About 30 projects applied for the awards, and seven were chosen by a panel including professional planners. "It's a mixed-use development that incorporates new residences, businesses and jobs all in close proximity to public transportation," said Rick Sinding, a spokesman for New Jersey Future. "And it enhances the character of the neighborhood. It has all the elements to make it a real smart-growth project." The awards will be presented on June 3 in Newark.

There is a house in Maplewood that reminds me of my son's Fisher-Price castle, with notches along part of the roof line that seem medieval. Another house I love has a cobblestone foundation. Ionic and Doric columns can be found supporting porches on many local streets, as well as stained-glass transoms and ornamental wood shingles that capture the eyes of many passers-by.

A few weeks ago when the weather started to get warmer, I was finally inspired to buy a pair of summer sandals. I had long been dreaming of gladiator style sandals with a slight wedge, but when I tried them on I was instantly turned off because they made my legs look shorter than they already are. I came back to the office and spoke to my co-workers who say they have similar problems with sandals. Not all sandals are the same and they certainly don't fit everyone the same way.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: What a scandal we've had brewing here in the Golden State. You're not going to believe this, but Miss California, a beauty contestant, posed for naked pictures. Her fate was decided by Donald Trump, who owns the Miss USA pageant. FRONT PAGE.

A picture caption on Saturday with an obituary about Dom DiMaggio, a perennial All-Star with the Boston Red Sox in the 1940s and ’50s, misstated the timing of the photograph showing him in uniform with his brother Joe and his teammate Ted Williams. It was taken during the 1942 season, not at the 1941 All-Star Game.

Because of an editing error, an Art entry in the Week Ahead report on Sunday misstated the telephone number of the Park Avenue Armory, which is opening Ernesto Neto’s “Anthropodino” installation on Thursday. It is (212) 616-3930.

An article on Saturday about La Caja Mágica, a new tennis complex in Madrid designed by the architect Dominique Perrault, misidentified the location of the new French National Library in Paris, which Perrault also designed. It is on the Left Bank of the Seine, not the Right Bank.
A contemporary art auction at Sotheby’s brought in $47 million, about half of what one work fetched last year.
A lawyer killed by gunmen over the weekend left behind a videotape saying that if anything happened to him it was at the behest of President Álvaro Colom.
A Libyan militant whose false information was used by the Bush administration as part of its justification for war in Iraq hanged himself in a prison in Libya, a Libyan paper reported.
Donald Trump declared that Carrie Prejean could keep her title, despite apparent violations of her contract with the Miss Universe Organization.

An article on Monday about the core of young players on the Los Angeles Dodgers — Russell Martin, Matt Kemp, James Loney and Andre Ethier — who are being counted on during the 50-game suspension of their veteran teammate Manny Ramirez, referred incorrectly to Ethier’s career background. He joined the Dodgers’ minor league system through a trade in 2005 with the Oakland A’s; he did not rise through the Dodgers’ farm system as did the other three players.

An article on Friday about GMAC’s probable need for a federal bailout erroneously included one company on a list of nonbank institutions that the Federal Reserve agreed last fall to convert into bank holding companies. MetLife is not among those to be converted. (It is already a federally chartered bank holding company, having started MetLife Bank in 2001.).

An article on Monday about the many ways that “American Idol” produces profit for its producers and the networks that broadcast it misidentified the channel that shows a companion series called “American Idol Rewind,” which repeats segments from earlier seasons. That show is syndicated and is carried by TV Guide Network. It is not shown on the Fox Reality Channel, which carries “American Idol Extra,” featuring interviews with eliminated contestants and performances by Idol contestants from previous seasons.

An article on April 29 about an appeal heard in a Scottish court by a Libyan who was the only person ever convicted in the 1988 bombing of a Pan American jumbo jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, misstated the location of the special Scottish court where he was put on trial. It was Camp Zeist, a former NATO air base near Utrecht, Netherlands — not The Hague.

An article on April 27 about the mayoral election in the 2014 Winter Olympic city of Sochi, Russia, which has a large Armenian population, paraphrased incorrectly from remarks about Turkey’s World War I genocide of Armenians made by Garry Kasparov, the former world chess champion, who was visiting Sochi to support the challenger to the Kremlin-backed incumbent. Mr. Kasparov said the “newly born Soviet power” had supported Turkey at the time of the genocide, a reference to the Bolsheviks who were rising to power in Russia at the time. He did not say “Soviet Russia” had supported Turkey. (Soviet Russia, or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, was not created until after World War I.).

An article on Monday about military training to counter computer attacks misstated part of the name of one institution that fielded a team in a competition to establish and protect a computer network against cyberattacks. It is the Naval Postgraduate School, not the Naval Postgraduate Academy.
Carlos Beltran drew a bases-loaded walk from Jeff Bennett with two outs in the 10th inning and the Mets rallied to beat the Atlanta Braves.

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about relations between colleges and their neighbors misstated the status of a new science complex for Harvard. The foundation of the building will be finished, then Harvard will decide whether it can afford to continue. The construction will not be “suspended, leaving a gaping hole and empty buildings” in the Allston neighborhood, the site of the project.
All civil lawsuits arising from the 2007 collapse of the Crandall Canyon coal mine were settled by an agreement that will require financial compensation but no admission of liability, lawyers said.
The Department of Defense has identified 4,279 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:.
The internal government memorandum challenged the scientific and economic basis of a proposed finding that climate-altering gases are a threat to human health and welfare.
