Construction on the Guangzhou Opera House, a $100 million structure designed by the architect Zaha Hadid for the southern Chinese city, was halted after the building caught fire on Saturday, The Architect’s Newspaper reported. In a statement, Ms. Hadid’s office said the fire broke out at the opera house’s construction site early Saturday and was contained by firefighters in an hour with no injuries reported. The architect’s office said that an inspection of the structure showed it to be intact after the fire but that an investigation into the cause of the fire would continue. The building was scheduled to open later this year. In February, a tower in Beijing designed by Rem Koolhaas caught fire when it was ignited by illegal fireworks, killing at least one person.

The Vatican has opened its secret archives, the repository of centuries worth of documents pertaining to the Holy See, to let the world get a closer look at a document presaging England’s split from the Church of Rome. Dated July 13, 1530, and addressed to Pope Clement VII, the letter, right, asks for the annulment of Henry VIII’s marriage to Catherine of Aragon and includes the seals of dozens of peers of England who concurred with the request. A reproduction of the document will go on sale next month for about $68,000 from the Venice-based publisher Scrinium, which plans a limited run of 199 copies. A second, more damaged copy of the document is in England, at the National Archives in Kew. The reproduction and accompanying scholarly texts will allow for closer perusal of “the cause of Henry VIII,” Monsignor Sergio Pagano, the Vatican archive’s prefect, told journalists on Tuesday. It will be officially presented in June, on the occasion of the 500th anniversary of Henry’s coronation, but the timing is a coincidence, Monsignor Pagano said. “We do not celebrate kings, only popes.”.
“Dancing With the Stars” dominated the ratings on Monday night.

The rock musician Peter Gabriel, below, and the conductor and composer Jose Antonio Abreu were both named winners of the Swedish Polar Music Prize, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Gabriel, a singer-songwriter and activist, was honored for his “outward-looking and boundary-busting artistry,” while Mr. Abreu was recognized for founding the Sistema music education program in Venezuela, which “has given hundreds of thousands the tools to leave poverty,” said the Swedish Royal Academy of Music, which chooses the winners. Mr. Gabriel and Mr. Abreu will each receive about $128,000 and will formally accept the prize from King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden at a ceremony in Stockholm on Aug. 31.

The American Federation of Arts, the New York nonprofit group that helps produce exhibitions, said that George G. King would be its next director. In a release, the organization said that Mr. King, the director of the Georgia O’Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., would begin his new position on Aug. 1. He succeeds Julia Brown, who resigned in December. ... BET announced that Jamie Foxx, the actor, singer and comedian, would host the 2009 edition of its annual BET Awards. In a news release, the cable channel said that this year’s show would take place on June 28.

Start an animated series with Mitchell Hurwitz, the creator and producer of the short-lived Fox comedy “Arrested Development,” populate it with the voices of Jason Bateman, Will Arnett and other alumni of that abruptly canceled show and — well, you know where this is going. Variety reported that Fox has pulled the final episode of its animated series “Sit Down, Shut Up,” which Mr. Hurwitz adapted from a live-action Australian high school comedy of the same name. The Fox show made its debut on April 19 in a Sunday time slot between the network’s hit cartoon series “The Simpsons” and “Family Guy,” but it failed to match the ratings of either show. A fifth episode scheduled for Sunday has been pulled, and the show is unlikely to be renewed for next season.

James Spader, left, first blazed bright in films as the ’80s bad boys Steff in “Pretty in Pink” and Rip in “Less Than Zero” before moving to television and winning three Emmys as the lawyer Alan Shore in “The Practice” and “Boston Legal” on ABC. Next up, theater: Mr. Spader will make his Broadway debut this fall in the new play “Race,” written and directed by David Mamet. The producer Jeffrey Richards, in announcing the casting on Tuesday, maintained his weeks of silence on the plot of the play (presumably a marketing strategy to heighten public curiosity); he also would not say anything about Mr. Spader’s role, though he did disclose that there are other characters in the play. “Race” is scheduled to begin previews at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Nov. 17 and to open on Dec. 6.

George O’Dowd, better known to ’80s-adoring pop music fans as Boy George, was released from a British prison on Monday after serving 4 months of a 15-month sentence, The Guardian reported. In January Mr. O’Dowd, the former front man of the band Culture Club, was convicted of falsely imprisoning a male escort named Audun Carlsen by handcuffing him to a wall in Mr. O’Dowd’s London apartment in 2007. Mr. O’Dowd said that Mr. Carlsen had tried to take photographs from his computer, but at his sentencing, Judge David Radford of Snaresbrook Crown Court in East London said the singer was guilty of “gratuitous violence.” The Guardian said Mr. O’Dowd is expected to wear an electronic tag for the remaining 11 months of his sentence.

Frank McCourt, the owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers, did not mince words after meeting with Manny Ramirez, who was suspended for 50 games last week for violating baseball's drug policy. ''We put a lot of confidence in Manny and built a relationship there,'' McCourt told The Los Angeles Times. ''Whenever a relationship is violated like that, there's a sense of disappointment.'' However angry McCourt might be, though, he should not shed too many tears from a business perspective. Economically, Ramirez's suspension could turn out to be a blessing in disguise for his club.

STOGEL--Sidney S. Of Newton, on Thursday, May 7, 2009. For 66 years, the beloved husband and bestfriend of Dorothy (Perlman). Loving father of Steven James Stogel and his wife Melinda, Susan Diane Stogel, and Scott Saul Stogel and his wife Nancy. Cherished grandfather of Samantha Rose, Christopher, Sarina Harding, Johnathan Church, Andrew Allen, Jackson Tyler and Ellie Hannah. Dear brother of Nathan Stogel and the late Philip and Frank Stogel, Lee Stogel Polinsky and Claire Stogel Marcus. Private services were held Sunday, May 10. A tribute site has been established with the Alzheimer's Association. His story and how to send remembrances may be found at http://act.alz.org/goto/ sidney.stogel

PERELL--Edward. Beloved husband of Nan, father of Stephanie, Timothy and Mary Ann, grandfather of Cameron, Isabel, Josephine and May. Retired partner at Debevoise & Plimpton. Passed away on Monday, May 11th. A truly wonderful man--he will be so deeply missed. Funeral services will be Thursday, May 14th at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial on Amsterdam at 76th. Construction on the Guangzhou Opera House, a $100 million structure designed by the architect Zaha Hadid for the southern Chinese city, was halted after the building caught fire on Saturday, The Architect's Newspaper reported. In a statement, Ms. Hadid's office said the fire broke out at the opera house's construction site early Saturday and was contained by firefighters in an hour with no injuries reported. The architect's office said that an inspection of the structure showed it to be intact after the fire but that an investigation into the cause of the fire would continue. The building was scheduled to open later this year. In February, a tower in Beijing designed by Rem Koolhaascaught fire when it was ignited by illegal fireworks, killing at least one person.

Alex Ovechkin versus Sidney Crosby in a Game 7 is a matchup made in hockey heaven. Their rivalry so far in the conference semifinals has been an aesthetic and dramatic success, and it seems to be sparking a renaissance in scoring in the N.H.L. Consider this: in the 44 games that made up the first round of this year's playoffs, the average number of goals per 60 minutes of play was 5.0 -- a level consistent in the N.H.L. postseason for close to 15 years.

DALESSANDRO--Fran. The Officers and The Board of Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home mourn the loss of a great friend and former board member, Fran Dalessandro. As a Director and Vice President, Fran was passionately committed to the Home and its campers, and her solid business acumen provided her with a pragmatic approach to governance. She chaired both the Long Range and Strategic Planning Committees which undertook the planning and building of the new dormitories and health center just opened last summer. Our campers and their families will always be in her debt for these wonderful facilities. We are deeply grateful for the many years of service Fran gave to the Southampton Fresh Air Home and extend our sincere sym-pathies to Fran's family. The Officers and Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home

An Ohio judge has ordered the N.C.A.A. to appear in court May 27 to explain why it has apparently not followed an order that invalidated its ban on the use of lawyers by baseball players during negotiations with professional teams. In a ruling issued Tuesday, Erie County Judge Tygh M. Tone found that the N.C.A.A. was probably in ''indirect civil and criminal contempt'' of a February court order that found the ban was illegal because it interfered with an athlete's right to legal representation. In April, an Ohio appellate court ruled that an N.C.A.A. appeal of the order was premature because the case had not yet concluded.

MELCHER--Pierson Fort, independent school head, non-public school management consultant and Renaissance man, died of a stroke in Easton, MD at age 83 on Thursday, April 30th. Philadelphian, descent of John Alden, son and brother, Gilbert and Sullivan performer and soloist, World War II Army Air Corps radio signal man, brother-in-law, Yale Class of '50, ROTC leader, pilot, Yale MAT '52, friend, colleague, teacher, husband, father, English Department Head, soccer coach, dormitory master, Assistant Headmaster, curriculum innovator, grammarian, Headmaster at age 37, educational reformer, feminist, uncle, beekeeper, horseback rider, fly fisherman, canoeist, master of inclusivity, sailor, lay reader, carpenter, plumber, jack of all the trades, poet, composer, writer, furniture builder, musician, father-in-law, breakfast king, host, linguist, Herman Melville incarnate, gardener, art collector, beachcomber, cross country skier, grandfather and great- uncle, world traveler, vocal jazz chorister, mentor, snowplow operator, geek, piano man, poodle enthusiast, dishwasher, steam train hobbyist, adventurer, good sport, rower, Obama supporter, flamenco aficionado. Friend, Lover, Partner. A private celebration of his life will be held June 20th. All former colleagues and students are welcome.

JACOBS--Ruth Cooper, 100, on May 12. Beloved wife of the late William Nathaniel; loving mother of Louisa and John Craddock and Michael and Rita Jacobs. An amazing person, she touched many lives and will be deeply missed by all of us.

8 P.M. (TCM) PRIME TIME FEATURE: DIRECTED BY BARRY LEVINSON When most film fans think about Mr. Levinson, they think about Baltimore, where he was born and where several of his movies are set. This three-film salute begins with ''The Natural'' (1984), starring Robert Redford as an aging baseball rookie who comes out of nowhere to save his team and redeem himself. In ''Rain Man'' (1988), at 10:30, Tom Cruise plays a con artist who discovers he has a wealthy savant brother (Dustin Hoffman). Mr. Hoffman won the Oscar for best actor, Mr. Levinson for best director. The evening ends with ''Diner'' (1982), Mr. Levinson's directorial debut, an autobiographical coming-of-age story about a group of Baltimore friends having trouble growing up, with, above from left, Kevin Bacon, Mickey Rourke, Daniel Stern and Paul Reiser. 7 A.M. (ABC) TODAY Ryan O'Neal and Alana Stewart talk about Farrah Fawcett's battle with cancer.

GIZELT--Italia Bertetich. With profound sadness we announce the passing of Italia Bertetich Gizelt on May 9. Beloved wife of the late Charles Gizelt, Ita was born in Fiume, Italy (now Rijeka, Croatia) in 1922. She came to New York in 1951 and resided there until 1985 when she moved to Stamford then New Canaan, CT. She leaves behind her children Alessandra Formentin and husband Robert, Paul Gizelt, and Renata Castiglia; sisters Egle Grondona and Azalea Cardano; four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Friends may visit with the family on Saturday, May 16 from 2-4pm at Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St., New Canaan.

This month dozens of academics at Oxford University received anonymous packages. Each contained photocopied pages from a book describing decades-old allegations of sexual harassment against Derek Walcott, the Nobel Prize-winning poet. It is still unclear who sent the material, but on Tuesday it had what was probably its intended effect. Mr. Walcott, a candidate to become the next Oxford professor of poetry in an election on Saturday, withdrew from the race.

LITTMAN--Mildred, of Demarest NJ, 93, on May 12, 2009. Widow of Maxwell L. Littman, M.D., Ph.D. Survived by sons, Robert (Bernice) and Michael (Marion) and four grandchildren. Quintes- sential matriarch, she mothered her family and friends with loving kindness. Pass- over she hosted 95 family and friends in her home and shed her love over them all.

LOHR--Franklyn H. Jr, 83, died May 9, 2009 in Providence, RI. He was a veteran of World War II, serving in the Army Air Corps. A life insurance agent throughout his career and member of the Million Dollar Round Table, he was the founder of Lohr & Associates in New York. In 1989, a lifelong passion for sailing led him to the Caribbean where he lived with his wife, Anne, often aboard their sloop Madeline, until 1997 when he returned to Rhode Island to be closer to family. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club, the Corinthians, the British Virgin Islands Yacht Club and the Bristol Yacht Club. He is survived by his wife Anne of Warren, RI; his former wife Jane of Mystic, CT; sons Franklyn Lohr III of Old Greenwich, CT and Randall Lohr of Stonington, CT; stepdaughter Jean Pike and stepson Lt. Col. Thomas Pike Jr., US Army, both of New York City; and grandchildren Dana Hambidge of Pawcatuck, CT, Kerrie Lohr of Burlington, VT, Franklyn Lohr IV and Phillip Lohr of Old Greenwich, CT, and Thomas Pike III of Washington DC. A memorial service will be held at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, Bristol, RI, on May 17th at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Music Program c/o St. Michael's Church. Please see: sansonefuneralhome.com for additional information.

Lewis Gordon Chair in Jewish Studies. Throughout his active years he worked for the New York Board of Education. He had a deep love of Judaism and was especially interested in its relevance to women. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his sons Mr. Fred Gordon, Dr. Charles (and Susan) Gordon and his grandchildren, Rebecca, Jacqueline and Justin. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chair, Board of Trustees Mordecai D. Katz, Chair, BRGS, Board of Directors

ENNIS--Jerome, M.D.,of New York City and Sharon, CT, died peacefully on May 11, 2009, at age 84. A psychiatrist and psychoanalyst for over 50 years, Jerry loved his profession and worked until his recent illness. He was a member of The New York Psychoanalytic Society and a faculty member of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute. He was cherished beyond words by his loving wife Fay, devoted daughters Susie and Betsy, adoring granddaughters Emma and Sarah, and son-in-law Richard Olcott.

The musical “Spring Awakening” was the big surprise pleasure of 2006, opening that summer at Atlantic Theater Company and then transferring quickly to Broadway, where it won the Tony for Best Musical in 2007 and earned more than $57 million before closing in mid-January.

Updated | 5:32 p.m. Hundreds of concertgoers who thought they bought tickets for a coming Bruce Springsteen show from Ticketmaster but instead purchased seats from TicketsNow, a resale service owned by Ticketmaster, will receive reimbursements or tickets to another of Mr. Springsteen’s shows, The Washington Post reported. More than 300 fans said that they were misled when they bought the tickets to Mr. Springsteen’s show this Monday night at the Verizon Center in Washington. In February, Ticketmaster said that it would change its sales policies as part of a settlement with the State of New Jersey after more than 2,000 Springsteen fans there made similar complaints. In a statement at Mr. Springsteen’s official Web site, brucespringsteen.net, his manager, Jon Landau, wrote that there “appear to be chronic problems” with how Ticketmaster uses TicketsNow and that he and Mr. Springsteen “deeply resent the abuse of our fans.”
The last person to appear as a guest on Jay Leno’s “Tonight Show” will be the same guy who will be seen first on Conan O’Brien’s version of “The Tonight Show” – Conan O’Brien.

The last time Terry Gilliam tried to make the movie “The Man Who Killed Don Quixote,” a reimagined take on the Cervantes hero, his shoots were ruined by a flood and the overhead flights of military jets, his leading man withdrew with a double herniated disc and the entire production was canceled in under a month. But Mr. Gilliam apparently doesn’t know the meaning of the word quixotic, and will try again to make the film next year, The Hollywood Reporter said. At the Cannes Film Festival, Mr. Gilliam said he would be working with Tony Grisoni, the screenwriter of the original film, and had found a new producer. No casting was announced, but the film’s previous incarnation (whose disastrous making-of process was depicted in the documentary “Lost in La Mancha”) starred Jean Rochefort as Quixote as well as Johnny Depp.

Updated | 5:00 p.m. After tapping Whoopi Goldberg and Hugh Jackman to host in recent years, the organizers of the Tony Awards have chosen a host for 2009 who has deeper roots in the theater but is less of a household name: Neil Patrick Harris, who starred on Broadway in “Cabaret” and “Assassins” and played the title role on ABC’s “Doogie Howser, M.D.”

“The Temperamentals,” a play about the pre-Stonewall gay rights movement in America, has been picking up strong critical reviews and selling out performances in the 40-seat black box at the Barrow Group Studio Theater since previews began on April 30.

Several New York City arts organizations have been selected to receive $50,000 grants from the Robert Sterling Clark Foundation. The effort represents the foundation’s response to the economic downturn’s impact on individual artists and small arts institutions. To distribute the grants geographically, the foundation chose three organizations that assist small arts groups in their boroughs — the Bronx Council on the Arts, the Brooklyn Arts Council and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. The foundation also selected two organizations that serve artists from specific disciplines throughout the city: ART/NY and the Joyce Theater Company. In addition, the foundation selected a financial services provider, the Nonprofit Finance Fund, which helps small arts organizations citywide.

Hospitals use a lot of power. The lights in emergency rooms burn around the clock. Outlets in the laboratories are taxed by computers, refrigerators and high-tech medical equipment. The air must be kept fresh and frosty to prevent the spread of germs, leaving air-conditioning and ventilation units on permanent overdrive.All together, New York City hospitals are responsible for about 1.5 percent of the city's total greenhouse gas emissions, city officials say, pumping them out at more than double the rate for a commercial office building. Energy is the second only to salaries in cost for hospitals, according to the Greater New York Hospital Association.

From our colleagues at DealBook:

Underwriters are rejoicing these days amid a near-record number of stock issuances by already established companies. There have been 127 such stock deals -- known as follow-on offers -- so far this year worth a combined $61.7 billion, which is a third more than the same time last year and nearly double the amount raised during the comparable period in 2007, according to Dealogic. The total is just shy of the record of $62.9 billion raised in a similar period in 2000.

Jonathan Bamber of the Bristol Glaciology Center in England has led a new analysis of just how much the loss of West Antarctica's ice could raise sea levels if the ice sheet fully disintegrated. He and his co-authors conclude in the current issue of Science that the maximum rise in seas, not including what could come from Greenland, of course, would be about 10 feet, half of the 20 feet or so that has been the rough projection for several decades. My news story on the study includes cautionary comments from some other Antarctic specialists who warn that the long-term rise in seas is less relevant than what could happen in the next 100 years. The new research was not aimed at answering the near-term question. (Here's more on the long-term melt risk.)

When you're E. L. Doctorow, chronicler of New York's bygone celebrities ("Ragtime") and gangsters ("Billy Bathgate") and faded nostalgic dreams ("World's Fair" and pretty much everything), then it makes sense that you'd eventually start thinking about the Collyer brothers. Homer and Langley Collyer, you may recall, were eccentric sons of the upper class who lived as hermits amid the squalor in their Fifth Avenue brownstone; when they died, the police carted more than 100 tons of junk from their home and discovered that Langley had been crushed to death under a pile of the newspapers he compulsively saved.

It was interesting to hear John Grunsfeld's comment yesterday that Hubble looked "in fantastic shape". Obviously good news. However, the +V3 side of Hubble, which is generally pointed at the Sun, showed the greatest amount of "distress" when we were there in 1997 and I don't know how much of that side John would have been able to see. You capture the telescope on the -V3 side. We didn't really notice the damage until sometime after the telescope was berthed. The crew or the ground might have a view of +V3 from the aft bulkhead cameras in the payload bay. The NASA "worm", which is on the top of the telescope on the -V3 side, was showing evidence of peeling in 1997.

Coty, like all companies that license perfume brands (Lauder, LVMH, Clarins, BPI, Arden), thinks extremely hard about the style of its brands' scents. And Coty owns a lot of scent brands: Davidoff, Calvin Klein, Vera Wang, Marc Jacobs and Kenneth Cole among others. Each brand's aesthetic course is charted via the influence of a million marketing and corporate factors, but most sail in a generally consistent direction. This is how Coty guides Kenneth Cole. The Kenneth Cole brand occupies an interesting place in the fashion world. It is known for its men's shoes, followed by its men's shirts, slacks and accessories (it is almost a shock to discover that Cole makes things for women), in a style cool enough to be cool in Denver and Chicago but not fashion enough to be "fashion."

Though fleeting, Hank Morris's work about 10 years ago for Bear Stearns, the defunct Wall Street investment house, offers an early, inside glimpse of how he became a pre-eminent practitioner of the art of access capitalism. But below the radar, Mr. Morris increasingly gravitated toward more lucrative activities, parlaying his political relationships to bolster a portfolio of private business interests.

The Los Angeles Sparks star Candace Parker has given birth to a girl. Goodwin Sports Management said the baby was born in Los Angeles on Wednesday. She weighed 7 pounds 6 ounces and was 20 inches long. Carlos Tevez and Michael Carrick led Manchester United to within a point of its third straight English Premier League title with a 2-1 victory at Wigan. United trailed after a goal by Hugo Rodallega in the 28th minute. Tevez went on as a substitute in the 58th minute and tied it three minutes later. Carrick scored the winner with four minutes remaining. United needs only to avoid defeat at home against Arsenal on Saturday to clinch the championship with a game remaining. It would then tie Liverpool with a record 18 titles.

A former associate of O. J. Mayo has told federal and N.C.A.A. investigators that U.S.C. Coach Time Floyd gave $1,000 in cash to a man who helped steer Mayo to the Trojans. Floyd did not immediately respond to the allegations, which first appeared in a Yahoo Sports report. The former associate, Louis Johnson, has told authorities that he accompanied Mayo’s handler, Rodney Guillory, to a meeting with Floyd at a Beverly Hills cafe on Feb. 14, 2007, and that Guillory emerged with an envelope stuffed with $100 bills.

It's hard to think of anyone that was better qualified to impart style advice to the un-rouged masses in the 1980s than Brenda Dickson, the daytime television actress who starred in "The Young and the Restless" and snapped up the 1988 Soap Opera Digest Award for Outstanding Villainess in a Daytime Serial. (The honor had narrowly escaped her in 1986.) Nearly 10 minutes long, this video can be muddled in parts - especially when Dickson carries on about the importance of curling one's eyelashes to achieve "a very professional look," and explains that she powders "very, very good."Having said that, there are several truly mesmerizing moments ("ostrich feathers, anyone?") that would come in handy to the many designers who have recently revived the glitzy excesses of the Ivana era. While it's sadly undeniable that Dickson's dictums are not particularly well articulated - "fashion is something that is acquired by looking at different fashions" and "style is as important in your life as your look" come to mind - I'm willing to bet that the impromptu show she stages in her closet will make an impression. I, for one, will not easily forget that suede and leather can be very dressy, especially when accessorized with a fox draped over one shoulder. Well, hello!

Chrisette Michele, a retro-leaning R&B singer with a Grammy under her belt, has the best-selling album in the United States this week with “Epiphany” (Def Jam), but it may not be a victory to brag about. With 83,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, “Epiphany” set a record for the least number of copies sold by a new album to reach No. 1 on the Billboard chart. In a particularly slow week for record sales, the next two albums on the chart were close behind hers: the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) is in second place with 82,000, and Ciara’s new “Fantasy Ride” (LaFace/Zomba) is No. 3 with 81,000. Rascal Flatts’s “Unstoppable” (Lyric Street) fell one spot to No. 4 with 58,000 sales, and last week’s No. 1, Bob Dylan’s “Together Through Life” (Columbia), dropped to No. 5 with 51,000. Overall album sales are down 12.9 percent from this time last year, according to Billboard.

SUNSCREENS should be applied often and liberally to exposed skin. Ideally, sunscreen should shield sunburning ultraviolet B rays and aging ultraviolet A rays. (Both can lead to skin cancer.) For UVA protection, look for ingredients like Mexoryl SX, titanium dioxide and an avobenzone that doesn’t degrade in light. For UVB, the American Academy of Dermatology recommends at least an SPF 15.

The Android development team at Google will release an update this week that gives the T-Mobile G1 phone a bunch of new functions and improves some old ones. The upgrade, called 1.5, adds a certain-to-be-controversial virtual keyboard, like the ones the iPhone and Blackberry Storm have. The keyboard works vertically or in landscape mode in all applications -- a feature the iPhone won't have until its new system release, which is expected this summer.

Composers love it when A-list interpreters champion their works, but most performers who reach the stratosphere slowly shed the contemporary pieces in their repertory. The mezzo-soprano Susan Graham has moved in the other direction. In the opera house she has created roles in works by John Harbison, Jake Heggie and Tobias Picker. Her recitals usually include at least a nod to modernity, and among her recordings are superb discs devoted to songs by Charles Ives and Ned Rorem.

Anyone who has had to meet someone at the airport knows that on-time arrivals are as rare as middle-aged Hannah Montana fans. While there are a lot of ways to get notified by phone that a flight has arrived -- several airline Web sites provide an automated text service -- timing a pickup best requires you to know when a plane is approaching an airport, not when it's already there. If you don't have a portable air traffic tower, you can use FlightTrack, an iPhone app that shows you a plane's progress as well as its departure time, estimated arrival and gate, and a map showing where the plane is.

FLIP-FLOPS are ubiquitous. But some foot-health experts worry that our collective love of the open toe is ruining our feet. Last year at the annual meeting of the American College of Sports Medicine in Indianapolis, Justin Shroyer, a biomechanics doctoral student at Auburn University in Alabama, presented findings that show flip-flop sandals alter the way a person walks, changing the gait in ways that could lead to heel, sole and ankle problems. Athletes are particularly prone to all sorts of foot maladies that are a result of wearing restrictive shoes during high-impact activities. So manufacturers are hoping that a new trend -- call it the après-sport sandal -- will give athletes post-sport relief and address some of the shortcomings of the typical flip-flop. ''It's a huge growth segment,'' said Pamela Lumpkin-Baffo, the director of sales for the World Shoe Association Show, the trade show where shoe manufacturers present their wares twice a year.

A civilian Defense Department employee who worked with the United States Pacific Command has been charged with conspiring to pass classified military information to China, according to a complaint unsealed on Wednesday by the Justice Department. The employee, James W. Fondren Jr., 62, a deputy director of the Washington liaison office of the Pacific Command, was charged with turning over several documents to an agent for the Chinese intelligence service between November 2004 and February 2008. The documents, taken from a classified computer, included opinion papers about Chinese military capabilities, according to a Justice Department official who spoke on the condition of anonymity because is not authorized to speak to the news media. Asa Hutchinson, a former Republican representative from Arkansas who is a lawyer for Mr. Fondren, said, ''Mr. Fondren did not knowingly at any time give any classified information to any agent of the People's Republic of China.'' Mr. Fondren, a former Air Force lieutenant colonel, is the second Pentagon employee to be caught up in what federal authorities called an espionage ring that had been run by Tai Shen Kuo, a naturalized United States citizen from Taiwan.

The Mets are a hard team to read. Jose Reyes keeps getting recklessly thrown out at third base when he shouldn't, but Carlos Beltran pulled off an uncharacteristically bold steal of third on Tuesday night that helped the Mets beat the Braves. In his career, Beltran has stolen 279 bases while being caught only 38 times, a success rate of 88 percent that is the best in the last half century for players with 120 or more stolen-base attempts.

The body of a guest at the Yale Club in Manhattan who apparently fell or jumped 10 stories to his death remained undiscovered for about two days because he landed out of public view, the police said on Wednesday. They said the body was on an old air-conditioning unit on the roof of the hotel's lower tier.

I've been converting an old Toshiba laptop into the fastest blogging machine possible, thanks to some tricks most technology writers wouldn't dream of telling you to try. Here they are: Install Vista Premium and turn on the Aero interface. Aero runs through your graphics card, like a video game, instead of bogging down your CPU (central processing unit).

LEHMAN--Lawrence Brad, M.D.,died Sunday, May 10, 2009. He was 55 years old. Son of Martha and Elmore Jerold Lehman, brother of Shari Lynn Leiman, beloved husband of Carol. His professional career included writer, neuro-surgeon, educator and Managed Care and Pharmaceutical Executive Medical Director. He graduated from Hofstra University, NY 1975 and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, NY 1979. He did his Residency in Neurosurgery and post graduate training at New York University Medical Center/ School of Medicine from 1980-1985. From 1985-1994 he was acting Vice Chair SUNY, Brooklyn; Director Neurosurgery, Coney Island Hospital; and Assistant Director, Department of Surgery, Maimonides Medical Center. From 1995-2002 he was Senior VP of Operations and Chief Medical Officer, Multiplan, Inc. In 2003 he was Medical Director, Merck & Co., Inc. In 2004 he became Medical Director at Pfizer, becoming Senior Director, Evidence based Medicine-Health Technology Assessment in 2008. He was author of numerous medical articles and was an active health-care investment consultant. He had a lifelong interest in developmentally disabled and mentally challanged youth. Larry loved music, debating, writing, thrift stores, and collecting pens. He was happiest when working, often regarding co-workers as his extended family. He was loved and respected by all who knew him. He will be remembered for his creative intellect, sense of humor and his generosity in advising and helping others. He will be greatly missed. A funeral service will be held on Sunday May 17th at 11:30am at The Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, NJ 07652, Telephone: 201-262-1128. No flowers.

MERIANS--Melvin. The HUC-JIR family mourns the death of Melvin Merians, a Governor Emeritus, and a recipient of the Doctor of Humane Letters degree, honoris causa from the College-Institute. Mr. Merians, and his beloved wife, Elaine, were stalwart supporters of the Hebrew Union College and encouraged the advancement of Jewish learning. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Elaine, his children and grandchildren whose loss we share. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Barbara Friedman, Chair of the Board

The European Commission fined Intel a record 1.06 billion euros ($1.45 billion) on Wednesday for abusing its dominance in the computer chip market to exclude its only serious rival, Advanced Micro Devices. The European Union's competition commissioner, Neelie Kroes, said the penalty against Intel was justified because the company had skewed competition and denied consumers a choice for chips.

LIPSON--Eden Ross. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of our beloved mother, wife, and friend on May 12. Always courageous, graceful, and dignified. Hope Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. The Mackey Mortuary, Greenville, SC.

For the first time, Senate Republicans blocked a nominee of the Obama administration, mounting a filibuster against the appointment of David Hayes to be deputy secretary of the Interior Department in a dispute over oil and gas leases in Utah. An effort to force a final vote on Mr. Hayes's nomination fell short of the required 60 votes Wednesday morning as Republicans stood nearly united against Mr. Hayes, a Interior Department official in the Clinton administration.

An English chemist may have found the hidden gateway to the RNA world, the chemical milieu from which the first forms of life are thought to have emerged on earth some 3.8 billion years ago. The discovery seemingly solves a problem that for 20 years has thwarted researchers trying to understand the origin of life: how the building blocks of RNA, called nucleotides, could have spontaneously assembled themselves in the primitive earth's conditions.

The World Cinema Foundation, the film preservation and restoration group founded by Martin Scorsese, said Friday that it had named Kent Jones its executive director. Mr. Jones, who will help the group acquire movies for restoration and have them shown in theaters, festivals and other spaces, recently left the Film Society of Lincoln Center, where he worked as its associate director of programming since 1998. He has also served on the selection committee of the New York Film Festival, and worked with Mr. Scorsese on the documentaries “My Voyage to Italy” and “A Letter to Elia,” a coming film about Elia Kazan. The foundation also said it had formed partnerships with the content companies B-Side Entertainment and the Auteurs, to help bring its films to iTunes, Netflix and other platforms.

If you want to see people from Woody Allen‘s past and present recount their histories with him, you’ll have to stick to his movies. Lawyers for American Apparel said that they would not call Mia Farrow, Mr. Allen’s former companion, and Soon-Yi Previn, Ms. Farrow’s daughter and Mr. Allen’s wife, as witnesses in a lawsuit that Mr. Allen has filed against the clothing company, BBC News reported. Last week, lawyers for Mr. Allen, who is suing American Apparel for using an image of him from “Annie Hall” without his permission, asked a court to prevent Ms. Farrow and Ms. Previn from having to testify at the trial, which is to begin on Thursday. Lawyers for American Apparel have said that they would bring up elements of Mr. Allen’s personal history, but are now saying their case will focus on issues of free speech and fair use, according to the BBC.

Warning: this post contains spoilers, or, as they’re known in Europe, spoileurs.Britain may have gotten the Beatles and the Rolling Stones before the U.S. did, but one thing America can still crow about — for two more days, at least — is that we got to see the “Lost” season finale before they did. The two-hour cliffhanger won’t be broadcast in Britain until Sunday, and dedicated viewers there are practically twisting themselves into pretzels as they try to guess what the fateful episode might have in store. (Not that we weren’t doing the very same thing until recently.)

The Broadway musical “Billy Elliot” took one of the top honors at the Drama League Awards, which were presented on Friday afternoon. The show, which has been nominated for 15 Tony Awards, was chosen by the league, a group of industry professionals and theater lovers, as distinguished production of a musical; the Yasmina Reza black comedy “God of Carnage” was named distinguished production of a play. “Hair” was selected in the musical revival category and “Blithe Spirit” in the play revival category. Geoffrey Rush was given the distinguished performance award for his role in the revival of Ionesco’s “Exit the King.”

Right about now in outer space, three men are crouched in a node of the International Space Station, watching J.J. Abrams’ reboot of “Star Trek” on a laptop. They chose the node, said NASA spokeswoman Nicole Cloutier, because it was “dark and quiet” and would be “a good spot” for three “Star Trek” fans to hunker down for the ultimate viewing experience.

New on the hardcover list this week is “Uncanny X-Men: Manifest Destiny,” which lands at No. 6. This latest chapter in the lives of Marvel’s band of mutant super-heroes involves a change of scenery as the team relocates to San Francisco. The often luckless heroes are still dealing with recent events that have left the mutant population decimated – what once felt like an overwhelming number of mutants was pared down to around 200, with the species seemingly on the verge of extinction. Though the team has a new home base, old enemies aren’t far behind, including Magneto, the mutant-slaying Sentinels and an all-new lineup of the Hellfire Club.

Baghdad-- Garbage on the surface of the Tigris River is collecting at a temporary steel bridge that runs beneath the 14th of July Bridge. The lower bridge, which is currently being taken apart, rests on steel pillars, where the garbage gets clogged. Apart from empty plastic bottles and plastic bags, there is bigger trash too, like refrigerators. The picture was shot from the lower temporary bridge, with the Green Zone on the left and the Karada neighborhood on the right.

Mariah Carey is the latest in a growing list of actresses who willingly make themselves ugly - plug ugly - in order to validate their acting chops. In "Precious," Lee Daniels's adaption of the novel "Push," which screened today at Cannes (for more about the festival go here), Carey plays a social worker assigned to Claireece Precious Jones, a 16-year-old girl pregnant with her second kid. Mimi is utterly faithful to the moment, Harlem in 1987. Her clothes are off the rack from S. Klein. Her hair is dark and stringy. Her accent is low-rent Brooklyn. And the mustache that shades her upper lip far and away surpasses Nicole Kidman's fake proboscis for sheer gutsiness. Carey may not be the greenest superstar in Hollywood lately - she's gotten flak for sending a private jet for her trainer - but she sure is the bravest.

Add Cambodia's royal oxen to the list of economic pessimists predicting hard times ahead. Reuters reported this week that Cambodia's version of Groundhog Day went poorly this year, as the King's oxen enjoyed offerings of corn, green beans and soy beans, but ignored a large plate of rice, "an omen the royal astrologer said boded ill for the harvest of the country's biggest crop." As the Chinese news agency Xinhua explained, the ancient ritual marks the traditional beginning of the rice-growing season in the region.

A federal court in Chicago issued an immediate restraining order on Friday afternoon against three companies accused of aggressively making robocalls selling car warranties across the country, the Federal Trade Commission announced. The order, which also froze the companies' assets, came in response to a a lawsuit filed by the commission on Wednesday.In legal filings, the commission said the robocall campaign had brought in sales of $10 million as a result of the calls and mailings, which falsely gave people the impression that their car warranties were expiring. The companies systematically dialed random numbers throughout the country, violating the Do Not Call registry, the trade commission said. The companies also regularly faked their own caller ID numbers, so it was unclear where the calls were coming from.

The Maplewood Police Department put out this news release this afternoon: "On Thursday May 14, at about 9:30 pm a 20 year old female was walking on South 4th St in Maplewood near Essex Ave when she was approached by a black male who demanded the woman turn over her purse to him. The female declined to give the male the purse and a brief struggle ensued over the purse. The black male then displayed a handgun to the woman and ripped the purse from the woman's shoulder. The actor was last seen running to a small, newer model, silver car and entered into the passenger side door of the car. The small silver car was last seen traveling south on Essex Ave. The female victim was not injured during the robbery. The actor is described as a black male, 15 to 17 years of age, thin build, 5'7" tall, with black hair in corn rows or short braids. He was wearing a baseball cap, red baggy shirt and dark jeans."

Every ten years the astronomy community takes a look at itself and tries to think ahead about the telescopes and satellites astronomers need to explore the universe in the decade ahead. That's why I was sitting in the auditorium at the National Academy of Science's Beckman Center in Irvine California with a hundred other astronomers, fighting off jet lag and a wandering mind, as our learned leaders explained the ins and outs of this complicated bureaucratic path toward building a consensus on the best path for the future of US astronomy. The National Research Council has its methods and we needed to learn what they were. We looked at many, many slides. I have had root canal work done, and it is worse. But not by much.

Twenty-four years ago, Nicholas Vreeland, Diana Vreeland's grandson, went off to India to become a Buddhist monk. Of the precious few possessions he could take with him, one was his camera. During his time at the Rato Dratsang monastery in the South India state of Karnataka, Vreeland took pictures simply to "do his scales" - maintaining his technique as a pianist would. What he didn't realize was that he was creating a photographic journal of individuals coexisting with their surroundings - there's the Dalai Lama, shrine chickens, a bull nestled up to a movie poster, each rendered poignantly in black and white. Since 1983, the Rato Dratsang monastery has provided a safe haven for Tibetan refugee children and has seen its community grow from 12, when Vreeland joined, to its current population of 120. In order to help raise the funds necessary for the repair and expansion of the Rato Dratsang, Vreeland is selling 20 of his photographs to benefit the monastery.

Groves, President Obama's nominee to lead the Census Bureau, told senators at a confirmation hearing on Friday that he would not seek to use statistical sampling in the 2010 census, offering reassurance to Republicans who have long opposed any effort to adjust for inevitable counting errors using mathematical models.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Does this name ring a bell -- evil Dick Cheney? He's in New York City. He's on another one of his stops on his "Don't Say I Didn't Warn You Tour." And he is in New York City. And he has one of those crazy, embarrassing New York City moments. He's driving in a cab. And it turns out the cabdriver is somebody Cheney had waterboarded. It was crazy.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: To raise money for California, Governor Schwarzenegger says he's willing to sell some of the state's aging landmarks, like San Quentin Prison. So far, the only bid has come from Dick Cheney. Apparently, he wants to use it as a vacation home in the summer. "I can just relax in the atmosphere."

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: A Canadian scientist was arrested for smuggling vials of Ebola into the U.S. And I'm telling you, this wouldn't happen if the government would just legalize Ebola. You know? Been saying this for years.

Another weekend, another big Hollywood blockbuster. "X-Men Origins: Wolverine" kicked off the spring/summer movie season two weekends ago, followed by "Star Trek" last weekend. This time around, it's "Angels & Demons," director Ron Howard's adaptation of the Dan Brown religious thriller which, like its predecessor, "The Da Vinci Code," will star Tom Hanks as intrepid symbologist Robert Langdon. It's opening in 3,525 theaters across North America. The betting money, though, is that "Angels" will not have anywhere near the $77 million box-office opening that greeted "Da Vinci" in 2006. Reuters predicts the film will make around $40 million this weekend, but the Hollywood Reporter thinks it will do better, in the $50 million range. Box Office Guru guesses $53 million.

One of the key provisions in a public acquisition agreement is the section setting forth the procedures that a target must follow if it receives a third-party bid. The target and initial buyer will often negotiate hard over these terms, with the initial suitor attempting to require as much procedure as possible when any third-party bid arrives as well as insisting upon matching and information rights about any such third-party bid.

Last night a friend and I went to the opening of the Richard Avedon fashion exhibition at the International Center of Photography. The Town Cars were double parked at the corner of Sixth Avenue and 43rd Street when we arrived, around 6:45, and there was a throng of guests inside. "Dovima with Elephants," taken in 1955, was the first thing I saw. There's a lot to see in this exhibition, in fact, and I like the arrangement of the pictures, which isn't necessarily chronological. Norma Stevens, who runs the Avedon Foundation and who worked with Avedon for nearly 30 years, was speaking on the lower level when we entered. People were leaning on the stair rails, crowding the steps. Above the crowd, rising perhaps a dozen feet on a wall, was a picture of Suzy Parker swathed in couture.

President Obama will announce on Friday that he has chosen Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the New York City health commissioner, as the next director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Dr. Frieden, a 48-year-old infectious disease specialist, has led an aggressive crusade to reduce smoking in New York, pushed for having calories listed in fast-food establishments, and done earlier work to stop a growing epidemic of drug-resistant tuberculosis infections. Recently, he also won positive reviews himself for his televised swine flu updates.

Returning $103.20 for a $2 win wager, Mine That Bird was the second longest-priced winner in the 135-year history of the Derby.

There's nothing like a welcome dose of warmer weather to stoke wanderlust, so T's latest travel issue comes not a moment too soon. This year, with travelers turning more than ever to "culture tripping" to give their journeys a greater sense of meaning, we've focused on places with a strong cultural and artistic bent, from our cover location, the Greek island of Patmos (a far cry from Mykonos) to the high-low American playground of Lake Tahoe to 29 art-oriented destinations that are worth a special trip, curated for us by a select group of experts. Along the way, we make pit stops in Jaipur, India, where artisans are reviving traditional craft; Glasgow, Scotland, which continues to make waves in the world of contemporary art; Pittsburgh, for a night out at a cool grass-roots bar; the Caribbean island of Nevis, where the artists Helen and Brice Marden have recently remade a resort; and Russia's Lower Volga, for some serious fishing. Throw in a comprehensive guide to the best of the best in art and cultural happenings this season and you've got an issue that's a feast for the senses and the mind - and sure to make you want to get out and hit the road.

The receiver legally changed his name in Florida last August and asked the league and the news media to call him Chad Ocho Cinco, a two-word nickname he had adopted referring to his No. 85. A picture on May 5 with the continuation of a front-page article about the porous Afghanistan-Pakistan border, and the strategic advantages it offers to Taliban insurgents fighting American troops, showed a silhouetted Taliban logistics tactician, who was interviewed for the article, holding a rifle, creating the impression that the weapon belonged to him. An obituary on Thursday about L. William Seidman, former head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, misstated his position on the productivity commission appointed by President Ronald Reagan in the early 1980s. He was the commission’s co-chairman, not its official chairman, which was William E. Simon, former secretary of the Treasury. (Some accounts described Mr. Seidman as the working chairman.).

An article on Tuesday about the investigative tools being used in computer security operations misspelled the surname of a political scientist at the University of Toronto. He is Ronald Deibert, not Diebert. It also misstated the surname of the editor of Infowar Monitor. He is Greg Walton, not Watson.

A film review last Friday about “Outrage,” a documentary about the “conspiracy” to protect secretly gay politicians who vote against gay interests, misstated the surname of a blogger shown in the film who believes such politicians should be publicly identified as gay. He is Michael Rogers, not Rodgers.

A music review on May 1 about the Ponderosa Stomp, in New Orleans, referred incorrectly to the appearance of the singer Roy Loney and the guitarist Cyril Jordan, the two original songwriters of the Flamin’ Groovies. While they performed their first full set together since 1971, they also performed together in 1991 in San Francisco when Mr. Jordan performed Flamin’ Groovies songs with the Sneetches and Mr. Loney joined them for encores. Their performance at the Ponderosa Stomp was not their first reunion onstage since 1971.

A picture caption on Thursday with the Abroad column, about concern in Aix-en-Provence, France, over plans for a train line that would cut through an area where Cézanne painted landscapes, misidentified the region of France in which La Rochelle, where President Nicolas Sarkozy was shown announcing plans for the rail line, is situated. It is on the west coast of France, not in southern France.

JERUSALEM -- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel met on Thursday with King Abdullah II of Jordan, who urged him to commit to a two-state solution with the Palestinians, according to news reports. Mr. Netanyahu made the unannounced trip to Jordan hours before he was to meet with Pope Benedict XVI. Mark Regev, a spokesman for the prime minister, said that Mr. Netanyahu and King Abdullah discussed bilateral issues and the peace effort with the Palestinians.

Italy's lower house of Parliament on Thursday approved wide-ranging security legislation that included measures toughening Italian immigration policies. Under the terms of the bill, illegal immigrants entering or residing in Italy will be fined up to $14,000, before being expelled. In addition, the period of time that foreigners can be held in detention centers was tripled to 180 days. The bill was backed by Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's coalition allies in the Northern League, which has championed a hard line against immigration. The bill must pass the Senate before becoming law.

The Spanish economy suffered its sharpest contraction in four decades in the first quarter of the year as slumping global demand and a national real estate bust buffeted job creation. Gross domestic product shrank by 1.8 percent in the first three months of the year from the previous quarter, the third consecutive quarterly decline, the National Statistics Institute said. Economic output was 2.9 percent lower than a year earlier. By both measures, it was the largest quarterly decline in output since at least 1970. Analysts predicted that the economy would continue to shrink at least through the end of this year. VICTORIA BURNETT

After more than five years of negotiations, delegates from 64 countries reached a broad consensus here on Thursday on a new international agreement regulating the recycling of ships and scheduled a final meeting on Friday to approve and sign the pact. The last time Benjamin Netanyahu met an American president as Israel's new leader, in 1996, it did not go well. Mr. Netanyahu lectured President Bill Clinton about Arab-Israeli relations, aides recalled, driving Mr. Clinton into a profane outburst after his guest left. Mr. Netanyahu is likely to avoid a repeat of that when he meets President Obama at the White House on Monday. But the relationship between Israel and the United States has become more unsettled since Mr. Obama took office.

But as long as the victims [...].

My Sunday column tries to shine a light on one of the great scourges of Africa, maternal mortality. It's so frustrating to see women -- and teenage girls -- dying so unnecessarily, when what's needed to save them isn't some new technique or drug but simply the political will. But as long as the victims are overwhelmingly poor, rural and female, they don't get much attention either from poor countries or donor nations. This issue is a theme in "Half the Sky," the book that my wife and I have written, coming out in September, and while there is no silver bullet there are silver buckshot that can make a difference.

The government said last week that wholesale prices for food spiked in April -- the biggest monthly jump in more than a year. Beef, pork, vegetables, fruit, eggs all rose in price. Some economists saw the increases as good news: it eased their fears of a deflationary spiral. But do American consumers, now experts in penny-pinching, have to worry about higher prices down the line?

A picture caption this weekend with a cover article about Roman sites in southeastern France refers incorrectly to the age of a fountain in Arles. The fountain shown on the cover in the shape of the head of Hercules is 17th century; it is does not date to the Roman Empire.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on May 8 about an exhibition in Berlin by the artist Gunther von Hagens that depicts dead bodies having sex misidentified another exhibition of bodies and body parts presented by Mr. von Hagens. It is “Body Worlds,” not “Bodies ... the Exhibition,” which is presented by the company Premier Exhibitions.

A picture caption in the Escapes pages on Friday with an article about fly fishing in North Carolina misidentified the type of trout shown being released into a river. It was a brook trout, not a rainbow trout. And a map with the article was published in error in some editions. It showed the Central Coast of California, not western North Carolina. (The map also accompanied, correctly, an article about San Luis Obispo in the Escapes pages.) The North Carolina map can be found at nytimes.com/escapes.
Pentagon officials stopped work on a costly new helicopter despite efforts by the contractors and their supporters in Congress to salvage part of the project.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the New York Philharmonic, at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, included outdated information. The conductor for tonight’s performance will be David Zinman — not Esa-Pekka Salonen, who withdrew because of back problems. (Mr. Zinman also conducted in Mr. Salonen’s place on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.).

When the trainer Chip Woolley started looking for a replacement for Calvin Borel, he wanted somebody who reminded him of Borel, the winning jockey in the Kentucky Derby. That meant finding a rider with experience, patience and a proven record of success in Triple Crown races. Woolley may not have Borel aboard Mine That Bird on Saturday in the Preakness Stakes -- Borel chose to ride the filly Rachel Alexandra instead -- but he says he has someone just as good in Mike Smith.

FLAGG--W. Allston, Junior, 81, died peacefully. He was the son of the late W. Allston Flagg and Lowrie Sage Flagg of Oyster Bay, Long Island. He is survived by a sister, Marjorie Flagg Strawbridge, five first cousins including his dear friend, Andrew G. C. Sage II, four nephews and nieces and five great-nephews and -nieces. Funeral services are pending.

General Motors told more than 1,100 dealers Friday that their franchises would not be renewed next year, bringing the total for the week to nearly 2,000 car dealers that learned they were no longer wanted. The action, which involved only half of the showrooms that G.M. ultimately hopes to eliminate, was another step toward a probable bankruptcy filing at the end of this month.

COMRAS--Jamie Stein, 50, beloved mother of Ashley and Bryan; cherished daughter of Leonard and Joan Stein and loving sister of Jeffrey, Marla, Gary and Kellie Stein. Passed away peacefully on May 14. Jamie was an extraordinary mother, daughter, sister and friend who enriched the lives of everyone she met. Jamie was a caring and giving person who was a wonderful anchor to her friends and family alike. She will be dearly missed. Service Sunday, May 17 at 3:30pm at The Star of David Memorial Gardens, 7701 Bailey Rd., North Lauderdale, FL.

CALTABIANO--Letizia S. (nee Serra), age 87 of Haworth, NJ on May 14, 2009. Beloved wife of Dr. Joseph A. Caltabiano. Devoted mother of David and his wife Tracy, Claudia and her partner Judy. Dear sister of Rita McGoff. Loving grandmother of Matthew and Anthony. Cremation private. Friends may call at the Caltabiano residence at 528 Beech St., Haworth, NJ 07641 on Saturday and Sunday from 2-6pm. Services by the Barrett Funeral Home of Tenafly, NJ.

HOGAN--Jane nee McGoey, 90, died May 14, Warwick, NY. Raised in Inwood, married the late Donald A. Hogan on November 20, 1948. 1941 graduate of Hunter College. Loving matriarch. Survived by seven children and 12 grandchildren.

Beyond the confidence and the bravado that the Boston Celtics and the Orlando Magic have displayed in the first six games of their playoff series, their postseason fates may be decided Sunday by whose shooting guard emerges from an inopportune slump. The sharpshooters Ray Allen of Boston and J. J. Redick of Orlando have found the going rough as the series has progressed. Allen hit a clutch 3-point shot in Game 5, but has not made much noise since; he has scored in single digits in three games during the series.

D. Wayne Lukas knows how to win a Triple Crown race with a filly. He did it in 1988 with Winning Colors, the last filly to win the Kentucky Derby. He also knows something about how to stop one from winning a Triple Crown race. In 1980, his chestnut colt Codex pushed around the Derby heroine Genuine Risk to win the Preakness Stakes. Lukas, a Hall of Fame trainer, would like to do the same to Rachel Alexandra on Saturday in the middle jewel of the Triple Crown, but he is not confident that he will. He says he doubts that his two colts, the long shots Luv Gov and Flying Private, have what it takes to beat Rachel Alexandra in the Preakness. He is not sure anyone does.

Loving mother of Patricia Milano (Michael) of Teaneck, NJ; Kathleen Taylor (Volney) of Bronxville, NY; John MacMahon (Susan) of Marshfield, MA; Theresa Finneran (James) of Rye, NY; twelve grandchildren, ten great-grandchildren. BURDETTE--Brooks R. Brooks was one of the finest and kindest of persons: a great friend and law partner, wise counsellor, and a brilliant lawyer. He worked strenuously to overcome serious childhood illnesses, never asked for or accepted favors because of his physical limitations, and wildly succeeded in the toughest environment any trial lawyer could compete in. Brooksy, we will miss the lunches, dinners, and discussions, but mostly miss knowing you were always there to help lend a hand. Good-bye, our friend: you're the best. David M. Brodsky Daniel J. (HBO) GET SMART (2008) Steve Carell, right, stars as the blundering spy Maxwell Smart, with Anne Hathaway as his partner, 99, in this new spin on the 1960s television series created by Mel Brooks and Buck Henry. The director here is Peter Segal; the writers, Tom J. Astle and Matt Ember. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis likened reviewing the movie to writing about the new packaging of a laundry detergent: the box may look different, but the stuff inside is pretty much the same. ''And in this case,'' she wrote, ''the stuff inside consists of exactly what most Hollywood movies based on old sitcoms are made of, namely feeble and funny jokes, brand actors and enough special effects to give you some bang for your summertime buck.'' NOON (13) THE OPEN MIND Harold Varmus, the president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, discusses his new book, ''The Art and Politics of Science,'' in Part 1 of a two-episode program.

Brad DeLong offers a neat little model of speculative fluctuations in asset prices, based on the idea that investors gradually switch strategies based on what seems to work for other people: if people buying stocks seem to be doing well, more people move into stocks, driving up prices and making stocks look even more attractive. It's very close to Shiller's notion of bubbles as natural Ponzi schemes. And Brad's version is very much what I was saying in this piece written in 1999 -- one I had a lot of fun writing.

While the rest of us surf the Web, Clay Marzo hangs ten off some of the most spectacular beaches in the world. Tahiti, El Salvador, Micronesia, Spain, Bali - the world is Marzo's tidal wave. ''My favorite place to surf is Fiji,'' he says. ''There is a surfing island called Tavarua that is like paradise.'' In search of the perfect break, he always comes prepared, typically taking four or five boards with him; he'd like to visit the coast of Western Australia next. Although Marzo has the developmental disorder known as Asperger's syndrome, it's never slowed him down: he got his start riding on the front of his father's long board at the age of 1; now 19, he is one of the most lauded beach bums in the world. ''I get most inspired by seeing photos of faraway breaks and sick, slablike waves.''

The weather is officially warm and it's not just a rebellion against a wintry spring that has women leaving their lingerie at home. Examining the spring runways, from Alexander Wang and Haider Ackerman to Jil Sander and Lanvin, there was nary a brassiere in sight. "Once you figure out how to incorporate a slip or an underpinning into your outfit in order to translate it to everyday life," says the swimwear designer Lisa Marie Fernandez, " it takes away so much." Sure, there are those magical almost-naked lingerie brands like Commando as well as those pasty (self adhesive) cutlets. (Amanda Brooks swears by them in her book, "I Heart Your Style.") But doesn't it feel nice sometimes not to fuss? The choice to go bare is definitely easier if you're a small-chested women. "I tend to go braless and not think twice about it," says Emily Weiss of Intothegloss.com. "I've always thought that if you have a small chest, like mine, what's the difference?" In fact, she only wears a bra when "I want it to peek out of my outfit and it's part of the look." And that look is obviously on the decline.

Some of the water in Lake Tahoe has been there as long as 700 years, a piece of information no less valuable for its appearance on a historical marker adjacent to the Fanny Bridge in Tahoe City, Calif. The view from here of the largest alpine lake in North America — 22 miles long, 12 miles wide, straddling California and Nevada — is kind of a twofer. On the one hand, there’s the pine-framed glimpse of Tahoe’s restless cobalt water as it meets the Truckee River’s sparkling, complacent green; at the same time, there’s a generous view of the Great American Backside, because so many tourists crowd in and bend over the bridge to watch the trout moseying upriver. This spot, known locally as “the Y” because Highways 89 and 28 meet here, is as good a place as any to consider the collision of old and new at Lake Tahoe, to observe this gloriously amenable haven’s latest incarnation.

Thank you, Peggy Orenstein, for writing about the importance of play for children (May 3). Rather than worrying about whether children will be reading in kindergarten, the emphasis, particularly in preschools, should be on how children react to the day-to-day experiences in their world. Can she cooperate when being asked to share? Is he able to negotiate with his peers using the appropriate words? Can she comfortably ask for help when needed, wait for her turn and, of course, know when and how to say please, thank you and excuse me? While your daughter was busy concocting a pretend math sheet because “all the other kids have homework,” there was plenty of creative thinking and learning taking place. There’s something to be said for the adage “play is children’s work.”.

To me as a religious-studies professor and Lutheran minister, the most telling line in Russell Shorto’s article (May 3) was, “This system developed not after Karl Marx, but after Martin Luther and Francis of Assisi.” The last time I taught in the Semester at Sea program, I found it necessary to interpret for our students the rich “social capital” that runs through the Northern European societies we were visiting. What they knew and had read in their guide books was that not many people are in church on Sunday morning, especially compared to the florid religiosity of the United States. So their working assumption was that Americans take religion seriously and Europeans don’t. The new thought that amazed them was that the unchurched Europeans live in social democracies deeply saturated with historic Christian values, while the much-churched Americans celebrate a society characterized by a ruthless social Darwinism that the God of the Bible, Old and New Testament alike, denounces.

In David Leonhardt’s interview with President Obama (May 3), the president provided a glimpse of what we should want from a reformed health care system. Implicitly, he held out the vision of individuals who, because they have insurance, feel encouraged to visit their doctors early in an episode of illness. Over time, doctor and patient build trusting relationships focused on the patient’s health as the only legitimate endpoint. And for their part, the doctors have both the information, available electronically, that they need to provide the most appropriate care and financial incentives that encourage them to do so.

McLOUGHLIN--John T.,94, of Princeton died in his sleep on May 14 in Washington, DC. Mr. McLoughlin was President of the Vick Chemical Company from 1961 to 1979. He began his career with Proctor & Gamble in the mid-West and then worked for several consumer products and health care businesses, including Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick. From 1958 to 1961 he was President of the Consumer Division of Mead Johnson. At the end of his career, he served as President of the Proprietary Association in Washington, DC and after retirement worked as an independent consultant. A native of New York City, Mr. McLoughlin graduated from Stuyvesant High School in 1932 and was awarded a Harvard Club of New York scholarship. At Harvard, he majored in math, graduating Magna Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa. Mr. McLoughlin was active in the Princeton community. In 1988 he convinced a group of courageous fellow Harvard graduates to create the Harvard Club of Princeton, of which he served as the first President. He was also a member of the Advisory Board of the Princeton YMCA Executive Club and was on the boards of Princeton Day School, Simon's Rock College and the Princeton Child Development Institute for Autistic Children. For many years, he was a member of the vestry of Trinity Church. He was an avid tennis player and a member of the Pretty Brook Tennis Club. In later years, he was active in the Nassau Club. He was also a long-time member of the Union League Club of New York. Mr. McLoughlin is survived by his wife, Harriette, and his three sons, John Jr., Hollis and Peter, and their wives as well as eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to the Princeton YMCA or the Princeton Child Development Institute. Funeral services will be held at Trinity Church in Princeton on Tuesday May 19 at 10:30am.

McGINN--Audrey, died of cancer on Friday, May 8, 2009 in New York. Born on May 4, 1943 in Jersey City, NJ, Audrey graduated from Cabrini College and received Masters Degrees from Lehigh University and the City College of New York. She taught in East Harlem for several years, then fashioned a distinguished career at Scarsdale High School from 1976-2005. Audrey was a devoted daughter to her parents Leo J. McGinn and Casimer (Devlin) McGinn; sister to her brother Jim and his wife Gretchen; and aunt to their children, Alexandra, Ben and Catherine. Family and friends will miss Audrey's love, guidance, support, and friendship, as well as her iconic red clogs. A memorial service will held at Scarsdale High School on June 12th, 2009 from 3-5pm.

CROSSING THE VIRGIN RIVER IN ZION NATIONAL PARK, UTAH Glena Kidwell, a 50-year-old business manager and travel agent from Indianapolis, right, with a colleague, Oct. 28, 2008. ''At least once a year I take a hiking vacation. I'd done my research on Zion and it looked beautiful, so I talked a group -- my sister and people from work -- into going. I think there were six of us. The temperature year-round in the water doesn't get above the 50s, and it was down in the 40s that day, so we had boots and waders on. The cliffs were probably three stories tall in some places, and we were walking between them in the stream; the sun was coming down through there. It was beautiful. Usually I choose my group carefully because not everyone is up for an all-day hike, but a couple of people on this trip weren't in as good shape as the others and they just kind of had to stop. We're already planning the next trip, out to the Sawtooth Mountains, and we're like, 'This person's not going and this one's not going, because they can't keep up.' '' As told to Seth Kugel

KUNZELMANN--C Dixon, beloved son, husband, father and grandfather died peacefully at home in Mountain Lake, Florida on Sunday May 10th. He was 67 years old. He graduated from St. Paul's School in Hanover, New Hampshire and Hobart College in Geneva, New York where he also served as a board member. He spent his career at JP Morgan in New York and London. He is survived by his mother Helen Dixon Kunzelmann, his wife of forty-one years Joan Atwood Kunzelmann, his children Christopher Kunzelmann and Laura Hastings and four granddaughters. A memorial service will be held on May 27th at 4pm at St. Bartholo- mew's Church located at Park Avenue and 51st Street, New York City. There will be a reception for his UK friends in London at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in Dixon's memory to Hobart College, 615 South Main St., Geneva, NY 14456.

BEARN--Alexander G.,M.D. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Alexander G. Bearn, M.D. Alick was an esteemed member of this community for nearly sixty years, first as a faculty member, then as a trustee. He found his way to Rockefeller in 1951 when his strong belief in investigative medicine led Dr. Henry Kunkel to offer him a laboratory appointment. Alick focused on rare metabolic disorders, eventually heading his own laboratory, the first at Rockefeller dedicated to human genetics. After joining the faculty of Cornell University Medical College in 1966, Alick continued his association with Rockefeller as a visiting professor and physician, and was invited to join the Board of Trustees in 1970. In 2002, he was awarded the David Rockefeller Award for Extraordinary Service to the University. Alick Bearn was a trusted friend and advisor to seven Rockefeller presidents. Through his trusteeship, his books and publications, his leadership of the Kunkel Society, and his membership on the Lewis Thomas Prize committee, to name just a few of his many endeavors, he continued to enhance the intellectual vitality of the University his entire life. He will be remembered for his wise counsel and his enormous personal integrity. Alick possessed a unique blend of warmth, wit, wisdom, and a profound sense of service to humankind. His charm and irrepressible ebullience made being in his company a true delight. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beautiful wife and partner of 56 years, Margaret, who is in every way his equal in warmth, intellect, and zest for life. We also extend our sympathy to their wonderful family: their daughter, Helen, and her husband, Rockefeller University Council member Russell Pennoyer; their son, Gordon, and his wife, Ellen; and their grandchildren. Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman and Life Trustee

'You've got a dominant player. Let him be dominant.' DWIGHT HOWARD, Orlando Magic center, after being held to 10 shots and 12 points in a Game 5 loss to the Celtics. He had 23 points and 22 rebounds in a Game 6 victory.

HADDAD--Mac A.,passed away on May 8, 2009 at the age of 100. Born in Aleppo, Syria, he arrived in America as an infant in 1910. Raised in Manhattan's Lower East Side tenements, he went to work at the age of 13 to help support his family of 12. He served this country as a sergeant in World War II, as a machine gunner in North Africa and Italy. In 1947, he and his brothers Hy and Joe founded Haddad Brothers, Inc., a children's wear company. Devoted to serving his community, he was an officer and significant contributor to the building of Congregation Shaare Zion, a founder of Congregation Beth Torah in Brooklyn, and President of Magen David Synagogue of Bradley Beach, NJ. He was tireless in his efforts on behalf of Camp Seven and Sephardic Renaissance, both of which served underprivileged children. He was a Past Master Mason. He neither asked for nor sought recognition for his many acts of charity, benevolence and kindness. A self-made man with integrity, character, warmth and humor, he was rarely seen without his cigar. He was a shining example of the "Greatest Generation" and his passing marks an end of an era. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife Mona, and four children Barbara, Alan, Lori, and Mitchell, his 12 grandchildren, and one great-grandchild, two brothers and three sisters. Dad, you are our hero and role model. Your love, generosity, wisdom, humor and kindness will be greatly missed. You made the world a better place for all those who had the good fortune to know you. We promise that the glowing embers of your precious memory will forever burn in our hearts bringing with it the warmth and comfort of your everlasting love, broad smile and eternal blessings.

Friend, Lover, Partner. A private celebration of his life will be held June 20th. All former colleagues and students are welcome.

WILLEY--Robert Allen, 88, a 37 year resident of Mount Kisco, NY died on May 12, 2009 at his home. Mr. Willey was born July 3, 1920 in Pasadena, CA the son of William S. and Minna E. Willey. He is survived by his beloved wife, Helen (Wagner) Willey and his sister, Mona Elmore of Honolulu, HI. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date.

With anecdotal evidence suggesting the number of foreclosures was accelerating in the New York metropolitan area, The New York Times set out to try to quantify the extent of the problem -- not just from a regional or county-level view, but down to the street level. After acquiring data that included the property addresses for more than 182,000 homes in foreclosure between January 2005 and August 2008, The Times used mapping software to plot the foreclosed properties and then computed the percentage of residential properties in foreclosure at various geographic levels. In addition, The Times also examined bank data since August for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, which showed a sharp increase in the number of monthly mortgage payments at least 90 days past due.
