CAMILLA AKRANS In light of all the traveling the photographer Camilla Akrans does, it's a good thing her main source of inspiration -- ''always colors'' -- is carry-on-friendly. For this issue, she headed to the island of Patmos, Greece, to capture its muted, rose-tinged light; stark, whitewashed walls; and saturated blues (''Rock of Ages,'' Page 104). A native of Sweden whose work has appeared in Vogue, Numéro and Harper's Bazaar (an example of her fashion photography is at near right), Akrans typically finds herself in Los Angeles one week and New York, Paris, Cape Town or Hawaii the next. Happily, she recently completed renovations on a country house outside Stockholm. ''I hope I'm going to have time to enjoy it,'' she says, ''since I live mostly out of a suitcase.''

BURNS--Gerard J. (Jerry), 60, died May 5th, 2009 in Hudson, NY. Jerry was a brother, an uncle, co-worker, cat-lover, a man of immense intellectual curiosity, a collector of a diverse set of friends, an accomplished aviator and a voracious reader. The Hudson River Valley held a special place in his heart and Acra, NY was where he settled. Jerry worked for Global Aerospace for 30 years. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Jerry's name to Best Friends Animal Sanctuary in Kanab, UT.

THE NEWS The Obama administration sought broad authority from Congress to oversee the often-complex but largely unregulated financial instruments known as derivatives. BEHIND THE NEWS One kind in particular, credit-default swaps, played a major role in the financial crisis, especially at the giant insurer American International Group, which was spared from collapse last fall by a $170 billion government bailout. Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, above, wants to require that swaps and other derivatives be traded publicly on regulated exchanges and, like bank loans, be backed by capital reserves.
Pop Jon Pareles

BEARN--Alexander G.,died peacefully at his home in Philadelphia on Friday, May 15, 2009 at the age of 86. Dr. Bearn is survived by his loving family, his wife of 56 years, Margaret nee Slocum, his daughter and son-in-law Helen and Russell Pennoyer of New York, his son and daughter-in-law Professor Gordon C.F. and Ellen Bearn of Bethlehem, PA, his five grandchildren, Gordon, Robert, Margaret Pennoyer, Cary and Alice Bearn, and his brother Michael Bearn of Hampshire, England. Physician, scientist, early human geneticist and author, Dr. Bearn was Executive Officer of the American Philosophical Society, Professor of Medicine Emeritus of Cornell University Medical College and Physician-in-Chief at New York Hospital, Trustee Emeritus and Professor of the Rockefeller University and former Trustee of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. He was also a Senior Vice President of Medical and Scientific Affairs, International Division for Merck & Co. Born in Cheam, Surrey, England, Dr. Bearn received his M.D. from the University of London and served with the Royal Air Force. After fellowships at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School, London, he came to the US in 1951 to the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, now Rockefeller University, where he pursued research in liver disease, Wilson's Disease and human genetics. A fellow of the National Academy of Sciences, the American College of Physicians, the Royal College of Physicians, London, Fellow Commoner of Christ's College, Cambridge University, and a member of the American Philosophical Society, he had also been President of the Harvey Society and the American Society for Human Genetics. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on Thursday, May 21, at the Brick Church, Park Avenue and 91st Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the American Philosophical Society or the Rockefeller University.

PICKERING--Thomas G.,MB, BChir, DPhil, FRCP, professor of medicine at Columbia University, passed away May 14, 2009 at age 69 after a one-year battle with cancer. He was an internationally renowned expert in clinical hypertension and a scientific leader in the fields of hypertension and cardiovascular behavioral medicine. He coined the term "white-coat hypertension" to describe those whose blood pressure was elevated in the doctor's office, but normal in everyday life, and later published the first editorial describing "masked hypertension" (the opposite phenomenon). He was formerly President of the Society of Behavioral Medicine, the Academy of Behavioral Medicine Research, and a leader in other national and international scientific organizations. He published over 500 articles. His core belief was that much of cardiovascular disease arises from psychosocial factors, and is hence potentially preventable or treatable by modifying these. Always a gentleman, he leaves a legacy of outstanding scholarship, collegiality, and many younger clinical investigators, who are now spread across the world. He was a wonderful mentor and friend and will be greatly missed by his colleagues and co-workers at Columbia University's Center for Behavioral and Cardiovascular Health and Division of General Medicine. Our sympathies go out to his wife Janet, his sons, Robert and William, and his grandchildren. Karina Davidson, Joseph Schwartz, Steven Shea.

ECCLESINE--Joseph Francis, 70, died peacefully on May 8, 2009. Beloved husband of Maureen for 47 years. Devoted father of Kevin, Meghan, Dorren and Peggyanne and father-in-law of Joanne, Peter and Sean. Adored and entertaining grandfather of Shane, Brendan, Dillon, Mary Claire, Max, Evan, Lily, Maureen, Patrick and Duncan. Brother of Kevin, Patricia, Mary and George. An inspiration to all of us. We will miss him dearly. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Essex Community Fund/Charlie Goff Fund Essex, NY, or The Nature Conservancy - Adirondack Chapter Keene Valley, NY.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Swing Won't Bail Out Ramirez This Time,'' May 10: The baseball Hall of Fame should be closed. WILLIS--Susan Crobaugh, died May 14, 2009, in New York City. Ms. Willis was born in Seneca County, Ohio, on August 27, 1925, the daughter of Burton and Mildred Crobaugh. Susan had one brother, Fred Crobaugh, who preceded her in death. Her marriage to Kirk Willis ended in divorce. As an actress, she worked extensively on Broadway in roles ranging from the classical Medea to Miss Mazeppa (opposite Ethel Merman) in Gypsy. She appeared alongside Sir Alec Guinness in Dylan, assumed the role of Fraulein Schneider (from Lotte Lenya) in the original production of the Tony winning musical, Cabaret. Her other Broadway credits include her debut in Take Me Along, plus Stephen Sondheim's Follies and Oliver with Patti LuPone. Much of Ms. Willis's career was situated in the theatre, including the off-Broadway Mirror Repertory stagings of Children of the Sun and The Madwoman of Chaillot. Her National Touring Company roles included a 350-city stint, playing Golda in Fiddler on the Roof (playing opposite five Tevyes), as well as performances in Mame, Picnic, Blithe Spirit, Desk Set, Zorba, and The Merchant of Venice. She essayed 23 of Shakespeare's characters over the years, beginning with her portrayal of Portia in The Merchant of Venice at the Barter Theatre in Virginia. Her regional and summer stock credits included Stella in Light Up the Sky as well as productions with the Great Lakes Theatre Festival, the San Diego Shakespeare Festival, the Old Globe Theatre and the Cleveland Playhouse, where she won a fellowship and began her professional career after graduating from Carnegie Tech (now Carnegie Mellon University) in Pittsburgh. Her motion picture roles included Clint Eastwood's Mystic River opposite Sean Penn, The Majestic with Jim Carey, What About Bob with Bill Murray, She Devil with Meryl Streep, plus the head teacher in The Faculty. She also appeared in Paul Newman's The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon, Marigolds, Ropewalk, and Petty Crimes. For three years, on the television series, All My Children, she played Helga Voynitzeva (Demetri's maid, who was ultimately thrown off a parapet in Budapest by Erica Kane). She also made guest appearances on Law & Order, Third Watch, S.V.U., the Fox-TV series, Million Dollar Mysteries and HBO's Sex in the City where she played Cynthia Nixon's elderly neighbor. She crowned her lengthy career by creating a unique cabaret act with pianist Rod Derefinko, called My First 50 Years in the Theatre, in which she performed songs by Cole Porter, Kurt Weill and Noel Coward. For many years Willis served as a council member of The Episcopal Actors Guild. She was also very active with The Village Recycling Center since its inception, and with the Fire Island Pines Arts Council. She was in the process of doing developmental reading of two plays, Dusa Died in Pittsburgh and The Roadway to Heaven. A memorial service is planned for June. At her request, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Episcopal Actors Guild, 1 East 29 Street, New York, NY 10016.

NAMED after the 1983 Catherine Deneuve/David Bowie/Susan Sarandon vampire pic ''The Hunger,'' François Nars's blood orange nail lacquer Hunger became an instant cult classic when it was introduced in 2001. Its discontinuation several years later only added to its appeal. Now, in celebration of the 15th anniversary of his makeup line, Mr. Nars has reissued the polish (in a limited edition), along with four other summery vintage shades: Cha Cha Cha, a sheer tangerine; Blue Lagoon, a shimmering turquoise; Zizi, a peachy gold; and Tallulah, a rich purple that Mr. Nars counts as his personal favorite. ''It's very elegant and deep,'' he said. ''It is the new dark red.''

GOLDBERGER--Sylvia, of Riverdale, NY, died at age 94 on May 10, 2009, after a long illness. An enthusiastic world traveler, she worked for many years as a senior administrator in the New York City Social Services Department. A graduate of Hunter College in 1933 at the age of 18, her many accomplishments were recognized by induction into the Hunter College Hall of Fame in 1973. Her late brother, Emanuel Goldberger, M.D., was a well-known cardiologist. Sylvia's generous and joyful spirit will be greatly missed by her two nephews, Richard N. Goldberger, a free-lance writer in Salt Lake City, UT, and Ary L. Goldberger, M.D., Professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, and by her devoted friend and longtime companion, Arthur Stern. She is also survived by her grandnephews, Zachary and Alexander Goldberger, and by her great-grandniece, Annabel Grace Goldberger. Private funeral services were held at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

GREENBERG--Leah (nee Koenigsberg), passed away peacefully May 9th in her 99th year. She was the beloved wife of the late Hy Greenberg and the proud mother of her adoring daughter Shelley Greenberg Meyer and son in law Harvey Joel Meyer. She was the family matriarch, a mensch and a spitfire, cherished by her Koenigsberg clan of nieces, nephews and cousins and loved by her extended family of friends, neighbors and "adopted daughters."

As the petals of the dogwoods fall, saucy skirts are causing men to turn their heads. These are not the full skirts of the '50s; they are fitted over the hips and then let loose in a flurry of godets, flanges and pleats. A printed design achieved its bounce through the weight of a hem of pink satin-ribbon. Knitted versions swing thanks to sunburst stitchery, narrow to start and then released to form ruffles at the hem. This change of silhouette from pencil skirts was the idea last year of the Paris designer Azzedine Allaïa, who constructed an unusual tulip-petal godet to give the skirt of his coats a sassy swing, right. The Allaïa skirts are the work of a major couturier and nearly uncopyable.

CULTURATI / (kul& cher a& tê) / n. / Those who make, influence and follow cultural affairs, particularly in the visual and performing arts, e.g., '''The culturati have been buzzing about the gallery scene in Glasgow, so I'm going next week to check it out.'' Among the world's most active jet-setters, the culturati also point the way for mainstream travelers who are increasingly interested in engaging with places through culture. D.I.Y. / (de ê wê&) / adj. / Acronym for Do-It-Yourself. Applied to projects, communities and establishments that have an improvised quality, as in ''In Pittsburgh we went to this bar-cafe-performance space put together by some artists -- very cool, very D.I.Y.'' In tough economic times, places with a D.I.Y. ethos are vital creative hubs, thanks to the intersection of original ideas and low overhead.

FISHER--Lois D.,of New York and Cherry Grove, Fire Island, died peacefully on May 11, 2009, at 72, after a ten-year struggle with breast cancer. Lois was a woman of extraordinary courage and grace, who set the bar high for living life large in the face of unrelenting health challanges. She traveled the world over, stubbornly refusing to cede to increasing physical limitations. She was a loyal friend, dedicated member of her cancer support group, avid lover of animals, and committed member of her community. Born in Delta, CO, Lois graduated from the University of Colorado and received an M.A. from California State University. For 19 years, Lois was a teacher and assistant principal in San Francisco before moving to New York in 1977, to join the General Service Office of Alchoholics Anonymous where she worked as a staff member until she retired in October, 2000. Lois is survived by her long-time partner Barbara Dowd, dear friend Audrey Hartmann, sister Patsy Ballard, and her family of choice. A celebration of Lois' life will be at a future date. In lieu flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Lois to: C.G.C.A.I. Benefactors Fund, Lenox Hill Station, P.O. Box 1615, New York, NY 10021, or the Cancer Initiative of the LGBT Community Center, 208 W. 13th St., New York, NY 10011.

''The timing was not that bad.'' Kristin Halvorsen, finance minister of Norway. As investors the world over sold in a panic last fall, she authorized Norway's sovereign wealth fund to buy billions in stocks, and helped the country make sizable gains.

TIRED of seeing T-shirts that benefited Africa but were produced in China, Yodit Eklund and her brother, Yohannes Mekbebe, started Bantu, a swimwear line that supports Africa's economy from the inside out: its many-colored prints come from West Africa, the heartland of Africa's textile industry, and the cutting and sewing is done in Ethiopia. ''We wanted to do something African that would employ people and promote sustainable business,'' said Ms. Eklund, who was born to an American father and an Ethiopian mother, and studied environmental economics at the University of California, Berkeley. Given the continent's vibrant beach culture, swimwear seemed an obvious concept. ''It would be pretty difficult to launch a ski brand from Africa,'' she noted.

ELTERMAN--Leonard. The family of Leonard Elterman mourns his passing January 2, 2009, Boynton Beach, FL. Earned a BA from Brooklyn College, MBA from NYU, he always valued education. Founded Huntington Chapter B'nai B'rith, received a letter of thanks from Abba Eban for UJA service. Plastics manufacturer and innovator, President of Popular Plastics, Northport (1950s). Charter Member of Shelter Rock Tennis Club. Brilliant card player, known as "Gin Rummy King." Survived by wife Selma, children Eileen, Joey, Vivienne and Judi, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

VITTUM--Daniel W.,Jr., founding board chair for the Noble Network of Charter Schools, former board chair and general counsel for the Northwestern University Settlement, and notable intellectual property attorney with Kirkland & Ellis, died after a long struggle with lung cancer. He was 70 years old. Dan is a descendant of Joshua Jones, founder of Monticello, Kentucky and cousin to Harriet Vittum, the social activist and long time Head Resident of the Northwestern University Settlement House in Chicago's West Town neighborhood. Daniel was the only son of Kathryn J. Vittum and Daniel W. Vittum, Sr. He was born in Kentucky where he lived until his family moved first to Chicago and then Arlington Heights at the age of three. A 1957 graduate of Arlington High School, he was top student and all around athlete, lettering in football, basketball, and his best loved sport, baseball. Dan attended the University of Illinois in Champaign-Urbana where he continued to excel academically. He graduated with a Bachelors in Science degree in Chemistry with high distinction, Phi Beta Kappa, in 1961. He went on to graduate from the University of Michigan Law School, first in class, Order of the Coif, in 1964. Daniel joined Kirkland & Ellis in 1964, became a partner in 1970 and retired in 2000. During his life, Daniel continued the long family tradition of family service to children, families and communities in Chicago. Under Dan's leadership at the Northwestern University Settlement the Settlement Association doubled in physical size, budget and participation of children and families. The Vittum Theater was constructed and then became home to Adventure Stage Chicago which currently reaches out to 13,000 students and 100 public schools annually. From 1998 to the present, Dan led the Settlement's successful efforts to obtain a charter from the Chicago Public Schools to found Noble Street Charter School. Under Dan's leadership the school has gained national recognition and since 2005 has gone through an expansion which will result in a total of 11 campuses by 2011. Dr. Christine L. Jacobek said of her husband, Daniel, He was a unique man, brilliant intellectually and compassionate, gentle and unpretentious, personally. I think he experienced and related to the world using the intellect of his mind and the softness of his heart. His loving memory comforts his wife; his two sons Stephen Frederic and Daniel Weeks, III, MD; his daughter-in-law, Bernice Man, MD; and his joyous granddaughters, Mora Kai, Tali Elizabeth, and Neenah Kathryn. A Memorial Service and reception will be held on Saturday, May 30, 2009 at 11am at The Vittum Theater. The address is: 1012 North Noble, Chicago, IL. Donations in Daniel's memory would be gratefully received by The Noble Network of Charter Schools at: 1010 North Noble, Chicago, IL 60622 or the Northwestern University Settlement Association at: 1400 Augusta Blvd., Chicago, IL 60622. Information: Heritage Cremations 800-936-1414.
Theater Steven McElroy

As expected, the four sculptures by Chakaia Booker in the garden at the Katonah Museum of Art provide the most stimulating experience of outdoor art in Westchester right now. Not only does Ms. Booker, 56, possess a natural eye for expressive forms, but her materials -- cast-off rubber tires from cars, trucks and tractors -- are manipulated with such zeal as to suggest a vivid essay on how to make art from unorthodox materials. The variety of the pieces further testifies to her command of sculptural techniques, control of detail and versatility as an outdoor sculpture specialist. Many artists have produced excellent outdoor public sculptures, but I can think of only a few who have been as successful -- and over such a long period of time -- as Ms. Booker. Part of that success comes from the material she uses, which is ideally suited to art in an outdoor environment.

CLAUSS--Edwin R. Beloved husband of Elizabeth, adored father to Allison and cherished grandfather.

DOMESTIC DISTURBANCES The Obamas have grabbed the national imagination like no other first family since the Kennedys. There's a particular immediacy to that sentiment here in Washington. There's a special, consciously self-indulgent kind of pleasure that goes with it. It's a feeling, I think, somewhat akin to what Michelle Obama was probably trying to express when she made her famous blunder about being proud of her country for the first time in her adult life. This feeling of pride is a reprieve from a moment of almost unrelenting national grimness that I think we're all entitled to. And maybe it actually has some greater value.

For sellers, holding a garage sale is a way to make a little extra money and do some spring cleaning and purging at the same time. For buyers, the garage sale taps into that universal desire to score a bargain. All motives are in keeping with the current recessionary spirit, and last weekend garage buyers and sellers were out in force in places like League City, Tex. (near Houston), and Brooklyn where they are known as stoop sales, garages being in short supply.

BURTA--Helen (Grabow), 82, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL (formerly of Brooklyn and Spring Valley), died on May 14, 2009 after a long battle with heart disease. She was an honorable, courageous woman, and who fought hard for life. Though mostly anonymous in her activities and influences, she left a legacy of outstanding principles and ethics. Her favorite expression, "The truth with the intent to deceive is still a lie," is emblematic of her entire being. She is now with her beloved husband Stanley of over fifty years, and is survived by her two children, Vicki Dodge and David Burta, her grandson Max Burta, son-in-law Mark Dodge, daughter-in-law Michele Burta, and her very dearest friend for life Anita Haymes.

This is the last issue of this section. Starting next weekend, to consolidate local coverage and reduce costs, it will be replaced by a new section, Metropolitan, a showcase for distinctive writing, ambitious photography and innovative storytelling about New York and its suburbs. The new section will include the regional arts and dining reviews and calendar listings, and the television listings now located in the back of the main news section.

With anecdotal evidence suggesting the number of foreclosures was accelerating in the New York metropolitan area, The New York Times set out to try to quantify the extent of the problem -- not just from a regional or county-level view, but down to the street level. After acquiring data that included the property addresses for more than 182,000 homes in foreclosure between January 2005 and August 2008, The Times used mapping software to plot the foreclosed properties and then computed the percentage of residential properties in foreclosure at various geographic levels.

FUCHS--Harry, 91. With great sadness we mourn the loss of the beloved husband of 60 years to Bea, devoted father to Richard, Judy, Nancy, Wendy and Frank, and loving grandfather and professor to Michael, Daniel and Benjamin. Widely known as a first rate comedian, historian and storyteller, he brightened many lives and will be sorely missed. Graduated from CCNY and Brooklyn Law School. He rose to the level of Captain in the US Army Military Government in Europe during and after WWII. Retired at the age of 82 from Rosenthal and Rosenthal, where he worked for 47 years and was Executive Vice President and head of the factoring division. President of the Toppers and the 475 Club. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association Founder's Affiliate. Service Sunday, May 17, 12:45pm, at The Riverside, Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St.

ARMOUR--Linda Freeman, 69, long-time resident of Lake Forest, Illinois, died of cancer at home on May 11, 2009. Wife of Vernon Armour, Linda is also survived by her mother Frances Freeman; son and daughter-in-law Douglas and Meghan Strubel; grandchildren Claire and Benjamin Strubel; son Craig Strubel; sister Clara Farah (John); stepchildren Linda A. Kelly (George), Cynthia A. Landreth (Colt), V. Kelley Armour (Miah), Gordon F. Armour (Anne), Mary Taylor Moulton (Allan), Christopher Taylor (Elizabeth) and William C. Taylor (Phyllis), and many nephews, nieces and step-grandchildren. Preceded in death by her father, Gaylord A. Freeman; sister Nancy Freeman Ellett; and her husband of 18 years William C. Taylor. Linda attended The Madeira School in McLean, Virginia, and was one of the first women graduates of Williams College. Linda was a member and former president of the Lake Forest Garden Club and member of the Boca Grande Garden Club. She was also active as a Lake Forest Historic Preservation commissioner, was the first woman elected to the Board of Directors of Lake Forest Hospital, and is a former member of the Woman's Board of Children's Memorial Hospital, Chicago.

MEADES--Gertrude Webb, the wife of the late Harry Meades, military hero who served as a Royal Air Force Officer and was decorated four times and held five Combat Medals. She was the granddaughter of former Mayor William J. Gaynor of New York City, NY. Gertrude passed away peacefully Saturday, May 9, 2009 at her home in Naples, Florida. She was raised in Manhasset, New York and known to her family and friends as "Punchie." Gertrude Webb Meades was born February 28, 1925 the fourth child of five children whose parents were William Seward Webb, Jr. and Gertrude Gaynor Webb. Her father was the founder of Webb and Knapp, real estate agent, and son of the late William Seward Webb, railroad builder and his mother was the late Mrs. Eliza Osgood Webb, a daughter of William H. Vanderbilt. Mrs. Meades mother was the late Gertrude Gaynor Webb, daughter of William J. Gaynor and Elizabeth Handwright. Her parents fortunes enabled the Webb's and Vanderbilt's to be among the earliest to enjoy summers in Shelburne, Vermont and go on to create the world renowned "Shelburne Museum". (The Shelburne Museum was founded by Electra Havemayer Webb and her husband J. Watson Webb whose parents were Dr. William Seward Webb and Lila Vanderbilt Webb. Their 19th century lakeside estate would become Shelburne Farms.) Gertrude (Punchie) Webb Meades, longtime character of life, regaled in living life to the fullest with long freighter trips to exotic ports of call, the love of animal husbandry, she had a passion for reading and enjoyed the solitude of needlepoint. She spent many productive years as a volunteer with the Naples Community Hospital Blood Bank. There was no one else like this woman, lovingly known as Punchie. She will be remembered for her love of family, her dear friends, her zest for life, and her elegantly gentle kind outlook on life, graceful manners, wit and warmth. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. She is survived by Emma II, her "Pug", her two sons, Michael Harry Meades of Apopka, Florida and Jamie Seward Meades of Sarasota, Florida, three granddaughters, Heather Portanova, Meredith Magennis and Mindy Meades and great-grandchildren, Caitlin Magennis, Caleb Portanova and Kayli Portanova. In addition, she is survived by her sister Frederica Webb Gamble of Westwood, MA, her nieces, Frederique Gamble, Susan Webb Porter and nephew W. Seward Webb. Memorial service was conducted Saturday, May 16, 2009 at the St. John's Episcopal Church, Naples, Florida. In lieu of flowers, family and friends may make contributions in Punchie's name to Vitas Innovative Hospice Care: Naples, Florida, Animal Refuge Center of Fort Myers: North Fort Myers, Florida or the Naples Community Hospital Blood Center: Naples, Florida.

NEIL KRUG'S stylized photos of his girlfriend, the model Joni Harbeck, were taken with Polaroid film years past its sell-by date. They have the kind of grainy, sun-scorched feel of a Sergio Leone spaghetti western. And ever since the couple began posting the photos on Flickr early this year, they've drawn a blaze of attention. ''I really never received this much feedback on my work before,'' said Mr. Krug, who has also directed music videos for Ladytron and Ratatat. He became interested in shooting Polaroid last year when it was announced that the instant film would be discontinued; and its eventual demise (it has been estimated that by September, the supply will be entirely depleted) adds a certain poignancy. ''It resonates with people,'' Mr. Krug said. ''I know I've fallen in love with it.''
Art Nicolai Ouroussoff

McNAMARA--Brooks, died on May 8, in Doylestown, PA. He was 72. Mr. McNamara held a bachelor's degree from Knox College, a master's degree from the University of Iowa, and a PhD in theater history from Tulane University. Mr. McNamara was a professor emeritus in the Department of Performance Studies, Tisch School of the Arts, New York University, and founding director of the archives of the Shubert Organization. He held a Fulbright Senior Research Fellowship and a Guggenheim Fellowship. His was a Fellow of the American Theater, and served on the boards of the Theater Library Association, the American Society for Theater Reseach, and the Doylestwon Historical Society. A scholar of American theater history and popular entertainment, he was author or editor of more than a dozen books, including Step Right Up: The American Meidicne Show; The New York Concert Saloon; The Devil's Own Nights; and The Merry Muldoons and the Brighteyes Affair, for children. He is survived by wife, Nan, his daughter and son-in-law Jane McNamara and John Oddy, his son and daughter-in-law Whitney and Monda McNamara and his grandchildren, James Brooks Oddy, Gwendolyn Claire McNamara, George Jansen Oddy and Thomas Carlin McNamara. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law Scott McNamara and Carol Wittels, his sister-in-law Sally Kudar and his mother-in-law Nan Jansen. Services will be held on Saturday May 30 at 3pm in Saint Paul's Lutheran Church, North Main and Spruce Streets, Doylestown, PA.
Classical Allan Kozinn

HOGAN--Jane nee McGoey, 90, died May 14, Warwick, NY. Raised in Inwood, married the late Donald A. Hogan on November 20, 1948. 1941 graduate of Hunter College. Loving matriarch. Survived by seven children and 12 grandchildren.

Is Toronto's Marco Scutaro having a career year at 33, or is he about to fall off a cliff? Scutaro, below, has never hit more than nine homers, but is on pace for more than 21. (Only one of those home runs, however, has come in the last three weeks.) He has never had an on-base percentage higher than .350 or walked more than 57 times in a season, but through six weeks he was at .404 with 33 walks. Ervin Santana had a breakthrough season last year, only to sustain an elbow injury. His first start back from the D.L. was a rocky one (three runs, three walks and seven hits in five innings Thursday), and the Angels, their rotation in tatters, will need steady progress from him, regardless of how weak the A.L. West is.

BURDETTE--Brooks R. Brooks was one of the finest and kindest of persons: a great friend and law partner, wise counsellor, and a brilliant lawyer. He worked strenuously to overcome serious childhood illnesses, never asked for or accepted favors because of his physical limitations, and wildly succeeded in the toughest environment any trial lawyer could compete in. Brooksy, we will miss the lunches, dinners, and discussions, but mostly miss knowing you were always there to help lend a hand. Good-bye, our friend: you're the best. David M. Brodsky Daniel J. Kramer
WILLIS--Susan. The Episcopal Actors' Guild mourns the loss of our dear friend and Council member Susan Willis.

Ever feel like you’re in one of those old-timey prison movies, where the wrongly convicted death row inmate is slowly making his way to the electric chair while his faithful wife and his crusading lawyer are breathlessly awaiting that phone call from the governor?

When we last spoke with Josh Schwartz, the co-creator of “Chuck,” even he wasn’t sure if that NBC comedy-action series about a nerdy secret agent would survive for a third season. If it didn’t, he and his “Chuck” co-creator Chris Fedak predicted, “People will set their living rooms on fire.”

CANNES, France — There’s no question that Lars von Trier knows how to get a rise out of the Cannes press -– along with its rapt attention, its incredulous laughter and, this year at least, its lusty jeers. The Danish middle-aged enfant terrible, who has been shaking up both the festival and world cinema for more than a decade with films like “Breaking the Waves” and “Dogville,” is clearly intent on holding on to his provocateur status, even if it means alienating (dividing, baffling) his audience further. This, in any event, seems one explanation for his latest, “Antichrist,” an alternately deadly serious and highly ironic exploration of psychosexual trauma with Willem Dafoe and Charlotte Gainsbourg as a married couple grieving the death of their only child.

A relapse is typically bad news, but in this case it’s a positive omen for fans of Eminem: the rapper is planning to play a free concert on Tuesday in Detroit to promote the release of his new album, “Relapse,” The Associated Press reported. The free show was announced on Eminem’s MySpace page, and tickets were scheduled to be given away on a first-come, first-serve basis on Monday at 5 P.M. at Record Time, a music store in the Detroit suburb of Roseville. The site of the show, which will feature DJ Jazzy Jeff, was not revealed. Last Friday, Eminem brought about 200 unemployed auto workers to Los Angeles to watch his performance on the ABC late-night show “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” Eminem will also appear on that show on Tuesday and Friday.

Updated | 12:40 p.m. So much for the trial of the century: a lawsuit filed by Woody Allen against American Apparel was quickly settled on Monday morning for $5 million, Reuters reported. Mr. Allen was suing the clothing maker for using without permission an image of him from “Annie Hall,” in which he was dressed as a Hasidic Jew, on billboards that appeared in New York and Los Angeles and in online advertisements.

The Supreme Court will not hear an appeal filed by a son and a granddaughter of John Steinbeck who were seeking rights to “The Grapes of Wrath” and other early works by the author, The Associated Press reported. In 2006, a United States district court in New York ruled that the son, Thomas Steinbeck, and the granddaughter, Blake Smyle, should be granted the rights to 10 Steinbeck novels, including “Of Mice and Men” and “Tortilla Flat.” They said they had filed a notice of termination that had ended a 1994 agreement between Penguin Books and Elaine Steinbeck, the author’s widow, who died in 2003. But last year, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled unanimously that the 1994 agreement could not be terminated by John Steinbeck’s biological heirs.

“Valkyrie” charges ahead on DVD this week. Bryan Singer‘s film stars Tom Cruise as Claus von Stauffenberg, a colonel who leads a 1944 bid to assassinate Hitler. In her review of the film, Manohla Dargis wrote that it “transforms World War II into a boy’s adventure with dashing heroes, miles of black leather and crane shots of German troops in lockstep formation that would make Leni Riefenstahl flutter.”

In a film and television career that spans more than 20 years, Jane Lynch is variously known for playing the autocratic electronics store manager in “The 40-Year-Old Virgin,” the tyrannical mentor-program director in “Role Models” and, of course, the disciplinarian dog breeder in “Best in Show.” Seeing a pattern here? On “Glee,” a new Fox series that has its debut on Tuesday (and which Alessandra Stanley reviews here), she plays her toughest character yet: a high school cheerleading coach named Sue Sylvester, who is the arch nemesis of the hopelessly dorky glee club chronicled on the show.

The song-writing partners Benny Andersson and Bjorn Ulvaeus, best known for transforming their music for the Swedish rock group Abba into the hit musical “Mamma Mia!” on Broadway and elsewhere, will present their musical “Kristina” in English for the first time at Carnegie Hall in September.

Fresh off hosting one of the biggest recent season finales of “Saturday Night Live,” Will Ferrell will step into another big role on NBC: He will be the first guest on Conan O’Brien‘s opening night as host of the “Tonight” show June 1. The musical guest will be an equally big name: Pearl Jam. Mr. Ferrell became one of the favorite guests for Mr. O’Brien during his run on his “Late Night” show — often performing a raucous striptease. From his earliest days on “Saturday Night Live,” Mr. Ferrell became a signature guest for Mr. O’Brien.

Why we do compulsively shop -- and how can we stop? And who doesn't like to be kissed?

The most familiar wildlife in Africa, from lions to rhinos, tends to be far from the continent's coasts. But increasingly, African beaches are turning out to be important havens for imperiled species. A case in point is in Gabon, where a trove of nesting leatherback turtles has been revealed on a stretch of largely untrammeled beaches. Biologists from the Wildlife Conservation Society, working with Gabonese conservation groups, estimate that anywhere from 15,000 to 41,000 female leatherback turtles are nesting there, making the spot the world's largest known nesting ground for the giant and extremely endangered reptile. The estimates grew out of aerial surveys led by Matthew Witt of the University of Exeter in England and are described in a paper being published later this year in the journal Biological Conservation. Most of the nesting is taking place in areas that are already designated as parks or otherwise protected, the group says. As I wrote not long ago, there are growing threats to the turtles in parts of Gabon, even in places where beachfront development or poaching aren't an issue. Thousands of stray logs drifting down the Congo River from clearing operations are cluttering some nesting beaches, forming deadly blockades that trap leatherbacks. But over all it's clear that leatherbacks have a strong beachhead in this country, at least for now.
The Tamil Tiger rebels in Sri Lanka have been defeated militarily, but where does that leave the Tamil diaspora that has supported the struggle?

Update | 6:36 a.m. | May 19 In a telephone interview with Britain's Channel 4 News on Sunday, a spokesman for Sri Lanka's Tamil Tiger militants, Selvarasa Pathmanathan, said that while the defeated rebels were laying down their arms, they would "not surrender." What exactly this means for the rebel force, whose leader the Sri Lankan army claims to have killed, is not exactly clear, but it does seem to encapsulate the mood of many in the large, vocal Tamil diaspora who are simply not willing to accept that this military defeat means an end to their dream of an independent Tamil homeland in Sri Lanka.

Scandinavia is one of our favorite places for creative cross-pollination here at the travel desk (check this out, and this). And here's one new reason why: The Creators Inn by Elvine is a capsule hotel in Gothenburg, Sweden, that puts up creative types visiting and working in the city - for free.Now the group behind it - the Gothenburg design firm Next Century Modern and the fashion label Elvine - have taken the concept to Stockholm for the summer, setting aside a block of rooms in the Scandic Malmen hotel for starving artists, designers, musicians, mimes, whoever applies and is deemed worthy of subsidizing. Over email, Jesper Larsson, the C.E.O. of Next Century Modern, told me, "We try to support up and coming creators of different kinds, the ones that would normally end up on someone's couch." To do that, they work first with local event organizers to find people who need a crash pad. But anyone, especially foreign guests, are welcome to apply. The Gothenburg location has brought in guests from Brooklyn to Tokyo, including the New York videographer and playwright Kevin Doyle and Copenhagen's lesbian D.J. duo Fagget Fairys.

Mining: I've added Coal Tattoo to my blogroll. [UPDATE, 6/19: Coal Tattoo reports that Don Blankenship, the president of Massey Energy, is seeking to debate James Hansen, the NASA climatologist and climate campaigner.]It's an ongoing exploration of coal mining in and around West Virginia by Ken Ward Jr. of the Charleston Gazette. The blog's name comes from a song by Billy Ed Wheeler, he explains. In a post last week, Mr. Ward noted that the Obama administration had approved 42 of 48 proposed mountaintop mining projects. This appears to reflect how the administration, the United States and many other countries remain stuck between a hard place (reliance on coal for cheap electricity) and a soft rock (bituminous coal). Reflecting that enduring reality, just last month the West Virginia Coal Association noted that Britnee Gibson, a senior at Gilbert High School, successfully led an effort to have the state legislature name coal the official state rock. (A hat tip to the daily news digest of the Society of Environmental Journalists for bringing Coal Tattoo to my attention.)

Nascar: Tony Stewart won his first race as a team owner on Saturday at Lowe's Motor Speedway. Too bad it was in the non-points paying All-Star event. Nevertheless Stewart, who left Joe Gibbs Racing after 10 seasons to start Stewart-Haas Racing, said the win was an important step for the team. "So to get those guys in Victory Lane and to get these guys on the team that haven't been to Victory Lane yet, to get them to there for the first time, that means more than a million dollars does to me," he told Autosport, referring to the $1 million purse. In its latest format, the annual race consisted of 100 laps divided into four segments, ending in a 10-lap shootout. In third position with five laps to go, Stewart charged ahead of Matt Kenseth with two laps remaining to take the win. He is currently second in the Sprint Cup standings.

What do store mannequins have to do with artists, or high-design furniture? Plenty, if you're Ralph Pucci. "SHOW," a soon-to-be-published book from Glitterati Incorporated, traces the multifaceted career of the man who took over his father and mother's mannequin business and then had the nerve to ask artists like Maira Kalman and Kenny Scharf to design, well, not your father's mannequins.Since finding himself in the furniture business after the legendary Andrée Putman asked him to represent her Ecart line in 1990, Pucci has attracted a stable of designers ranging from giants like Putman, Jens Risom and Vladimir Kagan to younger talents like David Weeks, Chris Lehrecke, and Herve van der Straeten. He loves to stage art shows (by people like Ruben Toledo, Christopher Makos, or James Brown) alongside those of design or fashion. In 1985, one of Pucci's earliest cross-disciplinary efforts had Putman designing a mannequin, a young Isabel Toledo dressing it, and Andy Warhol and Keith Haring autographing everything in sight at the party Pucci gave to show it off. "SHOW" itself (with photographs by Antoine Bootz) will be unveiled tonight at - you guessed it - a party at Ralph Pucci International's New York showroom.

Each May, TV networks host "upfronts," shorthand for an annual rite of passage for television networks and the industry that operates in orbit around them. It generally refers to three activities:No. 1: The unveiling of new television network schedulesNo. 2: The cajoling of advertisers by the networksNo. 3: The selling of billions of dollars in advertising timeNo. 1 is the most important for fans who want to know if their favorite shows will return and which new shows will join the schedule. Nos. 2 and 3 are the most important to networks who want to keep shows in production and keep generating profit for their parent companies, an especially tough task this year.

Ruth Padel, right, has been elected the new Oxford professor of poetry and will be the first woman to hold the post since it was established in 1708, the Guardian reported. Ms. Padel, the great-great-granddaughter of Charles Darwin, was chosen on Saturday following a controversial contest for the position. Last week the Nobel Prize-winning poet Derek Walcottwithdrew from the running because news surfaced about sexual harassment claims made against him by a Harvard student in 1982. A dossier containing the details had been sent anonymously to 200 Oxford academics. Mr. Walcott's withdrawal left Ms. Padel and the Indian poet and critic Arvind Mehrotra in consideration. ''I should like to thank the university and the people who voted for me,'' Ms. Padel said. ''I feel honored and humbled to be given this responsibility and shall try to carry it out as well as I can. My backers based their support for me on what they felt I could offer poetry and students. Now I shall do my best to fulfill their trust.'' Ms. Padel's selection follows close on the heels of Carol Ann Duffy's appointment as Britain's poet laureate; that post had been held by male writers for 341 years.

BEARN--Alexander G.,M.D. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Alexander G. Bearn, M.D. Alick was an esteemed member of this community for nearly sixty years, first as a faculty member, then as a trustee. He found his way to Rockefeller in 1951 when his strong belief in investigative medicine led Dr. Henry Kunkel to offer him a laboratory appointment. Alick focused on rare metabolic disorders, eventually heading his own laboratory, the first at Rockefeller dedicated to human genetics. After joining the faculty of Cornell University Medical College in 1966, Alick continued his association with Rockefeller as a visiting professor and physician, and was invited to join the Board of Trustees in 1970. In 2002, he was awarded the David Rockefeller Award for Extraordinary Service to the University. Alick Bearn was a trusted friend and advisor to seven Rockefeller presidents. Through his trusteeship, his books and publications, his leadership of the Kunkel Society, and his membership on the Lewis Thomas Prize committee, to name just a few of his many endeavors, he continued to enhance the intellectual vitality of the University his entire life. He will be remembered for his wise counsel and his enormous personal integrity. Alick possessed a unique blend of warmth, wit, wisdom, and a profound sense of service to humankind. His charm and irrepressible ebullience made being in his company a true delight. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beautiful wife and partner of 56 years, Margaret, who is in every way his equal in warmth, intellect, and zest for life. We also extend our sympathy to their wonderful family: their daughter, Helen, and her husband, Rockefeller University Council member Russell Pennoyer; their son, Gordon, and his wife, Ellen; and their grandchildren. Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman and Life Trustee

Cable news radiates from the giant flat-screen television over the green-tile fireplace with a jutting wooden mantel. McGINN--Sylvester P. Father Sylvester P. McGinn former parochial vicar at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Staten Island, NY on May 15, 2009. Google unveiled a grab bag of enhancements to its Web search engine and experimental features last week that aim to keep the company ahead of rivals. Google's engineers showcased an experimental feature called Google Squared that extracts information from the Web and displays it in a table. For instance, if you type ''science fiction television shows,'' it may return a table of shows with several columns of information about them, like their release dates, lead actors, directors and the networks that broadcast them. Results can be saved and shared in a spreadsheet.

METHOD MAN and REDMAN ''Blackout! 2'' (Def Jam) Method Man and Redman were already on their way out of vogue when they released their first collaborative album ''Blackout!'' a decade ago. In the early '90s slap-happy stoner was a worthy job title in hip-hop -- each rapper has a platinum solo album to his name -- but by the turn of the century Southern gangsters had rendered that archetype all but obsolete. ''Blackout!'' eventually went platinum, but even this duo's genial, sanitized sitcom ''Method & Red'' didn't make it past its first season.

POPKIN--Robert N. M.D.,82, of Manhattan, formerly of Shelter Island and Lake Success, NY, died May 16, 2009 at Lenox Hill Hospital where he had been a Psychiatric Resident over fifty years ago. Survived by his wife, close friend and companion, Betsy (Elizabeth Jackson Popkin), his loved and admired sons, Steven J. Popkin and Eric F. Popkin, his devoted daughters-in-law, Terri (Theresa Dunn Popkin) and Karen (Karen King Popkin), his adored grandchildren Megan, Kelly, Jackson, Matthew and Kayla Popkin. Doctor Popkin graduated from the SUNY College of Medicine Downstate and New York Psychoanalytic Institute and was a member of the New York and American Psychoanalytic Societies. He saw his last patient two days before his final hospitalization. During WW II Doctor Popkin served 21 months in the Pacific on an ammunition supply ship as a Merchant Marine Cadet. Funeral private and limited to immediate family.

As a 4-year-old Walter Kirn had a kindly adult mentor who taught him that knowledge was ''a way to assess your location, your true position, not a strategy for improving your position.'' But Mr. Kirn managed to make it through his school years by entirely ignoring that definition. He subverted it at every opportunity. ''Lost in the Meritocracy'' is a funny, self-mocking memoir about how persistently Mr. Kirn went astray. This book is also a clear example of the very same scheming that it decries. Mr. Kirn now blames himself for getting through his school years by taking tests well, echoing his teachers' opinions and telling people whatever they wanted to hear, thanks to his ''aptitude for showing aptitude, mainly.''

A earthquake measuring 4.7 in magnitude struck Sunday night on the southwest side of Los Angeles, announcing itself with a tremendous boom, sending pans and glasses tumbling and unnerving thousands of Angelenos. It was followed by a smaller aftershock. There were no immediate reports of major injuries or damage stemming from the quake, which struck just after 8:30 p.m. just east of Los Angeles International Airport and could be felt as far south as San Diego. But seismologists described it as the largest quake to hit the area since a 5.4 magnitude earthquake in Chino Hills last year.

LIONEL RICHIE ''Just Go'' (Island Def Jam) Lionel Richie is a one-man service economy through much of ''Just Go,'' his solicitous new album. He wants to make sure you're comfortable, fulfilled and secure in his devotion. ''I am not okay/Unless you're okay,'' he declares in one ballad, ''I'm Not Okay.'' On the lightly Caribbean-flavored title track -- produced by Akon and now on the Hot Adult Contemporary chart -- he sings, ''I'm here to take that stress from you.'' Then he offers to cook a meal, make the bed and spirit you by sailboat to the Bahamas, where he'll make good on the promise of a massage.

ROOM FOR DEBATE A report released last week by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that the percentage of children born to unmarried women is rising sharply. Experts weigh in on what the new numbers mean and what they think is the most striking trend in the data. nytimes.com/roomfordebate
FUCHS--Harry, your outrageous humor and sharp wit coupled with a keen intellect and gentle demeanor made you the perfect friend. We will all miss you. Roberta and Willard Block

Susanna Agnelli, a scion of the Fiat car dynasty, the only female foreign minister in Italian history and a formidable presence who brought American-style philanthropy to Italy, died Friday in Rome. She was 87. She died at the Gemelli Clinic from complications after a broken hip, said her daughter Priscilla Rattazzi Whittle of New York.

PICKERING--Thomas G. The Board of Directors and Members, Eastern Regional Chapter, American Society of Hypertension mourn the loss, on May 14, of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Thomas G. Pickering, President of this Chapter, 2005-2007, and an internationally renowned scholar, researcher and clinician in the field of hypertensive cardiovascular disease. He will be remembered fondly for his intelligence, grace and unfailing humor, and missed by all who knew him as a friend. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Janet, sons Robert and William, and their families. Steven A. Atlas, M.D., President

NAMAD--Dr. Ruth(Holzberg). Professor and linguist, died peacefully on May 17, 2009 following a long illness. She is mourned by her daughter Tanya, her brother Irving Holzberg, her husband Frank, nieces Rachel Hulst and Emily Holzberg. An inspiration to everyone and loved by all. Service Tuesday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Thousands of supporters of the Maoist former prime minister, Pushpa Kamal Dahal, rallied Sunday in Katmandu. An alliance of 22 political parties claimed later to have enough support to form a new government, a development that Mr. Dahal denounced.

An assistant principal at a New York City public school died of complications from swine flu in an intensive care unit of a Queens hospital on Sunday night, the first death in New York State of the flu strain that has swept across much of the world since it was first identified in April. Hours before the death of the assistant principal, Mitchell Wiener, city officials announced that five more Queens schools had closed.

GLANCE--Joan E.,age 64, beloved daughter of the late Dr. Harry and Helen Feldman, sister of the late Steven Feldman, cherished wife of the late Howard Glance, adored sister-in-law, aunt and great-aunt and loving and devoted companion of Howard Gottlieb, died May 16 after a valiant struggle with non-smoker's lung cancer. She was a gifted teacher who worked tirelessly for 35 years in early childhood education. She will be missed by her relatives, many lifetime friends and Mt. Sinai support group. Graveside services were held May 17.

JAFFE--Lucille (Moskowitz), 82, of Boca Raton, Florida, died peacefully in the early morning of Saturday, May 16, 2009. Born in the Bronx and raised in Hempstead (LI), New York by her adoring parents, the late Samuel and Lillian Moskowitz. Lucille was married to the late Sol Jaffe. She is survived by her loving daughters Donna Jaffe Block of Jupiter, Florida, NYC Civil Court Judge Barbara Jaffe of Manhattan, and Deborah Jaffe Mackler, of Taylorsville, North Carolina. She also leaves her adored grandchildren, Lauren Block Misrahi, Jaymie Mackler Beadie, Michael Block, and Leslie Block Zlotnick and her recently born great-grandchildren Charlotte Samantha Mackler Beadie and Ike Benjamin Misrahi. Services at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 175 North Long Beach Ave, Rockville Center, NY 10am Tuesday May 19. Shiva at the home of Barbara Jaffe and Jeff Alexander.

In a response to concerns about late broadcasts, World Series games will start about 40 minutes earlier this season, MLB.com reported. First pitches will be scheduled for shortly before 8 p.m. Eastern. Fox Sports is expected to announce the changes Monday. (NYT)

With springtime comes playoff time. Several of this year's series have gone to seven games, including Houston versus Los Angeles in the N.B.A. (won Sunday by the Lakers), and hockey's Detroit versus Anaheim, won by the Red Wings (above, Marian Hossa, left, skating against Mike Brown). The Lakers, with three championships in a row, from 2000 to 2002, have led the N.B.A. in viewers. The Red Wings and the Devils, with two Stanley Cups each since 2000, top the N.H.L. SHELLY FREIERMAN

JOE LOVANO US FIVE ''Folk Art'' (Blue Note) Joe Lovano's jazz records have taken on lots of different postwar stripes: bebop, the post-bop mainstream, big-band, third-stream, conceptual albums around the repertory of famous singers, more-or-less free jazz. Musically he's got what's required for all of it. But what he offers in a larger sense is generosity and optimism. The breadth of his sound, his billowing improvising and his consistent energy makes lots of kinds of music work.

COMRAS--Jamie. Loving mother of Ashley and Bryan, former wife and dear friend of David Comras. Your physical presence has been missed, but your values and zest for life are instilled within us. You would be so proud of our accomplishments to date. Your warmth, compassion, and sincere-kindness will always resonate in our hearts. Papa Joe has led you by the hand to a more peaceful and tranquil place. You will be greatly missed and forever in our hearts. Your loving family, Ashley, Bryan and David

Perhaps the most meaningful assignments for photojournalists are the ones they give themselves. Ozier Muhammad, 58, a staff photographer for The Times, has been photographing Harlem since he moved to New York in 1980. His affectionate, unflinching portrait of that changing American community has never before been published.

Update | 2:28 p.m. Out-of-state applications to public colleges are declining, and because nonresidents pay higher tuition, the trend is adding to the financial challenges these institutions are facing.

To make it easier for prospective students to figure out how much it will cost them to go to college, Congress last year passed a higher education law that, among other things, requires all colleges to offer a “net price calculator” on their Web sites by 2011.
Yesterday I wrote about my plans to get off the couch and onto the New York City Marathon course during the next five months, but my goal was met with a chorus of skepticism.
“Superior Donuts,” the latest play by Tracy Letts, will transfer from the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago to Broadway this fall for an Oct. 1 opening, the producer Jeffrey Richards said on Tuesday.

We asked readers to tell us what effect the economy is having on their life and work. Hundreds responded via ArtsBeat and by e-mail. Robin Pogrebin writes: “Perhaps most striking about the comments was the considerable number who were defiantly upbeat despite grim circumstances. Many artists testified that the recession had strengthened their commitment to their work or allowed them to concentrate on their art — since the time spent on side jobs had diminished — or had even been a source of creative inspiration.”

DreamWorks has acquired the rights to the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and plans to make a film about the civil rights leader, Variety reported. The film will be produced by Steven Spielberg, a founder of the DreamWorks studio, as well as Suzanne de Passe (a producer of “Lonesome Dove” and “The Jacksons: An American Dream”) and Madison Jones (the animated program “Our Friend, Martin”). Though other biographical films have been made about King (including the 1978 television miniseries “King,” which starred Paul Winfield and Cicely Tyson), DreamWorks said this was the first such project about him to be officially authorized by the King Estate, the company that controls the rights to King’s intellectual property and is run by his son Dexter King. Casting for the film was not announced.

Lars von Trier’s latest movie “Antichrist,” about a couple grieving after the loss of their son, has been the talk of the the Cannes Film Festival. Check out the trailer below that mostly hints at the film’s controversial subject matter.

The British police believe that they have solved the case of a Henry Moore sculpture that has been missing for four years, and now suspect that it was sold for scrap, The Guardian reported. In 2005, the two-ton bronze sculpture, “Reclining Figure,” was stolen from Moore’s estate in Hertfordshire, 30 miles north of London, and a flatbed truck and crane believed to have been used in the crime were quickly recovered. After more than three years of investigation, Jon Humphries, the detective chief inspector of the Hertfordshire police, said that evidence suggests the work was “cut up” on the night of the crime, “then taken to a location where it was irreparably damaged before it was shipped abroad.” He added, “In my mind we’ve managed to kill off the mystery as much as is possible.” The sculpture, valued at about $4.6 million, would have yielded about $2,300 in scrap metal, Detective Humphries said.

An autopsy of the adult film star Marilyn Chambers revealed that she died from the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage and aneurysm related to heart disease, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Chambers, the actress and model who appeared on boxes of Ivory Snow laundry soap at the same time that she could be seen in the 1972 pornographic feature “Behind the Green Door,” was found dead in her home in Santa Clarita, Calif., in April. She was 56. At the time, the Los Angeles County coroner’s office said that her death was being investigated but that foul play was not suspected. On Monday, the office released its autopsy results, as well as toxicology tests that indicated the presence of two prescription drugs in Ms. Chambers’s system but not in excess amounts.

Christopher Hampton, whose play “The Philanthropist” and translation of “God of Carnage” are now on Broadway, has signed on to write the English-language adaptation of the book for the musical “Rebecca,” based on the Daphne Du Maurier novel, according to a publicist for the production.

Bartlett Sher won a Tony last year for directing the revival of “South Pacific” for Lincoln Center Theater, and on June 7 he’ll be at the Tonys again, nominated as director for the revival of “Joe Turner’s Come and Gone.” The day after the Tonys, he’ll dive into his next project: a musical version of the film “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,” written and directed by Pedro Almodóvar.

Scheduling conflicts have derailed a proposed commercial run for Christopher Durang‘s “Why Torture is Wrong, and the People Who Love Them,” which recently concluded an extended run at the not-for-profit Public Theater, a spokesman for the producer attached to the commercial project said this afternoon.
If Jimmy Kimmel still has a job at ABC on Wednesday, he is either a very lucky or very deft comedian, or he has great blackmail photos of the network executives.

Scott turns his thoughts to hockey with “Slap Shot,” George Roy Hill’s crude and irreverent 1977 film starring Paul Newman as the coach of a minor league hockey team. Mr. Scott calls the movie “the evil twin of ‘Hoosiers’ or any other inspirational, uplifting sports flick about a group of underdog misfits led by a crusty old coach.”

For a crossword to be ultimately satisfying, it has to be hard enough to be challenging but eventually solvable. That's not the whole story, though. The missing ingredient for me is that I have to feel confident that I have it correct. I solve on paper so I might still be wrong (yes, PER GOD comes to mind), but I want to feel that I've nailed it.

Thanks again to Leon Kreitzman for four fascinating articles about biological clocks in everything from peonies to people. My sabbatical is rapidly drawing to a close - but it isn't over yet! Tommy Belsky, all of 6 years old, played catch with Derek Jeter and Robinson Cano at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday afternoon. Jeter handed Belsky a baseball, the boy whizzed it to Cano, then Cano tossed it to Jeter. Then they repeated the process.

D.J. Baker, a partner at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, is leaving to become the head of the restructuring practice at Latham & Watkins, according to a person familiar with the matter.

Yesterday we wrote about whether a developing country is hidden within the borders of the United States, based on how each American state fared in the Human Development Index (a measure of social and economic development used by the United Nations). In response, some readers asked if H.D.I. scores were available on an even more local level.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will propose new rules on Wednesday that would make it possible for a company's shareholders to elect a limited number of independent directors, according to commission officials, The New York Times's Stephen Labaton reports from Washington.
The president of Spain's La Liga, contrary to the view of many of his counterparts in top European leagues, supports FIFA's controversial plan to impose the so-called 6+5 rule.

President Obama pledged on Tuesday to make nuclear nonproliferation one of his highest priorities, saying he would work with Russia and other countries to "lock down loose nuclear weapons that could fall into the hands of terrorists.''

Top executives from the German automakers Volkswagen and Porsche threw themselves behind plans for a merger Tuesday after days of confusion about whether a deal would proceed, The New York Times's Matthew Saltmarsh reports from Paris.

LOS ANGELES -- After watching Jose Reyes test his sore right calf, Manager Jerry Manuel pronounced him ready to go for Tuesday night's game against the Dodgers. Manuel reinstalled Reyes into the lineup for the first time since last Wednesday.

The Maplewood Township Committee had a special meeting last night to discuss two sets of plans for the old police station on 125 Dunnell Road, which has been vacant since last spring and is a point of contention for residents who would like to see it developed and added to the tax rolls.

One of the more historic advances in the history of baseball's most historical period is ready for the historians to analyze, if you can forgive the histrionics. The wizards at Retrosheet, the volunteer organization that for more than 20 years has compiled, proofed and distributed box scores and play-by-play logs for every season dating to 1953, just released box scores for every major league game in the 1920s - the decade of Ruth, Hornsby and (read on) Cliff Lee.
The FM Brush Company of Glendale, Queens, makes about 17,000 styles of brush, all by hand, and distributes them globally. These are meant for use with cosmetics.

Two influential proxy advisers issued opposing recommendations on Tuesday in the contentious boardroom battle between the activist hedge fund manager William A. Ackman and Target, the nation's second largest retailer after Wal-Mart.
The city will begin converting part of Broadway into a major pedestrian thoroughfare this weekend, as the first stretches of the road in Times Square and Herald Square are closed to vehicles.

Perhaps no state on the political map has shifted more decidedly to blue from red than New Hampshire, where Democrats have been rising in numbers and now control every major elected office with the single exception of the Senate seat now held by Judd Gregg.

At Tuesday afternoon's upfront presentation in New York, Jimmy Kimmel, the host of ABC's late night talk show "Jimmy Kimmel Live," delivered a withering, blistering monologue that took direct aim at ABC, its potential advertisers and his NBC late-night rival, Jay Leno. The assembled advertisers received his performance with a mixture of uneasy laughs and the occasional gasp.
New York Times columnist Ron Lieber finds that there is some cause for concern in the sweeping credit card legislation that passed the Senate on Tuesday.

The Federal Election Commission has decided that $150,000 or more in clothing purchased by the Republican party for Sarah Palin and her family around the time of her vice presidential nomination did not violate campaign finance regulations.
Alexander Conner is a interdisciplinary artist continuing to make his art despite living on $12,000 a year.
NBC executives said Tuesday that they are considering another special on the condition of Farrah Fawcett after a strong reaction to the special the network broadcast last Friday night.
A campaign to stop drunken driving by putting some form of alcohol interlock in every new car is picking up support.

The world is a decidedly less chic place this week with the passing on Monday of the legendary transgendered beauty Octavia Saint Laurent, who won hearts and an honorary place in the pantheon of the fabulous with her star turn in Jennie Livingston's 1990 voguing documentary, "Paris Is Burning." Octavia, who later changed her name to Heavenly Angel Octavia Saint Laurent Manolo Blahnik before settling on the more recession-friendly Octavia Saint Laurent Mizrahi, will be remembered not only for her encyclopedic knowledge of feminine allure - her deconstruction of the many of the looks of Paulina Porizkova in "Paris Is Burning" should be required viewing for every drag artiste in training heels - but also for having lived a glamorous life worthy of tens across the board.

The folks who gave the world the Hummer, the poster child of fuel inefficiency, want to spawn a new generation of eco-friendly military equipment with cross-over potential in the "civilian sector," say a group of retired American military officers who released a sharply worded report on Monday calling on the Department of Defense to reduce its "carbon bootprint."

A federal bankruptcy judge dismissed the Greenbrier resort's bankruptcy case on Tuesday, clearing the way for a new owner to make good on his pledge to return the iconic West Virginia property to its former glory and profitability, The Associated Press reports.

Shareholders, angered by lofty executive pay in a time of dwindling earnings, turned their wrath on Royal Dutch Shell on Tuesday, voting against compensation packages for senior management, The New York Times's Julia Werdigier reports from London.

Some of the city's largest civic groups jumped into the simmering dispute at ground zero Tuesday, saying that government should improve transportation networks downtown and not put any more money into the development of speculative office towers on the 16-acre site.

Box office tea-leaf readers have been surprised at the staying power of "Star Trek," which continues to perform well during the week among young audiences even though school is still in session. Deutsche Bank continues to beef up its investment banking business at the expense of Merrill Lynch, as it has hired another Merrill banker, Jim Ratigan, who will become a managing director in the bank's industrial sector mergers and acquisitions group in the Americas.

I will be traveling in Spain with my 17-year-old daughter and two of her friends this summer. For much of the trip we will be taking classes in Seville and living with host families. How hot is James Cameron's "Avatar"? Hot enough that Imax so far has not lined up any other Hollywood movies for its ultra-big screen theaters between Fox's release of Mr. Cameron's 3-D science fiction thriller on Dec. 18 and the arrival of Tim Burton's "Alice in Wonderland" on March 5. Things could change. But the Imax people are mulling whether the several hundred large screens by then expected to be up and running with commercial films (as opposed to the museum-type fare) will be needed for almost three months to satisfy demand for Mr. Cameron's first feature film since "Titanic."

The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, announced on Tuesday that he will not run for the United States Senate next year. It was the latest sign that Democratic officials are coalescing around Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, who was appointed in January to fill the seat vacated by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. On Friday, Representative Steve Israel of Long Island, who had considered challenging Ms. Gillibrand in a Democratic primary next year, said he would stay in the House, at the request of President Obama, who asked him not to run.
NBC is dropping the supernatural drama "Medium" and the sitcom "My Name Is Earl."

CANNES - Apparently, the financial crisis has hit the Cote d'Azur. The evidence at Cannes: the dearth of Americans; the lack of Russian being spoken on the streets; the not so crowded restaurants and shops. But Cannes is still Cannes, and the French are here in full force to soothe any doubts and to make you feel, as usual, like a foreigner.

LOS ANGELES -- Carlos Delgado had arthroscopic surgery Tuesday morning to repair the torn labrum and bone spur in his right hip. The Mets said they expected Delgado to return in approximately 10 weeks. That means the earliest Delgado could be back is July 28. The Mets had a conference call scheduled for Tuesday afternoon to discuss Delgado's surgery.

The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to put new restrictions on the credit card industry, passing a bill whose backers say will make card issuers spell out their terms in fewer words, using plain English, and treat customers more fairly, The New York Times's David Stout reports from Washington.

From the Maplewood Police Department, tucked into their blotter reporting the week's crimes: "On Sunday, May 17, Ptl. James DeFazio responded to the area of Boyden Ave and Gifford Court on a report of a vehicle striking a telephone pole at 4:40 am. He located the damaged vehicle on Hughes St. occupied by a driver and a passenger. As the officer approached the damaged silver two-door Honda it began to pull away from the curb and struck a tree at the intersection of Hughes St. and Schaeffer Rd. As Ptl. Defazio parked his marked police car at the rear of the suspect auto it began backing up striking the police car several times in an attempt to flee the scene. The operator of the car, Jeremy Butler, 21 of Schaeffer Rd, was arrested and charged with Driving While Intoxicated, Aggravated Assault on a Police Officer and several motor vehicle offenses."

An expanded study of bicycle behavior in Midtown Manhattan has found that "a large number of cyclists routinely disobey many traffic laws." Thirty-seven percent rode through red lights, while 28.7 percent paused to look -- then ran the light. More than 10 percent rode against traffic, and fully two-thirds were riding without a helmet, a requirement for delivery workers and children under 14.

My recent post on the New Yorker profile of Fred Franzia, the man behind Two-Buck Chuck, inspired quite a few comments on the issue of wine prices. The comments are particularly pertinent because my column in Wednesday's newspaper is on good values in American wine.

One of the most vibrant presentations at this year's Salone del Mobile in Milan was at the Moroso showroom by the New York-based designer Stephen Burks of Readymadeprojects and Patrizia Moroso, the company's energetic creative director. The show went by the name M'Afrique and was a colorful homage to the mother continent complete with opening night temperatures that rivaled the mid-day heat in Ouagadougou. Works by contemporary African artists such as Soly Cissé and Fathi Hassan, the photographer Mandémory and the architect David Adjaye's "African Cities" research project were presented alongside new designs by Ayse Birsel & Bibi Sek, Phillipe Bestenheider, Tord Boontje, Patricia Urquiola and Stephen Burks himself, who re-upholstered many of Moroso's signature pieces in fabrics that he and Patrizia Moroso found on their trips to Senegal. On the occasion of I.C.F.F. and the presentation of some of these new designs in the company's showroom on Greene Street, Patrizia Moroso sat down with The Moment to explain the idea behind the show, her love for African craftsmanship, and why garden furniture needs to have a soul.

The basketball court on West Fourth Street known as the Cage is an undersized patch of concrete ringed tight by a chain link fence that both marks out of bounds and provides a sense of fortification against the surrounding West Village. Talented players have built or broken their reputations here, in a few cases refining the scrapping styles they carried to the pros. It is not just a public park, but one of the most competitive public basketball courts in the country, about as close to invite-only as playground basketball gets.

I've never been one for country living, but after discovering Best Made axes, I'm considering buying a cabin in the mountains just so that I can display them. They are forged and tempered in Maine by one of America's oldest axe companies, then painted by Peter Buchanan-Smith, a design director for Isaac Mizrahi who started Best Made with Graeme Cameron, an environmental entrepreneur and fellow Canadian. (Cameron actually built his house from scratch on the shores of Stoney Lake, Ontario.)The axes are all handcrafted and made in small batches, and come with a note of authenticity and a hand-engraved "X" mark; they range in price from $200 for the no-nonsense "Old Black" to $550 for the extravagantly patterned (and named) "Eureka Queen." Woodsmen can also purchase a basic but beautiful box in which to store the axes when they're not in use or leaning handsomely against a barn door. Andy Spade recently ordered a set of 10 for his store; the full catalog can be seen at bestmadeco.com.

The Olympic silver medalist and former University of Hawaii standout Kim Willoughby pleaded no contest to assault in Honolulu. Under a plea agreement, Willoughby will be sentenced to five years’ probation. She must also pay an undetermined amount of restitution to the victim, Sara Daniel. Daniel sustained a broken nasal bone and eye socket when Willoughby was said to have punched her at a Honolulu nightclub in 2006. The plea came in the wake of a May 7 announcement by the Italian Olympic Committee that Willoughby tested positive for a steroid, nandrolone, after her Italian club Perugia played Cesena on April 5.

The administrator of Nascar’s drug-testing program said he told the driver Jeremy Mayfield what banned substance was found in his positive test. Dr. David Black said he has had several conversations with Mayfield since his suspension on May 8 and has explicitly explained the test results. On Saturday, Mayfield said he was never told what he tested positive for, and has yet to receive a copy of his results. He maintains his positive result is from mixing a prescription drug with the allergy medication Claritin-D, an explanation Black has strongly rejected.

Drexel’s Nicole Hester was named the winner of the Honda Inspiration Award after she beat cancer and helped lead the team to its first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance. The award honors a female college athlete who has overcome adversity to excel in her sport. Hodgkin’s lymphoma was diagnosed in the fall of 2006. Hester returned to play the last two years, and as a senior, Hester helped the Dragons dethrone Old Dominion in the Colonial Athletic Association tournament semifinals.

Wearing white tape on her right shoulder Monday, Maria Sharapova played her first singles match on tour in nearly 10 months, and although she won, her game showed signs of rust. Sharapova had surgery for a torn rotator cuff last year.
