PICKERING--Dr. Thomas. We are deeply saddened by the passing of a True Pioneer in Medicine, and our friend and colleague of over 34 years. Tom, your contributions to the field of blood pressure measurement and treatment of hypertension have helped so many. Your dedication to scholarship, your compassion and kindness epitomized the best of medicine. We are heartbroken to lose you. We extend our deepest sympathy to Janet, Robert, William, Roberta, Sarah, Jiali, Sadie and Jesse. Your Friends at The Hypertension Center Weill Cornell Medical College

ARMOUR--Linda Freeman, 69, long-time resident of Lake Forest, Illinois, died of cancer at home on May 11, 2009. Wife of Vernon Armour, Linda is also survived by her mother Frances Freeman; son and daughter-in-law Douglas and Meghan Strubel; grandchildren Claire and Benjamin Strubel; son Craig Strubel; sister Clara Farah (John); stepchildren Linda A. Kelly (George), Cynthia A. Landreth (Colt), V. Kelley Armour (Miah), Gordon F. Armour (Anne), Mary Taylor Moulton (Allan), Christopher Taylor (Elizabeth) and William C. Taylor (Phyllis), and many nephews, nieces and step-grandchildren. Preceded in death by her father, Gaylord A. Freeman; sister Nancy Freeman Ellett; and her husband of 18 years William C. Taylor. Linda attended The Madeira School in McLean, Virginia, and was one of the first women graduates of Williams College. Linda was a member and former president of the Lake Forest Garden Club and member of the Boca Grande Garden Club. She was also active as a Lake Forest Historic Preservation commissioner, was the first woman elected to the Board of Directors of Lake Forest Hospital, and is a former member of the Woman's Board of Children's Memorial Hospital, Chicago. A Memorial service will be held at 4:00pm on Wednesday May 20th at The Church of the Holy Spirit in Lake Forest, Illinois. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Lake Forest Hospital. Information: Wenban Funeral Home. (847) 234-0022 or www.wenbanfh.com.

MILLER--Frances, died May 17, 2009, beloved wife of the late Benjamin Miller, adored mother of Myra and her husband Roy Gordon, Nancy and her husband Nicholas Wald, Judith Miller and her partner Joyce Harpell, and Helene and her husband Charles Linker, devoted grandmother of Emily Fowler, Steven Gordon, Karen, David, Richard, and Jonathan Wald, Joshua and Melina Auerbach, Sarah Sobel and Alex Linker, and Karen Avra Gordon who predeceased her, and beloved great-grandmother of eleven. Services will be at 11:30am Wednesday, May 20, 2009 at the Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10028.

BEARN--Alexander G.,died peacefully at his home in Philadelphia on Friday, May 15, 2009 at the age of 86. Dr. Bearn is survived by his loving family, his wife of 56 years, Margaret nee Slocum, his daughter and son-in-law Helen and Russell Pennoyer of New York, his son and daughter-in-law Professor Gordon C.F. and Ellen Bearn of Bethlehem, PA, his five grandchildren, Gordon, Robert, Margaret Pennoyer, Cary and Alice Bearn, and his brother Michael Bearn of Hampshire, England. Physician, scientist, early human geneticist and author, Dr. Bearn was Executive Officer of the American Philosophical Society, Professor of Medicine Emeritus of Cornell University Medical College and Physician-in-Chief at New York Hospital, Trustee Emeritus and Professor of the Rockefeller University and former Trustee of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. He was also a Senior Vice President of Medical and Scientific Affairs, International Division for Merck & Co. Born in Cheam, Surrey, England, Dr. Bearn received his M.D. from the University of London and served with the Royal Air Force. After fellowships at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School, London, he came to the US in 1951 to the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, now Rockefeller University, where he pursued research in liver disease, Wilson's Disease and human genetics. A fellow of the National Academy of Sciences, the American College of Physicians, the Royal College of Physicians, London, Fellow Commoner of Christ's College, Cambridge University, and a member of the American Philosophical Society, he had also been President of the Harvey Society and the American Society for Human Genetics. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on Thursday, May 21, at the Brick Church, Park Avenue and 91st Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the American Philosophical Society or the Rockefeller University.

SLAVIN--Edward J.,born November 29, 1916, died May 15th, 2009 in North Woodmere, L.I. He was predeceased by his loving wife, Nettie. Eddie was brilliant, funny, an avid golfer, mason, and an attorney to the poor and underprivileged, but mainly he was a family man. A son, brother, husband, companion, dad, "poppi", "great-poppi". He was beloved and will always be remembered by his daughter Karen Brody, his son Larry Slavin, his daughter-in-law Leslie, his grandchildren Rachel Rosenberg and Daniel Brody, his son-in-law Michael Rosenberg, his great-grandchildren Alexandra and Amanda Rosenberg, his brother Dr. Seymour Slavin and sister-in-law Claire Drucker, and his companion Sarah Harwitt.

KAGAN--Leonard Edward, born July 15th, 1921 died on-------- from bladder cancer. Leonard, aka Red, was a Pilot in the United States Air Core during the Second World War. Leonard was a Second Lieutenant in the 325th Bomb Squad, 92nd division. He piloted a B17 bomber with a crew of nine, and flew 19 combat missions over Germany, totally over 200 hours in the air. He was awarded the Air Medal with two OLC's, EAME Service Medal, two Battle Stars, American Service Medal and the WWII Service Medal. Leonard then spent 12 years in the Air Reserve Forces and retired as a Captain. While a reserve, Leonard worked for a knitted fabric manufacturer. Leonard was 87 years old and was a devoted and loving husband, father and grandfather. He leaves behind two sons, Laurence Kagan and Daniel Kagan, a daughter in law Jane Kagan, and three granddaughters, Samantha, Emily and Eliza, all from New Jersey. Len was a widower who was happily married for 54 years. His wife Freda passed away in 2001 from pancreatic cancer.

DAME--Leslie. Born March 22, 1923 in Hungary, died May 17, 2009. He lead a long successful career in music accessories. He is survived by his brother Frank of Delray Beach, FL and many nephews and nieces. Friends and family are invited to attend a memorial service on Tuesday, May 19 from 6pm-9pm at Swartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

LIEBSMAN--Beatrice, 1918-2009. Beloved mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, and great-grandmother of five, award-winning teacher in the South Bronx, Beatrice was a devoted partner for 66 years with her husband Raymond, an accountant who, in later life, was a gifted sculptor. In her retirement she and "Ray" travellled all over the world; she became a volunteer with the Spence Chapin thrift shop in New York City and later with the Arizona Cancer Center in Tuscon. Beatrice had an enduring fascination with the world and the people she met. She was a passionate Scrabble player, a storyteller and lifelong poet, and a friend, confidante, and mentor to countless people. Beatrice was preceded in death by her sister Johanna Grimes, founder of the Old Hickory rare medical bookshop in Brinklow, Maryland. A gathering of family and close friends will be held Sunday, May 24th in Tuscon.

With postseason games stretching further into the wee hours, Fox has announced that games for this year's American League Championship Series and World Series would begin before 8 p.m. Eastern time, nearly 40 minutes earlier. Major League Baseball has been trying to get the networks broadcasting the playoffs to move game times earlier. Ratings lagged and complaints grew last year when some World Series games lasted well past midnight with rain delays and even a suspended game.

STEIN--Marvin, M.D. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the loss of dear friend and cherished colleague, Marvin Stein, M.D., the Esther and Joseph Klingenstein Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry. Dr. Stein first joined Mount Sinai in 1971 as Chairman of the Department of Psychiatry, a position he held for 16 years. Dr. Stein was a transformative figure who led Mount Sinai's biological and neuroscientific psychiatric research. A trained psychoanalyst, Dr. Stein was a pioneer in the investigation of the brain, behavior, and the immune system. The Mount Sinai family extends our heart-felt condolences to Dr. Stein's loved ones. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

HUSSUNG--Alleen, 78, died May 14. Veteran Broadway licensing agent Alleen A. Hussung passed over on May 14, 2009 following a long illness. She is survived by daughter Carleen Simone and son Bill Hussung. She was previously married to deceased stage and film actor Will Hussung. Alleen was retired from Samuel French Publishing, where she licensed plays to theaters on Broadway and across the country. Alleen was a Texas native who came east to attend the Julliard School of Music and never left. She was a showgirl at the famed Latin Quarter nightclub and later worked in summer theatre, eventually running the Candlewood Theater in Connecticut. Ms. Hussung was a member of the Church of Religious Science and joins her deceased sister Georgia Boughten. Alleen was a proud grandmother to Isabelle and Winston Simone.

LITTLEFORD--William D. (known to his family and friends as Bill), former Chairman of Billboard Publications, Inc. (now part of Nielsen Business Media), died peacefully at his home in Princeton, NJ on Thursday, May 14th. He was 94 years old. Born in Ft. Thomas, Kentucky on August 4, 1914, he graduated from Highlands High School and attended The University of Cincinnati before joining Billboard Magazine in 1934 as a "printer's devil." Billboard, an entertainment publication founded by his grandfather William H. Donaldson in 1894, remained a family concern for over 90 years. Bill, who spent his entire publishing career at BPI, became general manager in 1946. He was elected as President in 1958, chairman 1976, and become chairman emeritus in 1985. Under his leadership, Billboard grew from a single publication with a small printing plant in Cincinnati, Ohio to a diversified communication organization headquartered in New York City. Bill served as chairman of American Business Media from 1960-1961 and in 1997 established the William D. Littleford Awards for Corporate Community Service that recognizes companies, organizations, and individuals who are actively involved in community service programs designed to alleviate social problems. Similarly, his work with the Advertising Counsel where he remained as an Honorary Director, was widely recognized. Along the way, he completed the Executive Education Program at Harvard Business School. After the death of his first wife (Mariana Weber) in 1957, Bill married Marian Hastings Towne. Together they were instrumental in the founding of the Vieques Conservation and Historical Trust on Vieques Island, Puerto Rico. They also founded the William & Marian Littleford Foundation which provides charitable support to deserving causes and the Marian & William Littleford Fund which supports college scholarships for students at Roslyn High School on Long Island. Marian preceded Bill in death in March of 2008. He is survived by his sister; Marjorie Littleford Ross, his children; Anne, Joseph, Michael, and Terry and three grandchildren, Ryan, Ariel, and William. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 28th at Calvary Church (277 Park Avenue South at 21st Street) at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Bill's memory to the Vieques Conservation & Historical Trust, Calle Flamboyan 138, Vieques, PR 00765.

Campbell Funeral Home (Madison and 81st St.), Thursday, 6-9pm; a Mass will be said on Friday at 9:30am at St. Ignatius of Loyola (Park and 84th St.). A funeral mass will be held Saturday, 10am, in Bermuda at St. Theresa's Cathedral in Hamilton. Interment will follow at Stella Maris Cemetery in St. George.

The Japanese women's national team canceled its three-game North American tour because of trepidation over the recent outbreak of the swine flu. But according to the coach of the United States U-17 women's team, Kazbek Tambi, little stands in the way of Japan's ascension to the top echelon in the world -- the Brazilians of the Far East, he calls them. ''They've made a concerted effort to bring loads of Brazilian players and coaches, and have followed the Brazilian philosophy, which is about having great technical skills and playing a beautiful game,'' Tambi said recently. ''We don't have the Brazilians coming here. Instead we've had 30 years of English influence.''

An individual of uncommon talent and extraordinary wisdom and insight, Phil was not only our neighbor, but a friend to us all, touching each of us in his own special way. Board of Directors 133 East 80th Street Corp.

COHEN--Fern W.,died at age 74 on May 17, 2009, in the company of her family at home. Fern loved and in turn was deeply loved by her husband Dan, daughter Elizabeth Giamatti, sons Seth and Josh Cohen, son-in-law Paul Giamatti, daughters-in-law Elizabeth Uchitelle and Ruth Metzger, and her grandchildren Jake, Sam, Lucas and Olivia. Daughter of the late Judge Edward Weinfeld and Lillian Weinfeld, sister of the late Ann Schulman, Fern was a lifelong resident of New York City, a psychoanalyst and psychotherapist, author of the memoir, "From Both Sides of the Couch", a passionate tennis player, and a wry, honest and unafraid observer of the world around her. Services will be held on Wednesday, May 20th at 11:45am at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Doctors Without Borders.

TANENBAUM--Wil J.,M.D., 83 years old, died peacefully at home on May 15, 2009 from complications of Lewy Body Dementia. Wil was a respected psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who worked both in the public health field and as a private therapist. He was a long time member of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute and taught in the residency program at Albert Einstein College of Medicine where he had a reputation as a popular and charismatic teacher. He later worked at Kings County Psychiatric Center for many years until his retirement. He had a deep appreciation of music of all types and was fascinated with the sounds of speech. He loved listening to people's stories. He was articulate and eloquent with an intelligent, easy going and gentle spirit. He showed amazing courage through his years of illness and till the end could still make the pithy observation. Beloved by all his friends and family, he is survived by his wife Imelda Fagin, his daughters Sara and Kate Tanenbaum, and his nephew, Dr. David Felson. With special thanks to his longtime aide, Valentine Smith and to Bridgette Maxius, LPN who gave not only their professional care but their hearts as well. A private memorial service will be held at his home on May 30th. Please send any donations to the Lewy Body Dementia Association, 912 Killian Hill Road SW, Suite 202C, Lilburn, GA 30047 or online at http://www.lbda.org. Guestbook for Wil Tanenbaum at: http://memorialwebsites. legacy.com/WilTanenbaum

Elsie B. Washington, whose 1980 book, ''Entwined Destinies,'' is widely considered the first black romance novel, died on May 5 in Manhattan. She was 66 and had lived in Yonkers in recent years. The cause was multiple sclerosis and cancer, her brother, James E. Peterson, said.
It appears that a group of Indiana pension funds are trying to do what several hedge funds would not: openly challenge the government-sponsored sale of Chrysler to the Italian carmaker Fiat.

If Chrysler‘s bankruptcy plan is approved, current owners of Chrysler, Dodge and Jeep vehicles may find that their right to sue the automaker for injury-causing defects is a matter of debate, The New York Times’s Christopher Jensen writes.

Green Day opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart this week with “21st Century Breakdown” (Reprise), the band’s first album in nearly five years. Despite heavy promotion, the album sold a relatively modest 215,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Because it was released last Friday it registered only three days of sales for the week that ended Sunday. (Albums are usually released on Tuesday.) Also this week, the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) holds at No. 2 with 68,000; Cam’Ron‘s new “Crime Pays” (Asylum) is No. 3 with 43,000; Lady Gaga continues her run in the Top 10 with “The Fame” (Interscope), which rose two spots to No. 4 with 41,000 sales; Rascal Flatts‘s “Unstoppable” (Lyric Street) is in fifth place with 33,000.

The opening of the new Acropolis Museum will take place on June 20, almost five years after it was originally scheduled, the Greek Culture Minister told reporters at a news conference in Athens on Wednesday.

In a turn of events that viewers have variously found surprising, validating and frustrating, the underdog contestant Kris Allen was named the winner of “American Idol” on Wednesday night, receiving more votes than Adam Lambert, who was perceived (by some) to be the likely champion. Even Mr. Allen was slightly stunned by the news: after the host Ryan Seacrest had told him he had won, he said, “Adam deserves this.” (By contrast, Simon Cowell appeared to lodge a silent protest from his seat, declining to stand and applaud Mr. Allen’s victory with his fellow judges.)

Should you ever find yourself in the Durham, N.C., courtroom of U.S. Magistrate Judge Wallace W. Dixon, whether or not you agree with him on matters of law, do not challenge the judge on his knowledge of 1980s comedies.

Previously, we asked readers to suggest questions for Jeff Daniels, a Tony Award nominee his performance in “God of Carnage,” and Allison Janney, who is nominated for her role in “9 to 5,” about their shows and their acting careers. Answers from Mr. Daniels and from Ms. Janney can be found below. The Tony Awards will be presented at Radio City Music Hall on June 7 and broadcast live on CBS.
What we’re reading on Wednesday morning.

In the only cultural moment that could conceivably bring together Katie Holmes, Suri Cruise and Anthony Hopkins, Tuesday night’s episode of “American Idol” featured the final sing-off between the contestants Adam Lambert and Kris Allen. Mr. Lambert crooned Tears for Fears’ “Mad World” and Sam Cooke’s “A Change Is Gonna Come,” Mr. Allen warbled Bill Withers’s “Ain’t No Sunshine” and Marvin Gaye’s “What’s Going On,” and both singers made the best of “No Boundaries,” a new song whose authors include the “Idol” judge Kara DioGuardi. (Plus, the “Idol” alum Carrie Underwood turned up at the end to sing a smashing cover of Motley Crue’s “Home Sweet Home.”)
CBS will introduce one new sitcom to its Monday night comedy block and add two dramas on Tuesday night in the fall, the network announced Wednesday.

Updated | 11:43 a.m. Before Bob Dylan was the grizzled bard of “Time Out of Mind,” and long before he had spilled “Blood on the Tracks” or visited Woody Guthrie at the Greystone Park hospital in New Jersey, the young Robert Zimmerman, age 16, composed a poem about a dog that was brutally killed. In June, The Associated Press reported, Christie’s will sell a handwritten copy of that poem, called “Little Buddy” and written by Mr. Dylan in 1957 for a summer camp newspaper. Lisa Heilicher, a childhood friend of Mr. Dylan and the former editor of the Herzl Herald at Herzl Camp in Webster, Wis., told The A.P. she had kept the poem for years. “When I realized how famous he had become, I put it in a piece of plastic and stuck it in an encyclopedia,” Ms. Heilicher said.

The shanty home of another child star of the movie “Slumdog Millionaire” has been demolished by the authorities in Mumbai, The Associated Press reported. On Wednesday, the home of Rubina Ali Qureshi, who played the young version of the movie’s heroine, Latika, was torn down by demolition crews that clear away shanties before India’s monsoon season. Munni Qureshi, the stepmother of 9-year-old Rubina Ali, told The A.P. that her husband had been beaten by police officers who were supervising the demolition. Last week, municipal workers destroyed the home of Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, the 10-year-old actor who played the character Salim as a child. The government of Maharashtra state has previously promised to provide housing to both actors. The movie’s makers have set up trust funds for the young actors that they will have access to at age 18.

Updated | 3:10 p.m. The producer of Lars von Trier‘s new film, “Antichrist,” said the director would make cuts to his film so it would be more commercially palatable in the United States and other countries, Agence France-Presse reported. But IFC Films, which on Wednesday acquired North American distribution rights to “Antichrist,” said it was planning to release the Cannes cut of the movie in theaters. The film, which was screened on Monday at the Cannes Film Festival, stars Willem Dafoe and Charlotte Gainsbourg as a couple trying to come to terms with the death of their son, and features graphic scene of sexual mutilation. Peter Aalbaek Jensen, who runs Mr. von Trier’s production company, Zentropa, told Agence France-Presse that Zentropa made an agreement last year with the director to excise some scenes from the film. Otherwise, Mr. Jensen said, they would be unable to sell the movie “to prude markets like southern Europe, Asia and the United States, where you can’t show a naked man from the front.”

As individual donations and corporate sponsorship revenue continue to fall short, the public television stations WNET (Channel 13) and WLIW (Channel 21) said Wednesday that they planned to reduce their staffs by an additional total of about 50 people. That will bring the number of layoffs since January, when a first round of reductions was announced, to about 130 people, or nearly 25 percent of the staff.

Two children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have threatened legal action against a planned film about their father, saying that the project did not have their approval, The Associated Press reported. On Tuesday, DreamWorks announced that it had acquired the rights to King’s life story from the King estate, which is led by the civil rights leader’s son Dexter, for a film to be produced by Steven Spielberg. But two other King children, Bernice King and Martin Luther King III, told The A.P. they had not been consulted on the deal. “They don’t have the blessings of Bernice and Martin King,” Bernice King said. The King siblings have battled in court over projects about their father’s legacy, as well as a planned biography of their mother, Coretta Scott King.

Some fans of Michael Jackson who thought they would be among the first to attend his monthslong “This Is It” concert series at London’s O2 Arena in July won’t be seeing his performances until next year because he has rescheduled several shows, BBC News reported. The opening night of the six-month run (with a break from October through December), originally scheduled for July 8, has been postponed until July 12, while other shows planned for that month have been rescheduled for March. The BBC said the shows had been delayed so Mr. Jackson could spend more time rehearsing. In an e-mail message the promoter of the concerts, AEG Live, told the BBC, “We wanted to ensure that all of Michael’s fans attending the concerts get the same quality in staging and level of entertainment.”

I'll admit it: I've seen his whole career and I don't know what to make of Melky Cabrera. I see him on a roll like this, and I think he's a legitimate major league outfielder. He homered on Wednesday and went 2 for 4, raising his average to .321 and helping the Yankees to their eighth victory in a row, 11-4 over Baltimore. And he's a reliable defender.

Reyes appeared to reinjure it while running out a ground ball to second in the top of the inning. He rejoined the lineup Tuesday after not starting the previous five games. Ramon Martinez replaced him at shortstop.

I grew up in San Francisco, and when I was in the eighth grade my best friend lived in Hayward. Every evening, after finishing up our homework, we would spend hours and hours and hours on the phone. This was before unlimited long distance, free nights and weekends, and fave fives, so as our two area codes chatted, you can only imagine the long-distance phone bills my poor parents would get. One month, our marathon calls totaled in the hundreds and, naturally, my phone privileges went dead.

The Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change at M.I.T. has published work, described earlier this year, that greatly elevates the odds of calamitous global warming should no significant action be taken to stem the buildup of greenhouse gases. The team ran a suite of 400 computer simulations incorporating both what is known about how the climate could react to a greenhouse-gas buildup and a wide range of variations in the global economy and other human factors that might affect the outcome.

CANNES - Sleeping can be an issue when you're in a place that never sleeps. At Cannes you can easily slip from some fashion designer's disco after party right into an 8:30 a.m. press screening at one of the many small theaters along the Rue D'Antibes. This after having spent the previous 24 hours drifting in and out of various movies and parties, going from the bright sunlight of the street to the darkness of the theater and back again, mixing one fantasy world with another. You do not even need a change of clothes, as a good tuxedo -- a sort of James Bond uniform, with or without the "de rigueur papillon noir," required if you want to get into the Palais du Cinema -- always looks right in Cannes, no matter the time of day. Of course, if you want to try that lifestyle, you will need more than one tuxedo.But if your lifestyle, like mine, factors in a couple of hours of sleep, starting and ending your day at the Martinez Hotel is the way to go. The hotel is celebrating its 80th anniversary on la Croisette, but like those Frenchwomen who make good use of plastic surgery and never give up smoking, the white stucco facade, the circular driveway perpetually choked with tourists armed with cameras, the pool bar and restaurants crammed with journalists asking questions to silent starlets, the beach club with its long dock and tanned bodies, do not show their age. The hallway, downstairs by the bar, is always good for an encounter with, say, Pedro Almodóvar on his way out to another morning press conference or on his way in after another movie party the night before. And with fashion showrooms set up on every floor and Chopard occupying the 10,000-square-foot penthouse suite, there is a constant flow of garment bags and bodyguards and jewelry up and down the stairs while publicists for actors and publicists for fashion houses and publicists for diamond and watch companies talk nonstop on their cellphones, probably to one another.

With Washington caught up in almost non-stop news on pending congressional legislation, the C.I.A. interrogation dispute and other events, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s tour in the Balkans has largely been relegated to the inside pages.
A victim of abuse by a Catholic priest in Ireland responds to the release of a 2,600-page report on "endemic" abuse in Catholic-run industrial schools and orphanages in the country.

A decade after "States of Fear," a six-part documentary series about the physical, sexual and emotional abuse of Irish children in reform schools, orphanages and hospitals run by the Catholic Church, was broadcast on Irish television, a commission of inquiry set up in response to the allegations published its report on Wednesday in Dublin. According to one of the thousands of victims of abuse during this period, Colm O'Gorman, who was raped by a priest as a teenager, the abuses detailed in the 2,600-page report are "horribly, horribly shocking."

The House gave final approval Wednesday afternoon to a set of new rules on credit card companies as Congress raced to send President Obama a trio of consumer-related measures before a Memorial Day recess, The New York Times's Carl Hulse reports from Washington.

Earlier this week a two-paragraph article on the Web site of the Israeli newspaper Haaretz, on how a book by Mark Twain might factor in the quest for Middle East peace, sparked a brush fire of commentary from bloggers and journalists. The fact that both the White House and the the prime minister's spokesman told The Lede on Wednesday that Mr. Netanyahu's gift to Mr. Obama was another book, a Bible, reminds us that blogging is a lot easier if you don't have to base your posts on confirmed reports.

Shopping in Cape Town once meant beaded barrettes and safari-themed tchotchkes. And while there's still plenty of those in town - like the adorable miniature jig-saw puzzle of an elephant I picked up at the African crafts emporium Tribal Trends (72-74 Long Street) - it's refreshing to witness the swell of designer boutiques, gourmet food shops and art galleries in this South African city. Among the most noteworthy arrivals is Lalesso, which sells bright screen-printed tunics and beach dresses designed by the fair-trade-minded owners Alice Heusser and Olivia Kennaway (no relation to the American label Alice + Olivia). The duo employs refugee nuns in Kenya to do the intricate crochet detailing on garments.

If you happen to find yourself in the Gateway City -- St. Louis -- before June 7, check out "2 Fists of Iron and a Bottle of Beer," the latest interactive installation by Steve Powers (formerly known as ESPO), which is currently on display at White Flag Projects gallery. For the show, the New York-based graffiti artist has merged the two places people flock to in tough times -- the church (the house of the holy spirit) and the bar (the house of many spirits). The altar is a juke box, and sinners are depicted as saints in spray-painted stained glass windows. There's also a drive-through wedding chapel and a custom auto-graphics shop. But the most provocative pieces are the posters, done in his signature style, announcing recession-era slogans like "We Buy Gold," "Get on Disability" and "Tent City."

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Now, oh, you know what NASA is up to? You remember the Hubble space telescope? They're repairing it. The NASA astronauts went up there and they're doing a lot of work. Having some trouble. Because it's difficult. Everything is more difficult in space. You know that, right? Yeah. And they're having trouble. And I said: "Well, no surprise to me that they're having trouble making these repairs. After all, these people aren't exactly rocket scientists."

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Joe Biden accidentally revealed the location of the Vice President's top secret bunker. The guy can't help it. But he did apologize. He said, "I am so sorry for the mistake. The launch code is 85334. It will never happen again. It will never happen again. My Gmail password is robot23. What am I doing? The house key is under the plant near the doorstep."

MUMBAI | It's summertime, but the living isn't easy in Mumbai, where temperatures are now touching 95 degrees. But the sweltering summer has one silver lining: mangoes. It's mango season, and every Mumbaikar is trading tips on where to buy the best fruit.  To see the widest variety of mangoes and comparison shop, visit the massive Crawford market. Be prepared to bargain hard and ask for samples. Hyper City mall (www.hypercityindia.com) also has a mango festival on, if you prefer to buy clearly labeled mangoes in air-conditioned comfort. Check other supermarkets for similar offers, or ask around your neighborhood for reliable vendors who deliver to your door. Beware of the vendors at traffic signals selling crates of what they claim are highly prized Alphonso mangoes at bargain prices. They usually aren't.

FINA, swimming’s governing body, rejected 10 high-tech racing suits and approved 202 others Tuesday for the world championships in July. FINA said its panel sent 136 models back to the manufacturers, who have 30 days to submit modified designs.

The Atlantic Coast Conference will send its ninth bowl pick to face the top selection from the Mid-American Conference in the GMAC Bowl next season. The agreement was reached after the A.C.C.’s contract expired with the Humanitarian Bowl in Boise, Idaho. The A.C.C. will take the place of Conference USA, which had sent a team to the GMAC Bowl in each of its 10 years. Jerry Silverstein, the GMAC Bowl president, said that if fewer than nine A.C.C. teams were bowl eligible, the game would pick a team from another conference for the Jan. 6 game in Mobile, Ala.

Rachel Alexandra’s victory over Mine that Bird on Saturday in the Preakness Stakes was seen by an average of 10.9 million viewers on NBC, the most since 11.6 million watched Smarty Jones win in 2004 and the second most for the second leg of the Triple Crown in 20 years. The viewership covers the period that the network calls “the race portion,” from 5:56 to 6:50 p.m. Eastern, although NBC’s Preakness programming began at 4:30.

Russian sports authorities said they would more than double bonus payments for medal winners at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver in a bid for a record-beating performance. Gennady Alyoshin, the deputy sports minister, said gold-medal winners would receive $135,000, silver winners would earn roughly $81,600 and bronze medalists $54,400. Russia, which will host the 2014 games in Sochi, is aiming for 40 medals at next year’s Games, with a minimum of nine golds. That would be almost double its 22-medal haul in Turin, Italy, in 2006.

The Well column on Tuesday, about the hospital visitation rights of unmarried couples, misspelled the surname of a woman who lay dying in a Miami hospital while her partner was fighting to be able to see her. She was Lisa Pond, not Ponds.

An article on Tuesday about the role of primary cilia in cell signaling misstated the affiliation of a researcher, Bradley Yoder. He is at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, not the University of Alabama.

A film column on Friday about the Cannes festival misidentified the rapper who sings “Life’s a bitch and then you die” in the song “Life’s a Bitch,” which is used in a film being shown at the festival, “Fish Tank.” While the song is from an album by Nas, and he is one of its composers, those words are sung by AZ, who also performs on the recording; they are not sung by Nas.

The Abroad column on Tuesday, about the reaction in Berlin to the first production of “The Producers” there and its “Springtime for Hitler” number, misspelled the surname of a German Jewish comedian who commented on the use of the Holocaust in comedy. He is Oliver Polak, not Polck.

An article on May 12 about the proposed creation of a South Village Historic District in Manhattan, and the changes that have been made to buildings in the area since the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission received the proposal in January 2007, referred imprecisely to changes Consolidated Edison has made to its power plant on 11th Avenue at 58th Street, an example of a building under consideration for landmark status that has been altered. While Con Ed has removed all six of the original smokestacks on the 1904 building, one built in 1967 remains.
Practicing a kind of catch-and-release astronomy, the astronauts of the space shuttle Atlantis oh-so-gently let the Hubble Space Telescope slip back into the heavens on Tuesday.

The Popular Demand listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday about audience ratings for playoff games misidentified the New Jersey Devils’ opponent from Colorado in the 2001 playoffs. It was the Avalanche — not the Rockies, the baseball team.

A federal appeals court ruled that the White House Office of Administration did not have to make public its records about an e-mail system that may have lost millions of messages from the Bush administration.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about the future of The New York Times Company, referred incorrectly to the company’s statements on expectations for the second quarter. Company officials have said that they believe the rate of decline in advertising revenue in the second quarter will generally be similar to that of the first; they have not said that second-quarter results will be similar to the $74.5 million loss in the first quarter.

An article in some editions on Saturday about a state appeals court’s dismissal of a lawsuit challenging the use of eminent domain to seize property for the Atlantic Yards development project in Brooklyn referred incorrectly to the decision. As an eminent domain case, it was heard first in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, so there was no lower-court ruling.

An article in some editions on Saturday about the release of documents showing that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has spent $18.7 million on his re-election campaign so far — nearly twice what he had spent at this point in the 2005 race — referred incompletely to his total campaign spending for his election in 2001. The amount, $81 million, is adjusted for inflation as of 2005.

An unauthorized biography of Tom Waits that mirrors its subject’s own junkyard aesthetic.

The playoffs are where “amazing happens,” or so the N.B.A. insists in the artsy ads that seemingly run during every commercial break. The truth is a little less than amazing.

The day after the Tony Awards, Bartlett Sher, who is nominated for his direction of “Joe Turner’s Come and Gone,” will dive into his next project: a musical version of the film “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown.”
Lynn Nottage’s Pulitzer Prize-winning drama, “Ruined,” was honored at the annual Village Voice Obie Awards on Monday.

DreamWorks has acquired the rights to the life story of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and plans to make a film about him, Variety reported. The film will be produced by Steven Spielberg, a founder of the DreamWorks studio, as well as Suzanne de Passe (a producer of “Lonesome Dove” and “The Jacksons: An American Dream”) and Madison Jones (the animated program “Our Friend, Martin”). Though other biographical films have been made about Dr. King (including the 1978 television mini-series “King,” which starred Paul Winfield and Cicely Tyson), DreamWorks said this was the first such project about him to be officially authorized by the King estate, which controls the rights to Dr. King’s intellectual property and is run by his son Dexter King. Casting for the film was not announced.

An autopsy of the pornographic-film star Marilyn Chambers revealed that she died from the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage and aneurysm related to heart disease, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Chambers, the actress and model who appeared on boxes of Ivory Snow laundry soap at the same time that she could be seen in the 1972 pornographic feature “Behind the Green Door,” was found dead in her home in Santa Clarita, Calif., in April. She was 56. At the time the Los Angeles County coroner’s office said that her death was being investigated but that foul play was not suspected. On Monday the office released its autopsy results, as well as toxicology tests that indicated the presence of two prescription drugs in Ms. Chambers’s system but not in excess amounts.
Christopher Hampton, whose play “The Philanthropist” and translation of “God of Carnage” are now on Broadway, will write the English-language adaptation of the book for the musical “Rebecca.”

The rapper Kanye West pleaded not guilty to charges stemming from an altercation with a photographer at Los Angeles International Airport in September, The Associated Press reported. He was arrested and charged with misdemeanor battery, grand theft and vandalism; his road manager, Dan Crawley, was also charged. A spokesman for the Los Angeles city attorney’s office told The A.P. that Mr. West’s plea was entered on Friday by his lawyer and that Mr. West was not present. The next hearing in the case is scheduled for July 15.
ABC and CBS battled to a draw in Monday night’s ratings.

The British police believe that they have solved the case of a Henry Moore sculpture that has been missing for four years, and now suspect that it was sold for scrap, The Guardian reported. In 2005 the two-ton bronze sculpture, “Reclining Figure,” was stolen from Moore’s estate in Hertfordshire, 30 miles north of London, and a flatbed truck and crane believed to have been used in the crime were quickly recovered. After more than three years of investigation, Jon Humphries, the detective chief inspector of the Hertfordshire police, said that evidence suggested that the work was “cut up” on the night of the crime, “then taken to a location where it was irreparably damaged before it was shipped abroad.” He added, “In my mind we’ve managed to kill off the mystery as much as is possible.” The sculpture, valued at about $4.6 million, would have yielded about $2,300 in scrap metal, Detective Humphries said.
Minutes into “American Hwangap,” Lloyd Suh’s likable new play about a Korean-American family, the author’s affection for his characters is clear.
As Keith McNally revamped a Greenwich Village relic, did anyone expect that he would come up with the best steakhouse in the city? That’s what Minetta Tavern turns out to be.
“Blueprint America: Road to the Future,” to be seen Wednesday on PBS stations, provides snapshots of the contrasting state of transportation in three American cities.
George Crumb’s “Vox Balaenae” was the centerpiece of an ambitious multimedia event, “The Voice of the Whale Project,” at the American Museum of Natural History on Sunday.

The president is expected to get the measure before the Memorial Day recess after differences in the House and Senate versions are resolved.

Sales of heart devices remained flat, and a stronger dollar cut into the value of overseas earnings.

This chocolate pudding, made with silken tofu, has a texture that is almost unbelievably good — and no one would have an inkling that it is dairy free.

If Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, declares that the Republican Party has turned a corner, does that make it so? Mr. Steele made that declaration on Tuesday in a buck-up, cheer-up speech at National Harbor, along the Potomac in Maryland, to committee members who have been dismayed by polls showing public support for their party dropping.

GINGER ALE is an age-old remedy for sick children and grown-ups alike. Now, homemade ginger ale is appearing on drink menus across the country under happier circumstances. In Atlanta, it is a mixer for cocktails at Drinkshop, the newly opened bar in the W Hotel Downtown developed in collaboration with Sasha Petraske, the New York-based drinks master.

LINHART--Magda, passed away May 18, 2009 at age 93. Born January 10, 1916 in Uzhorod, Czechoslovakia to Samuel and Ethel (Reichman) Markovic. Survived by cherished children Jan (Ellen) Linhart of Purchase, NY and Catrina Linhart Schmicker (Robert) of Rye, NY and adoring grandchildren Gregory, Nancy, Tommy, Zachary, and Alexander. One of the students at the Vaganova Ballet Academy in St. Petersburg, Russia, in a dress rehearsal. WOLPE--Rabbi Gerald I. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the death of our esteemed colleague, Rabbi Gerald Wolpe. Known for his compassionate leadership of Philadelphia's Har Zion Temple, and for his many contributions to bioethics, caregiving, and medical education, Rabbi Wolpe served from 1997 to 2002 as director of the Louis Finkelstein Institute for Religion and Social Studies of JTS, during which time the institute became involved with issues of biomedical ethics, and as a member of the Chancellor's Council. Ordained at JTS in 1953, he later earned a master's and a doctor of divinity degree at JTS as well. May his wife, Elaine; sons David, Steve, Daniel, and Paul; and his eight grandchildren be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

CHERNOW--Ruth, 83. Adored mother of Bart and Ron, daughter of Bertha, sister of Linda, grandmother of Shandee. Ruth was a magnificent woman of rare beauty, wisdom, warmth, and compassion. She radiated emotional intelligence long before the term was invented and taught us the invincible power of pure goodness. Her generous spirit, innate kindness, and unerring insight enriched an entire family. And she gave her two sons the finest gift that children can receive-an almost magical faith in their future.

ARMOUR--T. Stanton, died at his home in Lake Forest, IL on May 18, 2009 of a long illness. He was 85. After graduating from St. Mark's School in 1942 he served for 3 years in the Navy during WWII and graduated from Yale University in 1949. He had a long career in the investment business. Serving as President and chairman of Mitchell Hutchins and Co. and as a Director of Paine Weber and UBS. A lifelong and enthusiastic sportsman, Mr. Armour was President of the Ruffed Grouse Society and also a Trustee of Shedd Aquarium in Chicago. He was Chairman of the Salvation Army Chicago Advisory Board. A life trustee of Northwestern Memorial Hospital and Chairman of the Northwestern Memorial Foundation. He was also a member of the Prints and Drawings committee of the Chicago Art Institute. He is survived by his loving wife of 61 years, Jean Reddy Armour, two children Tony (Robin) Armour and Audrey Ayars, four grandchildren, brother Vernon Armour and sisters Elizabeth Hollins and Leola Macdonald. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Chicago Chapter of the Salvation Army, 5040 N. Pulaski, Chicago, IL 60630. A memorial mass was held at the Church of St. Mary, Lake Forest. Info. Wenban Funeral Home, Lake Forest (847) 234-0022 or www.wenbanfh.com

As the Pakistani Army squeezed the main city in Swat on Tuesday, fleeing residents described roads mined by the Taliban, indiscriminate firing by the military, and a small group of besieged government officials hanging on with dwindling food and fuel. The city, Mingora, has been emptied of many of its 200,000 people, but a sizable population remains hemmed in there and has lived without electricity or much water for more than a week, the fleeing residents said. The people who remain are now in danger of being caught up in the looming fight for the city.

UMANSKY--Dorothy, of Stamford, CT.,formerly of New Rochelle, NY. Beloved mother of Myrna Levy, Ellen Umansky and Amy Umansky Kahn. Cherished grandmother of Marc and Matthew Levy, Adam and Ethan Kahn, and Abraham, Ezra and Seth Kannof. Mother-in-law of Warren Kahn and Alan Kannof. Devoted sister of Seymour Colen and Diana Laub. Service Wednesday, May 20, 11:30am, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains. Contributions may be made in her memory to Stamford Hospital Foundation, 1351 Washington Blvd., Stamford, CT 06902. Strong, loving, and caring, she will be greatly missed.

STEEL--Kuniko Nakamura, (Born June 3, 1929) died on Wednesday, May 13th, after a distinguished and award winning career as an artist. She studied with several important artists while living in Paris and later New York. After growing up in Tokyo as a child, Mrs. Steel attended the University of California at Berkeley, and then studied art in Chicago, Paris, and New York, won numerous prizes in juried art shows throughout the United States for her paintings, and once participated in an exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. She was a member of the Art Students League in New York, was a dedicated volunteer as a restorer at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum in New York, and also volunteered at New York Hospital. After living in New York for many years, and leading a very active life, she moved to California in 1995. She was the widow of the late John Steel, originally from Munich, Germany, and more recently from New York. He was a member of the Lowenbrau beer family. She is survived by her brother-in-law and nephews, Howard, Eric and Scott Takaoka, her sister and brother-in-law, Tom and Eunice Yoshio Yanari, and her nephew and nieces Carl, Doris and Yoko Yanari, and great-nephews Brandon and Brian Yanari, all of Palo Alto, California. She is also survived by her stepdaughter Danielle Steel, of Paris and San Francisco, and grandchildren Beatrix Seidenberg, Trevor, Todd, Samantha, Victoria, Vanessa, Maximillian and Zara Traina, and great- grandchildren Sebastian and Isabel Seidenberg, and Daisy, John, and Delphina Traina, of New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco. Kuniko was greatly loved by all who knew her and will be much missed. Funeral Services were held in California on May 19th. Interment in New York.

PAIN FOR THE CREDITWORTHY Credit card companies, about to be barred from profitable tactics that penalize people who fail to pay on time, are setting their sights on those who pay in full each month. RETURNING THE BAILOUTS Now that big banks seem to have stabilized, regulators are trying to determine how and when they should be allowed to return their bailout money -- and whether such a step might leave them vulnerable to another crisis. [B1.]

An Indonesian military cargo plane crashed into a village in East Java on Wednesday, killing at least 78 people, the air force said. Television images from the scene showed the aircraft consumed in smoke and flames even as rescue workers tried to reach others still inside. Bambang Soelistyo, an air force spokesman, told Reuters that 11 crew members and 99 passengers had been on board, including air force personnel and civilian family members.

SINDOS--Henry, was an invaluable member of the Board of the Metropolitan Center for Mental Health on which he served. He was devoted to its mission from its earliest days in the late 1960s when it was a small pioneering mental health clinic providing dynamically oriented psychotherapy on the upper Westside, as well as being involved in the development of the Metropolitan Institute for Training in Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy. As a person, he was enormously intelligent and insightful, had a great sense of humor, and was in all respects a delight to know. His death leaves a hole in the world. Louise Horowitz, President MCMH

SINDOS--Henry. The Metropolitan Center for Mental Health and The Metropolitan Institute for Training in Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy mourn the death of Henry Sindos. For over 30 years, Henry was a board member of both from their inception. He had served as President of the MCMH board, and had been active with the Institute as a Supervisor. His depth of knowledge and sound judgement, as well as his sense of humor, will be sorely missed.

BENJAMIN--Barbara J. (nee Bloch), 83, peacefully at home in Sleepy Hollow, NY on May 18, 2009. Devoted widow of Ted Benjamin of White Plains. Mother of Elizabeth Sanders of Somerville, MA and Ellen Benjamin of Chicago. Stepmother of Phyllis Benjamin of Cambridge, MA and Jill Benjamin of Ocala, FL. Proud grandmother of James Hines; Paul, Matthew, and Orpheus Bates; and Sam and Julia Shia. Doting great-grandmother of Amelia Bates. McNAMARA--Brooks, died on May 8, in Doylestown, PA. He was 72. Mr. McNamara held a bachelor's degree from Knox College, a master's degree from the University of Iowa, and a Ph.D. in theater history from Tulane University. Mr. McNamara was a professor emeritus in the Department of Performance Studies, Tisch School of the Arts, New York University, and founding director of the archives of the Shubert Organization. He held a Fulbright Senior Research Fellowship and a Guggenheim Fellowship. His was a Fellow of the American Theater, and served on the boards of the Theater Library Association, the American Society for Theater Reseach, and the Doylestwon Historical Society. A scholar of American theater history and popular entertainment, he was author or editor of more than a dozen books, including Step Right Up: The American Meidicne Show; The New York Concert Saloon; The Devil's Own Nights; and The Merry Muldoons and the Brighteyes Affair, for children. He is survived by wife, Nan, his daughter and son-in-law Jane McNamara and John Oddy, his son and daughter-in-law Whitney and Mona McNamara and his grandchildren, James Brooks Oddy, Gwendolyn Claire McNamara, George Jansen Oddy and Thomas Carlin McNamara. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law Scott McNamara and Carol Wittels, his sister-in-law Sally Kuder and his mother-in-law Nan Jansen. Services will be held on Saturday May 30 at 3pm in Saint Paul's Lutheran Church, North Main and Spruce Streets, Doylestown, PA.

Practicing a kind of catch-and-release astronomy, the astronauts of the space shuttleAtlantis oh-so-gently let the Hubble Space Telescope slip back into the heavens on Tuesday. Reporting to mission control in Houston at about 9 a.m. as the telescope and shuttle slowly drifted apart, Scott Altman, the Atlantis commander, called the last mission to refurbish the fabled telescope ''an incredible journey'' that demonstrated how humans could overcome challenges by working together.

At a remembrance ceremony held on Tuesday, a New York City officer etched a name from the State of New York Police Officers Memorial in Albany. The names of more than 1,260 officers who were killed in the line of duty are engraved on the memorial.

The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to put new restrictions on the credit card industry, passing a bill whose backers say will make card-issuers spell out their terms in fewer words, using plain English, and treat customers more fairly. The 90-to-5 vote, following a 357-to-70 vote in the House on April 30, made it likely that President Obama will have a measure on his desk before the Memorial Day recess. The differences between the House and Senate versions will have to be worked out, but given the political atmosphere it seems likely that the House-Senate negotiations will move quickly.

BURDETTE--Brooks R. Brooks was one of the finest and kindest of persons: a great friend and law partner, wise counsellor, and a brilliant lawyer. He worked strenuously to overcome serious childhood illnesses, never asked for or accepted favors because of his physical limitations, and wildly succeeded in the toughest environment any trial lawyer could compete in. Brooksy, we will miss the lunches, dinners, and discussions, but mostly miss knowing you were always there to help lend a hand. Good-bye, our friend: you're the best. David M. Brodsky Daniel J. Kramer

One of the more historic advances in baseball's most historical period is ready for the historians to analyze, if you can forgive the histrionics. The wizards at Retrosheet, the volunteer organization that for more than 20 years has compiled, proofed and distributed box scores and play-by-play logs for every season dating to 1953, just released box scores for every major league game in the 1920s -- the decade of Ruth, Hornsby and (read on) Cliff Lee. This information has never before been publicly available, especially on a trustworthy, easy-to-peruse Web site.

NAMAD--Dr. Ruth(Holzberg). Professor and linguist, died peacefully on May 17, 2009 following a long illness. She is mourned by her daughter Tanya, her brother Irving Holzberg, her husband Frank, nieces Rachel Hulst and Emily Holzberg. An inspiration to everyone and loved by all. Service Tuesday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

When Amazon first introduced its Kindle e-book device over a year ago, it waived its 10-cent fee for letting you e-mail your own text and PDF documents to Amazon so that they could be wirelessly sent to the Kindle. Blame it on the economy, or on the fact that more people are taking advantage of the service, but that perk came to an end on May 4 -- and what's more, the fee has increased to 15 cents a megabyte, rounded up, the equivalent of sending a text message. Fortunately, Amazon's service is optional. You can avoid the fee altogether if you convert your documents yourself and upload them to your Kindle via the oft-neglected U.S.B. cable that came with the device.

The Federal Election Commission has decided that $150,000 or more in clothing bought by the Republican Party for Sarah Palin and her family around the time of her vice-presidential nomination did not violate campaign finance regulations. Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington had filed a complaint against the Republican National Committee, its treasurer and Ms. Palin, governor of Alaska.

FOR many people tofu has become a staple in their diets, and rightly so. Though it is made from soy milk in roughly the same way cheese is made from mammal milk (a curdling agent is added, and it's drained of excess water), tofu doesn't take nearly as many forms as cheese. But neither is it solely the stuff of stir-fries. For example, I can almost guarantee you will be impressed by this dessert, a pudding that takes about as much time to make as hot chocolate. But there are a few qualifiers. Without chocolate, the flavor is unimpressive; it tastes like sweetened tofu. Add chocolate and a few Mexican spices, however, and you have a real winner. And certainly no one I've fed it to had any inkling that it was dairy free.

It began modestly enough back in 2005, when an American freelance writer and journalism teacher living in London, Heather Brooke, entered a request under Britain's newly promulgated freedom of information act for details of the expense claims of British members of Parliament. Ms. Brooke's initiative to expose the politicians' greed, now led by one of the country's principal newspapers, The Daily Telegraph, has led to the biggest scandal to hit the House of Commons in decades. On Tuesday, the affair claimed its biggest victim yet when the speaker of the House of Commons, Michael Martin, became the first man to be ousted from that job in more than 300 years.

The FM Brush Company of Glendale, Queens, makes about 17,000 styles of brush, all by hand, and distributes them globally. These are meant for use with cosmetics. Frederick Mink Sr. established the operation in 1929, and it is still run by the Mink family. It now has about 150 employees in Queens and at a second plant in Thailand, which it opened in 1987. ''New York offers a highly skilled labor force and is conducive to the cutting-edge couture products that we produce, resulting in the shipping of over half a million brushes a month,'' said Victoria Towey, the director of marketing. LEFFERTS--Cynthia, of New York and St. Huberts, NY, died peacefully in her Manhattan home on May 8. She was 80. Cynthia had been ill for some years with primary progressive aphasia. She was valiant to the end. Cynthia leaves many loving friends and family members, including two nieces and two nephews: Susan Lefferts of Salem, OR; Sarah Lefferts of Portland, ME; Thomas Lefferts of South China, ME; and Nicholas Lefferts of Denver, CO. Independent in mind and spirit, Cynthia had a keen interest in politics and in the life of the nation. Her working life was marked by high ideals. She began her career in 1951 as an administrative assistant at the Ford Foundation; she went on to serve as executive secretary of the New York State Commission on Government Operations of the City of New York and later of the New York State Moreland Commission on Welfare. She was a special assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller from 1963 to 1966, and then worked devotedly for Common Cause, serving in the 1970's as executive director of the organization's New York office. Cynthia was born in Santa Barbara, CA, in 1928, while her parents, Halleck Lefferts and Sarah Barney Lefferts, were on the faculty of the Thacher School in nearby Ojai. Her brothers Barney and Charlie died before her, in 1976 and 1996. Cynthia was educated at Concord Academy and the Winsor School, and graduated from Vassar College in 1951. From an early age, Cynthia loved the mountains, lakes, and streams of the Adirondacks, where she had a second home. When the effects of polio kept her off the highest peaks, she continued to walk, hike, and swim with vigor, and she took up tennis with a gracious tenacity. She was a longtime member of the Ausable Club in St. Huberts and a trustee of the related Adirondack Mountain Reserve. In 2007 Cynthia was given the Harold Weston Award for "personal dedication to the unique spirit and qualities" of the AMR. She also served on the board of managers of the Havens Relief Fund Society in New York. She was especially proud to be a trustee of the Pomfret School in Pomfret, CT, where her father had been headmaster. Cynthia's grace and courage were inspiration and example to her friends and family. She had steel in her sinews, but she was never hard. She was kind and fair-minded, and naturally elegant. A memorial service will be held this summer in Keene Valley, NY, in the Adirondacks.

LITTLEFORD--William D. (known to his family and friends as Bill), former Chairman of Billboard Publications, Inc. (now part of Nielsen Business Media), died peacefully at his home in Princeton, NJ on Thursday, May 14th. He was 94 years old. Born in Ft. Thomas, Kentucky on August 4, 1914, he graduated from Highlands High School and attended The University of Cincinnati before joining Billboard Magazine in 1934 as a "printer's devil." Billboard, an entertainment publication founded by his grandfather William H. Donaldson in 1894, remained a family concern for over 90 years. Bill, who spent his entire publishing career at BPI, became general manager in 1946. He was elected as President in 1958, chairman 1976, and become chairman emeritus in 1985. Under his leadership, Billboard grew from a single publication with a small printing plant in Cincinnati, Ohio to a diversified communication organization headquartered in New York City. Bill served as chairman of American Business Media from 1960-1961 and in 1997 established the William D. Littleford Awards for Corporate Community Service that recognizes companies, organizations, and individuals who are actively involved in community service programs designed to alleviate social problems. Similarly, his work with the Advertising Counsel where he remained as an Honorary Director, was widely recognized. Along the way, he completed the Executive Education Program at Harvard Business School. After the death of his first wife (Mariana Weber) in 1957, Bill married Marian Hastings Towne. Together they were instrumental in the founding of the Vieques Conservation and Historical Trust on Vieques Island, Puerto Rico. They also founded the William & Marian Littleford Foundation which provides charitable support to deserving causes and the Marian & William Littleford Fund which supports college scholarships for students at Roslyn High School on Long Island. Marian preceded Bill in death in March of 2008. He is survived by his sister; Marjorie Littleford Ross, his children; Anne, Joseph, Michael, and Terry and three grandchildren, Ryan, Ariel, and William. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 28th at Calvary Church (277 Park Avenue South at 21st Street) at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Bill's memory to the Vieques Conservation & Historical Trust, Calle Flamboyan 138, Vieques, PR 00765.

The Sri Lankan president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, on Tuesday savored a victory that had eluded every Sri Lankan head of state before him: he declared on television that after more than 25 years, his troops had defeated one of the world's most enduring guerrilla armies on the battlefield. Behind that victory speech was a historic and bloody family triumph, guided by two of the president's brothers: Gotabaya, the influential secretary of defense, and Basil, a so-called special adviser who devised the political strategy around the war effort.

The city will begin converting part of Broadway into a major pedestrian thoroughfare this weekend, as stretches in Times Square and Herald Square are closed to vehicles. Part of Mayor Michael R. LIEBESMAN--Beatrice, November 18, 1918 - May 6, 2009. Beloved mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, and great-grandmother of five, Beatrice was a devoted wife for 66 years of her husband Raymond, an accountant who, in later life, was a gifted sculptor and her partner in world travels. Beatrice had an enduring fascination with the world and the people she met. A consummate Scrabble player, storyteller and poet, she was a confidante and mentor to countless people. Beatrice was a self-taught antiquarian and ran the Bee-Hive Antiques shop before becoming an award-winning teacher of disadvanteged sixth graders in the South Bronx. Following her retirement, she became a volunteer with the Spence-Chapen Thrift Shop, and later with the Arizona Cancer Center in Tucson. Beatrice was preceded in death by her sister Johanna Grimes, founder of the Old Hickory rare medical bookshop in Brinklow, Maryland. A gathering of family and close friends will be held Sunday, May 24th in Tucson.

COHEN--Fern W.,died at age 74 on May 17, 2009, in the company of her family at home. Fern loved and in turn was deeply loved by her husband Dan, daughter Elizabeth Giamatti, sons Seth and Josh Cohen, son-in-law Paul Giamatti, daughters-in-law Elizabeth Uchitelle and Ruth Metzger, and her grandchildren Jake, Sam, Lucas and Olivia. Daughter of the late Judge Edward Weinfeld and Lillian Weinfeld, sister of the late Ann Schulman, Fern was a lifelong resident of New York City, a psychoanalyst and psychotherapist, author of the memoir, "From Both Sides of the Couch", a passionate tennis player, and a wry, honest and unafraid observer of the world around her. Services will be held on Wednesday, May 20th at 11:45am at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Doctors Without Borders.

Now on Hulu: rock concerts. On June 1, the popular television Web site will offer its first live concert with a Dave Matthews Band show at the Beacon Theater in New York, the band announced. The Hulu showing will be in addition to the deal announced last week by Fuse, the cable music channel, to broadcast the Beacon show, followed by a week of Dave Matthews programming. Hulu (which is a joint venture of NBC and the News Corporation, with the Walt Disney Company added recently as an equity shareholder) will also show a Dave Matthews Band documentary and music videos music beginning May 28, and the Beacon show will remain available for streaming after it’s over. The Hulu stream, which will begin at 9 p.m. Eastern time, is part of the promotion for the band’s new album, “Big Whiskey and the GrooGrux King” which will be released by RCA on June 2.

As recent history has shown, the author and graphic novelist Alan Moore is very careful about what works he lets his name appear upon. (You won’t find it, for example, on the film adaptations of his comics “Watchmen” or “V for Vendetta.”) But one unexpected place that Mr. Moore’s name will soon turn up is alongside the rock musicians Andrew Broder (of the band Fog), Mike Patton (of Faith No More) and Justin Broadrick (of Godflesh) on an audiobook and soundtrack, Billboard reported. The performers are providing soundtrack elements for a recording of a semi-autobiographical multimedia work by Mr. Moore, to be published in 2010 and tentatively titled “Unearthing.” The British independent label Lex Records said that it would be releasing the deluxe version of “Unearthing,” which will include a photographic novel, art prints, a two-hour audiobook and a musical soundtrack on vinyl.

The Salzburg Festival in Austria announced that it had chosen Alexander Pereira, the director of the Zurich Opera House, as its next artistic director. In a news release, the festival said that the decision was made at a Tuesday meeting of its advisory board, and that Mr. Pereira would officially begin his five-year term in October 2011. He will succeed Jürgen Flimm, who in 2010 will take over as artistic director of Deutsche Staatsoper Unter den Linden in Berlin. Mr. Flimm announced last year that he would not continue at the Salzburg Festival, where since 2006 he has served as its artistic director and had clashed with Thomas Oberender, the festival’s drama director. Agence France-Presse reported that other candidates to succeed Mr. Flimm included Pierre Audi of De Nederlandse Opera in Amsterdam and Stephane Lissner of La Scala in Milan. This year’s Salzburg Festival runs from July 25 through Aug. 30.

An analysis of ticket sales for two Bruce Springsteen concerts at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., this week suggests that you may have a better chance of becoming a member of Mr. Springsteen’s E Street Band than buying tickets to one of his shows. The Star-Ledger of Newark, in an analysis of documents provided by Ticketmaster to the New Jersey attorney general’s office found that of the 38,778 seats made available for two shows, on Thursday and Saturday, only 6,000 individuals were able to buy tickets for one or more of these seats. The Star-Ledger said that 10,494 tickets had been set aside for the performers, their record label and booking agent, the show’s sponsors and others. Internet customers had an advantage as 75 percent of the tickets were sold online, but the traffic to Ticketmaster.com overwhelmed the Web site. The action by the attorney general was initiated when more than 2,000 fans complained that when they tried to buy tickets online, they were instead directed to TicketsNow.Com, a resale site owned by Ticketmaster, where the prices were higher.

Whether you were surprised or satisfied with the results of the eighth-season finale of Fox’s “American Idol,” in which Kris Allen was crowned winner over Adam Lambert, the show’s ratings offered their own surprises, not all of them pleasant. According to Nielsen estimates released by Fox, the two-hour finale drew 28.8 million viewers, easily the largest audience for the night. But that number is down more than 3 million from last year’s finale (which drew 31.7 million), and the finale is likely to rank as the second-lowest-rated season finale of “American Idol” in the show’s history, topping only the first season, when 23 million viewers watched Kelly Clarkson defeat Justin Guarini in September 2002. “Idol” also won a fifth consecutive year as the No. 1 show among viewers age 18 to 49, but Wednesday’s broadcast was the lowest-rated finale among that demographic.

The second pair of classic plays produced jointly by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, London’s Old Vic Theater, and the director Sam Mendes’s Neal Street Productions— a collaborative effort known as the Bridge Project — will be Chekov’s “Three Sisters” and Shakespeare’s “As You Like It,” a spokeswoman for the academy said on Thursday. Mr. Mendes will direct both plays, which will run in repertory at the academy starting in January 2010, said the spokeswoman, Sandy Sawotka. Mr. Mendes directed the first pair of plays by the Bridge Project earlier this year, “The Cherry Orchard” and “The Winter’s Tale.” No casting decisions are ready to be announced, Ms. Sawotka said.

A new documentary from Michael Moore, the director of “Bowling for Columbine” and “Fahrenheit 9/11,” will be released on Oct. 2. The studios Overture Films and Paramount Vantage announced Thursday that they would handle the United States release of the film, an as-yet untitled movie about the global economic downturn. In a statement, the studios said that the documentary would “take a comical look at the corporate and political shenanigans” that resulted in the worldwide recession. The film was announced at the 2008 Cannes Film Festival, and follows Mr. Moore’s 2007 documentary, “Sicko,” about the American health care system.

CANNES - This town is catching up with me, and to be honest I am not so sure how much longer I will last before surrendering to the call of the beach. Today was Tarantino day, with much anxiety and anticipation in the air, as much for the premiere of "Inglourious Basterds" as for the arrival of Brad and Angelina, who were scheduled to walk up the stairs of the Palais at 6:50 p.m. local time. The action has really picked up these last 12 hours; the halls of the Martinez are now closed to the public and guests are required to carry a special I.D. in order to get through all of the newly installed security checkpoints.Without a movie commitment for the afternoon, I take a deep breath and dive not into the hotel pool but rather into underworld of the festival. By underworld I don't mean the business of buying and selling and distributing films, or even the hangers-on who keep the various V.I.P.'s stocked with call-girls, rent-boys or other addictive substances of choice. No, here I'm talking about the fashion product placement industry -- the business of putting gowns, tuxedos, earrings and necklaces on the backs, ears and necks of celebrities, not to mention the screens of your television and the pages of your newspapers and magazines.

On Thursday in London, the British government announced a change in policy that will allow Nepalese Gurkhas, who have been recruited to serve in the British Army for almost 200 years, to settle in Britain after they retire. On Wednesday, that group and representatives of General Electric, Microsoft and Sunrise Solar gathered in Washington to launch the Innovation, Development & Employment Alliance, or I.D.E.A. The initiative is aimed at pressing Congress and the Obama administration to ensure that global climate-treaty talks don't weaken protections on who can profit from new technologies that provide abundant energy without abundant pollution. In a town that celebrates reinvention, the show "Nine Lives" (through May 31st) at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, seems more than appropriate. The nine artists featured in this exhibition all live and work in the greater Los Angeles area, and all of them have a real talent for telling out-there stories and creating alternate universes. But that's where the similarities end in this idiosyncratic, quasi group show. Since the sixties, the painter Llyn Foulkes has been pointing out the hypocrisies of pop culture and Hollywood, the global industrial complex that runs this city. In "Deliverance," above, Foulkes depicts himself shooting Mickey Mouse, a dangerous figure, which he believes has been brainwashing children for years. The artist Charles Irvin has his own ideas about conspiracies. Working in the vein of R. Crumb, Irvin fills his drawings and paintings with weird-looking aliens and creepy people and plenty of irreverent slogans. He rounds out his installation with a faux documentary about the False Memory Syndrome Foundation, a support group for individuals who claim to have been wrongly accused of child molestation.

The Danish director Lars von Trier will make cuts to his new film, “Antichrist,” so it will be more commercially palatable in the United States and other countries, Agence France-Presse reported. The film, which was screened on Monday at the Cannes Film Festival, stars Willem Dafoe and Charlotte Gainsbourg as a couple trying to come to terms with the death of their son, and features a graphic scene of sexual mutilation. On Wednesday IFC Films said it had acquired North American distribution rights to “Antichrist” and planned to show the version screened at Cannes.

Green Day opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart this week with “21st Century Breakdown” (Reprise), the band’s first album in nearly five years. Despite heavy promotion, the album sold a relatively modest 215,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, but because it was released last Friday, it registered only three days of sales for the week that ended on Sunday. (Albums are usually released on Tuesday.) Also this week, the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney) holds at No. 2 with 68,000; Cam’ron’s new “Crime Pays” (Asylum) is No. 3 with 43,000; Lady Gaga continues her run in the Top 10 with “The Fame” (Interscope), which rose two spots to No. 4 with 41,000 sales; Rascal Flatts’s “Unstoppable” (Lyric Street) is in fifth place with 33,000.

The first of Michael Jackson’s “This Is It” concerts at London’s O2 Arena has been rescheduled along with several other shows, BBC News reported. The opening night of the six-month run (with a break from October through December), originally scheduled for July 8, has been postponed until July 12, while other shows planned for that month have been rescheduled for March to allow more time for rehearsal. In an e-mail message the promoter of the concerts, AEG Live, told the BBC, “We wanted to ensure that all of Michael’s fans attending the concerts get the same quality in staging and level of entertainment.”.

The shanty home of another child star of the movie “Slumdog Millionaire” has been demolished by the authorities in Mumbai, The Associated Press reported. On Wednesday the home of Rubina Ali Qureshi, who played the young version of the movie’s heroine, Latika, was torn down by demolition crews that clear away shanties before India’s monsoon season. Last week municipal workers destroyed the home of Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, who played the character Salim as a child. The government of Maharashtra State previously promised to provide housing to both actors.

Two children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have threatened legal action against a planned film about their father, saying that the project did not have their approval, The Associated Press reported. On Tuesday DreamWorks announced that it had acquired the rights to Dr. King’s life story from the King estate, which is led by his son Dexter, for a film to be produced by Steven Spielberg. But two other King children, Bernice King and Martin Luther King III, told The A.P. they had not been consulted on the deal.

A poem initially offered for auction by Christie’s as an early work by Bob Dylan has turned out to be a modified version of a song by Hank Snow. The Associated Press reported that Christie’s planned to sell a poem called “Little Buddy,” handwritten by Mr. Dylan in 1957 for a summer camp newspaper. Lisa Heilicher, a former editor of The Herzl Herald at Herzl Camp in Webster, Wis., told The A.P. that she had kept the poem for years. The poem, which tells the story of a dog that is killed by a drunkard, turned out to be virtually identical to a song by Snow, also called “Little Buddy,” which he wrote and recorded in the 1950s. Reuters reported that Christie’s now acknowledges that the poem is a modified version of that song and will still offer it for sale. In a statement, the auction house said, “This still remains among the earliest known handwritten lyrics of Bob Dylan, and Christie’s is pleased to offer them in our Pop Culture auction on June 23.”.
