This week I am going all '90s on App of the Week and recommending a browser. My hands-down favorite mobile browser is Skyfire, a browser that is still in beta test phase, but works on Windows and Symbian phones.

Garmin's $500 Oregon 550 is a hand-held GPS navigator that can snap photos with its onboard 3.2 megapixel camera and, naturally, geotag them. Given the new GPS enhancements to iPhoto and a broadening interest in geotagging, it's worth a look. The Oregon 550 is a waterproof hand-held device that's perfect for outdoorsy types. Its camera offers a 4X digital zoom and 850 megabytes of internal memory; it also includes a microSD slot for additional photo storage. Every photo is automatically geotagged with the precise location where it was taken.

BINDHARDT--Margaret "Margo" Humphrey. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the passing of Margo Bindhardt, a Member of the Metropolitan Opera Association since 1986, and a longtime member and former Great Lakes Regional Chairman of the Metropolitan Opera National Council. Margo's generosity, warmth, delightful good humor, and dedication to opera and the arts will long be remembered by all who knew her. We extend our sincere condolences to her mother, Honorary Director Louise Ireland Humphrey; to her aunt and fellow Member of the Association, Kate Ireland; to her husband, Klaus Bindhardt; and to everyone in her family and wide circle of friends. Christine F. Hunter, Chairman of the Board William C. Morris, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager

CHERNOW--Ruth, 83. Adored mother of Bart and Ron, daughter of Bertha, sister of Linda, grandmother of Shandee. Ruth was a magnificent woman of rare beauty, wisdom, warmth, and compassion. She radiated emotional intelligence long before the term was invented and taught us the invincible power of pure goodness. Her generous spirit, innate kindness, and unerring insight enriched an entire family. And she gave her two sons the finest gift that children can receive-an almost magical faith in their future.

BULHACK--Sadie (Syd), passed away May 19th. She would have been 100 years old on May 28th. A woman way ahead of her time, having graduated from NYU with a Bachelors in Education, a Master's Degree and her Ph.D. equivalent. Syd was an accounting teacher at George Washington High School in Manhattan. Upon retirement in 1974, she and her beloved husband Morris relocated to Hallandale, FL. Widow of Morris, survived by her children; Michael, Neil (Phyllis), Kenneth (Vicky) and daughter Phyllis Wagner. She was surrounded by her loving grandchildren; David, Beth, Lisa, Kenneth Jr., Bernard, Andrea and Joshua, and her greatgrandchildren; Joshua, Michael, Ryan and Matthew, and for many years was privileged to be cared for by Molreen Nathaniel. Predeceased by her parents Philip and Lena Sherman. Brothers; Joseph Sherman, Morris Sherman. Sisters; Mona Feller and May Garvin. Graveside services held Friday, May 22nd, 11am at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY.

WALKER--Howard, died peacefully on May 16, 2009, in Connecticut, following a brief battle with lung cancer. He was 72. Howard was born in Brooklyn, NY, the son of the late Harry and Betty Walker. Howard was president of Crown Foundations Inc., an intimate apparel company headquartered in Bridgeport that manufactured top-of-the-line shapewear for the mature figure. He worked there for 50 years, serving as President and Owner since 1981. Recognizing that girdle shops were becoming extinct, Howard helped Crown Foundation transition to selling to almost every national cataloger in the United States. The company continues to thrive today. Howard is survived by his loving and adoring wife, Sandra, his two adoring sons and daughters-in-law, Jonathan and Bridget of Fairfield, and Samuel and Stacey of Weston, CT, as well as three grandchildren, Zander, Ellery and Cobie. Everyone who met Howard recognized him as a unique individual. He was a true mensche, a loyal and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. He will truly be missed and never forgotten.

KEARNS--George W.,78, of Manhasset, NY and Norfolk, VA, retired Merrill Lynch Vice President, died on May 15, 2009. He is survived by his beloved wife, Trudy, devoted children, Michael and Rosemary, and son-in-law Peter Zemanian. His grandchildren, Steven, Carolyn, and Laura were the joy of his life. Services were private.

The Republican National Committee backed away on Wednesday from a resolution that officially called Democrats the ''Democrat Socialist Party,'' but instead voted to condemn Democrats for what it called a ''march toward socialism.'' The voice vote in Washington came after a special meeting that underlined fractures among Republicans on how to deal with President Obama and the Democratic Party. The original resolution was backed by some of the party's more conservative members but was opposed by the chairman, Michael Steele, and other leaders. The opponents said the proposal made the Republican Party appear trite and overly partisan, and would prove politically embarrassing.

BEARN--Alexander G.,M.D. Weill Cornell Medical College, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and the Department of Medicine at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend Dr. Alexander G. Bearn. Chairman emeritus of the Department of Medicine at Weill Cornell Medical College and former physician-in-chief at NewYork -Presbyterian/Weill Cornell, Dr. Bearn was an influential leader who forged institutional bonds and furthered medical science. A respected authority on the genetics of rare metabolic diseases, he made key contributions to our understanding of Wilson's disease, an inherited disorder that causes an excess of copper to accumulate in vital organs. He founded the first human genetics laboratory at Weill Cornell, and together with colleagues at Rockefeller University, created a joint M.D./Ph.D. program at the two institutions. Brilliant and much-loved as physician, scientist, teacher and friend, Dr. Bearn will be greatly missed. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Margaret, his daughter and son-in-law Helen and Russell Pennoyer, his son and daughter-in-law Gordon C.F. and Ellen Bearn, and the entire Bearn family.

(21) SHORELINE SONATA: A LONG ISLAND LOVE STORY In this homage to the island's waterways, classical and contemporary works performed by the Constellation Trio, Dave Brubeck and Harry Belafonte are merged with images of Nassau and Suffolk Counties; poetry from Gladys L. Henderson, Victoria Twomey, Jean Kemper, Jack Trested and Walt Whitman; and lyrics by Billy Joel and Jimmy Webb. The journey begins in Eatons Neck and goes on to state parks -- including Sunken Meadow, Nissequogue River Preserve, Captree and Connetquot -- the Gold Coast and the Hamptons before heading all the way out to the North Fork and Montauk, above. 7 A.M. Pentax will be selling a new midlevel D.S.L.R. that has some pretty sweet specs wrapped in a compact, sturdy chassis. It's currently priced at about $100 more that its nearest competitors, the Canon EOS 50D and the Olympus E-30. But watch online retailers for discounts.

McELROY--Heather Ann, of Harris, NY formerly of Rockville Centre, NY. On May 19, 2009 at the age of 38. Loving daughter of Nancy and Francis X. (Tony) McElroy. Adoring sister to Shannon. Cherished granddaughter of the late Dorothy K. and Matthew Doyle and the late Margaret A. and Frank X. McElroy. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10am, St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Road, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family would greatly appreciate donations be made to the Center for Discovery, Harris, NY 12742. mackenmortuary.com

THE fashions May 14 at the ''Tulips and Pansies'' runway show could have used some pruning or, failing that, a generous spritz from a garden hose. The show, a fund-raiser for Village Care of New York, a health care agency, held at the Edison Ballroom in Manhattan, gave florists a chance to unspool their giddiest fantasies. The rose-and-orchid-lavished headdresses were more than a match for the dresses they complemented -- frocks by the likes of Tory Burch, Zang Toi and Thierry Mugler. The most eye-catching bonnets included a rose-covered sombrero (far right) and a floppy-brimmed picture hat with fragrant gardenias (above, center). Sybil Bruncheon, a drag performer, at right, squeezed into britches before donning a Napoleonic bicorn festooned in Asian orchids.

McGINN--Audrey, died of cancer on Friday, May 8, 2009 in New York. Born on May 4, 1943 in Jersey City, NJ, Audrey graduated from Cabrini College and received Masters Degrees from Lehigh University and the City College of New York. She taught in East Harlem for several years, then fashioned a distinguished career at Scarsdale High School from 1976-2005. Audrey was a devoted daughter to her parents Leo J. McGinn and Casimer (Devlin) McGinn; sister to her brother Jim and his wife Gretchen; and aunt to their children, Alexandra, Ben and Catherine. Family and friends will miss Audrey's love, guidance, support, and friendship, as well as her iconic red clogs. A memorial service will held at Scarsdale High School on June 12th, 2009 from 3-5pm.

SEVENTY-SIX years ago, Franklin Delano Roosevelt took to the inaugural dais and reminded a nation that its recent troubles ''concern, thank God, only material things.'' In the midst of the Depression, he urged Americans to remember that ''happiness lies not in the mere possession of money'' and to recognize ''the falsity of material wealth as the standard of success.''

Netbooks, netbooks everywhere, and not an end in sight. From Samsung, Dell, Hewlett-Packard, MSI and others, the category continues to grow, with 2009 sales projected to exceed 20 million units. With the price of Intel Atom chips falling as the netbook market expands and volume ramps up, the pressure is on companies like Apple and Sony; neither is yet a player in this game.

McENTEGART--James Stephen, 84, of Saddle River, NJ and Jupiter Island, FL, died on May 20, 2009. He was born on March 2, 1925 to the late James A. McEntegart and Ethel V. McEntgart. He served as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy during World War II, and graduated from Cornell University in 1949. Upon graduation, he joined the family firm and was president of McEntegart Construction Company, specializing in the construction of churches and cathedrals in New York and New Jersey. He expanded the firm, and over the next twenty five years built numerous schools, municipal buildings, commercial office buildings, and apartment complexes in New Jersey and Florida. He was president of Melmac Management Company, Inc., a commercial real estate management company located in Montvale, NJ. A lifelong resident of Bergen County, Mr. McEntegart also served on the Board of Directors of Citizens First National Bank, and the Planning Boards in Park Ridge, NJ and Saddle River, NJ. He was an avid sportsman whose passions included international fly fishing, upland bird shooting, and golf. He was a member of Arcola County Club, Paramus, NJ and Jupiter Hills Club, Tequesta, FL. A dedicated husband, father, and grandfather, he is survived by his wife of 58 years, Ellen Brennan McEntegart; his daughters JoAnne McEntegart McCoy and Ellen Blake Milliken; his grandchildren James McEntegart Goett and Whitney Brennan McDonough; great-grandson Brogan James McDonough and a sister Dorothy Armstrong. Visiting hours will be held on Friday, May 22 from 6-9pm at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ. A funeral mass will be celebrated on Saturday, May 23, at 10:30am at St. Gabriel the Archangel Church, 88 East Saddle River Road, Saddle River, NJ. In lieu of flowers the family requests that contributes be made in his memory to the Valley Hospital Foundation, 223 North Van Dien Avenue, Ridgewood, NY 07450. www.feeneyfuneralhome.com

Lou Ureneck writes in From the Ground Up about building a cabin in the Maine woods and offers advice for those thinking of building their own. This week, he reports from Greece, where he's found inspiration in indigenous materials, Mediterranean landscapes, an area native and the pleasures of incorporating history into design. An excerpt: The village of Loukadika is perched nearly 1,000 feet above the sea in southern Greece. Its stone houses date to the Middle Ages and the area has been settled since the Stone Age.

WALKER--Howard, of Westport, Connecticut, died peacefully on May 16, 2009, following a brief battle with lung cancer. He was 72. Howard was born in Brooklyn, NY, the son of the late Harry and Betty Walker. Howard was president of Crown Foundations Inc., an intimate apparel company headquartered in Bridgeport that manufactured top-of-the-line shapewear for the mature figure. He worked there for 50 years, serving as President and Owner since 1981. Recognizing that girdle shops were becoming extinct, Howard helped Crown Foundation transition to selling to almost every national cataloger in the United States. The company continues to thrive today. Howard is survived by his loving and adoring wife, Sandra, his two adoring sons and daughters-in-law, Jonathan and Bridget of Fairfield, and Samuel and Stacey of Weston, CT, as well as three grandchildren, Zander, Ellery and Cobie. Everyone who met Howard recognized him as a unique individual. He was a true mensche, a loyal and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. He will truly be missed and never forgotten.

SELMONOSKY--Daniel J.,died on May 16th at age 43. He is survived by his loving wife, Lisa, and daughters Olivia and Isabella. He is the son of Dr. Carlos and Sonia Selmonosky, son-in-law of Kathy and Richard Smith, brother of Deborah Selmonosky, Arlene Miller and Monica Selmonosky, brother-in-law of Josh and Jeffrey Smith and Allison Fisher. Daniel was a loving husband, devoted to his children and family, and cherished by his many friends and colleagues. Daniel was a graduate of Columbia University in New York City and worked as a partner at BC Partners of New York City, New York. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Thursday, May 21st at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 89 Baldwin Road, Bedford, New York. The interment will follow the service at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, New York.
DAVIDSON--Nathan J. 5/21/99. Thank you, God, for the gift of his life-a joy to so many, an inestimable treasure to me. KMD

BURDETTE--Brooks R. Brooks was one of the finest and kindest of persons: a great friend and law partner, wise counsellor, and a brilliant lawyer. He worked strenuously to overcome serious childhood illnesses, never asked for or accepted favors because of his physical limitations, and wildly succeeded in the toughest environment any trial lawyer could compete in. Brooksy, we will miss the lunches, dinners, and discussions, but mostly miss knowing you were always there to help lend a hand. Good-bye, our friend: you're the best. David M. Brodsky Daniel J. Kramer

LIVINGSTON--Marvin Robert, 90, on May 20. Loving husband of Marcie (Shlansky), devoted father of Michael and Ellen, adoring grandfather of Benjamin, Daniel, Lesley, and Matthew. Cherished father-in-law of Anne Weiss and Jason Brown. Dear brother of Harriet and the late Sylvia Bernstein. A gentle soul, he will be missed by all. Sweet dreams, Papa. Services 12:30pm on Thursday May 21, Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

LEFFERTS--Cynthia, of New York and St. Huberts, NY, died peacefully in her Manhattan home on May 8. She was 80. Cynthia had been ill for some years with primary progressive aphasia. She was valiant at every turn. Cynthia leaves many loving friends and family members, including two nieces and two nephews: Susan Lefferts of Salem, OR; Sarah Lefferts of Portland, ME; Thomas Lefferts of South China, ME; and Nicholas Lefferts of Denver, CO. Independent in mind and spirit, Cynthia had a keen interest in politics and in the life of the nation. Her working life was marked by high ideals. She began her career in 1951 as an administrative assistant at the Ford Foundation; she went on to serve as executive secretary of the New York State Commission on Government Operations of the City of New York and later of the New York State Moreland Commission on Welfare. She was a special assistant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller from 1963 to 1966, and then worked devotedly for Common Cause, serving in the 1970s as executive director of its New York office. Cynthia was born in Santa Barbara, CA, in 1928, while her parents, Halleck Lefferts and Sarah Barney Lefferts, were on the faculty of the Thacher School in nearby Ojai. Her brothers Barney and Charlie died before her, in 1976 and 1995. Cynthia was educated at Concord Academy and the Winsor School, and graduated from Vassar College in 1951. From an early age, Cynthia loved the mountains, lakes, and streams of the Adirondacks, where she had a second home. When the effects of polio kept her off the highest peaks, she continued to walk, hike, and swim with vigor, and she took up tennis with a gracious tenacity. She was a longtime member of the Ausable Club in St. Huberts and a trustee of the related Adirondack Mountain Reserve. In 2007 Cynthia was given the Harold Weston Award for "personal dedication to the unique spirit and qualities" of the AMR. She also served on the board of managers of the Havens Relief Fund Society in New York. She was especially proud to be a trustee of the Pomfret School in Pomfret, CT, where her father had been headmaster. Cynthia's grace and courage were inspiration and example to her friends and family. She had steel in her sinews, but she was never hard. She was kind and fair-minded, and naturally elegant. A memorial service will be held this summer in Keene Valley, NY, in the Adirondacks.

Dinner with President Obama? Sounds nice, doesn't it? And it could be yours -- for the low, low price of just $5. No, it is not that Mr. Obama is a cheap date. It is a bit of fund-raising gimmickry, courtesy of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, which is holding a dinner June 18 to ''celebrate President Obama's plans to bring needed change to our country,'' said an e-mail message sent to supporters on Wednesday. Donors who send $5 or more will be ''automatically entered into a contest to win a trip to Washington, D.C., to attend our special dinner,'' the e-mail message declares. ''We'll pay for airfare and a hotel. All you'll have to do is decide which friend you would like to bring along and start packing!''

In what we assume is the first cinematic competition in which a graphic and divisive movie by Lars von Trier has faced off against a family-oriented Disney-Pixar film, the animated feature has prevailed. The movie “Up,” a 3D cartoon, has won the Palm Dog prize, an award given annually during the Cannes Film Festival for best canine performance, BBC News reported. The prize, a satirical alternative to the Palme d’Or and voted by British film critics, was given this year to the animated character Dug, a dog who is able to talk by means of a high-tech collar. The critics made an exception this year by considering a talking fox from Mr. von Trier’s violent horror film “Antichrist” for the award; a black poodle from the Quentin Tarantino action movie “Inglourious Basterds” was also in the running. In Mr. von Trier’s defense, his 2003 film “Dogville” won the Palm Dog in 2003.

CANNES, France — The last time the French director Gaspar Noé was in the Cannes Film Festival, in 2002, it felt as if a hurricane were approaching. The word in the festival halls was that his “Irrevérsible” included a scene with a nine-minute rape, news that seemed to excite some attendees. As it happens, though the buildup is interminable, the assault is briefer. I know because when I saw the film again for review, I timed it because I wanted something to think about besides the sights and sounds of a woman being brutalized: it was my way of resisting Mr. Noé’s obvious interest in assaulting his audience.

One of the ongoing dilemmas of being a comic book fan is deciding which format to buy. Do you support the series by buying the monthly comic book? Do you wait for the collected edition (which, if the monthly series has poor sales, may not occur)? If so, which collection to get? Some series receive the hardcover treatment first, followed by a softcover months later. A handful of popular or critically acclaimed series get deluxe treatments like Marvel’s Masterworks or DC’s Absolute collections. “Y: The Last Man” is the latest comic series to pose the existential question: opt for the 10-volume softcover set (the first volume of which is No. 10 on the paperback list) or wait for new deluxe editions? Enough readers chose the second deluxe volume to put it on the top of our hardcover list. A too-short preview of the first issue of “Y: The Last Man” is available here.

Eventually you get those test papers handed back, and if you're very unlucky, you'll see a certain two-word phrase scrawled along the top: SEE ME. The PEN/New York Review panel discussion on the economy is online. I'll outsource the discussion of what went down to Brad DeLong. Just this to add: it's bad enough to have people resurrecting 75-year old fallacies about macroeconomics right in the middle of a crisis in which knowledge is our only defense against catastrophe. What's really bad, however, is when they do so believing that these fallacies are deep insights that have somehow eluded those of us who have, you know, been studying these issues for a while, and saw some (not all) of this crisis in advance.

Today Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave a commencement speech at the Boston College School of Law. It sounded remarkably more hopeful, and less crisis-oriented, than his speech last year at Harvard's Class Day (which apparently flopped; video here). I've often compared the truth-seeking process of journalism, when dealing with a complex subject, to the increasingly endangered art of celestial navigation. I only toyed with that skill when I was lucky enough to be on the crew of a circumnavigating sailboat 30 years ago (the preceding link is to a narrated slide show explaining the relationship of that voyage to this blog). In the middle of the Indian Ocean, I watched the skipper, Lon Bubeck, take a sight on a star, make some calculations and draw a line on a chart. We were somewhere along that line, plus or minus a range of error to each side related to the precision of his watch, the sextant (ours was cheap and plastic) and other factors. But he'd repeat the process with other stars until there was a triangle created by multiple lines. The more sights, the tighter the triangle and better the estimate.

LONDON | Crisis, Britain's national charity for single homeless people, is hosting several weeks worth of "Hidden Gigs" in London as part of a national campaign against recession-era homelessness here. Gigs will take place through June at undisclosed clubs and locations in Central London. The exact site remains "hidden" until 24 hours before the gig, when a text or email is then sent to ticket holders.

At the United States Naval Academy on Friday, President Obama gave his first commencement speech as president to graduates of a military academy. He used the event, a rite of passage for every commander-in-chief, to reiterate the message he offered Thursday at the National Archives in Washington, that in an age of terrorism, he can both protect Americans from attack and uphold fundamental American values.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is often frustrated by the Senate and its rules, but on Friday she embraced the filibuster.

It's Friday. The week is winding down. It's lunchtime. Your boss is out of the office. So go ahead. Take a look at these intriguing videos, selected by Erik Olsen, a video journalist at The Times, for their quality, novelty, ingenuity and insightfulness. We'll be offering this guilty pleasure every week.

Pierce Derkac is a junior longstick defensive midfielder for Cornell's lacrosse team. Every game, he draws the opposing team's top offensive midfielder. He is also a valuable groundball man on face-offs and is the team's emotional leader. He shared with the Quad his thoughts this week as his team prepared for its appearance in a national semifinal game against Virginia on Saturday in Foxborough, Mass.

Starting Monday, Memorial Day, modifications will take effect for eight Manhattan bus routes -- the M5, M7, M6, M10, M20, M27, M30 and M104 -- as a result in the city's changes to Midtown traffic patterns along Broadway between 59th Street (Columbus Circle) and 23rd Street.

I would like to buy a larger Manhattan co-op for my family, but I need to sell my current co-op first. Would a seller be willing to enter into an agreement with me stipulating that the deal is contingent on the sale of my current apartment?

I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in Brooklyn and pay a preferential rent of $1,081. My new lease indicates that the "legal" rent on the apartment is $1,173, and the allowed increase of 4.5 percent brings the total to $1,226. The landlord claims that this increase of $145 is legal.

It's Memorial Day weekend. Time to dust off the bike and hit the roads and trails. To get you ready for this great biking weekend, The Local has been taking a close-up look at biking in the three towns. We previously looked at overall bike safety issues and plans for better biking in South Orange and Millburn. Now it's Maplewood's turn.

What benefits does your company wellness program offer? It's worth finding out. Many employees fail to take advantage of perks like discounted gym memberships and financial incentives for staying healthy.

Whether or not you've solved the Amazing Card Trick Puzzle posed on Monday, you can tackle another card-trick puzzle now. This one was submitted by Pradeep Mutalik, who picks up the imaginary scene on Jon Stewart's "Daily Show" where we left off Monday. Imagine that President Obama has just stunned Mr. Stewart by identifying the jack of hearts as the card in Mr. Stewart's pocket.

CANNES - The serious critics and members of the various juries start their day here with breakfast and a movie. For my tired self, however, leaving the sunny daylight and entering the refrigerated darkness of the Palais is traumatic enough as it is, let alone sitting through a two-hour black-and-white film in German before my caffeine has had a chance to kick in. But Cannes likes to surprise, and "The White Ribbon," by the celebrated Austrian director Michael Haneke, is one of the best films we've seen this week.

Memorial Day is upon us, marking the unofficial start of summer. Predictions are for great weather this long weekend. For most of us that means relaxation, cookouts, outdoor activities, time with family and a parade. But it doesn't mean a weekend without art. There are several destinations worth visiting and as the composer and artist John Cage always maintained, art exists everywhere if you remain open to experience.
While they are standing around the barbecue this weekend, Wall Streeters can think about how Washington is busy cooking up new pay guidelines for the financial industry.

Diane LeBleu, who has been chronicling her breast cancer treatment here on Motherlode, has completed chemotherapy. A few weeks ago she "rang the bell" at the oncology treatment center in Austin that she has been visiting regularly since January - a tradition to celebrate the last infusion.

Monaco is not only the most unique race on the calendar because of the location -- through the streets of this extraordinary ancient city -- it is also the only race of the season where nothing happens on Friday. First practice sessions are on Thursday, Friday is a down day, and we swing back into action on Saturday.
The Windsor Spitfires may have needed to reach a certain level of desperation to figure out how to play in the Memorial Cup.

Rafael Nadal, the clay-court king, will begin his pursuit of a fifth (that is, five consecutive) French Open title against a qualifier. And it remains entirely possible he could face rival Roger Federer, the man who ended Nadal's 33-match unbeaten streak on clay this month in Madrid, in the final. Federer has only defeated Nadal on clay twice in his career -- Madrid being the second time, ever.

Over the course of a week, I run across all sorts of cool links to Local Land, links that remind me that I live in the presences of greatness, that we are all tiny crystals tumbling together in the nutty kaleidoscope of current events, bumping up against circus performers, perfumers, tennis champs and moms trying to crowdsource the wording on birthday party invitations. Life is good!
The long weekend will be anything but a holiday for General Motors, the giant automaker struggling to stay out of bankruptcy protection.

European stocks rose Friday, recovering from a sharp fall Thursday and shrugging off overnight losses in the United States and Asia as investors clung to hopes that the global recession was bottoming out and looked for bargains ahead of the weekend.

Private equity firms looking for bargains amid the nation's ailing banks got some encouraging news Thursday when the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced that has agreed to allow a consortium of buyout shops, including WL Ross, the Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group, buy the failed lender, BankUnited Financial.

Chinalco, China's top aluminum maker, is under increasing pressure to reorganize its $19.5 billion deal with the heavily indebted Australian mining company Rio Tinto. A revision of the terms is almost inevitable, and Rio has everything to play for, Breakingviews says.

Today's idea: Was the Holocaust in some sense a "European project"? The collusion of non-Germans in Nazi atrocities has been largely unexplored, a German magazine says, and the Demjanjuk trial will shed light on the issue.

BERLIN | It's springtime for Hitler in Germany, but not the way you might think. Yes, the weather here has been unusually divine for weeks, but some Berliners are just as excited for the arrival of the hit musical, "The Producers" being staged in Berlin.

Fall meant football at the University of Michigan, but the photo department at The Michigan Daily, where I worked as its first woman photographer, was given only four press passes. As a freshman, I was not entitled to one. Seniority was not the only problem. In 1968, the passes all said, "No women, children or dogs allowed on the field." This was no joke. There were no women in the marching band; no women cheerleaders; no women security guards. A year later, I earned one of the coveted passes. The rules had loosened a bit. The new passes said, "No women or children allowed on the field."

This week, I join health columnist Tara Parker-Pope and my colleagues at Well on our marathon endeavor: Run Well. Over the coming months, we will offer expert advice for finding the right training program for your running level, tips for preventing injury and guidance for staying healthy during your marathon training.

Google's new Search Options feature, unveiled last week, include a couple of inventive ways to see your results. After you click the "Show options" link on the search results page, a link in the left column lets you see your hits as a Wonder Wheel - a graphic that shows the search term encircled by a set of links leading to related keywords and phrases. Image and standard Web page results are also listed along the right side of the page. The left column on the Options page has a Timeline view as well, which tries to sort results based on chronological order.

A Sports of The Times column on Sunday, about the recent sale of the filly Rachel Alexandra, referred incorrectly to an accomplished horse trainer who is related to Scott Blasi, the assistant trainer who works with the horse. The relative is Helen Pitts-Blasi, not Helene, and she is Mr. Blasi’s sister-in-law — not his wife. (She is married to Greg Blasi, who is also involved in the sport.).
A film review on Thursday about “Terminator Salvation” misidentified the character who has a “quasi-romance” with Blair Williams. He is Marcus Wright, not Kyle Reese.

The Books of The Times review on May 14, about “Gone Tomorrow,” by Lee Child, and “Even,” by Andrew Grant, misstated a word in the opening paragraph of “Gone Tomorrow.” The paragraph says: “Suicide bombers are easy to spot. They give out all sorts of telltale signs. Mostly because they’re nervous. By definition they’re all first-timers.” It does not say, “Maybe because they’re nervous.”.

The Breakingviews column on Wednesday, about the introduction of the Shareholder Bill of Rights in Congress, misidentified the consulting firm that released a study on the percentage of chief executives who also serve as board chairmen. It is Booz & Company, not Booz Allen Hamilton.
Jose Reyes was listed as day to day after an MRI scan on Thursday confirmed that he had tendinitis behind his right calf.

An article on May 14 about Norway’s relative economic stability in the midst of a global downturn misstated its debt status. While the government enjoys a budget surplus and is a net creditor, it has liabilities related to social security and other programs equal to about 50 percent of its gross domestic product; its ledger is not “entirely free of debt.”.

An article on Thursday about the possibility that California will hold a convention to overhaul its constitution misstated, in some editions, the date of a ballot proposition that would create open primaries in the state. It will appear on the ballot in June 2010, not next month.

BULHACK--Sadie (Syd), passed away May 19th. She would have been 100 years old on May 28th. A woman way ahead of her time, having graduated from NYU with a Bachelors in Education, a Master's Degree and her Ph.D. equivalent. Syd was an accounting teacher at George Washington High School in Manhattan. Upon retirement in 1974, she and her beloved husband Morris relocated to Hallandale, FL. Widow of Morris, survived by her children; Michael, Neil (Phyllis), Kenneth (Vicky) and daughter Phyllis Wagner. She was surrounded by her loving grandchildren; David, Beth, Lisa, Kenneth Jr., Bernard, Andrea and Joshua, and her greatgrandchildren; Joshua, Michael, Ryan and Matthew, and for many years was privileged to be cared for by Molreen Nathaniel. Predeceased by her parents Philip and Lena Sherman. Brothers; Joseph Sherman, Morris Sherman. Sisters; Mona Feller and May Garvin. Graveside services held Friday, May 22nd, 11am at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY.

The interviews for a job on the Supreme Court are continuing at the White House. President Obama has met with at least one other finalist, an official confirmed Thursday, bringing the number of face-to-face interviews to at least two. Earlier this week, Mr. Obama met with Judge Diane P. Wood, who sits on the federal appeals court in Chicago. The other finalist was not identified.

APPEL--Marian Kirk, died in Haverford, Pennsylvania, on May 19, 2009 after a prolonged illness. Her knack for friendship, keen mind and sense of fun will be sorely missed by young and old. Daughter of a distinguished naval officer, Alan G. Kirk, who commanded the U.S. Navy forces in the 1944 Normandy landing and served as Ambassador to Belgium, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China on Taiwan, she went with her parents from coast to coast as her father rose through the ranks, spreading charm and joy wherever she went. She graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1940 and married Dr. John W. Appel, a psychoanalyst, on January 4, 1941. Mrs. Appel was a lifelong member of the Garden Club of America, serving as the President of the Weeders, a Main Line GCA chapter, as well as a Regional GCA Board Member and as a member of the GCA Conservation Committee. She also initiated and hosted a local TV channel show, "All About Radnor," interviewing local township personnel and environmental leaders in Radnor, Pennsylvania, where they lived. She also served as President of the League of Women Voters for Lower Merion Township. Always a supporter of Bryn Mawr, she was President of the Class for decades, organizing four major class reunions. Mrs. Appel is survived by her three children, Deborah Appel Chomiw, Kenneth Goodrich Appel, and Lydia Selden Appel Forbes, her sister Deborah Kirk of Solbert and brother Roger Kirk, and five grandsons.

BKLYN YARD Chalk up another win for culture over capitalism. In the last few years the Bklyn Yard, above, a grassy spot near a former oil silo on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, has turned into a party destination, with live music, dancing and festivals that drew as many as 1,000 people on weekends. The organizers, MeanRed Productions, known for staging blowouts in unusual spots, thought the summer of 2008 would be their last: the space was under contract for condos. ''Then literally about a month ago everything fell through, and it was like, we're back,'' said Jenny Gottstein of MeanRed, which has its offices in the silo year-round. (''Aside from the backwind, it's gorgeous,'' she said.) Now they are busy programming the rest of the season.

CHANDLER--Tim, 58, of New York City, died on May 15, 2009 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. Born on July 28, 1950 in Columbus, Ohio to the late Dennis and Edna Chandler, Tim was a 1972 graduate of Otterbein College. He later received a Masters degree in theater from Bowling Green University, and served in the U.S. Air Force. A resident of New York City for the past 35 years, Tim most recently worked as a Senior Publicist at HBO Networks for 15 years. He worked on scores of projects including documentaries, theatricals, made-for-television movies, specials, series, and sports. Previously, he established a long and varied career in theatre, particularly at the New York Shakespeare Festival where he served as an assistant to the late Joseph Papp, and at Lincoln Center's Public Theater partnership. For well over a decade Tim was a tireless volunteer who advised fellow members of the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation, where he was namedVolunteer of the Year by the New York City chapter in 2004. He was predeceased by his partner Rob Peters, and is survived by brothers Marty of Mount Vernon, Ohio and Jeff of Cincinnati, sisters-inlaw Trudy and Laurel, niece Jennifer Price and nephew Paul Chandler. Memorial contributions can be made to: Crohn's and Colitis Foundation, New York City Chapter, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016, or to the Calvary Fund, c/o Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

FURCHGOTT--Robert F. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Robert F. Furchgott, Ph.D., Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Physiology and Pharmacology and former Chair of Pharmacology, and a 1998 recipient of the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. Dr. Furchgott was an extraordinary scientist who made major contributions to our understanding of cardiovascular physiology and pharmacology. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine for identifying the fundamental role that nitric oxide (NO) plays in the regulation of cardiovascular function. Dr. Furchgott discovered that the cells lining blood vessels produce a substance he called endothelial-derived relaxing factor (EDRF), which induces vascular relaxation. He subsequently proposed that EDRF is nitric oxide. Dr. Furchgott's discoveries, conducted in his laboratory at SUNY Downstate, have helped scientists understand and find new treatments for cardiovascular diseases and other conditions ranging from immune disorders to memory loss, pulmonary disease, and erectile dysfunction. Dr. Furchgott also received a Gairdner Foundation International Award in 1991 and the Albert Lasker Award for Basic Medical Research in 1996. Dr. Furchgott's brilliant career spanned several decades at SUNY Downstate. Throughout his tenure he was an inspiration to SUNY Downstate's students, faculty, administration, and staff. In Dr. Furchgott's honor, the Robert F. Furchgott Society was established at Downstate to support students and fellows conducting basic science studies in a broad array of subjects. Each year, the Society gives the Robert F. Furchgott Award for Excellence in Research to four individuals, including fellows and graduating students. We extend our deepest sympathies to Dr. Furchgott's children, Janie, Susie, and Terry Furchgott. A memorial service is planned to take place in Seattle on Saturday. The family suggests that, in lieu of flowers, donations in Dr. Furchgott's memory may be sent to the Furchgott Life Enrichment Fund, c/o Ida Culver House, 2315 Northeast 65th Street, Seattle, Washington 98115, which is also the site of the service, at 2:30pm. John C. LaRosa, M.D. President Ian L. Taylor, M.D., Ph.D. Dean of the College of Medicine Robert K. S. Wong, Ph.D. Distinguished Professor and Chair, Physiology and Pharmacology

New software from I.B.M. can soak up huge volumes of data from many sources and quickly identify correlations within it. The company says it expects the software to be useful in analyzing finance, health care and even space weather. Bo Thidé, a scientist at the Swedish Institute of Space Physics, has been testing an early version of the software as he studies the ways in which things like gas clouds and particles cast off by the sun can disrupt communications networks on Earth.

RIFFATERRE--Hermine. Born in Toulouse, France on June 14, 1932, Hermine fled on foot to Spain with her family to evade the German occupation. Following the war, she emigrated to the United States where she was educated at Hunter College (BA) and Columbia University (Ph.D.). She taught at Barnard College, ran her own business and raised a family. She was a woman of remarkable force and spirit. Only cancer got the better of her, and that only after a long fight. Daughter of Harry and Sonia Bilfeld, mother of Marc Oberfest, beloved wife of Michael Riffaterre. She is survived by her son Jason Riffaterre and his wife Jessica; her stepdaughter Lee Riffaterre and husband Frank Boyle and their children Kate and Isaac. Her ashes and those of her husband will be scattered in Southampton, NY and Hossegor, France. She was happiest in those two places.

My Sunday column is the last from my win-a-trip journey with Paul Bowers, and it looks at malnutrition -- which has worsened because of the global economic crisis. I also think we often tend to conceive of malnutrition incorrectly, looking only for kids who are starving overall, rather than those who are starving for particular nutrients. Some of the most cost-effective ways to help fight poverty involve the provision of micronutrients such as iron, iodine, vitamin A.

HEALY--Nicholas J.,of Glengarriff, Ireland, formerly of Garden City, NY, died at age 99 on May 20, 2009, at his home in Ireland, of natural causes. He was the founding partner of the distinguished maritime law firm of Healy & Baillie, LLC He is survived by his loving children: Nicholas Jr. of Naples, FL, Margaret Parker of Glen Rock, NJ, Rosemary Bell of Naples, FL, Mary Louise White of Garden City, NY; Donall of New York City, Kathleen Hamon of Harrisville, NH, 21 grandchildren, 21 great-grandchildren and his sister Marjorie Borden of King of Prussia, PA. His beloved wife of 66 years, Margaret Ferry, died in 2003. A wake will be held at Perazzo's Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, New York, NY, 2 - 5:00pm and 7 - 9:00pm Monday, May 25. Funeral Mass at 10:00am on Tuesday, May 26, St. Joseph's Church, 371 Sixth Ave., New York, NY, Contributions may be made to the Nicholas J. Healy Lecture on Admiralty Law, Development Office, NYU, 161 Sixth Ave., NYC, NY 10013.

WEITZNER--Carol Richter. Passed away peacefully May 22, 2009. Beloved mother of Cherie Weitzner Acierno and Gregg Harrison Wietzner. Adoring and adored grandmother of Jane Celine Aceirno. Dearly loved sister of Gary Richter. Cherished mother-in-law of Lou Acierno. Treasured sister-in-law of Judy Richter and Dorothea M. Weitzner. Dear aunt of Stacy Richter Mercugliano and Wendy Samuels. Mrs. Weitzner was the loving wife of Morton Leonard Weitzner, who passed away in 2004. She was the devoted daughter of Maxwell and Estelle Richter, also deceased. Mrs. Weitzner attended Finch and earned a bachelor's degree in business from New York University. She was a financial maven. She loved her family with all her heart, and was the greatest mother, grandmother, and daughter imaginable. Friends may call Sunday 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Service Monday, May 25, 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Entombment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

Turkan Saylan, a champion of women's rights and education for poor children in Turkey and a leader in the fight against leprosy, died here on Monday. She was 73. The cause was breast cancer, which she had for 19 years, said her doctor, Yavuz Dizdar.

A factory boss and nine foremen have been arrested in eastern China after the police raided a brick kiln late last month and found 32 mentally disabled people working in what were described as slavelike conditions, according to the state-run news media. The police said Friday that 80 officers had carried out the raid last month and rescued the workers, some of whom had been beaten. The workers were all between the ages of 25 and 45.

BARABAS--Frank, 76, on Wednesday, May 21, 2009 in Flushing, Queens. He was a Senior Information Officer in the Press and Publications Division for the Department of Public Information of the United Nations and was best known for his work in computerizing the Department of Public Information at the UN. He started his career in the UN in 1955 as a clerk and retired in 1993. Afterwards, he worked as Press Officer for the International Seabed Authority on a freelance basis. Frank Barabas was a graduate of Columbia University. He was born in Jersey City, NJ and was a long time resident of Corona, Queens, NY. He is survived by his wife, Anne; his daughter, Florence Jacqueline Fedyshyn; three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held Tuesday, 7pm at the Della Torre Funeral Home, 515 21st Avenue in Paterson, NJ. Visiting hours will be Tuesday 2 to 4pm and 6 to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Muscular Dystrophy Foundation in his name would be appreciated.

SLEVIN--Naomi, on May 21st at age 84. Beloved wife of Harvey, loving mom of Jeff (Debbie), Barry (Lynne), Ken (Jane), cherished grandmother of Bailie, Matt, Ted, Sam, Jeremy, Mickey and Julie. Funeral service May 24th, 12 noon, Plaza Funeral Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street. Burial at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I.

A caption on Sunday with a grouping of pictures of the Nascar Pit Crew Challenge misidentified, in some copies, both the front-tire changer whose gloved hand and power tool were shown and the driver for whom he works. The tire changer is Trevor Lysne, not Bryan Jacobson. The driver is Juan Pablo Montoya, not Reed Sorenson.

ROCHMAN--Morton, in his 76th year, on May 21. Adored and devoted husband for 54 years of his high school sweetheart Barbara. His children, Diane (Rich), Larry (Leslie) and David (Diane) will miss his unconditional love, guidance and energetic support. His beloved grandchildren Paul, Zoe, Laura, Max, James and Noah will always remember Poppy's optimism, wisdom, fairness, curiosity, zest for life and endless love. To his sister Toby (Michael), he was the best traveling companion. To his brother-in-law Neil (Susan), a terrific guy who enjoyed a great scotch and a laugh. A graduate of Cornell (class of '54), he served in the air force and enjoyed a long career at Northrop Grumman. He leaves a huge circle of friends. Morty, Mr. Fixit, was a Mensch. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Cornell Engineering School, Ithaca, NY.

TARNOPOL--Mickey. Beloved husband, father, and grandfather on this fourth anniversary of your death, not a day goes by that we do not think of you, talk about you, miss you and love you. You are in our hearts forever. Your loving family, Lynne, Lori & David, Lisa & Mario, Nick, Jami, Lucy & Jack

ROBINSON--Gladys (nee Kerrick), a loving and beautiful lady, passed away graciously on May 22 at her home in Amityville, at the age of 95, after leading a full and extraordinary life. She is the beloved wife of the late Dr. Arthur Robinson formerly of Ozone Park and Amityville and the loving sister of the late Dorothy Stagg. Gladys is also survived by her sister- in-law Irene Robinson and her nieces and nephews Karen and Ken White, John Ritter, Alan and Elizabeth Shulman, Ruth Orange, Dr. Ronald and Barbara Robinson, Dr. Gerald and Joyce Robinson, along with 16 loving great-nieces and -nephews and many great-great-nieces and -nephews and loving cousins. Visitation will be at the Powell Funeral Home, Inc., 67 Broadway (Rt. 110), Amityville on Tuesday, May 26, between the hours of 2-4:30 and 7-9:30pm. Burial will be at the Amityville Cemetery Wednesday after meeting at the funeral home at 10am.

(HBO) KUNG FU PANDA (2008) In this DreamWorks animated film, Po, an awkward, rotund panda, right, voiced by Jack Black, learns martial arts at the hands of Master Oogway (Randall Duk Kim), an ancient turtle who invented kung fu and now serves as spiritual adviser to an elite squad, including the mustachioed red panda Shifu, above (Dustin Hoffman), and his students, the Furious Five: Tigress (Angelina Jolie), Viper (Lucy Liu), Monkey (Jackie Chan), Crane (David Cross) and Mantis (Seth Rogen). Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called the film ''high concept with a heart.'' She added: ''In the end, what charms the most about 'Kung Fu Panda' is that it doesn't feel as if it's trying to be a live-action film. It's animation through and though.'' 11:30 A.M. Victoria Azarenka has stormed the top 10 this season at age 19, winning three tournaments, including the Sony Ericsson Open in Miami, and defeating the world's top two players -- Dinara Safina and Serena Williams -- along the way. It has been both impressive and loud, with Azarenka punctuating her ground strokes with Maria Sharapova-like shrieks. And it all might not have worked out nearly so well if Azarenka's path had not intersected with one of the N.H.L.'s top goaltenders and his family.

CANNES, France — This year’s Cannes Film Festival was notable for its blood-splattered screens, digital projections and emergent and resurgent auteurs. It was a year when internationally established filmmakers like Pedro Almodóvar, Jane Campion, Marco Bellocchio, Lars Von Trier and Quentin Tarantino went home empty-handed while the newcomer Brillante Mendoza took the directing prize for “Kinatay.” It was the year that the French director Jacques Audiard broke through to new heights with his early critical favorite, “A Prophet.” (The film took second prize.) It was also a year that Alain Resnais’s brilliant competition entry, “Wild Grass,” became the only selection to receive a symbolic Palme d’Or from critics from the French movie magazines Positif and Cahiers du Cinéma. (More critic rankings are available at Le Film Français.)

Tuesday is the 50th anniversary of a great pitching feat in baseball history: Harvey Haddix's near perfect game for the Pirates against the Milwaukee Braves in 1959. Haddix took a perfect game into the 13th inning before losing the perfect game, a no-hitter and the game in one of baseball's most bizarre endings.Gerald Eskenazi, a former sportswriter for The Times, recounts the game, from the perspective of a Times copy boy getting updates on action on the ticker tape. May 26, 1959, also happened to be Eskenazi's first day working for The Times.

Murray Rolls | 2:55 p.m. As day turns into night in Paris, third-ranked Andy Murray had no trouble against Juan Ignacio Chela, 6-2, 6-2, 6-1. But the player he is drawn to play in the quarters, seventh-seeded Gilles Simon, struggled before his homecourt crowd. The Frenchman avoided an upset by defeating the American Wayne Odesnik in five sets, 3-6, 7-5, 6-2, 4-6, 6-3. Odesnik is the rare American man who does well on clay but not as well as European or South American claycourt specialists. Simon will next face 86th-ranked Robert Kendrick, another American and another winner in five sets. He defeated the qualifier Daniel Brands, 6-7 (7), 7-5, 7-6 (11), 4-6, 6-3. Other winners include No. 9 Victoria Azarenka and No. 11 Nadia Petrova in the women's draw, and No. 13 Marin Cilic and No. 14 David Ferrer among the men.

While it's nice to talk about the American Triple Crown races extending back to the advent of the Belmont Stakes in 1866, the fact is that the first Triple Crown racing for 3-year-olds in America actually dates to 1907. It started in 1907 and ended abruptly in 1908, and it even had a bonus provision for the 3-year-old who might sweep the series.

An article in the Long Island section on May 10 about falling retail sales and rising store vacancies referred imprecisely to the ownership of the Mall at the Source, in Westbury. While the Simon Property Group has a 25 percent ownership interest, it does not own the mall.

A report in the Slap Shot hockey column last Sunday about the first N.H.L. playoff meeting of Eric Staal of the Carolina Hurricanes and his brother Jordan of the Pittsburgh Penguins misstated their birth order in relation to their brother Marc, who plays for the Rangers. A news analysis article last Sunday about the mixed reviews Pope Benedict XVI received during his trip to the Middle East, including criticism from Israelis over the pope’s failure to acknowledge his past as a youth in Nazi Germany, misstated the publication day of a satirical page in Yediot Aharonot, an Israeli daily newspaper, that poked fun at the criticism. It was Friday, May 15 — not Saturday, May 16. (The newspaper does not publish on Saturday, the Jewish sabbath.).
